Pours black query a thin khaki head. Aroma is alcohol and dark chocolate. Taste is strong of dark chocolate and alcohol. Not bad but a bit much.

Bottle. Pours black with a short dark tan head. Smells of coffee, dark chocolate, and molasses dominate. Heavy body and smooth and creamy on the palate. Lingering boozy warmth on the tongue. Sweet with flavors of chocolate and coffee, and nicely balanced with hoppy bitterness. Really nice stout!

Wonderful beer! I really enjoyed this beer. Starts with a nice dark fruit taste then turns into more chocolate and coffee overtime. Its also a nice bitterness in the taste from the roasted malts. As it warms up there is a boozy alcohol taste. So be careful if you drink this one! This beer will cellar very well!
Thought this was very good. Tasted a bit like chocolate and was very dark. A bit bitter. Immensely complex flavor. Overall I was impressed.
This pours a pitch black color with a slight light brown head. The aroma is rich and very malty. The taste is rich, robust, and very flavorful. Delicious!

Little deep brown head and strong lacing. Chocolate with alcohol aroma. Light carbonation on the tongue. Chocolate and coffee taste with strong alcohol bite afterwards. Very good imperial stout! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

dense chocolate beige head fades with structured lacing. coffee coloured. aroma bit boozy, hint of coconut, caramel, chocolate. taste is slight sweet, bitter chocolate, liquorice, ashes with a long bitter chocolaty finish. velvet mouthfeel, soft carbonation. very nice balance and smooth, abv well hidden, a real treat to drink! bottle 35,5cl / bd feb-2012

Unbelievable chocolate bomb! Great aftertaste that lingers.Alcohol well hidden.One of the great stouts! Sit back put your headphones on and enjoy on a cool fall night! You might not get out of your chair!

Bottle. Pours a black color with tan head. Roasty, burnt, licorice aromas. Roasty, licorice, malty, syrupy flavors. Very nice full bodied stout. Not my favorite, because it has some black licorice flavors that Im not a fan of, but its still a top notch stout.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2014 330ml bottle served in a snifter glass.
A: Pours a deep brown to black color forming a medium and nice thin bubbled beige head. Medium to low retention and only few spotty lacings left on the glass. A thin layer persists for quite a long time
S: Strong roasted malts and coffee aroma. Licorice and very earthy yeasts. Strong notes of wood too. Very earthy and boozy in the end
T: Strong roasted malts, mainly. Strong notes of coffee, brown bread, licorice, oak, earthy yeasts. Upfront taste is slightly sweet and molasses but, in overall, its very bitter and roasted. Intense. And really bitter as an American Imperial Stout should be
M: Heavy, thick, creamy and molasses body. Medium to low carbonation. Intense roasted and bitter aftertaste
O: Great drinkability. An American RIS classic
[ BA Review @ 7/3/2013 ]

Bottle. Dark as night black pour. Aroma is chocolate, dark fruits, raisin and roasted malts. Taste is bitter chocolate, malts and coffee. Very thick velvety mouth feel. Smooth finish. Well done. Can?t wait to age and revisit.

Pours a thick inky black with a tan head leaving a little lacing. Roasted malt nose with a little chocolate. Spiciness in the front with malt coming in and a bit of molasses, chocolate, and almost burnt coffee in the end. Not bad, but not one of my fav beers for a stout.
Bottled. Jet black oily thick pour with a tan head that subsides. Roasted malt aroma and bitter chocolate. Oily chocolate flavors with a bit of dark fruits. Quite good.

Poured in snifter.  Pours black with a mocha brown head. Rich roasted malt, coffee , cocoa, and dark dried fruits aromas. Flavor is dark roasted malt, espresso and unsweetened cocoa. Followed by a light sweet dried prune flavor. Finishing with a dark cocoa bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. This brew is jacked up full of flavor.

From the label: "13415 PKGD 08/22/14 C" so it is just under two months old.

Appearance: Oily black with a thick creamy khaki head that fades leaving fine bubbled lacing on the glass.

Aroma: I pick up the scent of caramel and a hint of coffee. It is very light on the aroma.

Taste: It has a very very rich flavor consisting of coffee, oak, chocolate, molasses, and a hint of bourbon around the edge. The bottle doesnt say anything about bourbon barrels or anything but this is how it tastes. It is a very excellent tasting stout.

Mouthfeel: The mouthfeel is superb. It is thick and smooth. It is a sipper, but it doesnt burn with the high alcohol content.

Overall: This is a very excellent RIS. It is thick, smooth, and full of flavor. Less than two months in the bottle and it has the quality of a well-aged imperial stout. I highly recommend trying this out and buying more than one. It is very easy to drink and is delicious.

Bottle traded with Steasy66 a year or so ago. Pours very very dark brown to opaque black out of the bottle with a tan head which dissipates to nothing very quickly. It looks rich with some dark brown clarity at the edges in the glass. Nose is malty, yeasty, yeast extract, little bourbon barrel perhaps, Shreddies malty cereal. Any coffee or chocolate is very subtle in the nose. Little buttery. Taste is very fine. It has a lightness and a delicate body which is very unusual for an imperial stout. Silky and luscious body on the tongue. Very slight oiliness. Ill get to the flavours in a moment, but the mouthfeel is remarkable. Taste is really quite hard to describe. A real blend of perfection. Roasted malt, dark chocolate, yeast extract saltiness, very subtle black coffee in the background somewhere, something vinous and alcoholic like the kind of sunshine you get in a Sauternes, syrupy dark chocolate, the beginnings of some dried dark fruit or roasted gooey plums. Each flavour is almost perfectly balanced. The roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate blends perfectly. The yeast extract maltiness and saltiness is slightly dominating, which is my only pedantic criticism. Soy sauce saltiness. The mouthfeel is just a revelation. Never had something with this silky oily vinous texture other than sweet wines. Its not thick though, really light. Ive had a lot of American imperial stouts which are just totally overrated or bourbon bombs, but this is almost perfectly balanced. Its almost a perfection of subtlety, mouthfeel and texture.

Dark nearly black pour with dark brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate and vanilla. Intense velvety dark chocolate flavors. Finish is like baking cocoa and cream and very roasty. Delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pouts Black with medium carbonation and a light brown head. Aroma is rich chocolate, coffee, dark deep fruit, slight hints of both raisins and soy. Flavor is bold chocolate coffee with a perfect bitterness to round it out.

Nose is predictably boozy with caramel, deep sugars and fruits like plum. First taste hits you with the abv with a little sugar tang finishing into a tobacco, coffee earthy tone. Not gonna nitpick this is what I want out of this style, to a T.

Transfer from BA review on 7-9-13-

 Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

 Appearance  Served a nearly pitch black color with a one finger tan colored head. The head fades rather fast leaving only a moderate level of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma was dark and roasty with lots of roasted malt, chocolate malt and coffee aromas. The chocolate is a mix of both bitter cocoa and sweet milk chocolate with aromas of vanilla and caramel adding to the milk chocolate sweet smell. Mixed with these aromas is a little bit of smoke and hop as well as some lighter notes of darker fruits giving a rather roasted and sweet aroma overall.

 Taste  The taste begins with a nice roasted malt flavor with lots of chocolate and coffee upfront. The chocolate starts out a little more on the roasted/cocoa side but gains a sweetness as vanilla, milk and caramel come to the tongue. While a more milk chocolate flavor develops more toward the middle it is balanced by an increase in the coffee bitterness of the brew. Toward the end the sweeter flavors fade more while the coffee remains the same. With a lighter earthy and herbal hop flavor coming to the tongue at the end, along with a light alcohol flavor that comes to the tongue at the end, a nice roasted and moderately sweet and bitter (of coffee and hop) flavor is left to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the slightly thicker and quite creamy side with a carbonation level that was rather average. The feel of this one was quite nice and very appropriate and fitting for the roasted flavors and big feel of the brew.

 Overall - A very delicious imperial with a good blend of roasted malt flavors, sweetness, a tad of booziness, and a nice bitter hop and coffee flavor mixed within. Definitely one to try.
Love this beer. Next to the batch 8000 & 9000 editions. My favorite. Smooth, strong, bite and a clean finish
Pours black tan head and big carbonation. Aroma of rich french roast coffee. Wonderful. Taste takes it to the next level, dried fruit of raisin and prune with some black licorice. Fantastic.

One heck of a brew, slick and oily, black with fast disappearing beige head. Robust but mild aroma leads into sharp, crisp and deep smoky taste. Mouth feel is slick and slippery, lingering coffee bitterness/ Well worth its high ratings.

2008 vintage at Akkurat. Pours matte black with a low semi-compact mocha head with some froth on top. Swirling it leaves almost no lacings on the i side of the glass. Aromas of chocolate, muscovado sugar, honey, slight leather and tobacco, roasted nuts, vanilla. Taste is chocolate, honey, muscovado sugar, roasted nuts, dark red berries, slight burnt meat tones as well as some vanilla hints. Mouthfeel is very smooth yet with oly coatings and a long-lasting impression. Aftertaste is heavily roasted chocolate with roasted nuts and some honey as well. Superbly well balanced!

2012 bottle pouted into a snifter darkest black brown with a brown head that quickly dissipates.
Aroma of molasses dark fruits dark cocoa.
Flavor is incredible rich chocolate cherry coffee roasted malts.
So smooth and luscious. Wonderful blend of flavors. Almost perfect.

Well not much to say most people have had this and it is great. This was bottled 10/22/12. Today is 7/30/14. It is like a thick dark chocolate milkshake in aroma, appearance, taste, and palate. A little bit of smoke in taste. Excellent! Cheers.

Bottle pour, big tan head over opaque black body. Aroma is raisin, bread, bourbon, roasty malt. Taste is raisin, molasses, spice, coffee, bourbon - boozy, roasty bitter malt. Mainly sweet, slightly bitter finish. Palate is rich and thick, carbonation subdued. Pretty big contrast between sweet start and bitter finish.

355ml bottle thanks to BenH.
Appearance - opaque black and viscous with fawn head. 
Nose - dark chocolate with booze and spiced fruit cake. 
Taste - raisins sweet spices and chocolate all engulfed in a boozy case. 
Palate - full bodied with a big sweet viscous texture and a fairly balanced finish despite the big sweetness at the front. 
Overall - yeah great stuff. A multi dimensional imperial stout.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2014 355 ml bottle at home. Black color with a very nice brown head. Aroma is roasted malty full of chocolate, some coffee, fruity (raisins) and alcohol. Taste begins sweet but it becomes very bitter quickly. Milk chocolate, dark chocolate and coffee. Full body, creamy, flat carbonation, bitter coffee finish.

0.355l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. A little treat on this Easter day. It has a deep deep dark brown body with a small islandy and side sticking brown top. It has quite a deep and somewhat complex aroma. Somewhat on the sweet side with lots of sweet licorice, lots of confectionery chocolate. So much that Im having a hard time member in the last time I had this much confectionery chocolate in a beer. Soft vanilla, a little gift of green banana and oak. Not sure if this had been barreled on anything, but it definitely smells of oak. A little bit of charcoal and lots of licorice! Its really comfortably carbonated with a good solid oily mouthfeel. Chocolate, roasted, a fantastic bitterness. Just a lovely flavored beer. The finish is packed with dark chocolate. Almost like Ive finished a plate of dark chocolate by myself. 31.03.2013
Pours black. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate. Taste is amazing and I wished I picked up more bottles of this in April when it was still available.
UPDATED: JUL 20, 2014 Nice beer . Not too heavy, a very drinkable beer,smooth with all the typical stout flavors.A very good all rounder,great for all seasons.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Bottle. Black with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet chocolate, roasted malt, and bourbon. The taste adds espresso and dark fruits, raisin, and plum. Very rich big mouthfeel. Excellent! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from bottle to glass. Black hue with creamy brown hue. Aroma malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, peppercorn, ethanol. Mouthfeel is nice with a fill body and soft carbonation. Taste is sweet initially with astringent bitter following and ethanol finish. Overall this is a really nice stout.

12 oz. bottle, thanks to Dunn4040. Pours black, with a small, brown head. The aroma is strong coffee and bitter chocolate, caramel, faint cherries and tobacco, cinnamon, and peat. Very sweet and malty, with a light roasted bitterness. Very heavy body, sticky, syrupy, and a little chalky. This is a quite a nice stout. Thick, sticky-sweet, and very aromatic. This bottle is about a year old, and I can imagine a few more wouldnt hurt.
Oily black colour, dark brown foam. Soft carbonation. Full body. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Very bitter hoppy finish. Not much sweetness. Well balanced. Good!
Full blown taste in your mouth out of this world beer. Heavy mouth feel yet velvety. Amazing beer.

Pours black w/ absolutely no head or lacing. The aroma has some dark fruit notes & a touch of roastiness. The taste is rich & full upfront & finishes w/ just enough bite to let u know its an imperial. Its medium to full bodied & pretty fantastic on the palate. Beautiful man!

I had this at Global Brew. Pours black with tan head. Taste chocolate, roasted malt, coffee. I thought it was ok. I would not drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
What a big beer tons of flavor. Aroma opens as it warms. Pour is dark black with a nice tan head. Lots of malts and bitter like dark chocolate. Coffee and chocolate cover cherry rule this beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a jet black with lasting beige head. Aroma is massive: chocolate and coffee bitterness, roasted malts, a lactic complexity. Flavor is huge and palate coating: above plus a fruity sweetness over the roasted malt bitterness. Clean finish - outstanding.
Draft. Poured black with a tan head. Bitter sweet chocolate and molasses aroma. Bitter, dry on the palate with coffee a coffee, molasses, cocoa flavor.

Poured from 355mL bottle (pkgd 07/26/13). Creamy jet black with tan head. Nice balance of chocolate and coffee with some subtle sour-sweet raisin and smoked characteristics. Mild alcohol notes. Texture quite creamy. Full body.

Look: pours a dark black. Very thick. Has a dark grown head that is also thick. Leaves heavy lacing on the side of the glass.
Smell: very sweet smell like chocolate candy. Dark dried fruit. 
Taste: coco powder flavor. And bakers chocolate. Bitter coffee flavor. 
Feel: thick on the palate, leaves a thick film on the mouth. 
Overall: good beer. Slightly sweet. Coffee flavor comes out as it warms up.
First drank: home 5/11/14

Poured into a tulip glass. Opaque black with tan head. Improved as I drank, started a little roasty but mostly bland. As it warmed up Im getting black licorice, vanilla, star anise. Pleasant beer to experience as it changes.

Very cocoa chocolate aroma and flavors. Almost a dark chocolate mud like character. Deep flavors and very nice in that respect. Masked alcohol. Very smooth and really a great stout. Just have not been fully in love with the style to rate it super high

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

5/IV/14 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ home - bottled: 10/II/12 (2014-338) Thanks to Jeremy for the bottle!
Dark brown to black beer, creamy dense beige to brown head, pretty stable, non adhesive. Aroma: some chlorine, cocoa powder, sweet, dark chocolate, some caramel, charcoal. MF: soft carbon, full body, smooth texture. Taste: fruity start, berries, little sourish, caramel, sweet, lots of chocolate, cocoa powder. Aftertaste: pretty bitter and hoppy, sweet caramel, mocha, coffee, dark chocolate, alcohol, sugary touch, very yum yum!
Bottle. One of the best and it gets better with age. Pours jet black. Smells like dark fruit, chocolate and alcohol. Tastes like it smells. Bitter aftertaste.

A - 4/5 - nice dark brown black beer with a mocha head that dissipates quick due to the high abv
 A/smell - 10/10- dark coffee, dark chocolate, espresso, smoke
T - 10/10 - dark coffee. Espresso. Roasted notes. Bonfire, smoke, jerky. Cream. 
M/palate - 5/5 - very thick, alc covered , aftertaste roasty chocolate malt, espresso, smokey
O - 19/20 - great imperial stout. This is the 2012 batch so 1.5-2 years old

Pours dark black, oil like. Lots of cocoa, dark fruit, and even bitter cocoa on the nose. Palate is the same, but I also get some roasty characteristics in this one. Finishes pretty smooth for the ABV.

On tap. Poured a nice dark chocolate with a decent khaki head. Roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and a little alcohol on the nose. Taste was toast, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and some plum. Got some alcohol along with a medium bitter to start but it turned almost sweet to finish.
Best non bourbon aged stout ever. Great pour. Finish shows that it is well made

Sweet caramel, toffee flavors, but not overwhelmingly sweet, especially given the alcohol level. A bit of dried fruits. Long finish. Complex flavors.

Roasted coffee flavors, hint of smokiness.

Remarkably full bodied. Almost "well used machine oil", but in a positive way.

This is a great beer.

12 oz bottle @ home. Thanks Al! Pours jet black with a minimal tan head. Nose is full of roasted dark malts, chocolate and some light vanilla. Nice thick mouth feel. Taste is chocolate, lots of roasted malts, some liquorice, light smoke and some sweet fudge.

Bottle. Whoa!!! This was a big beer. Black, velvety, thick. Big chocolate cooled head. Aroma was coffee, chocolate. Taste, was thick, rich coffee and chocolate but one can still detect the hoppy undertone. Really great!

On tap at Macgregors. Black pour with a thick tan head. Aroma is heavy roast and sticky smelling with some caramel, molasses and some dark cocoa. The flavor is huge and rich with a dark slick body, featuring notes of dark cocoa nibs, roast black malts, a bit of molasses, dark earthy caramel and a warming boozy dark cocoa finish. Sweet and roasty, full of sticky black malts and mild sweetness. The alcohol is hidden well.

Bottle. Apprearance: oily, black, with nice brown head. Aroma: milk chocolate, nuts, dried fruits, christmas cake, figs. Taste: although its 10,5% vol., I couldnt feel alcohol. In taste also some coffee, again figs, nuts, chocolate, very rich! Nice long bitter pleasant aftertaste. Nice ballance between sweetness and bitterness. Can not feel saltyness, which is good.

12 oz bottle, poured to a snifter. Jet black with lacey tan head. Aroma is huge dark fruit and complex malt, with coffee/roast overtones. Flavor is smooth and rich, with notes of dark raisins, roast and melanoidins. Hop bitterness on the medium high side, but not detracting. Worth coming back year after year.

12oz bottle. 2013 aged 7 months. Pours pitch black with minimal tan head. Dark goodness of burnt chocolate, coffee, caramel, aged fruits. Very smooth. Everything a RIS should be. Highly recommend if you can find it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I cannot believe I have not rated this yet. Aged only 2 months. Aroma is dark fruit figs, chalky, plums, chocolate, resins. Taste seems to change every sip. Chocolate, dark fruits, lots of dark roasted malts. Aftertaste is medium to long with the alcohol slightly more pronounced. An absolutely great beer! Will definitely cellar some bottles.

P: Completley black with a thin dark brown head. S: Roasted barley, chocolate, molasses, coffee, rum, and dark fruits. T: Dark chocolate, burned coffee, roasted malt, nuts, oak, balers chocolate and some soy. M: Thick and chew with some bitterness. O: Whoa what a big ass non-ba beer.

At long last got my hands on this. Dont really trade so been looking for it in various bottle shops that sell Bells since roughly 08. W00t, they sell Bells here now. At the total tap takeover at tap and Mallet. Appearance is a solid 5/5. Dark, great looking tan head, dark with no highlights. Great retention. Nose is hefty chocolate dominated affair, with a bit of coffee and roast. Full rich mouthfeel.

From a 4oz sample. Id like to get my hands on a bottle of this sometime. Aroma is really good with chocolate, bourbon, and soy sauce. Taste has more of the soy and hint of bourbon, with some vanilla and wood. Full body, creamy and smooth.

Bottle 2013
Pour- black, small amount of creamy reddish, tan head.
Aroma- roast coffee, chocolate, red licorice, raisins, prunes, small amount of booze
Taste - sweet dark fruit turns to bitter, burnt malt, with medium booze taste. Also bitter hops taste in the finish.
Palate- medium bodied, oily mouthfeel with soft carbonation. The finish is actually kind of short and bitter.

Awesome imperial stout. Complex and satifsying with a nice balance of sweet and bitter. I have 2 of these in my cellar and cant wait to see what time does with them.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2014 6-pack of 12 oz bottles ($16.99) dated 9 months ago from Hy-Vee Muscatine. Black appearance with minimal brown head, lingering. Aroma of dark chocolate, caramel, oak, toffee, bourbon, coffee, vanilla, roasted malts and light bitter hops. Similar flavor, adding a touch of dark fruitiness. Rich, sweet and balanced flavor. Full body, thick and creamy, yet pretty easy to drink.  Perhaps the best beer that comes in a 6-pack.  Fairly priced at $17 (approx. $5 a bomber).  I wish I could get this in CO.

2012 bottle. Black, tan head, some lacing. Nose is dark chocolate, roasted malts, dark fruits. Taste is bitter dark chocolate, mocha, dark fruits, raisins, roasted malts. Lasting bittering hops and bittersweet chocolate on the finish. Sticky syrupy mouthfeel. A touch too much carbonation for my liking. My favorite regular RIS. Even Zhukov and Southampton RIS are a step below. Would love to try this with a few years on it and/or on cask.
Tasty, dark stout that pours very thick. Overall its a very good beer that tastes great.

Batch 9971 (2010). Black with a great chocolate head. Aroma is liquorice, soy sauce, molasses, coffee, vanilla. Velvety/syrupy mouthfeel, roasty on the palate with a little booze burn on the finish. Taste is liquorice, coffee, roasted malts, soy sauce, wood.

poured from a bottle, probably 5 months old, this beer had to work hard to produce a thin brown head... Other than that, I cant find any faults with it. It has a subtle coffee aroma, smooth mouthfeel and delightful slightly sweet, slightly bitter aftertaste.

On tap at Beer Authority, NYC. 
Black black black with tan foam. Aroma is very big malt profile; dark choc, mild soy sauce, rich. Taste is so syrupy and full bodied - dark malt, oats, sweetness, so oily. Lingering roasty sweetness. Really like this vibe. Though sweetness is a little intimidating. Does it need a bit of age? Like syrup. Nice finish - mild bitterness with a malty destruction of the palate.

Poured with little head. But did have a slight caramel tinge to it. Nose of dark roast coffee, molasses and chocolate.and drinks about the same. Every taste an adventure. The dark coffee taste is very interesting to me. Solid beer. Especially that it is non barrel aged. Would love to see thus distributed to WA.
Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is of sweet aged fruit chocolate. Flavors are more of a burnt chocolate in multiple levels of fruit and roasted malt. A nice oily mouth feel.

3/4/14. Draft at Surf Club. Exemplar Russian imperial. Stronger roasted notes and bitterness than some. Still wonderfully complex and deep. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle date stamped with a fill date of 2 Oct. 2012. Served in a Belgian snifter.
Pours opaque and nearly black, but with red-brown highlights at the edges. Small dark tan head soon recedes. 
Aroma: semi-sweet and appealing but relatively subtle.
Flavor: Rich and strong, with dark fruits, dark chocolate, dark roasted grains, and hints of molasses and coffee. Great balance, yet both sweet and bitter notes are easily detected.

12 oz bottled 10/02/2012, Aroma is dark fruit, booze and roast. Taste is very reflective of the aromas. Much smoother than when fresh, if I recall. Feels a little thinner than I prefer, but I still think this is a fantastic Imperial Stout

2011 vintage poured into a Bells snifter glass. Thin brown head, diminishes quickly but leaves spotty lacing across the oily top. Sticky webs of lace cling to the glass after each sip. Aroma is balanced with sweet dark fruits, molasses, chocolate and anise. Taste is bold anise paired with chocolate and dark fruits. Nice bitter hops across the end. Finishes nice and dry. A classic.

Bottle at home, purchased Florida, rate # 700. 1st March 14. Cracked the bottle the aroma punched me in the face, full on, thick liquorice, chocolate and leather. Pours, viscous and rich, taste is rich, liquorice, salty smooth and decadent. Top drawer!
What a great stout almost perfect in everyway no real downfalls, it has good flavor and looks wonderful

9/19/11 355ml bottle. Pours black with a thin mocha head. Aroma is a large. Slightly creamy and roasted with mild bitter chocolate. Taste is bitter but balanced well. Big roasted flavour with a creamy bitter dark chocolate and a bitter, roasted finish. Full body with a low-medium carbonation. Huge mouth feel with a perfect carbonation. Overall a superb beer. Great aroma, taste and mouth feel. Well worth tasting. Cheers!
Uh baby love this stuff! My favorite brunch beer of all times. Not too bad at night either

Black hue, zero visibility with mostly diminishing fizzy light brown head. Spotty lacing. Aroma of sweet dark fruit, strong alcohol, when it warmed it smelled like soy sauce. Heavy malt and dark fruit up front with a light short coffee finish. Hints of chocolate as it warmed. Full body, oily texture, flat carbonation.

12 oz bottle. Pours jet black. Smells like fruit, chocolate and booze. Tastes basically like it smells, although the alcohol is less present. Pretty bitter on the back end. Really good beer. Excellent candidate for cellaring.
Wow, this is really good. Tastes mostly of dark chocolate, with strong notes of dried fruit as well. Smooth, almost creamy going down. Incredibly good beer.

pours black with a dark brown head. aroma of dark roast, cherries and chocolate. flavor of coffee, pure chocolate,burnt sugar and cherries.. low carbonation. full bodied. oily mouthfeel. finish is very bitter. alcohol is present but balanced. this imperial stout is fantastic. another fine michigan beer

Draft - Pour very black with a dark brown head. The nose is full of rich dark chocolate and fudge. More dark chocolate in the taste, very smooth with a slight hint of alcohol. This is a very rich, great beer.

Fantastic ! ....One of the best Imperial Stouts ever !...Its in the top category with others like Founders, AleSmith, Thirsty Dog Siberian Night...these are are all so good, but taste different, so it will take time to decide which is the absolute best....$17.99 per 6 pack around N.E. Ohio....Ummmm life is good...

Pours a thick black with a frothy tan head. Certainly packs more taste and smell than other stouts. The chocolatey and roasty notes are extremely pronounced. The body is quite creamy which can even been seen from its flow. Finishes with a mildly bitter aftertaste and a little boozyness makes an appearance. Excellent. Consistent with other great beers from Bells.

Tap at Jeffrey. Pours jet black with pretty beige head and great lacing. Nose is chocolate and light hops. Mouthfeel is excellent velvety texture. Tastes of chocolate, plums, light leather, molasses, coffee, and some pine. Despite being rich in no way cloying and abv is pretty well hidden making this dangerously drinkable. Hopslam kicked before I got here bit this is fine consolation.
The darkest beer Ive had, no head just a little a film for lacing. It smells and taste of chococlate, coffee, malts, toffee and it is just great

Tykflydende sort, tæt brunt skum. Intens aroma af engelsk lakrids. Smagen er tyk og fed, cremet med malt, bitterhed og mørke bær. Altsammen varer ved i lang eftersmag, suppleret af boozy alkohol. Wow.

Draft at Clinton hall NYC for the launch event. Pours a deep black color. No head but slight lace on the side. Sweet boozy milky imp stout.very good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2016 On tap at The Good Life in Massapequa..jet black pour with fluffy tan head..aroma of coffee,chocolate,roasted nuts..smooth creamy mouthfeel..dry with some hop bitterness..really good.
Serious black, strong, and chocolate stout. Caramel and coffee notes. Great sipping beer, great with a cigar.

Bottles pours charcoal with ample dark brown head. Intense aroma of dark fruits, cocoa powder, and roasted malts. Flavors of dark fruits (plums, raisins), vanilla, coffee, tart cherries, and a hint of cocoa. Very, very smooth with a creamy mouthfeel.

Poured from 2-yr aged bottle into tulip: Pours black with a nice tan head. Great appearance. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and some dark fruit. Taste is very sweet, but flavor profile is the same as the aroma with booze throughout. Full body, nicely carbonated, just too cloying and boozy for my taste. I think I would have liked it (bitter) fresh.
UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Second only to Dragons Milk in high gravity Michigan stouts. Same high Bells quality as Two Hearted Ale.

Perfect appearance: pitch black with a thick, creamy tan head. Warming aroma. Surprisingly smooth for the ABV; boozy but not harsh at all. The malts have a complex mix of chocolate, toffee, dark fruit, and burnt toast. Sharp, resiny hops with some spruce notes. Very unique and complex flavor. Highly bitter. Cant wait to have this again after aging it for a couple years.

Poured from bottle 6 months aged. Pours black. Head dissipates quickly. Good lacing. Aroma is chocolate and pepper. Taste is malty with a little bitterness at the end. Mouth feel is chewy. Enjoyed this beer.

Aroma is faint dark chocolate. The head is big copper brown that turns into a velvety tan brown with lots of lacing. The mouthfeel is rich and you get a sniff of alcohol as you take this down. Dark cocoa and toasted malts. Really delicious and smooth. Would love to try this on a nitro draft sometime (if possible).

Black pour with a thick khaki head. Nose is heavy roasty and sticky smelling with some caramel and lots of molasses and dark cocoa nibs. The flavor is huge and rich with a dark slick body, featuring notes of dark cocoa nibs, roast black malts, a bit of molasses, dark earthy caramel, boozy ester heaviness, and a warming boozy dark cocoa finish. Sweet and roasty, full of sticky black malts and mild sweetness.

Aroma intenso y agradable, digno de una Imperial Stout. Al primer contacto aromático se percibe profundos aromas a café y chocolate amargo. De igual forma se percibe ligeramente maltas y madera, así cómo un agradable dulzor. Aroma delicioso.

De apariencia, literalmente un petroleo negro. Color profundamente obscuro sin dejar pasar ni un destello de luz. Cuerpo completamente redondo. Carbonatacion prácticamente nula. Lo único malo es que no existió corona de espuma, quizá por el alto contenido alcohólico, aun que rn los bordes de la coa existe una ligera espima de color completamente café.

En boca suave y ligera, café combinado con un grandioso sabor a chocolate y un rico final ligeramente dulce.

Al paladar es ina cerveza grandiosa y con un equilibrio fabuloso. Un dulzor general es equilibrado con un ligero amargor que permamece hasta el final.

En general es una Imperial Stout increíble, reune todos los requisitos que una cerveza debe contener para considerarse grandiosa. Aroma, sabor, complejidad, equilibrio! Excelente!

Poured from a bottle into a tulip. Pours nearly black with a creamy mocha head that dissipates into a thin cap. Incredible aroma - roast, chocolate, dark ripe fruit and a touch of hoppiness that is present at first but fades as the beer warms. My taste experience went something like this - intense sweetness, mostly chocolate and roasted malt, then a flood of dark ripe fruit, the finish is slightly dry and bitter. Very delicious beer; complex and interesting - one to try again and again. This was my fourth of a 6 pack; saved 2 to age.

Served just above room temp in a snifter. Sweet, malty aroma. Beautiful tan head and lacing. The bitterness stands out immediately. Very creamy mouth feel; viscous. Honestly a strange stout, bitter yet sticky sweet, dark chocolate, faint burnt taste on the back. Looking forward to aging a few bottles, because this beer begs for it.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2014 Drank at home with Thierry 29-1-2014. Looks really dark, small amount of foam. Awesome smell. Tastes like coffee and pure chocolade. Very thick beer. Great richness.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2016 Update 2-7-16 has mellowed nicely with age.  Very smooth with overripe dark fruit and the dry tannin qualities have disappeared.

Solid imperial stout, poured from bottle into snifter. Pours a deep black with a thin tan head that only exists were the beer meets the glass. Strong alcohol on the nose with a tar like hint. Very dry palate with hints of dark cocoa, deep plum and dark berry. Has tannins on the mouthfeel. Think I may save the remainder of the 6 pack and see how they mellow with age.

This is one of Bells finest! This is surprisingly smooth for a high ABV. This is an imperial stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black with a brown head; Decent lacing. Aroma of cocoa nibs/chocolate, vanilla, roasted barley and malts. Smokey and roasty flavor upfront with a dark chocolate and vanilla finish. Heavier body with some mild carbonation. Very Nice!
12 oz bottle pours like motor oil with a thick brown head. Roasty, toasty with hints of, licorice, chocolate, vanilla. Yum!

Pours a dark black with a little head. Aroma is roasted malt, with coffee and licorice. Very thick mouthfeel, but it is nicely balanced given the fact that it is 10.5% ABV. This one will definitely warm you up and is a great beer.

Pours nearly black from a bottle. Almost no head. A boozy aroma of black licorice and coffee. Toasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, and almost a burnt toast flavor leads. Excellent dry finish. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Chocolate, coffee, roast on the nose. Pillowy tan head. Thick mouthfeel with hint of bitter and alcohol. Cant wait to age it.

What a delight! Knew it was going to be strong after seeing the abv at 10.5, but was impressed how smooth this brew goes down! Great chocolate and malty taste with a beautiful finish!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma - is full of chocolate and alcohol. There are other elements as well.
Appearance - The appearance on initial pour is amazing! Its moves quickly from its black 1/4 glass fill to that stout set-up where it starts cascading in the glass and turns brown and bubbly. The final set up results in a black body with a big frothy tannish brown head. All the way through it maintains a tan halo.
Taste - the taste is full and complex. Its a perfect balance of coffee, chocolate, alcohol, roasty bitterness, and dark fruit seeps in on the back end.
Palate - the body is full as it gets. The texture is intensely creamy. The carbonation is lively, and the finish is a big long play bitter alcohol pleasant burn. 

I saved my 400th rating for something grand. Number 12 on RateBeers list, and it was well worth the wait. This was a great beer. Sometimes a beer hits the notes, but it isnt enjoyable. This really was enjoyable for sure.

12 oz. bottle in a snifter. Appearance is just about jet black. There is no head other than a thin ring of brown carbonation. Aroma is huge: rich malts, dark fruits, licorice, chocolate, and a bit of roastiness. The richness of the aroma is almost overwhelming. The taste isnt quite as rich, and the roastiness is much more apparent. This is an excellent stout, one of my favorites.

Popped a 2012 vintage to see how this had developed and notice that I yet to rate. What?!?!? Aroma is perfect mix of booze, dark fruit, chocolate, grape, and coffee. Pours deepest brown with large medium brown head. Flavor is sweet up front with nice muted bitter finish. Thick and just lively enough in my mouth. Complex and wonderful. Bottle - Ale Yeah! - Decatur, GA

12oz bottle served in a snifter

A - Creamy black liquid with a thick and frothy chocolate milk cap that holds up throughout the entire session. Speckled lacing left on the glass.

S - Chocolate malts, roasted malts, chocolate bread, muddled fruit, sweet cream, chocolate lined alcohol.

T - Creamy milk chocolate upfront, sweet and decadent, heavily roasted malts and strong bitterness come in quickly and overtake the creamy sweetness. The middle provides anise, smoked molasses, and a strong bitterness that runs throughout the drink. The finish brings intense roasted malts, bittering chocolate, notions of fruit, hints of grass and winds up for a smooth and roasted chocolate finish.

M - Incredibly viscous, thick and full bodied. Moderate micro carbonation, dry roasted finish. One of the best mouthfeels Ive come across.

Theres something to be said about being complex in a simple way. This beer is simple but it brings outstanding precision and subtle complexities, with a strong bitterness to round out the sweetness. Very focused flavors that bring maximum flavor with a stellar body that is as creamy as they come. My favorite Bells by far!

Serving type: bottle

10-12-2013
Huge thanks to Kcbeernerd for the bottle! Smell is dark chocolate chocolate with a little vanilla. Taste is rich chocolate. Very smooth, with a good aftertaste. Man is this good!!

Every once in a while you come across a beer and youre just like "Hey, I wonder what this beer would taste like after sitting on the floor of my closet for 12 months!" on even rarer occasions you indulge yourself in this process... Ive been cellaring this beer for a year now and tasting them every 6 months. At first it was much more stouty. It tasted like a 10.5% beer. It was sort of boozy but a very sweet and over the top chocolate flavor. As it has aged it has slid away from the booziness and more towards the chocolate malty flavor. This is a great beer. Its super sweet and easy to drink, and smooth, its silky and delicious... I enjoy this beer a lot.

Ive been aging a 6 pack for a year now, so this one is a few days more than a year old. It definitely has improved since I last drank it at 6 months old. It tastes sweeter and has a nice rich chocolate taste. You cant taste the 10% alcohol at all which is both good and kind of scary. Overall this is excellent and ages very well. I only wish I had bought more so I could have had more to drink when it gets even older.
Chocolate and sweet aroma. Pours nice, little head. Strong taste of molasses and a heavy, thick feeling beer. Good

1/17/14 bottle drank after an ipa at CBO. GREAT STUFF
pours close to black with a small finger head. Nose is rich roasted coffee, chocolate possibly nutty? Taste is bitter cocoa and chocolate, vanilla, mouthfeel is the only thing keeping it from beating TenFidy. THIS IS AWESOME!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an oily black with the thinnest of chocolate colored heads that dissipates immediately. Aroma is huge and very pleasant. Starts with a sugary chocolate that turns into dark fruit with a huge malt presence. The taste begins with an oily smooth texture that gets more and more chocolatey. Very roasty, no smoke, lots of dark fruit in the middle, has a sweetness throughout that warms your throat and stomach with the slight burn of the booze. There is a huge amount of malt that doesnt overpower with sweet at all that is the backbone that the other flavors bounce off of. Overall a massively impressive beer, I typically dont care for this style but this hits all the right notes.
Very roasty, malty. Chocolatey, smoky, dates, figs, bitter. A very balanced beer. Imposing darkness and intense roast character with just enough hops to bite. One of my favorite beers. Hella sick
2012 12oz bottle pours a dark black with a thin tan head. big roasted malt chocolate aroma. taste is the same with slight coffee, as it warms the taste really comes out

This beer is so good and so tasty. Smells roasty and chocolatey. Very dark in appearance. This brew is really heavy, and took me a while to get through a glass. Very sweet to me, syrupy, molasses, chocolate, some coffee. This would be a great beer to put away for awhile.
When pouring noticed the resin and felt the weight of this brew. Tight carbonation coffee , coco, earthy and slight smoke taste. Awesome stout and winter warmer.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Draft. Nose full of dark chocolate and dark cocoa. Small light brown head. Pitch black in color. Taste is full of molasses, tobacco and rich chocolate. Some roast as it warms up. Just a touch of alcohol warming in the finish and exhale. Very full and thick. Tasty. 

Had a rottig old bottle that had been oxidixing for about 5 years.  Even more complex dark fruits.  no papery oxidation. lots of vinous character.  WOW, bumped my score up 0.3
Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Smells very vanilla, chocolate. Very rich and thick, lots of chocolate with a bit of coffee finish, bitter backbone. Really solid, really good.
Great stout. Very rich with creamy mouth feel. Had six pack from Holmes. Has a boozy aftertaste with sweet malty flavors.
as with most of Bells stouts, this one was above average with most of the stout notes they are known for. good as is most of their products.
Aroma smells like it will have a high ABV burn but it's actually pretty mild. Not bad.
Pitch black, rich and robust aroma and taste. Extremely drinkable. Definitely one of the better imperial stouts out there.
Wow - big, bold, complex Russian imperial stout. Mega aroma, flavor, and mouthfeel. Yummmm!!!

Bottle. Dark brown pour, not quite opaque, with a small brown head. Aroma is boozy, roasty, and a little bready, with coffee, dark fruits and dark chocolate. Flavour is the same, very complex with lots of fruit notes and a beautiful balance of strong bitterness and smooth sweetness.

Bottle at home. Pours a viscous black with a mocha colored head. Smells of roasted malt, char, and burnt coffee, Taste is well balanced with a nice chocolate coffee burnt flavor upfront. Mouthfeel is as would be expected. Overall, an excellent RIS.
Pours black with dark tan head. slight hop/bitter coffee taste with small fruit/chocolate aroma underneath the roasted malt. Smooth taste with medium palate weight.

You smell alcohol, chocolate, little bit of bread, of course coffee, roasty flavor, the jet black skim milk look, gorgeous brown head, and that coffee taste, the sweetness is perfect with the bitter taste. The after taste is perfect as well. One of the best stouts out there!

Amazing RIS! Amazing... Did I say amazing? Aroma hots your nose as you pour. Caramel, toffee, licorice... And chocolate. Flows smooth over your tongue in a way that lightly and temporarily covering your mouth. All those aromas come in the taste as well with hints of vanilla. Id say it was barrel aged if I was blindfolded. 

Overall you cant get much more of a complex brew than this, especially without barrel aging for this price. 

Going back to stockpile this to test aging characteristics.

Black with a deep brown, lasting, lacy head. Deep smell of coffee, chocolate, burnt and nice deep roast. Full oily body. Tastes of burnt chocolate roasty malt with a silky middle with a boozy black, liquorish,super malty finish.

Bottle courtesy of Kermis at Deans night before the night tasting, Den Haag. Poured a clear dark brown with a bubbly round light tan head. The aroma is smoky dry roasted malt smooth light caramel with a some boozy alcohol. The flavour is moderate to heavy bitter with a big creamy alcohol liqourice palate. Full bodied with soft carbonation. An oily mouthfeel and a long bitter finish. Superb.

Bottle at the night before the night tasting. Pours dark brown with a brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, bourbon, prunes, caramel and alcohol. Taste is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Great balance. Long finish with lots of coffee. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Pours a beautiful deep motor oil. A thin tan head forms a ring around the edges. Aroma is caramel, malt, cocoa and raisin. Alcohol is present on the nose as well. Taste is toasty malt, soy sauce, bitter chocolate and a nice alcohol warmth. Smooth and full bodied with a mild carbonation. Overall a very nice imperial stout. Definitely worth a taste, and one of my favorite seasonal stouts. Bells gets my seal of approval everytime.

Poured from a bottle. Dark brown color, short lived small tan head. Sweet roasted malt aroma. Full body sweet burnt malt with a smooth phenolic finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma of malt with a dark brown colour not much head. Complex taste of coffee, malt, and phenols. With a phenolic palate.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2014 Bottle poured into a brandy snifter.The aroma is initially a tart cherry and cherry pie aroma with some burnt toast, dark chocolate, and oak with late caramel. Beautifully opaque, brown-black, with rich, dark brown head that fades fast, but a very thin layer is present throughout drink with a dense, soap-bubble medium thin ring and a few specks of lace. The taste is heavily sweet with a medium heavy, chocolate coffee bitter, and a touch of umam to it. Its a viscous, chewy mouth feel with light carbonation. The body is full with notes of chocolate, tart cherries, coffee, and a nice, smooth alcohol warmth to the finish. As it warms up more caramel notes come through with a burnt quality to the finish. The aftertaste is that of dark chocolate and cherries with a bit of a smokiness.

Poured to NB globe.
Batch 9971: 09/13/10
First tasting: 08FEB11
Second tasting: 30AUG11

A: Pours dark brown with no head formation. Upon stir, get a temporary dark mocha, loose bubbled head (1/2 finger) which disappears very quickly. Border remains.
A2: Dark brown, under 1/2 finger dark mocha head falls slowly to a broken sheet of the same. Spotty lacing. Clarity irrelevant. 

S: Roasted malts, grains, hints of dates, figs, licorice. Theres quite a metallic scent here too, a bit off setting. (2.5)
S2: Roasted malts of coffee, dates and prunes. My initial impression upon opening this beer was a healthy dose of molasses, I no longer really smell this. Some cocoa there as well. Licorice is evident, but nicely integrated. (3)

T: Wow, the licorice takes over here. Also quite bitter. Dark, unsweetened cocoa in here. Fairly one dimensional. Finish resonates for what seems forever. It tastes burnt. (3) 
T2: Dry cocoa powder, licorice, burnt coffee, molasses now bites back. Hmm, reminds me of burnt toast with a wee bit of cinnamon/sugar over the top (very wee bit). (3.5)

M: Thick, low carbonation, very very sticky. (3)
M2: Thinned out a bit, medium on low carbonation. Leaves a sticky finish with a dry feel. (3)

D: One is more than enough. I cant stand behind this beer. (3)
O2: This beer is too roasted and burnt tasting for me. If it had a bit more molasses flavor, it would remind me of Nightstalker by GI. Although I dislike how sweet NightStalker comes across, this one comes out with too much of the burnt malts and not enough balance with the other flavors. (3)

Serving type: bottle

08-31-2011

2012 bottle thick black oily pour, wonderful thick creamy tan head with good staying power. Aroma - heavy chocolate roasted malts, anise, coffee, maybe a bit of hops, smells freaking delicious! Taste - strong roasted malts, thick mouthfeel, some nice sweetness in the middle, dry bitter coffee aftertaste, alcohol is well hidden.

12oz bottle (bottled 8/29/13) pours near-black with a small finger of tab head. Nose is rich earthy roasted coffee, nutty almond, vanilla. Taste is creamy silky smooth bitter cocoa and chocolate, vanilla, mouthfeel is heavenly. Finish is dark bitter roasty cocoa and creamy vanilla, little bits of booze and faint dark fruit. This is amazing stuff.

Bottle at a local restaurant. Poured a deep, dark brown with little head. Aroma was chocolate, coffee. Taste was heat, alcohol heat followed by coffee, chocolate, raisins with a thick mouthfeel and tailing off into a dry and quick ending. Quite the winter brew.

Bottle 2012: aged this a year and the alcohol bite was cut down and the malty chocolate goodness came forward. Excellent example of the Russian imperial style done by one of the best. Enjoyed!

The appearance has a large brown head with an opaque black color, and the brew smells only like roasted malts. The taste is quite umami, touch sweet, and slightly bitter, and the palate fuses a thick body, soft carbonation, creamy texture, and a long finish that is an extension of the flavor.

Pours dark with a tan leather head. It smells of smoke and strong espresso. Tastes of bitter chocolate with a clove aftertaste and finishes with a dry palate. Overall one of the best American stouts on the market.

Bottle @ Max. Pitch black, small tan head, good lacing. Aroma, roasted malts, dark chocolate, licoriceroot, coffee, some alcohol, dark fruits, brown sugar. Taste, roasted malts, dry liquorice, dark chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, brown sugar. This is good, i really like the licorice aromas. Bitter dark chocolate dry aftertaste. Dry mouth feel.

Nothing fancy here...just a perfect RIS. Found a sixer on sale at a local grocery store for $14. May go back and beg for more. Been drinking Goose Island Bourbon Country Stout the last couple of days, and its a little better, but for value, this blows it away!

Bottle. Opaque black liquid with small to medium tan head. Aroma of chocolate, leather, raw sugar, coffee, bread, licorice, pumpernickel and toast. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of coffee, chocolate, biscuit, licorice and leather. Full bodied with low carbonation and sticky mouthfeel. Really nice.

From a bottle dated 10/12/12. Thick viscous black pour with thin tan head. Big malt profile with dark chocolate, plum coffee and caramel. Deliciously complex , sip on it as it warms up and an amazing personality emerges. A truly great Stout!

Thick dark pour with very little head. Mocha and coffee aroma. A really think chewy taste...roasted malts, chocolate with a little espresso. This is a dam good beer, complex with a great long finish.

Pours a very dark brown with a very large, melted chocolate ice cream colored head. Chocolate, mildly smoky, and sour woody aromas. Viscous and chewy texture. Fresh melon flesh near the rind, dark chocolate, and finishing with a smoky, strong coffee flavor. Quite unique.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2013 Nice stout. Beautiful ebony color. Roasted chocolate malt stands out nicely. Perfect amount of sweet and bitter mixes nicely with hints of coffee.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep black color with a thin creamy light brown head. Aroma is full of roasted malts, chocolate. Taste packs a punch with heavy roasted malt, light bitters, light chocolatey sweetness. Coats the palate with a thick creamy goodness with a light lingering bitter burnt chocolate. Awesome stout!

Pours inky black with a frothy tan head. Aroma is full of dark rich roast malt, chocolate, espresso, and strong stone fruits. Slight hints of booze near the end. Flavor is amazing blend of heavily sweet fruits with a bitter long duration throughout. Great beer, Absurdly good

Pours black with a nice thick tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, faint coffee, and something heavier than molasses - treacle maybe. Taste is smooth roasted malts & coffee up front, taking on a creamy (not quite) chocolate mid and finishing with an easy roasted bitterness.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2015 A overlooked stout. I always stumble on it in my fridge and am always happy with it thanks bells.  Let these age.  Revisited a year later.  So good.  Holy crap. Age this.  It so mellows well

12 oz. bottle. Bottled 7/26/13. Pours a medium, well retained, dark beige head, with some lacing over a black brown (SRM 40) body.....nose is chocolate, coffee, dried fruits, hints of umami, ethanol.....taste is lightly sweet, with coffee, chocolate, dried fruits including plum, fig, hints of brown sugar, light beef tones, finishing with a soft bitterness.....mouth feel on the heavy side of medium, sticky, alcohol warmth present but subdued, carbonation low with a soft finish. This is a lovely complex confection. The bitterness is subdued, but the balance is superb. BJCP 9/3/17/5/8

33cl bottle, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: pitch black beer, nice stable beige head.

Fantastic stout. Beautiful aroma that seems a bit hoppy. Black in appearance. Lightly sweet and moderately bitter in taste. A full bodied, thick beer. Perfect for winter.

Absolutely amazing Impy Stout. I just tried this for the first time tonight and it was a 2012. Wow super complex, picking up dark fruits, cherries, plum and raisin notes as well as chocolate, toffee, butterscotch as well. A year has done wonders on this beer.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 On tap at World of Beer, Ann Arbor poured into snifter. Midnight black with tall chocolate milk-colored head that leaves rings of lacing on the drink down. Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, roasted malt, and alcohol. Taste is similar - malty with chocolate, coffee, and roasted flavors. Modest bitterness from hop and espresso supply balance. Wow. How awesome is this ? Take a sip and let all the flavors wash over in groups. Amazing !
Creamy malty soy aroma. Thick light brown head and very dark body. sweet chocolate and some vanilla, roasty malts. Smooth and creamy on the palate.
Leather and play dough aroma. Tastes like chocolate and flour. Feels like gravy. Could drink from a shot glass.

3 mos old. Black with edges of ruby red. Nice chocolatey head. Complex nose is an understatement. A carousel of malt, dark fruit (cherry raisin), roasted chocolate, a little booze. Taste is short fruity which quickly turns into roasted coffee and chocolate. Bitterness slowly grows and then slowly goes away. Light burn in the esophagus from the booze. Wow. Complex and amazing. I had to laugh as I was pouring it--it almost looks like some kind of thick motor oil going into the glass, and then, even with a nonaggressive pour, theres all that deliciously chocolate-like foam. The aroma is dark cherry, bourbon, chocolate, figs. The flavors meld all of the aforementioned with an earthy toasted malt. The 10.5 ABV is a bit evident in the nose but well-hidden in the taste. Palate is smooth as can be. Hops come through casually in the finish. I am not a fan of stouts, and in fact, generally avoid them. Theyre usually much too roasted and smoky for me, but this one has much more going on, and the roast and smoke are held to the background. I could return to this one often.
Bottle.Black pour with a thin tan head with a short duration. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, coffee, dark fruits, chocolate and hops. As good as advertised.

Very nice stout. Nice and dark with and very earthy taste. Also used it to cook with and was amazing.

Complex aromas, licorice, burnt caramel, soy, tar, dark roasted coffee, and cacao. Smooth black with a light tan head. Dry, roasty, bitter, and burnt, with savory soy, and lingering coffee notes. Full bodied, sticky and thick, strong but not aggressive with alcohol, and finishes with great roast and burnt flavors lingering.

Tasted from bottle. Pours jet black with a tan head. Some lacing. Aroma is robust coffee and dark chocolate. Lot of roasted malt aroma. First taste is sweet toffee caramel, coffee, chocolate. The sweetness fades into moderate bitterness with huge coffee and chocalate taste. Ends with a mild alcohol burn. Just a huge beer. For close to 11% it really does hide it well. You really got watch it because it goes down really smooth. Absolutely incredible beer. It's the best imperial stout I've had.

The aromas that dominate for me are alcohol and vanilla. The alcohol, however, is not dominant in the flavor. This is a smooth, drinkable RIS from one of my favorite breweries. Deep, roasty and licorice flavors, and a full-bodied mouthfeel make this an excellent beer.

Appearance is jet black with a creamy tan head that dissipated quickly. Aroma is an intense collection of molasses, licorice, and deep toasted chocolate/coffee. Taste starts with sweet roasted chocolate malt with molasses and dark fruit, giving way to an sharp hop bite. Mouthfeel is medium to thick, with a nice viscosity and creaminess. Finish leaves a nice roasted malt character on the tongue without being too much. Very well balanced with a bit of alcohol warmth. Outstanding imperial stout

Pours a dark black, almost nothing on the nose, maybe a small about of chocolate. Bold flavors on this brew, a balanced smokey malt. Nice long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled 8/22/13 and poured into a shaker pint : ... I wanted to age this one, but decided to drink it now, and then age any bottles that I get later. $2.99 single.

Appearance: I poured aggressively thinking this wouldnt give me much of a head, boy was I wrong. I got about 90% of the beer poured and the glass was full, almost half with foam. Gorgeous beer, and one of the best RISs Ive seen. As youd expect, the beers an abyss. The mocha (almost orange) three finger or more of head dies down to about half of one. Lacing is phenomenal.

Smell: Quite good, but just not quite what I was hoping for. Has a very nice aroma to it, but its not as pungent as I was hoping for. Maybe its the thick head I have on top thats blocking out some of the notes. Roasted coffee, deep, dark chocolate, a hint of smoke/ash, and a bit of soy sauce. As Expedition Stout warms, nondescript dark fruits come out to play.

Taste/feel: First off, the feel. It is every bit of what an RIS lover would hope for. Super thick and creamy, with a subtle carbonation. The taste is fabulous, though, like the smell, not killing me with gigantic bold flavors, and the bitterness isnt nearly as harsh as I was lead to believe. Like the smell, roast, coffee, chocolate... theres also a pretty big ash sort of flavor on the finish. There is an alcohol warmth (surprised, surprise!), but there doesnt really seem to be an alcohol flavor... maybe slightly.

Overall, I actually want more out of this. It has a big body. It has a really bold "feel" to it, but the flavor isnt reeking of coffee or chocolate like I thought it might. Still, Im ecstatic that I enjoy RISs as much as I do now. Im really enjoying this beer... I couldnt ask for more from the appearance and mouthfeel, as they are truly flawless.

This is black, rich, bitter, sweet and complicated. And really, really good. Tasted something different with each sip. Should probably buy a bottle and age it for a few years....see what happens. Love it, but a few sips was really enough. Dont know if i could or would drink a whole bottle- its pretty aggressive in every way, but truly delicious. Like espresso- a couple of ounces and I am happy.

Bottled 8/29/13. This stout is as dark as pitch, rather complex and evolving. Bitterness provides significant structure which gives way to chalkiness, sweetness and eventually a salty, malty character.

Pours a nice black with a chocolate head. Has a very robust chocolate aroma. It has a heavy chocolate taste that lingers for a while after you swallow. Goes down smooth. I can see why its one of the top 50.

Delicious. Beautiful. 2013 edition opened fresh. So much amazingness in this beer. Bitter. Full. Complete.

Jet black pour, nice coffee aroma. Tatse is very good. Smooth chocoolate notes and light coffee flavor.

Bottle. Not much aroma but nice roasted malt stout flavor. Pours tar black with thin tan head. Would like to save some of these to see how it taste after aging a couple months.

August 2013 bottle pour..jet black with quality dark brown 1 finger head that dissipates nicely..aroma is a sign that this is complex and perhaps worthy of the hype..full of coffee..chocolate..vanilla..roasted goodness..smells of barrel aging as well..mouthfeel is amazingly medium bodied with all kinds of smoothness..just enough bitter bite to keep things in check..no real alcohol heat or burn on finish but on linger this does warm up the insides..slight licorice/anise character on palate as well..quite tasty and looking forward to stashing a few bottles to see how it develops over time..

Smooooth. Strong coffee and roasted malt aromas. Not too heavy for such a strong stout. One of my favorites.

On tap at Bethlehem Brewworks. Pours pitch black with thin tan head. Roast, coffee, vanilla, plums. Moderately bitter, lightly sweet. Surprisingly light, smooth body.
Jet black beer with a foamy brown head. Has a strong malty flavor and hints of fruit.

A very solid stout by Bells. Nice dark head and creamy finish. A definite go to stout for Bells.

Been looking forward to this one for a long time. Poured from a 12oz bottle in to a pint glass straight down the middle. Pours black and leaves a moderate lacing. Strong coffee and chocolate on the nose, and even more so at first taste. nice bitter chocolate flavor on the finish. Tremendous beer

Bottle from Justin, 2012 vintage. Thanks!
Pours black with a small dark brown head that rest down to a small film.
Aroma has loads of chocolate, mud cake, raisins, roasted malt, molasses.

Cellar temperature. Poured as dark as oil with a big tan head. Aroma is cocoa with a bit of coffee. Taste is rich dark chocolate with a well-balanced sweetness and bitterness finding the right spots on your tongue. Excellent!

Have had this fresh, but this rating is from an August 2012 bottle opened in October 2013. Poured into a goblet. Pours a deep brown, near black, with a persistent brown head. Heavy brown lacing. Aroma of deep roasted malt, dark, slightly bitter espresso, chocolate, vanilla. Taste is licorice, espresso, dark chocolate. Great on a cold night.

Meet expectations from reviews I have read. One of those beers that should be reserved for quite 1 hr downtime to sip and reflect. Clear buy again favorite

Pours a near black with a tan head. Aroma of black licorice and syrup. Taste is dark and strong. With a peppery bite in the finish. Strong and good.

Bottled on 8/29/13, so two months old, this beer is very rich and complex. Its roasted malts bring dark, rather bitter flavors, and a medium sweetness. Color is very dark to black with a tan head. Bitter finish. I would love to let this one age and mellow, but Im sure it wont last that long.

12oz bottle. Dark impenetrable beer, good lacing, oyster head. Aroma is very appetizing, matches taste, intensifies as it warms. Taste is phenomenal, just unbelievably good. Agree with description as far as malt body and taste profile. Like drinking a dark chocolate bar, with more complexity & slight carbonation! I have a hard time describing just how good this beer is, and Im looking forward to re-rating it when I take a bottle out of the cellar in a year.

1/19/2010. 12 oz. bottle. A masterpiece of a stout. Black, thick, oily, complex. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, licorice, dark fruit. Bitter and hoppy with just the right amount of alcohol burn on the finish.
Dark and thick. Amazing aroma. Roasty dark malt, coffee, caramel and chocolate to name a few. Taste is lightly sweet roasted malt, coffee, molasses and caramel. Absolutely outstanding stout.

Very nicely blended - thats what makes this stout a notch above others. The roasted tones compliment a small amount of sweetness very nicely, and on top of that, a very smokey finish comes as a very pleasant surprise. Bit pricey, but certainly worth it.

This is the best stout I have ever had. Super coffee flavored and high alcohol content. Smells like fish brewed coffee. Pours a dark brown almost black.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2014 Pours a thick and nearly jet black. Thin light brown head that dissipates into a wispy thin top to the beer. Smells like bakers chocolate, dark fermented fruits, a little boozy, and a little bitter. A little licorice, as well as a little bit of an earthy wood smell to it. Each time I take a whiff I get something different. Great complexity in the aroma. Taste is phenomenal. Dark chocolate, smoked wood, licorice, dark fruits, molasses, some bitterness but not as much as I would expect from an imperial stout that is this young. Feels thick and luscious in the mouth. Each sip is literally a different experience. This is as good as an Imperial Stout gets. I cant wait to try this with some age on it. Phenomenal beer.
My favorite imperial stout. Black pour, tan head. Thick. Chocolate coffee aroma. Big milk chocolate coffee and dark fruit. Big mouthfeel. Small to medium carbonation.

Bottle poured into a Pint glass, Bottled On: 7/26/13 Pours black, completely opaque, even at the edges of the glass. Three finger thick brown head that slowly settles in. The aroma is of strong black coffee, bread, and milk chocolate. For the taste, acrid coffee prevails, but the mouthfeel and contrasting sweetness are similar to chocolate milk. Theres a hint of alcohol as you swallow. Full bodied, leaves behind vertical strings of lacing. Very good beer, and it hides the alcohol much better than imperial stouts of similar abv. Highly recommended.
From bottle. pours a black/brown with a thin tan head. Aroma was all dark chocolate and sweet booze. Taste follows with dark fruit and roasted notes, Very balanced and complex. Nice.

On tap at Ridgewood (Raleigh). 

Pours dark with a couple finger head. Looked fabulous. Equally fabulous aroma of malt and pure stout goodness. Taste includes a nice combination of coffee, malt, and cocoa. A slightly dark and bitter stout - excellently done.

89 Buick oil change black. Thin, vanishing deep tan head. Malt, bitter chocolate nose. Huge flavor. Licorice, dark fruit, malt sweetness, subtle coffee notes. Slick and sticky all at once, nice bitter on the back end. Wonderfully smooth at 10.5.

This was my favorite of the stouts from the sampler I had yesterday at Bells. Picked up a 6 pack from their store and brought it home for this taste test. Starts out with a roasty coffee and chocolate nose. Pours an inky black in the glass with minimal head. At first taste you pick up a bitter coffee on the tongue. Dont rush through this one! It gets even better as it warms and the other flavors come through. Overall this is a wonderful example of an imperial stout. Great beer to enjoy at the end of a long day while watching the Tigers beat the Red Sox!

12 oz bottle. The pour is a used oil. Both in consistency and color. There is a thin dark mocha head that fades quickly. The aroma is heavy in licorice, dark fruit and some booze. The taste is much of the same. It's beautiful. The mouth feel is very viscous and clingy. I absolutely love this beer!

Pours literally like oil out of a barrel. I cant believe how thick and inky it came out. Feels the same way. Much deserved of its incredibly high rating. One of the better stouts Ive ever had. Wow. Drink it!

Jet black pour. Nice thick mouthfeel. Abv very well hidden. Didn't realize it was 10.5% till later. Taste is wonderful. Deep roasted background with some light sweetness and a moderate bitterness that folds in at the end. I've had it fresh, 1 year, and 2 year aged now. It gets better the longer it goes. Buy some and stash it away. One of the best non-barrel aged, easy to get stouts out there.

Neverending tap sampler, Bells Eccentric Café, 31/viii/13. Upfront Malt fruitiness of figs and nuts on a viennese coffee underbelly, with a rum-raisin woody aftertaste. Smooth and complex: ABV serves aroma, assertive, astringent dryhop bitterness sets in later as if timeclocked, creamy chocolate malts as it warms. Definitely the suave & obscure standout beer of the range. Would love to revisit this bottled.

12-ounce bottle cellared since 2011. Pours a deep, deep brown with a very thin layer of mocha head. Almost no lacing. Smells of chocolate, dark fruit, and alcohol. Taste of chocolate, candied fruit, raisins, and alcohol, with a hint of smoke. Absolutely phenomenal.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2014 Bottled 7/26/13. Pours black as a starless night with a lasting head.  Subdued nose of roast.  Nice creamy mouthfeel, light carbonation and with the 10.5% alcohol content well covered by the malty sweetness, hops and roast. A strong, but pleasant, aftertaste of roast and malt sweetness with that alcohol "burn". For such a "big" stout, this is exceptionally well balanced. One of the best stouts I have ever tried and this one struck me as smoother than their Kalamazoo variant.  Smooth finish with the chocolate malt asserting itself.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Bottle: Squids ink black, no light getting through, with a super dark, deep tan head that shows excellent staying power and leaves behind some great lacing. Aroma is full of rich, bittersweet dark chocolates, highly roasted malts and barley, caramel, lightly sweet black licorice, a good bashing of some dark fruits, and a bit of balancing, back-end hops. Taste is great; sweet & burnt brown sugar, dark caramel, very light black licorice, sweetness in the form of over-ripe dates & figs, roasted cocoa beans, bitter espresso & coffee... bitter, creamy, lightly milky, thick. The ashy, leafy hop profile asserts itself nicely and plays well with the malt. Super thick mouth feel, huge body. Such an awesome stout. And whats even more is that its available and local.

Draught at the Bells Eccentric Café, Kalamazoo, MI.
Black colour with a small brown head. 
Absolutely balanced aroma of oatmeal, malt, mild sweetness and mild hops. Roasted malt, hops, grain, mild bitterness and liquorice in the flavour. Superb! All 10.5% very well hidden. Absolutely great brew!

Pours headless into rich black with a finger deep brown sugar head - like an espresso. Some lacing even. First whiff was cocoa flower and then a touch of cinnamon/ malt. Taste is very rich with cinnamon and even floral notes giving way to roasted malt, just-burnt coffee and baked chocolate with just the right amount of bitter hop balance. The booze is there, but complementary. This is like drinking chocolate rum cake. The flavors are diverse and yet all blend so well that even the aftertaste is pleasurable. This beer has to be in the conversation among the world's best stouts.
