Pours a thick, dark, opaque brown. Crisp, clean aroma with notes of citrus. Taste is excellent, initially sour that quickly dissipates to a smooth caramel finish. Finishes with a light flavor of dark chocolate and coffee.
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Simply amazing beer. Aroma is not as prevalent as I would have liked but still good. Kind of creamy, has a coffee and dark chocolate taste. Amazing beer.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, trade with pandableh (thank you!), savoured on October 3 2013; eye: black, opaque, tiny sheet of dark brown head that turns into a tiny ring, light lacing; nose: roasted barley, soy sauce, dark chocolate, light burnt barley, molasses, slight alcohol, intense, coffee; mouth: roasted barley, dark chocolate, black coffee, light burnt barley, soy sauce, molasses, alcohol, pepper, light alcohol warmth, light caramel, finale in roasted barley with presence of alcohol, slightly below-average carbonation, slightly bitter, slightly sweet, lightly alcoholic texture; overall: really good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 355 ml, 10,5 %, échange avec pandableh (thank you!), savourée le 3 octobre 2013; il : noire, opaque, petite couverture de mousse brun foncé qui se transforme en un minuscule anneau, légère dentelle; nez : orge torréfiée, sauce soya, chocolat noir, léger orge brûlée, mélasse, très léger alcool, intense, café; bouche : orge torréfiée, chocolat noir, café noir, léger orge brûlée, sauce soya, mélasse, alcool, poivre, léger chaleur dalcool, léger caramel, finale en orge torréfiée avec présence dalcool, corsée, carbonatation un peu sous la moyenne, très légèrement amère, très légèrement sucrée, texture légèrement alcoolique; en résumé : très bonne
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2014 A very solid stout by Bells. Nice dark head and creamy finish. A definite go to stout for Bells.

(3/26/13) Pour - A deep black brown with a finger of creamy mocha head. Pour it in a cappuccino cup and I would think I was having a cappuccino.

Nose - Tons of malty sweetness. Both bakers and milk chocolate. Roastiness. There are some notes of wood too. Its like booze soaked chocolate cake.

Taste - Again, lots of malty sweetness. Dark chocolate bitterness. Coffee roast and espresso. A bit of roasty earthy bitterness on the finish. Complex and subtle.

Mouthfeel - Thick, creamy, and silky.

Overall - Elegant is the word that comes to mind when I describe this. The aromas and flavors are subtle and play off of one another. This brew (with 4 months on it) was not nearly as in your face as other Russian imperials, and much sweeter as well. I had the same feel drinking this as I do when I have dessert at a good restaurant.

From a bottle into a tulip, this beer looks amazingly velvety thick and dark. Smells very nice of chocolate, malty, vanilla, almost banana hoppy craziness. Very interesting imperial stout. The taste is pretty much the same and can really catch the hops in this one. Really enjoy this stout, and glad I saved one for a little because it was even better I thought after about 6 months.
Love how it pours so dark this is a very well done stout done again by the bells. Lookin to try it again soon

I do want to try this one again. This was poured a dark black, with very little head. Got a lot of malt taste to mix in with the chocolate and coffee. There was a sweetness in it that hinted at vanilla (but might be incorrect on that). There is a bit of hop bitterness to it. It made it more complex than I was originally thinking. I think if I started with this beer, it might be rated higher, so am anxious to try it again. It was full bodied. Definitely a sipping stout, which I quite enjoyed.

2012 bottle from deekyn - cheers Dustin my friend! Black pour, big tan head - looks brooding. Wonderful chocolate, coffee, light vanilla and deep roasted malt on the nose. Full bodied chocolate, deep dark fruit, coffee, earthy hop bitterness, light vanilla, light blackberry in the taste. Wow. What a cracker. Such balance. Lingering dark fruit and chocolate notes with a decent degree of hop bite. Pure quality. Up there with the best beers Ive had. Top stuff.

Good stout. The alcohol is a little too prevalent in both aroma and taste in my opinion. I have had better but I definitely have had worse. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours black with thin tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee,bitter chocolate and some oak and woody notes. Taste is big bold coffee, bitterness, charred wood, burnt malts. Full bodied, creamy beer with good carbonation. Great stout!

From a bottle at least 7 years old...poured in a Chimay chalice.
Pours black with small brown head...slight lace.
Aroma of dark roasted malts, powder sugar, dark chocolate.
Modest carbonation and significant mouthfeel.
Flavors of dark roasted malts, molasses, burnt malts, raisins, toffee, minerals. Overall for the age, this has held up wonderfully with minimal oxidation. Ill rate on the merits of the beer aged and fresh as Ive been drinking this for at least a decade and once went to the brewery...ayiee!
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 BevMo on my Michigan spree day, very good imperial stout, super dark and rich, chocolate notes, espresso, black pour, tan head, wow.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2013  Bottle. Pours opaque black with a thin layer off toffee colored head. Aroma of roasted coffee and malts. Taste begins with roasted coffee before making way to a more chocolatey aftertaste.

Aroma: chocolate. App: black to the point of losing youself in it, no head. Taste: bitter chocolate, heavy malt. Palate: full but not chewy, very long finish. Overall: very good. Not my favorite but awesome none the less.

Very strong and dark. A little bitter but still good. Definitely a beer you sip. Not something I would drink more than one at a time. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Probably one of the finer stouts that I have had in a while. Dark, thick, and delicious.

Very good and different. The aroma was sweet, and like burnt caramel with roasted malt. The color was black with a barely there dark tan head. The palate was heavy and thick. I would like to know what the OG was as this was almost syrupy. Carbonation good. Definitely a sipper with caramelized malts and sugars, roasted grains, licorice, spice and alcohol. Good and strong.

Pours jet black with nice 1 finger tight tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Sweet malt taste upfront followed by hints of chocolate and char. Perfect bitter finish to balance. Nice medium mouthfeel with good carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2014 Bottle at home in Salisbury, CT - picked up at Grassroots in Jacksonville, FL. Pours black, oily, with a thick, tight mocha cream head. The aroma has charred malts, baking cocoa, burnt wood, big roast, milk chocolate. Medium to big sweet flavor with balancing robust bitterness, more char, some molasses, dried dark fruits, raisins, well roasted malts, bitter chocolate. Full bodied with fine, creamy carbonation. Modest warmth to finish, lots of bitter cocoa, strong roast, a bit more molasses, burnt marshmallows. Very solid. (September 2013)

Uppskattas vara ca 1år. Doftar inte så mycket. (För kall?) sträv men oerhört bra. Får direkt en flash till courage russian imperial stout. Vore kul att dra parallellt nån gång. Just nu drar vi den mot hunahpus (ej fat). Kul att äntligen få testa denna raritet. Tack Lenner

Pours black with a finger tan head. 

Smell strong chocolate and roast barley.

Taste strong ashy, vanilla, cream, rich red fruit, almost smokey on the tail. 

Pretty full bodied. Good.

Bottle from Wine Warehouse. The pours deep brown with a thick tan head. The aromas chocolate syrup, mild coffee, toasted cinnamon bread. Nice earthy sweetness. The taste is moderately bitter. Dirty hops. Rich roasted malts. Bitter dark chocolate. Pain au chocolate. Supple, smooth. Oily body, soft carbonation. Overall, really tasty.

Very dark, near black. Good flavor, not going to knock your socks off but I'd buy again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black, finger thick khaki head nice lacing. Aroma roast malt, dark fruits, burnt caramel, anise, molasse, slight alcohol. Tast extremely complex, roast malt, anise, alcohol up front, molasses, burnt caramel, roast and black malt and alcohol mid mouth, slight bitter, molasses and dark fruit finish. Mouth feel is thick and rich, alcohol heat, little carbonation, sweeter finish. Overall very good, definitely on the roast and molasses side, not chocolate and coffee, good change of pace.

@Akkurat: vilken fantastisk komplex doft av kaffe, choklad, nötter, russin och arrak. Smaken är helt fantastisk underbar med fin balans stor fyllighet, vinös och med en lite nötig och lång eftersmak. Herregud va gott!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (bottled 12/27/2012)

Aroma: Dark chocolate, alcohol

Appearance: Oily black with a small, foamy, cocoa colored head

Taste: Black licorice, bitter chocolate

Palate: Heavy body, filling mouthfeel. Alcohol burn on the tongue. 

Overall: Big, complex beer. I can imagine that this would age terrifically, and the lack of any intense bitterness makes this a great sipper. Definitely going to get a few of these this year and cellar them away.

Bottle, huge thanks to GT2. Pours jet black with a brownish head. Aroma of molasses, chocolate, some coffee notes, roasted malt, some dark berries and some floral notes. Flavor is sweet roasted malt with some caramel, grains, coffee, warning alcohol and brown sugar. Full body, average carbonation.

Bottle 355ml @ Hotel Room, Holiday Inn Express, Escondido, CA
[Courtesey of GT2] Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice, alcohol with hints of dried fruits and coffee. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, roasted, licorice and bitter finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle from tom10101, thanks a lot Tommy! Bottled in 2011. Aroma is really really nice, with licorice and roasted malt dominating. It evens feels barrel aged to some extent. Taste is also quite impressive with a good sweetness balanced out by an agressive coffee/burnt grain presence. Some alcohol is felt but it is not out of place. Mouthfeel is full, silky. One of the better ones for sure!
Motor oil black and murky. No head to speak of. Smells of coffee toffee and smoke. Deep dark malty flavor with vanilla and caramel yielding to smoke and on the finish. This is quite nice.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2014 wow first time. shared a bottle. pours a deep black color with a verry small head. aroma is a lot of roasted malts, bit of smoke, vanilla and coffee. taste is malts and coffee. small sweetness, small chocolate taste. some alcohol to. overall this is a fantastic stout. if anyone can hook me up with this please contact me
Holy cow. This was fantastic. Very roasty. Burnt toast and coffee. Just wonderful.

2011 vintage poured from the bottle. Pours jet black with very little head. Head is tan once swirled around in glass. Nose is dark chocolate and roast with a hint of coffee. Taste is very earthy and chocolatey with a bitter finish.

12 oz bottle from total wine. Pours pitch black with tan head, two finger pour. Aroma is heavy coffee and chocolate. Creamy buttery texture and coffee flavors dominate. Backside is surprisingly bitter. An amazing imperial stout, not the first time Ive had so this review could be a little biased!!

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Pours black as sin with a brown, cappuccino-like, foamy head that slowly reduces to a thick ring around the sides. Copious sticky lacing. Aroma is dark toasted malts, molasses, burnt marshmallow, and subtle hints of licorice and booze. Taste is lusciously bitter dark chocolate on a backdrop of dark toasted malty sweetness. Palate is rich and creamy. Full bodied brew with an aftertaste like the finish on a cup of Kahlua-spiked hot cocoa. This is one of the best stouts Iâve had. Delicious!

Jet black pour with a tan head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate, and some anise notes coming through as well. Big roasty flavors come through with the first sip followed by coffee and anise notes in the finish. Abv is well hidden too. Id be interested to see how this would evolve after a few years in the cellar. Solid brew.

Bottle with Ben on the meadows. Cheers Benh. This was something else. Pours black with a dark brown head. Aroma is intensely stouty. Coffee, chocolate and burnt toast. The flavour has notes of burnt sugar, raisins, coffee, liquorice and bags of chocolate. Sizeable bitterness to finish. Thick and extremely full bodied, this beer definitly deserves its seat at the table. Sublime stuff.
On draft. Pours thick and black with a creamy coffee head. Heavy and dark. Smoky flavor with coffee. Lots of dark malt and hops. Very intense.
12 oz bottle and draft. Huge imperial stout with tons of coffee and chocolate. Darkness Darkness oh delicious Darkness!
'11 Bottle from Peter, thanks! Pours black with nice brown head. Aroma is rich roast, chocolate, licorice. Taste is massive roasted bitterness, with a smooth finish, awesome stout!

Bottle. Big thanks to Mike for this one. Black with tan head. Rich aroma of coffee, licorice and chocolate. Taste is intense, heavy roasted, licorice, coffee and dark chocolate. All flavours balanced perfectly. Thick heavy and sweet with a long licorice and chocolate finish, some bitterness. Exceptional beer

Poured from the bottle. Color is deep black with just a small head. Aroma is roast, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is strong coffee and dark chocolate. This is good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is my favorite stout, hands down. I probably won't be giving many beers a 5 star review, but every time I see a sixer of this, I have to pick it up. It is so complex, yet balanced, and I appreciate that it isn't Bourbon Barrel Aged. Expedition blows Black Note out of the water. 

--via Beer Buddy from my iPhone.

12 oz bottle aged 9 mth. Aromas are raisin, cherry, molasses and chocolate with some earthiness. Pours viscous black with ruby highlights and 1" khaki head that laces nicely. Smooth, creamy full bodied that is about perfect in my opinion. Flavors follow the sweetness of the aromas, fruity and a hint of milk chocolate, but finishes with notes of pepper, vanilla, and some hoppy bitterness. some alcohol heat is noticable as well. Excellent imperial stout and Ill pick a few more when I find it again.

This brewery seems to only produce great beer. This stout is BIG! It is a high alcohol imperial with a bunch of hops. I have had it twice and recommend aging it a little before opening. The first time I tasted it was right off the shelf and it overwhelmed my palette and head. The second time was with a friend who had been holding on to a bottle and it was so smooth and a totally different taste. Great stuff!
Extremely well balanced stout and very smooth for such a big beer. This is the best stout Ive ever had.
Bottle from Bells in Kzoo. Poured oily black with a nice tan head. Aromas of slightly boozy choc and resin. Taste is moderately bitter dark chocolate but quite smooth.

I really enjoyed this brew along side a KBS tasting with some 90% dark chocolate. What stood out about this stout was its strong hop punch! I tasted the chocolate and coffee, but my palate kept going back to the hops. Overall, I loved it and was honored to be drinking 2 top 20s in the world.

Bottle poured a deep dark brown w/ a huge dark tan mostly diminishing frothy head w/ excellent lacing. Big aromas of molasses, roasted marshmallow, floral hop and roasted malts. Initial flavor is a heavy sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish. Tastes are molasses, dark chocolate, coffee, orange, raisin, prune, roast, vanilla, licorice, soy, and toast. Full bodied, soft carbonation, oily mouthfeel, and moderate alcoholic finish.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Josh Clauss. Thanks Man! 2011 vintage. Pour is pitch black with a frothy brown head and good lacing. Figgy, roasty, pruney, earthy, lightly spicy, dark cocoa, dark fruity, light cardboard, caramelly aroma. Taste is rich dark chocolate, big coffee, toffee, raisins, figs, somewhat woody, dark fruits, prunes, and brown sugar. Slick/syrupy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Rich decadent, and super smooth for such a high ABV and great chocolatey aftertaste. This one ages gracefully.
Bottle at zombie burger ..boys night...pitch black pour.. big brown head... crazy arona of alcojol and cocoa ..taste is similar...good beer to close out the night with.. strong and freaking delicious
Whoa. Strong but smooth flavor. Cocoa and coffee prominent. Bitter bite up front, smooth finish with almost no bite. One of the better stouts I've had.

Love that this is in the regular lineup!  Pours a dark black with medium tan head and good lacing.  Aromas of serious roasted goodness with hints of chocolate, toast, and toffee.  Flavors of pure roasted goodness.

Bottle to Tulip snifter. Dark black pour with a beautiful red brown head that is thick up front and recedes quickly. Nose is sweet dark chocolate and coffee. Thick chewy mouth feel, coats the side of the glass and hits the palate strong with with dark fudge, dark fig, roasted malt and coffee. Quite the stout for sure.

(Bottled, 2011 vintage, thanks 50belair) Almost black with a small, firm and brown head. Aroma of thick and syrupy, roasted malt, molasses, a touch of oatmeal sourness. Flavor is roasted-malty, sweetish and syrupy, but balanced with loads of hop bitterness. Hides the ABV nicely. Quite full body, leaving sticky lips behind, lowish but slightly fizzy CO2. A quite clean and balanced, but straightforward Imperial Stout. Like a regular stout from which water is removed by freezing; that "something extra" youd expect from a Ratebeers #11 beer is missing. 6648

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 The 2011 batch from the tap of Beverage World, this brew pours dark reddish brown black with a big tan head. Aromas and flavours of molasses cookies, spicy ginger snaps, cinnamon, bitter chocolate, coffee, hints of wet straw, soy sauce, grass, & vanilla. Full bodied, rich palate combines with dry, crisp, smoky roasted finish. Truly outstanding!
Truly remarkable.  The golden copper foam on top makes you delerious.  An imperial without the harsh alcohol finish.  I love this.

All I can say is WOW. Some beers you hear so mu hype that once you try it you end up scratching your head. Not this one. Bottle from friends in the North. THANK YOU! Poured into a traditional English style pint glass. Thick caramel head and a very black, opaque pour. Very think to even the eye. The aroma was strong with coffee, chocolate, cocoa and roasted malts. The taste was very complex with coffee dominant, roasted malts, alcohol (booze taste), and dark chocolate. Mouth was very thick, yet smooth and silky. It was drinking a great chocolate malt shake with booze.
Great dark brown color without much head. Some coffee grinds and roast malt/hop prominent in the nose. A very thick beer with great texture. Definitely a winner. Glad to have finally found this one.

The fact that this is semi regularly available with wide distribution at a great price makes this a true winner for me. Very refined and blanced as I have noticed seems to be the trend with Bells. Soy sauce and creamy bourbon vanilla vie for attention in the mouth and up the nostrils. Medium bodied with a excellent carbonation level. Rich and dessert like. Fantastic. Glad I have three bottles for the cellar. RERATE. Now I have tried this fresh, with a year on it and three years on it I can attest to the incredible cellarbility of this beer. It gets fuller and more pungent, creating an amazing sipping beer. Huge.

12oz bottle from steve
Been waiting a long time to try this one
And it was worth the wait
Pours a pitch black with a huge frothy beige head lots of clingys
Weird it smells like marmite and malt and i like marmite :)
Thick and creamy sweet malt  very good and worth the wait
I got a lot of leather taste.  Not my favorite, but not bad.  Would love to try this aged.

Amazing beer. Everything comes together in perfection with this imperial stout. Creamy texture - not too syrupy - great head and lacing, black pour. Aroma of pungent roast malt and hops, dark chocolate and light coffee in perfect balance. A little booze but very well hidden, as well as some spiciness in finish. Taste is bittersweet like great chocolate. All of this and its super cheap and ubiquitous compared to other beers. I feel like my entire ratebeer career has been waiting for a beer thats this good, cheap and available at the same time. Bottle, one-year aged thanks to GT2.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head.  Chocolate and malt aroma.  Chocolate, malt, coffee flavor.

Pours black into the glass with a tan head that is beautiful to watch as it slowly fades leaving nice lacing. Aromas are roast and chocolate with some caramel like sugar hints and touch of leather. Flavors are big roast, creamy cocoa, some booze, bittersweet chocolate and just a touch of coffee. The palate is so thick, rich and strong it coats the palate perfectly. Overall this is an amazing beer, great example of the style and wonderful that its available in 12 ounce form when a lot of similar beers only come in 22 ounce bottles. Get it if you can find it.

A: looks good. carbonation is thick and creamy. Looks like ice cream. mmm ice cream.
S: A little boozy. A little creamy. A little chocolate. Alcohol comes through a bit more than other things. 
T: A little acidic. Nice chocolaty. Malty. Smooth. Boozy. I mean... a nice stout but nothing crazy.
P: Smooth but a little acidic.
Overall this is a very nice beer. Lots of good characteristics but the acidity cuts through to where its thought to enjoy. Creamy mouthfeel though. Definitely worth checking out.

Bottle from International trade; dark brown pour with velvety tan head, milk chocolate and coffee aroma, glorious chocolate and coffee taste, roast malts, slick mouthfeel, vanilla liquorice real full bodied complex meaty stout.

Wow, this is so badass! Tastes like dark chocolate truffle with plum filling that has been covered in espresso, toffee, and bourbon.  It is hopped perfectly so as to give it complexity and bite but not enough to throw off the balance.  The only thing that keeps me from giving a perfect rating is the whole soy sauce thing, its definately there and I dont think its a plus.  If you like big take no prisoners imperial stouts this has got to be got...

Maybe the best looking pour on an imperial stout Ive ever seen. Opaque pitch black with a large fluffy brown head that doesnt die down. Huge toasted malt nose, lots of dark earthy chocolate notes, subtle coffee, caramel, a bit of raisins and a little boozy. Taste is massive bitter chocolate, caramel, dark fruit, dark coffee and a hint of alcohol. Full bodied, supberb balance, absolutely delicious.
Excellent malt character. Fantastic take on a traditional stout. Love the malt and balance of hops. Great, drinkable stout.

Bottle 2011 Vintage - Soy sauce, sweet oak and some vanilla.  Jet black with a very thin brown ring.  Sweet, oaky and some light bitter chocolate.  Nice if you like the soy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Roast and molasses in the nose with notes of coffee and dark bitter chocolate.  Black with a tan syrupy head.  Bittersweet like quality dark chocolate with strong notes of espresso and roast malt.  Full bodied and slightly oily with a thick bittersweet finish.  A true champion of the style.
Pours almost black with very thin head. Aroma of malts, raisons, chocolate, molasses, and caramel. Hops come through on the end. Great imperial stout.  Larry Bell...kudos again.

Pours oil can black with a several fingers of khaki head.  The aroma is sweet dark fruit and a hint of vanilla.  The taste is dark chocolate and coffee.  You can also get a bit of sweetness on the back end.  It is really a tasty stout.  The mouth feel is a thick creamy treat.  I have three of these I am going to drink and 3 I am going to age.  I will try one of the three for the next three years and see how it changes.

Pours black and has a finger and a half length, tan head that dissipates slowly into nothingness.  Aroma is so strong with alcohol.  There is also this awful toffee and vanilla that doesnt work at all.  In the background, there is this dark chocolate that seems to remind me of the 1st bottle of this 6-pack I had 6 months ago.  The mouth is fantastic at this point though.  Velvety and smooth, and dark chocolate in the back of the mouth that lingers for quite a while.  I had one of these too soon, and will probably re-review this 6 months later when I have another bottle.
From a bottle. Pours opaque dark brown with thin tan head. Tastes like coffee, chocolate, caramel, raisins. Very sweet. Smells like sweet, dried fruit. Medium body and medium carbonation.

Aroma: honey and molasses hit the nose in the bottle and in the snifter; almost reminiscient of bbq sauce with a little soy sauce. Appearance: Gorgeous motor oil; creamy, khaki head and well-balanced lacing. Head retention is decent to good. Taste: tangy honey gives way to sweet molasses and finishes on a boozey note. Not as rich and roasty as I remember my last glass, but that may be because I poured at 55 degrees Fahrenheit. Going to let it warm up a bit. Palate: A light syrup; washes down reasonably well, but pretty thick. 

Outstanding beer, and I can definitely see why the barrel aged Black Note I had was so amazing: this is an excellent starting point.

12 oz. Bottle from Edina Liquor served at just below room temp.  Pours a dark brown/black color. Thick looking but smooth. Minimal head upon emptying contents into glass.  Hints of chocolate and nuttyness are strongly apparent with some caramel like aftertaste.  Has a coffee like aroma.  Moderately carbonated. Just the right amount of alcohol in my opinion for this type of stout.  At 10.5% you can tell that its there but it doesnt overpower the taste.  One of the best stouts Ive tried to date.

Dark, thick, black pour with a nice tan head, tan lacing. 2012 vintage. Man this is a nice beer! Sweet, roasted malt and chocolate on the nose and again in the taste. There is some nice hops backbone here to help balance out the thickness and sweetness of this beer. Excellent.

First time having this! MIke in MI sent it to me. 12oz fresh batch, 2 finger head, oily black pour. nose is fantastic. everything youd expect in a stout. bitter hoppy at the start, middle is choclate and caramel. oaky finish. sweet and drinkable like hopped chocolate milk! I could drink this every day.

Aroma is a big killer of this beer.  Smell is very very faint malt to vanilla barrel.  Appearance is a head that mildly lingers and fades.  Taste is sweet to sweet.  Not blanced.  Taste is sweet vanilla not stout like at all.  meh an average beer, there are much better imperial stouts with lower reviews.  Nice creamy texture on the palate however.
Delicious! These tend to be over the top in alcohol and/or sweetness, but this is relatively balanced. Creamy, caramel, chocolate, not boozy or overly bitter.

Pours black and viscous. Head is tan and creamy, but not very long lived. Roasty and sweet malty aroma. Some over-ripe banana notes as well. Hints of cocoa and vanilla. Taste is heavy roast, sweet malts, liquorice and chocolate. Alcolhol is present but not overwhelming in any way. Full bodied and oily.

Bottle, shared with Bergen Beer Geek Tasting Crew. Pours a oily black body with a small off-white head. Nose is dark chocolate, candi sugary sweet malt notes, licorice, unripe banana, leather, hints of alcohol and soy sauce. Taste is licorice, leather, dark chocolate, coffee, sweet malts and hints of unripe banana and wood. Smooth silky body, soft carbonation. Very nice and smooth imperial stout with good taste integration. Perhaps not quite worthy of the score, but still a damn fine beer.

Backlog. Bells Expedition Stout is exactly what people all over the world rate it as...a World Class Imperial Stout.

Ive enjoyed bottles of it the for the past 5+ years, and it is one of the most consistent Imperial Stouts.

Raisin/licorice aroma taste. Vanilla and caramel on the finish. Fantastic beer.

Bottle pours a deep dark cola with a medium tan head and notable lacing.  Aroma is initially big dark chocolate and slight booziness followed by licorice and dark fruits. Taste begins with enjoyable blend of  bakers chocolate and dark fruit followed by hints of espresso and licorice leading to a silky finish.  Big, slightly sticky mouthfeel with flavors lingering.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2016 Ive blown through 2 sixers in the last month, and a third will fall soon. It deserves a bump from 4.5 to 4.6, because it deserves to be at the top spot. I love the hell out of this beer.
 Blind RIS experiment [Sample 13 of 20, 4/28/2015] 
 Fresh bottle (2014)
Poured by Summer. Dark brown, with ample light brown head (1 finger or so); dissipates to a ring, some lacing splotches. Aroma: mmm, this smells good. Rich thick chocolate syrup. Roast bordering on smoke and ash. Taste: Sweet, chocolate balanced with roast. Cookie/biscuit going on, giving this nice chocolate-covered cookie dough with graham cracker base. Palate: silky, sexy velvety smooth. Full body. Definitely potent -- Id guess this could go even northward of 11%. Overall: This is great. So much better than anything Ive had so far.
 
Guess: Evil Twin or maybe 10 Fiddy -- not getting the metal that usually ruins 10.5 for me, and loads of roasty smoky stuff, so Im guessing ET? Im kind of praying that this is Expedition, though, since I remember this level of excitement from that beer my first time.
 
Would pay: $5 / bottle no problem. I hope this is a shelfy. 
RB rating: 9/4/9/5/17. 
------- /> 
Blind RIS experiment [Sample 7 of 20, 4/11/2015]
 Aged bottle (4+ years)
Poured by Summer. Near black pour with deep brown head, dissipates in short order to a ring. Aroma: this smells old, so Im pretty sure its the Expo I put in the mix (only aged bottle). The oldest bottle of this Ive had, though, so thats a fun treat and new experience. Anyway: oxidation is present, and works well -- the aged hops/oxidation lends a deep dark fruit quality. Roast is subdued.
 
In the mouth: ooh, this is nice. Very flavorful, with lots of chocolate, brown sugar, molasses, dark fruit, pleasant subdued roast. Its all very mellow, though -- it gels. My hypothesis is that this "mellow, subdued, muted with combo of nice sweetness and quiet dry, oxidized finish" is due to the aging. If it is in fact Expy then Ill have a chance to see how I like the fresh bottle. Full body, oily texture, average carbonation.
 
Overall: IMO, this is probably a testament to a well-made beer that has aged well. Many dont. This one has. (Of course, it will be hilarious if I find out later this is not an old beer at all, in which case we can all just laugh at me.)
 
RB rating: 8/4/9/4/16 
Would pay: up to $5 / bottle without much hesitation as a "once in awhile" beer. $4/bottle as a regular thing.

Addendum: Even though its lovely, something about 12 oz of old beer isnt nearly as nice as 6 oz of old beer. I should remember this before I try any more aging experiments ... keep doing them, but be sure I have people with whom to share :).
-------- /> 
(2/23/2015) Ive had this several time since this first rating. My first rating should not be forgotten - as a "high water mark," as Carl sometimes puts it, 4.7 is where this belongs. At its best, this beer is magical. At it worst, its still great. Re-rates (both blind and sighted) have ranged from 3.9 (low) to 4.2-4.3 (more typical), but never quite so high as the first time. Still hands down my favorite imperial stout.
-------- /> 
(3/29/2013) Bottle brought by my brother. Aroma: sexy. Sexy as hell. Aroma of chocolate, bourbon, roast. Pours viscous black, motor oil with minimal mocha tan head. Dont even want to drink it Im too busy looking and smelling. Taste is roast, chocolate, beautifully integrated booze, smoky, just the right amount of coffee bitterness coming through lingering nicely in the long, luxurious finish. Silkily viscous texture, soft carbonation and full body. Overall: love this. Absolutely love this. 9/5/9/5/19.

I did not like this beer & will not buy it again.  I couldnt put my finger on it, but while I was drinking this, all I could think about was - theres too much...  (but I couldnt describe what there was too much of).  Then I read it on here... 5 times the hops of their other stout.  Enough said.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2015 Re rate: On tap at bells, complex aroma with chocolate,  malts, hops and some heat. A similar flavor! Really good!
Bottle in trade with joromiller. Pours jet black with no head. Nose of roast, chocolate. Taste is sweet with the same elements in the nose. Body is super silky.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter. Pours a jet black with good 2 finger mocha head and good lacing. Smells of roasted malts, cocoa, bit of day old coffee and a little booze. Taste is very rich... Cocoa up front, bit of coffee, and some hop bitterness. A bit of a sticky mouthfeel. Great stout.

If I had to compare this I would say it tastes like wake up dead but lacks the caramel notes.   Without the sweet caramel notes this beer tastes a bit too strong and having more than one glass feels like too much.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle. Pours a thick black with 2 fingers of mocha head. Aromas of toffee, chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Taste is rich espresso, followed by chocolate, toffee, and vanilla. This is a delicious beer!

Pours black with frothy tan head. Roasted grainy smells with some sweetness. Super smooth for as grainy as it is. Lightly creamy with a sweetness and red berries and grapes. Smooth light hearted roasted grainy finish with some bittering dark chocolate lingering. Exceptional brew.

Pours a nighttime brown, Thick caramel brown head. I smell chocolate, roasts, and hops. Despite the hop bitterness at the end it still seems to keep a smooth characteristic about it. The chocolate and roasted coffee taste begin the taste buds with a rather creamy sweet taste then they hops come in to give it a satisfying zing. Another dime from Bells.
Great beer. Nice balance. Malts and bitter chocolate and roasty taste. overall great beer.

A fantastic stout. Soft on the lips and then full bodied. If you had one stout to drink this would be it.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2014 Vintage 10/2/12. Rated 3/7/13. Deep dark black with quickly dissipating dark brown head, leaving a small amount for the remainder and some drippy lace. Aroma is chocolaty, milk and dark chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits. First sip..wow. Thick, full, sticky. Complex. Waves of character. Difficult to take it all in - the glass seems to empty before you can.Chocolate, spices, smokey, woody, coffee, roasted malt, hops, dark fruit. Melts in your mouth. Balanced sweetness and bitterness. Woody finale. ------ update ------ 6/20/14. Aged over 1.5 years. Still a beautiful beer. Rich chocolate and roast aroma. A little dry. Less fruitiness. Still a luscious full body. Amazing complex roast and chocolate, coffee. Fantastic! Dont really find any fruitiness or hops anymore. Majestic roasty finish.

hints of malt, chocolate, cream,  a  unique freshness
 
chocolate malt to bitter sweetness.
varying hints of roasted wood.
Tastes- Malty and bitter mixed with coffee, chocolate, wood, dark fruit. maybe vanilla

12oz Bottle A - Pours black with a one finger cocoa head. Good retention/lacing. S - Dominate soy sauce & a background of cocoa powder. T - Dark chocolate, licorice, & bitter espresso. M - Medium/full bodied. Slick texture. Mild carbonation. Long bitter chocolate finish. O - Delightful once I got past the smell of soy sauce.
Liked the Plead the 5th imperial stout more - it seems more balanced than the the expedition stout. It's maybe too sweet for it's kind.

2010 bottle from Pawel. Batch 10105. Thanks!

A; Black and lightless as a brick. Very dark mocha head that settles in at about an inch. Looks like motor oil. 

N: Roasted malt, green hops, dark chocolate, dark cherry, prune. Has a pronounced dark fruit sweetness, particularly that of raisins. Lots of raisins. Truly a smell of dried grapes.

T: Deep rushes of dark chocolate. Leather and bark. Cedar, tobacco, raisins. Smoke and roast. Hops lend an earthy backbone with some leafy hints. Coffee overtones. Superb, and reminiscent of HotD Adam of all things.

M: Thick, coating, yet somehow, supremely drinkable.

O: This is just sublime. Really wise to store it for the extended aging and very much worthy of the high score. Might be my favorite non-BA stout.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2015 Thanks to Dad for this. Very lovely stout. Coffee, bitter chocolate and boozy dried fruits. Smooth with a brown foam head. Serving: Bottle
Excellent taste with a rich, smooth taste to it. Good taste from the begging to end.....

Rated from notes on 3/1/13.......A: notable sweetness, rather bready......A: pitch black, tan head that grows after the pour to an inch or so.......T: sweet, bitter chocolate, roast coffee and licorice...so smooth for 10.5..........P: full bodied, chewy, bitter in all the right places..........O: great beer....this is why Bells is Bells...if you set the bar you become the bar setter.

Very dark thick pour with slight coffee head micro bubbles that have to be coaxed. 

Delicious chocolate aroma with light floral bouquet. 

Sweet and coating. Mild bittering after taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Roasty, caramely malts; sweet and biscuity. Mildly oxidized nose. More hoppy than I remembered, and it works quite well atop the rich stout base. Exp Stout remains one of the very best off-the-shelf RISes.

I think this might be my favorite Imperial Stout.  Pitch black, nice head retention and lacing.  Tastes of milk chocolate, coffee, piney resin, toffee/caramel. Almost tastes like a cafe con leche made with the worlds most overroasted espresso...but in a good way.  Sticky body, but not overly sticky.  Its not going to stain your glass like a Hunahpus or Dark Lord, but that just adds to its drinkability...

The thing that sets this Imperial Stout apart from the other heavy hitters is the drinkability.  Its heavy, but I could drink enough to get me into trouble.  If someone wanted the perfect example of an American Imperial Stout, this is probably what Id hand them.

A superior Imperial stout, comparable to stones. Dark head great aroma w/ hints of caramel & toffee. Slightly bitter entry, malty & coffee aftertaste. Look forward to putting this in the cellar....

Dark brown. Finger-width caramel head; quickly dissipates. Malty, espresso smell. Very malty taste, slight chocolate finish. Low carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. Great beer!

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2013 2009, 2012, 2013 Vertical

A black body is capped by a 1.5" tight dark khaki head displaying decent retention and solid spatters of clinging lace all around

Batch 12314 bottled 09/19/13
Eloquent, creamy, cascading layers of treacle, chocolate, licorice, dark caramel, and pie crust with accents of piney-citrusy hops, figs, smoke, and brown sugar on a heavy, coating palate finishing with a focus on the chocolatey pie crust notes merging into a drying, spicy, softly warming finish

Batch 11503 bottled 10/22/12
Aromas of mocha ice cream with a splash of blueberry, flavors offer a flash of the acidic, lemony, woody notes set to develop, then wonderful, rich dark chocolate notes, fig and raisin, plumb and dark berry nuances come into play with faint vinous accents, as residuals build, the dark sweet treacle notes appear, prefacing black licorice and cola, sweet with a more acidic cutting bitterness which creates a sharper, less elaborate finish, really nice with some interesting developments in year one

Batch 9435 bottled 11/11/2009
Yikes, this batch comes off acidic and shallow at this age, wafting some muddled brown notes reminiscent of dehydrated cow patty and leather, there are a few transitional notes of chocolate cherry and an overlay of woody espresso like roast, but this is generally unimpressive and unenjoyable, based on reputation, this one must be in a funk, hopefully trending towards something sweeter in a couple years, this acidic, shallow state seems to be par for the course on 3-4 year aged American imperial stouts, had very similar results from Yeti and Founders, well see what happens with the other bottles from this batch in a few years

12oz bottles served at 55º into 16oz Spiegelau Soiree brandy snifter

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 Full, complex, succullent flavors. A creamed coffee colored head that stays a while and lends plenty of lacing. A pungent, almost fruity aroma. The malts are roasted dark... very dark. Initial flavor is reminiscent of dates, steak grilled with burnt edges, sumatra coffee, burnt caramel... a slight sweetness initially, dissipates into a deep bitter finish. Sticky mouth feel. The aftertaste lingers a bit longer than desired and reminds of toast that has been in the toaster too long. A bit over roasted and hopped in my opinion but still a good brew.

nearly black porn with a mocha head. aroma is sweet with malt coffee and chocolate.taste is similar to aroma but the malt seems roasted. this is nearly a desert.Revised: initial rating was to high. By the end of twelve ounces,  it became to bitter. Still good, but not the perfect first impression it gave me.
Aroma of roast, chocolate, molasses. Appearance is black with ample light brown head. Taste is super roasty with coffee and bitter chocolate. Big sticky mouthfeel. Definite classic.

Super dark and thick. Chewable. Nice slick mouthfeel that turns super astringent. I almost wanted a drink of water halfway through. Milk chocolate flavor that turns dark and espressoy.

12oz flaska. Svart, lätt trögflyrande vätska med ett brunt tjockt skum. Komplex doft av choklad malt, lätt rostade toner. Ckoklad, kaffebönor, lite lakrits och aska tillsammans med en inte påträngande humlebeska. Fantastiskt balanserad både med tanke på humleinnehåll och alkoholhalt.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2013 12oz bottle. Pours black with a think tan head. Aroma is malt, chocolate and a slight hoppiness which is fairly appealing. Taste follows the aroma. Strong malt/slightly bitter presence with a hop finish. The bitterness will linger for a bit in your mouth. Pretty smooth and not heavy. Dont really notice the 10.5 ABV. Quality brew all around.

12 oz bottle pouring very dark brown with a dark khaki head that dissipates quickly. Rich aroma with heavy roasted chocolate notes. Very thick heavy mouthfeel. Taste is heavy in the roasted malt with chocolate and a strong coffee finish. Very good  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Drinking this is a bit of an expedition in itself. Extremely rich flavors of chocolate and coffee, pits like syrup. Even better after aging

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a snifter. Pours a very dark brown almost black, with little to no cream colored head. First whif  brings a strong mix of chocolate, roast and coffee. A slight Hoppiness to it. The sweetness of the chocolate and vanilla come into play at the front, followed by a slight hoppy bite. As it slowly moves down, the delicious roast and coffee flavors take over. The coffee mixed with a little booze remains a few minutes later. Very espresso like at the end. A full bodied beer with a very long finish. A pleasure to drink. My favorite Imperial Stout, hands down.

From notes. Had Christmas evening. Rich nose of dark, roast malts, chocolate, espresso. Strong flavors of bitter, dark chocolate, coffee, roast. A bit harsh for me and a fairly good alcohol burn. May need to cellar this for a year or two.

Pours very dark with a good creamy reddish head. Smells of coffee and chocolate with a bit of hops. Initial flavors are exactly how it smells- coffee, chocolate, and a little bit of hops. Very smooth stout. The finish is long and complex. You start with slightly bitter coffee and hints if cocoa, then it fades into citrus and floral notes with a lot of hops. It ends more like an IPA than a Stout. Excellent beer with complex flavors. I'd recommend this as often as you get a chance
Overall great stout.  It has a great roast to it that gives away to a slight coffee finish.
Extremely solid. Malty sweet, dark pour from 12oz bottle. Thin to no cream colored head.

Bottle Courtesy Camons. Creamy lightbrown excellent fully lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy wonderfull aroma. Vanilla nicely present. Heavy bitter very roasted flavor with nice coffee and vanilla notes. long heavy bitter nice finish. Creamy palate. World class brew.

Nice robust aroma of dark chocolate and boozy molasses.  Pours pitch black with a dark brown head.  Molasses taste to start with a bitter finish, coffee and dark chocolate notes as well.  Full thick body with a long finish.  Definitely a sipping beer. Awesome stout.

Another great stout by Bells.  Great full bodied beer with great aroma, pallet is a nice mouthful, finish is very good for an imperial stout (ie, good balance to avoid a harsh, bitter finish).  Expensive, but worth picking up a six pack.

12 fl oz bottle from Matt / Nekrobarr (non on ratebeer)! Sampled on January 27, 2013. Bottle marked 12/27/12.Black color, dark brown head. Sweet, malty, alcohol, grainy, some yeast scent. Fruity, peppry alcohol taste. Alcohol and "vingummin" aftertaste. Plenty of warming alcohol. Medium mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 2009 vintage - Smells excellent, chocolate, coffee, molasses and malt.  Nice caramel colored head, even the lasting bubbles are of a tan color.  Taste is exceptional -- perfect balance and ultra smooth.  Hardly taste the alcohol, heavy on the malt, coffee, molasses.  Originally rated a perfect 5.0, but on a re-rate, was not quite as impressed.
Dark as night with a small and fast dissipating tan head. Smells of coffee, hay, malt, molasses and alcohol. Tastes as it smells. Very smooth. Great beer. No words can do it justice.
Bottle. This is the heart of darkness.  A solid drinkable impy that comes in a 6 er and never lets you down.

Very dark thick pour with large mocha head. Smells of chocolate, oatmeal, cocoa, malt and some hops. Taste starts with a decent hop bite, with a sweet chocolate hop with a little roast. After taste of bitter with a ashy like taste.

Pour from a 12oz.  Pitch black with a half inch frothy tan head that settled rather quickly. Taste is roasty coffee, boozy, hops, bitter finish really hits the palate.  Nice and thick, this one is a slow sipper.  Enjoyable on a bitterly cold night.
alcohol, raisin, roasty, coffee, chocolate, caramel, minimal head, black, heavy cloying sweetness, full body, oily feel, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, bitter,

Bottle given from jredmond (thanks!!!) in NYC sept 2012. Black beer with a nice brown head. Malty, dried dark fruits, tar, nuts, chocolate, vanilla, coffee, Aroma with lovley creamy notes. Similar flavour with a really wounderfull mix of flavours. This is love in a bottle :-)

Pours jet black with thin tan head that recedes quickly.  Aroma is roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate and some dark fruits.  Taste follows suit with the addition of a little bite at the end.  Palate is thick and rich.

Bottle from the brewery. Pours a deep opaque black with a tiny bit of brown head that rings and makes intricate patters on the surface of the beer. Smell is distinctly an imperial stout, lots of malt smells, bready, figs, coffee, lots of dark fruit, and maybe a hint of brightness. Palate is thick bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. Taste is quite nice, a bit sweet at first, but then evolves into a very roasty note which spilts a bit in your mouth focusing more on a slightly bitter and yet fruity note. Aftertaste is long lasting and much like a good espresso, plus some alcohol heat you can feel a bit in your throat. Excellent example of the style!

Jet black pour with a thumbs worth of mocha head.  Aroma of Black coffee, Roasted malt, Dark bittersweet chocolate. Bitter hops up front, wood, dark chocolate, Black coffee, Dark fruit, very slight smoke.  Full body, almost syrupy mouthfeel, medium carbonation.  appropriately named - If I was planning on braving the Tundra for a week Id want a couple cases of this to see me through.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2013 Poured from 2007 12oz bottle at bells vintage tasting. Black pour with reddish hue and no noticeable head. Molasses, rich sugary malt, very rich smokiness in the scent. Oily, warm mouth feel, very viscous with low carbonation. Rich tastes of dark chocolate, molasses, dark fruits like figs, dates, etc, some ashiness and sour fruits like cherry. Smoother than an unaged bottle for sure. Bitter finish, sour and syrupy.
Huge flavor that lingers on the palate. Strong dark and handsome. Toasted malt flavor is amazing. Would drink again
Dark and slightly bitter. a true american stout.almost gritty and hits you with a ton of flavor instantly.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry ou Blankboy. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de chocolat noir, de café noir, de malt rôti aux notes fumées (fumée de bois), moyen de caramel toffee, léger dalcool doux et de mélasse ainsi quavec des notes fruitées (cerises, prunes et raisins), de réglisse noire et de houblon herbeux. Ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi quune texture très riche, crémeuse et sirupeuse. Goût fruité (cerises noires, raisins vineux, léger de prunes) aux petites notes boisées, léger de réglisse noire avec des notes de vanille ainsi que quelques traces de chocolat au lait (faibles notes lactiques) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de chocolat noir et de malt rôti (à la limite du brûlé et avec quelques faibles notes fumées), moyen de mélasse avec des notes de carmael toffee. Parallèlement, lon retrouve, et ce jusquen finale,  un goût dalcool moyen et réchauffant ainsi quune amertume de houblon herbeux et dun goût  de café espresso (une progression croissante vers la finale. Post-goût moyennement amer et aux notes sèches, composé de rôti, dalcool moyen, de chocolat noir et de café avec un léger goût fruité (moût de cerises et de raisins, pelures de prunes) ainsi quavec des notes de fumée de bois.

Pours a sludgy black tar with dense dark beige head. Smells like chocolate pavement! One of the best imperial stouts out there.

Pours pitch black with small brown head. Smells of molasses, dark coffee, and hints of dark chocolate. Taste is espresso, dark chocolate, hints of roast, and booze. Full-bodied with a smooth, thick texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Bells Expedition Stout finishes with a roasts bite and a slight boozy tingle.

Wow... Wow... Killer snifter pour of motor oil with full dark creamy head. Nose is super rich, full of dark coffee and heavy chocolate... You can smell the weight. Caramel, smooth caramel. Flavor is heavy rich... Tastes like everything I want in motor oil. Dark chocolate and creamed coffee. Not very bitter. Sweet caramel and milk chocolate finish. Intense all over...

A classic, wonderful stout.  This beer looks, smells and tastes like molasses.  The fun doesnt end there, however.  Pours a completely opaque, jet black with the consistency of motor oil.  A few dark mocha bubbles but hardly any head.  Smells a bit chocolately but the molasses pervades the nose.  The taste is wonderful and balanced with a nice syrupy mouthfeel.  You can pick up the oatmeal, roast, coffee, chocolate and of course, molasses in this brew.  Gets better as it warms to room temperature, dont miss this one if you find it anywhere.
UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 Had on tap, thick chocolately malt with the aroma of coffee/chocolate.  Very tasty.  Would like to cellar some of this for a few years.

Bottle at tasting, thanks Jonno. Dark brown, hardly no head. Aroma is booze, fudge, bit roasty, oaty, porridge. Taste is very nice. Nice dryness, dark chocolate, wheaty, something savoury. Really nice.

Viscous black pour, moderate brown head. Crystallized caramel, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, blackcurrants, plums, figs, and deep roasted malt. Creamy, smooth, full-bodied. Alcohol is pleasantly melded into the other aroma and tastes in the beer.

Pours a deep brown/black with a golden cream head, smells of rosted malts and chocolate, taste is burnt roasted malts dark chocolate and bitter hops...took me a bit to get over the burnt kinda taste but once i got use to it, this beer wastn to bad

12 oz. pour.  Bottled on 1/28/09, enjoyed on 1/13/13.  Pours dense black with very little carbonation and almost non-existent head.  Huge roasty malt taste up front, followed by toffee, caramel and licorice notes, somewhat bitter finish.  Thick, silky smooth mouthfeel which leaves a great coating on the roof of your mouth.  Rich and complex.  Excellent Imperial Stout which ages as nicely as advertised.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2014 2013 bottle. Pours black with a good head and lacing.  Aroma of dark chocolate with mild umami and some dark fruit, but subdued.  Taste dark chocolate with roasted malt and then some bitter chocolate.  Hints of cherry. Quite a bit of bitterness from hops and roast.  Finishes very dry lingering bitter.  Slick mouthfeel with a full body and moderate carbonation.  Also had a 2012 bottle that had all the characters listed above with the addition of a very slight oxidized aroma and less dark chocolate.  Good beer that needs some age to become great. 3 or 4 years is probably the sweet spot.

Bottle to tulip glass.  Pours black with thick dark tan head.  Aroma is full on malt with some roasted tones and traces of chocolate and soy and a permeating sweetness.  Awesome lacing. Taste is less malt with a smokey quality.  Surprising bitterness that tends more towards the hops than the coffee, but both are there.  A sweetness that is accompanied by the taste of dark fruits.  Some alcohol meanders throughout but is not displeasing.  Thick, full, slick mouthfeel.  Good overall but the sweetness puts it behind some other stouts for my taste.

Bottle:
Pours used motor oil black-brown with a dark tan, quickly gone cap.
Smoky, chocolate aroma....licorice.
Taste is a coffee-alcohol forward bitter.
Resiny hops, roast.  A bit of dark fruits.
Love to try this aged somewhat...
Very...very.....good.

12oz bottle dated 10/2/12 pours a dark thick brown/black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt, caramel, molasses, soy, licorice, and hops. Taste of bitter hops and chocolate malt into coffee and a meaty bitter earthy smoke with a touch of dark fruit sweetness on the finish with some alcohol warming. Delicious!

Pours pitch black into the glass.  Poured right down the center and got less than a finger of a dark mocha colored head.  The aroma on this beer is a generic chocolate with a hint of licorice, some dark fruits, maybe cherry and a hint of coffee and hop with maybe a touch of alcohol.  The front of the palate is very creamy with a slight pop of carbonation.  There is a taste of chocolate and dark fruit, still seems cherry.  This moves into a very bitter coffee and bitter dark chocolate, the finishes with a hoppy dryness.  This beer is incredibly complex and I can tell some age will do it well.  Excellent beer.

355 mol bottle that was aged 4 years.  Pours an oily, thick black with a moderate chocolate coloured head.  Aroma is licorice, leather, dark earth, and alcohol (bourbon).   Taste is bitter coffee and black licorice, perhaps some roastiness.  Slick and oily texture, fairly soft carbonation with a medium bitter finish.  Not my favourite combination of flavours, would not try again.  Full disclosure, this bottle has travelled with me from Minneapolis to Winnipeg to Toronto to Ottawa.  I would consider re-rating with a new bottle.

Bottle. Pours black with a ring of tan head. Aroma is roasted malts and chocolate. Flavor is a super smooth stout with wonderful vanilla and chocolate blended with roasted malts. Abv is very well hidden.  Solid beer.

Smells very strong with malt flavor. Very dark brown foamy head. Pours thick and oily. Has a very bitter flavor and a taste of licorice.
Quite flat without much visible carbonation. Very black in appearance.
Bitter and very strong. Liked it.

NOTE - DRANK FRESH (same year as bottled). Bottled 1/2012; drank 12/2012

Pours like night, great rich head, mild sickly sweet aroma. Good balance of malt throughout, mild acidic front end and lingering alcohol flavor on back end. Lacking of hops (bouquet  more than flavor) or a milky richness for my tastes - I believe there should be one or the other at least in a stout. 

Again - drank fresh. If left to age for 12 to 36 months longer, likely would be a much better brew.
Sampled in a 12 oz bottle that was aged over five years. A stunning brew. So creamy and smooth. Shared with four people and a drop was not wasted.

Pours black with lingering khaki head. Aroma is dark fruits, chocolate and alcohol, some hop bitterness in support. Taste opens with alcohol bite and some hops, followed up by chocolate and finishing strong with roasted malts. Strong carb keeps it lively but still smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the best stouts Ive had. Perfectly well rounded, roasty, thick, rich, coffee, chocolate. Delicious.
My favorite Bells stout. Great balance of malt character with hop finish. A definite must-have for stout lovers!

Had paid exactly $7 for a snifter to be filled at Local Option. Its pour is undeniably charcoal black with a shortish khaki head. Good retention, supremely awesome lace. Smells meaty and dark: West Virginia coal, steak grease, mint, ash, self-roll tobacco, roast, and brown sugar. Tastes primarily how it smelled: coal, roast, tobacco; and adds American hops, marshmallow, London yeast, caramelized dates, and dark chocolate to the mix. Vanilla, coffee dregs and licorice by swallow. Ends bitter and slightly earthy. Also, fantastic warming booziness which lingers for a little while, which was discovered almost immediately. It balances sweetness and roast very well and efficiently. Keyword here: viscous. Well done!

Really liked this one.  Pitch black appearance with a dark tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and dark roasty malts.  Flavor contains the same dark chocolate and a huge hop punch of beautiful bitterness.  Finishes dry with a slight alcohol burn.

Poored from bottle into snifter glass. Poured black as night no light shining through at all. Brownish head that sticks around for awhile. Lacing and alcohol legs are present. Smelled of dark chocolates, smoke, light coffee, earthy woody smell, maybe some vanilla. Taste - roasted chocolate coffee and alcohol. Not overehelming alcohol by any means but you get a little bite. A smokey light tobacco flavors is coming through as well. Covers the entire tounge. Not as heavy as I was expecting. Very good beer definitely doesnt dissapoint.

Reviewed 12/21/2012. 12 oz bottle into a Duvel tulip.

A: Pours a pitch black color. No "really dark brown" bollocks, this one is nearly perfectly opaque. The head is a one finger tan color that gives Ten Fidy a run for its money in terms of darkness. The retention is pretty good, and a thick collar around the glass diameter lingers nicely.

S: I immediately notice a large amount of dark fruits, like raisins, currants, and plums. Beneath that, theres a bit of licorice, anise, coffee, chocolate. and light booze. Very similar to a revved-up version of the Stone IRS - if we can compare it to any other RIS on the market, that is.

T: The flavor seems roastier than the aroma. Roasted malts open the flavor profile with a punch to the face, before a fruity midtaste and alcoholic, vaguely hoppy finish. Even for an imperial stout, the balance is lacking. Really, the palate is just beat down with roast, bittersweet dark fruits, and booze. Not much subtlety here - its aggressive and even harsh. If there was any beer that was more suitable for drinking after a year in the cellar, this is it.

M: Thick as a brick. I cant think of any other way to describe the bigness of the body. It finishes with a lot of wet slickness and lingering roasted malts. It certainly feels decadent, but again, the big booze detracts instead of complimenting the flavor profile.

O: This one is a bit harsh, frankly. Good news is, aging it will kill that harshness stone dead. Bad news is, I only bought a single bottle. Damnit. Then again, Im of the school of thought that a beer should be consumed as soon as its purchased, so the middling scores stand.

Bells Expedition Stout is just outstanding.  Its dark, absolutely opaque, no light at all gets through this baby.  Theres little head at all and the aroma is big coffee, malt, and some molasses.  The flavor is both huge and balanced.  Very strong, very rich, with a really big malt and sweet notes of chocolate, brown sugar and espresso, but more bitter hops in the finish than I expected. Sticky, oily body.  My mouth adjusted to it toward the end of the glass, but it never became cloying or predictable.  This is a good one.

Dont know why I havent rated this black beauty but I just sipped on one during our Christmas Eve dinner so figured I would rate it fresh. Mirror black pour with lasting khaki head. Aromas and flavor of dark cocoa, roasted malt and grains, figs, light vanilla, light coffee, citrus flavored hops, oak, and a little bit of licorice. Everything is layered beautifully, malt and hops working in unison. Body is creamy smooth and finishes with a sticky fudge aftertaste. An exceptional stout all around. Merry Xmas Bells.

Absolutely outstanding stout. Pours thick with an ephemeral creamy froth. Malty backbone, with underlying roasted coffee notes. No bitterness whatsoever. Has a nice freshness, too.

Pours black as night with a thick light brown head that sticks around for a while. Nose is roasted malt a bitter hop.   Taste of roasted malts, coffee and cocoa. Nice lacing in the glass. Mouthfeel is thick and oily. Fantastic beer.

Fresh bottle from polomagnifico...thanks, Ryan!  Pours thick and dark.  Nose is dark roasted malt, some earthy grains, molassess, and dark chocolate.  Taste is the same plus some fig and anise with bitter hop finish.  Viscous, oily mouthfeel.  Top notch...looking forward to laying some bottles down for  a long nap.

Flavor is bold roast malt with additional bitterness coming from earthy hops and dark coffee notes with spice and faint dark fruit esters; dry, ashy finish. Full body and low carbonation.

Aged over a year in bottle.  Pours super thick and black.   Strong taste of coffee with a boozy nose.  Excellent stout.

Black pour with a huge espresso head.  Thick mouth with a huge roast component.  Super creamy.  Bitterness lingers for a long time in the mouth.  Lots of lace.  Almost black IPAish in the amount of hops used for this.  Aroma is pretty muted with a little bitterness.  This is an excellent beer.

2010 Vintage
Aroma is a balanced blend of chocolate, roast and a touch of alcohol. There is a bit of oxidation and soy sauce creeping into this beer. A touch of dark fruit, mainly cherry and prune. There is a bit of a molasses and burnt caramel note as well. 
Pours a deep black with a thick mocha head that recedes steadily leaving a nice film on the edges. 
Flavor has rich, sweet chocolate notes with some lighter roast character. Some hints of dark caramel present as well. Some low dark fruit character, similar to dark cheers and prunes. A solid bitterness helps balance the beer, though by this time the hop flavor has faded. Some alcohol spice in the finish. Some oxidation, and in particular soy sauce, is starting to show; as it warms the soy sauce fades away and takes on more of a sherry note. The roast character takes on a touch of a smoked meat character in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is full bodied and chewy. Carbonation is fairly low which only helps to make this beer seem thick. The alcohol is present and warming but quite clean. Astringency is low and almost non existent. 
Overall it's a nice beer, but I would like to have tried it next to a fresh version. I don't know that I would let this go more than two years as its already starting to show its age in a bit of a negative way. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is dark chocolate, expresso, and toffee.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2015 Poured from a bottle (dated 10/22/12). thick black color with dark tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate and roasted coffee. Malty flavor, bitter, with coffee undertones. Complex flavors as it warms. Great beer. Highly drinkable and highly suggested. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great beer; might be even better cellared(if I ever had the patience).  As is, I like a few others better  because of drinkability and lower price.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A magnificent beer. Hot and hoppy when fresh. Dark as night. Ages beautifully. Full bodied. Brown head. Toffee, licorice, orange, chocolate, and coffee. This years batch does not disappoint.

12 ounce bottle. Bottled on 10/22/12. Opague black color topped by a medium-sized creamy brown head. Intense bittersweet chocolate and espresso roasted malt aroma. Rich, silky bittersweet roasted malt flavor. Some licorice and currants emerge. Complex and smoky with resiny hops and a chewy thick espresso finish. Wonderful to behold. You must seek this out and drink it.

12oz bottle from Southern Season. Another one Ive been chasing for a while - this is impossible to find on the west coast. Pours thick inky black with a big brown head that laces well. Aroma is charred malts and a hint of syrupy sweetness. Taste is super dark roasty malts followed by big bitter hops. Lots going on here: dark chocolate, licorice, raisin, and a hint of bourbon. The dark malts and bitter hops dominate here, unlike many other imperial stouts where the barrel notes do.

Pours all black with a dark khaki, almost brown head that slowly expands into full as the beer settles.  Pretty cool.  Aroma is potent, and I must say unique.  Raisin and alcohol stand out the most, but there is plenty of chocolate, coffee, and licorice in here as well.  Moving on to the taste, it is dominated by the darker impressions.  This being chocolate and coffee, while the liquor notes are still strong.  This one is is full bodied with a thick, oily texture.  The aftertaste is heavy and long lasting with chocolate and raisin.  The alcohol content hits you quite quickly.  It doesnt hide.  For what Im looking for in this style, this might be close to perfection.  I am stingy and I throw 4.5 ratings like theyre manhole covers.  But this is worth it.  This might be the best stout Ive ever had.

Pours ink black with a quickly receding tan head and beautiful lacing. The nose is chocolate and coffee. The palate is oily and viscous with tastes of chocolate covered wafers and a nice dose of mellow hops. The coffee flavor really stands out here. This is really fantastic stuff.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of Jeff, thanks ! Pours pitch black with creamy brown head, leaving lacings. Aroma of rich roasted malts, dark chocolate, sweet caramel, light coffee notes, and abit of alcohol. Flavor of roasted malts, rather bitter, coffee, dark chocolate, some piney / grapefruitly hope. Full body, soft carbonation, hides the ABV very well, lasting dry bitter finish. Very nice brew. 131212

Sweet rom of chocolate covered raisens and bourbn. Pours dark brown black that you cannot see through, with  a smallish light brown head. Hits you like  a cannonball with flavor and alcohol burn right off instead of at the end. Mouthfull is full and creamy  and clings to your mouth. Low carbontion. Sweet mollasses, rum, raisen, and cherry are offset with lots of hops as they begin to tke off in the middle and then expand with the finish. Heavy and slightly balanced towrds sweet, but stisfying in winter and very tasty.

Bottle 07.12.12
Visual: Pours a jet black with a small tan head. 
Aroma: Dark malt, caramel, alot of of dark malt,  chocolate.
Taste: Chocolate caramel , dark malt, smoke malt, medium to heavy body, light carbonisation. Very very Great beer.

Bottle that has been cellared for one year. This beer has so much chocolate flavor to it that it would be real easy to chug three or four of these. Nice malty backbone and a creamy finish.


Visual:
Aroma:
Taste:

Bottle that has been cellared for one year. Jet black with huge chocolate head. This beer has so much chocolate flavor to it that it would be real easy to chug three or four of these. Nice malty backbone and a creamy finish.

Thick, hearty backflipping kiss to my lips and braincheese. 

So deep and interesting from across the room, it commands your attention and participation. 

If youre having one, lucky you.

smells of dark roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, a bit of alcohol. Despite all of the dark roastyness, there is a sweetness to the aroma.  It doesnt taste as sweet as it smells, but this is not a bad thing.  Up front you get the roasted malt and dark chocolate. It finishes with a slightly tart acidic tinge, which is probably from the hops.  Very nice.
Just a nudge more alcohol than I like. Beautiful pour, black with dark tan head. Flavours lie creamy on the whole tongue. Each sip reveals more complex flavour.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2013 12oz bottle into snifter glass.  Thick jet black color with thin tan head.  Aroma of espresso, dark chocolate and roasted malt.  Taste is coffee and dark chocolate right up front, somewhat smokey, very heavy on the roasted malt, some medium bitterness finishing up.  Cant detect any alcohol heat for the ABV.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Awesome.

Bottle pour to snifter.  Thick, dark black color; sparse, but persisent mocha head. Very rich and luscious on the palate; roasted malt; espresso coffee, dark chocolate.  Tastes like a big ABV without beating you up side of the head with booze.  I need more!

Poured from 12oz bottle (bottled 10/22/12) into snifter.  Pours jet black with light brown head.    Smells of roasted malts. Mouthfeel is pretty thick    Tastes of coffee and chocolate are present and you can def taste the roasted malt. There is a slightly bitter finish and surprisingly not too boozy considering the ABV.   Looking forward to trying one if these after a year in my basement.

2012 bottle into a pint glass. Poured with a thick, 1 finger mocha head. Head does not last very long. Aroma of chocolate, roast and a bit of alcohol. Lots of roast in the taste. Lots. Has almost a smokey flavor from all the dark malts. Alcohol is well hidden behind all the roast. Medium viscosity. Each sip clears the pallet well. Well balanced even with all the roast.

Location: 12 oz bottle from jcos, 11/27/12, Rating # 2600!


Aroma: It is roasty and sweet, with coffee, chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, and hoppy undertones

Appearance: It pours a thick, dark brown-black color with a small medium brown head

Flavor: The taste is a little bit less sweet then the nose would have suggested, theres still quite a bit of roast, with a little smoke, and it finishes roast, and medium bitter, with just a little bit of booze

Palate: The body is medium-full, it is creamy and smooth, has a fairly soft (leaning toward average) carbonation, a touch of heat (but remains dangerously drinkable at 10.5%), and has a long, dry finish

Overall Impression: 
Thanks Kramer!  I cant believe I havent rated this one before, but this is a heck of a beer.  They figured out how to meld the roast, smoke, sweet malts, and hop bitterness together pretty much perfectly to make a world class beer.  What else is there to say?  This beer is great!

Aroma is malty with tons of chocolate. Slight hint of warming alcohol. Appearance is deep dark and black slight tan head. Taste starts chocolate forward, and slight roast malt. Deep caramels and velvety chocolate. Palate is heavily viscous. Very enjoyable. Overall, let it sit awhile and mellow, the sugars are pretty complex and do well with a slight age. Lovely stout.

Bottle to English Jug Glass. Pours deep mahogany with one inch head that leaves heavy lacing. Smells of malt, chocolate, dark roasts. Taste heavy malt, low bitterness, raisins. Fills out as it warms up. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle.  Pours very black with a decent brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit, chocolate, coffee, and licorice.  Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruits, molasses, licorice, and a bit of alcohol.  Big and complex.  Nice.

12oz bottle, bottled 01/18/2012.  Pours a jet black color with a tan head that fades to bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Aroma is molasses, roasted malt, chocolate.  Heavy on the palate with soft, smooth carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, malty, roasty, chocolate, a little bitter coffee, a little nutty, with a smooth, bittersweet chocolate finish.  Excellent.  Surprised I havent rated this yet...

Bottle(kindly delivered by jonas!!!): Literally black with a stable and creamy yellowish to tanned head, almonds, rye bread, coffee, roasted malt and sweet caramel in the otherwise dry bitter nose; velvet MF, full bodied, solid solid dry bitter flavour; lingering dry fruity-toasty and nutty finish. Gorgeous stuff

Easy to see why this is near the top of the rankings. This is a fabulous brew, a classic example of the style. Black color with great brown foam, settles fairly quickly leaving lots of lacing. Roast and chocolate form in the nose with a surprising hint of hops wafting up as well. My only ding is that the aroma is a bit faint. Hop bitterness comes through on the palate as well - more so than any other imperial stout that i can recall - along with cocoa, coffee, and an earthiness. Long lasting bitter finish. Flavor profile is much more intense than the aroma.

I missed my chance to try this one last year, but found a 10-month-old bottle this week.  It pours black, with a fair tan head and good lacing.  Aroma has lots of licorice, raisins and alcohol with touches of coffee and dark chocolate.  Body is full, with only slight carbonation.  Mouthfeel is sticky.  This is a sipper, for sure.  Its bitter taste and alcohol/licoroice flavor werent quite what I expected, but great anyway (perhaps cause this one had a chance to start aging).

Bottle. Pours a jet black, some mocha colored head (and to be honest, left this in the freezer and forgot about until it had ice crystals, so yeah...) Nose is all roasted malts and dark chocolate, just begging to be drank. Mouth is loads of dense chocolate, coffee and dark roasted malts, fades into a hint of licorice and then long, lingering bitterness. Like I said, nearly froze this one, so the boozy warmth I was expecting didnt show all its teeth. Gonna cellar some of these, one of the nicest stouts Ive had. Happy Thanksgiving indeed!

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Final beer of a very thankful and loaded night - this has lots to live up to, by golly.  Aroma - mmm.  Best yeast I have ever smelled in an impy.  Nice dark chocolate with coffee roast.  Great appearance of darkness with incredible head and retention; very good lacing also.  Flavor - oh geez.  This is just so.  Best beer night of my life.  I get Stone Double Bastard, and then this?  Has God blessed me this much?  Blends all the best coffee characteristics of their Java with all the richness and licorice and complexity of their Kalamazoo.  w00ters.  NEARLY at the Founders Breakfast Stout, methinks, if not quite at the *@&$ level of Goose Island Bourbon.  Blind taste testing someday plz?  RE-RATE: At the level of Founders.  Would be hard-pressed to decide between the two.  ANOTHER RE-RATE: It was not quite at the level of Founders.  Little heavy on the palate.  Still a phenomenal beer.

So boozy; great imperial stout.  I loved the dark chocolatey color, and I must say I was a little...too excited to drink this ahahaha Im drinking it right now and I wish I had shared it with the guy because it is STRONG!  Little to no head on the pour.  Wonder if I should have cellared and waited.

Tasty stout! Nose dark chocolate/expresso. Taste Roasted goodness with slight expresso and cocoa nib finish. Great bitterness cleans palate. Mouth feel creamy. Surprisingly drinkable. Well balanced. Cellaring a couple for a yr and 2. Cant wait to revisit

Im trying not to gush too much over this beer, it seems suited to my taste buds. It isnt perfect, but it is so robust, tasteful and well intentioned, I just cant find much to criticize. It is a typical Bells dark beer, meaning a bit on the coarse side. But on this occasion, its working to their advantage.

On draft at Whole Foods Watering Hole. Dark brown with a dark mocha head. Aroma of biscuit, molasses, chocolate milk and just a touch of coffee. Taste of dry coffee, cocoa with hints of anise and burnt toast. Somewhat astringent palate with a very dry finish. Good, but I expected more from such a highly rated stout.

Lucky enough to find a keg at Trapeze Pub while passing through. A beautifully drinkable imperial stout. Great roast, coffee, and chocolate aroma. Taste follows with a perfect balance of dark chocolate and sweetness. Palate is perfect for me, easy to drink for such a heavy beer. Fantastic.

From bottle 1 month after bottling date.  Great head and aromas.  I like the bitterness that is sure to mellow out with cellaring. I really like Surly Darkness and this just might beat it (plus it gets convenience points for being in 12 ounce bottles in my book)

Completly dark.  The slightest of head formed around the edge of the glass.  Possibly one of the darkest imperial stouts ve tried.  The darkness covers up the sweetness that is in there.  Notes of chocolate, coffee and campfire, but nothing that prevelant.  Really really good stout, but not as good as a lot that it is rated in front of.  I put it slightly behing the ten fidy I tried yesterday.

12 oz bottle of 2012 vintage.  Black with 1 finger brown head.  Aromas of roasted malt, booze, and some piney hops.  Flavors of chocolate, coffee, lots of hops.  Medium body with medium to high carbonation.  I think this beer needs some age, the hops are just a bit overwhelming right now and it takes away from the malt character.

12oz bottle---->tulip.  Pours pitch black with a medium dark khaki head that disappears quickly and leaves little lacing.  Aroma is sweet artificial chocolate candy and mild licorice.  Taste is chocolatey, mild coffee, licorice, hop bitter, and alcohol burn.  Palate is a bit on the thin side.  Enjoyable overall, but not in the top tier of Impys.

Near black with a brown head, looks thick when pouring. Smells smokey, woody, faint black licorice, and earthy hops. Taste is only moderately bitter, with licorice flavor that lingers. Heavy bodied with the warmth of the 10.5% coming through.

Tap at the Brentwood Tavern, New Buffalo - 03/11/12.
This beer looks the bollocks, thick black with a big dirty coffee head that retains well.
Nose is roast malt, liqourice and chocolate.
Tastes of roast malt, molasses, chocolate, a little booze and a pinch of liqourice.
Full bodied with soft carbonation, rich and smooth.
Good stuff, although given the high scoring I was perhaps expecting a little more.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
On tap at bells brewery. Really smooth but sharp, intense flavors. Excellent

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
