UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Delicious. Pours a midnight black with a  creamy mocha head. Smells of incredibly rich dark fruits, dark chocolate and espresso bitterness, mild chocolate sweetness, very dry.  Tastes of all those things and more with a great clean dry finish. My kind of impy stout

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a thick viscous black color with a big three finger mocha head that hangs out like your buddy without a job. Big roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, dark fruit and burnt candy on the nose. On the palate its big and burnt... Nice bitterness from the hops balance the deep dark chocolate coffee and raisin notes. A bit boozy... look forward to trying this after a year or so to mellow.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2014 Pours dark with a late-forming small mocha head. Smells very sweet like tootsie rolls with some licorice and a hint of vanilla. Very sweet but with a nice bitter finish that keeps it from being cloying. Brown sugar and vanilla up front with a burst of chocolate as it goes down. Good carbonation. Lingering cocoa. Solid stout on national stout day. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

In a vertical 6 pack from Hops & Vinies, circa 2010, complex spice and aged rum liquor on the nose. flavor is rich and complex with a roasty malt profile & spice plus annese, coccoa, and mole pepper.  Finishes dry with more roasty aged spicy flavors.  CELLAR THIS BEER!

Bottle from Maris.  Pours thick, motor oil style black with a small brown head that quickly dissipates to a tan group of bubbles.  The aroma is milk chocolate, coffee grind, a little mocha and booze.  The taste is really chocolate forward.. really delicious with a subtle coffee toward the end of the flavor.  This has some booze on the finish but it is 10.5%.  Tremendous sticky palate that really ensures you take your time with this one.  Great but not as good as a few others, in my opinion.

Excellent beer, black pour, off white i inch head.  Definite malt aroma,picking up the hops...nice.  full body, warming feeling, 10.5%abv I guessit would do it, but not overwhelming alcohol flavor. creamy, full body, complexity in this brew, well balanced.  Nice taste of malt/hop characteristics.  Highly recommend!

Bottle. Poured straight black with a thin tan head. Exactly what an imperial stout should be  great rich flavor with a hint of chocolate and a great warming alcohol taste and sensation at the back of the tongue.

Thick black with no light shining through, about a one finger brown sugar tanhead with perfect bubbles.  Aroma was mild with just a hint of chocolate and sweetness of some mild dark fruits.  Taste follows the nose exactly with the sweet fruit at the finish.  A mild alcohol flavor at the end, fine with the 10.5% that is in it.  Mouthfeel is very smooth and heavy, perfect all around stout.

A great tasting well balanced stout. Smooth, rich, creamy. Nice coffee and chocolate

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours opaque deep black with a large brown head and some lacing. Aroma is coffee, dark roasted malt, and cocoa powder. Flavor its the same with medium sweetness, notes of dried fruit, and a light coffee bitterness.

12oz bottled dated 10/2/12 - poured into snifter.. 
Near perfect darkest brown color, very light head. Quite pleasant aroma - while cold not showing off its 10+% abv.

Draft, 2012 vintage. Pours dark with a nice foamy head. The aroma is solid with a lot of malt and dark fruit notes, some sweetness to it. The taste is a little bitter up front and in the tail-end finish. Drinks thick like a RIS should. I was hoping for a pour of blacknote, but they ran out and ended up with this instead, so the rating may suffer a bit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours an almost-black color with a small light brown head. Nose has some roasted and coffee notes to it with some subtle underlying bitterness to it. Taste has some bitterness to it, but the stout characteristics carry this. Wow.
Tons of malt. Caramel and coffee notes as well. Thick, black, true to stout form. 2012, roasty and malty. Thick to almost greasy on the tongue. Good imperial stout, cant wait to age it.
Huge. Slam. Dunk. What an after-school treat in october from the good people of Michigan at Bells. Superb balance. Kinda wish this stuff came out of the tap when I turned on the sink faucet.

Bottle. 2010 vintage. Tar, thick dark chocolate, smokey and phenolic nose. Black as can be, thin dark brown head. Wow! Very sharp dark fruit (berries, cherries) in a chewy initial; mid palate offers up richer chocolate and a hit of warming alcohol; final has a small and intensifying carbonation and then a heavy smokey  coating. Thick palate, almost oily. A superb imperial stout. The two years have matured this beer nicely and moderated the blast of flavors and phenolic burnt rubber notes it had when fresh. Looking forward to another bottle of this vintage in a year or so.
From bottle. Great toffee and chocolate scent. Beautiful tan head. Drinks like a more appropriately hopped storm king. Great strong stout.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2013 Fresh 2012 bottle.  Pours thick, ink black in color, minimal beige head that gathers at the edges.  Big lacing on the glass.  Musty and thick aroma.  Lots of roasted malt and dark chocolate with hints of black licorice, raisins, cream, and vanilla.  Taste is extremely smooth and creamy.  All of the aromas mix nicely together.  Moderately bitter finish leaving a roasted coffee and lightly fruity taste.  Full body, thick and sticky mouthfeel.  A very good Imperial Stout that should improve with age.  I plan to lay a bunch of this down for a while.  Re-rate 2/13/13 - Tried a 2011 bottle and loved it even more.  Roasted malt and chocolate flavors fade a bit which brings out more of a tobacco, raisin, and soy sauce taste.  Love the flavors, love the mouthfeel.  Just an awesome beer.
Pithc black viscous with a small mocha head. Aroma is; chocolate, rich, roasted coffee. Taste is bitter chocolate, coffee, liquorice dark fruits, raisins, sweetness, alcohol. A very good stout!

Rich malt, mocha aroma. Pitch black pour. Taste is very rich, lord of malt and coffee and chocolate. Still very balanced. Almost creamy mouth feel. Very good, very, very good. Would like to try and age it.

Tempting mocha aroma and perfect black appearance with a balanced taste and subtle lingering mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is coffee, booze, dark chocolate, maybe some toffee as well. Very malty. Appearance is beautiful, just a thick black stout, with a brown, one-finger head. Taste is sweet chocolate first, fading into dark chocolate, and finally ending with a deep, coffee bitterness. It is a very intense flavor. Mouthfeel is soft, creamy, light carbonation. Overall, this is fantastic. The intense coffee bitterness balances the high abv perfectly. I only bought one, but I plan on buying more. Very solid.

bottle shared with friends. thanks to tom10101! pours very dark brown, almost black, with a very nice crema, decent retention and lacing. tons of roastiness, fresh roasted cereals, coffee, smoke, hint of vanilla, some maple, hint of soy and lactic notes. almost cloying. full body, soft carbonation, very nice bitter coffee and peppery finish. tingling and warming alcohol. very good brew!
Aged bottle. Pitch black with small head. Vanilla and coffee aroma, taste vanilla, roasted coffee beans, dark chocolate and a lasting bitter aftertaste.
Outstanding stout.  Deep color, flavor, and texture.  Reputation is deserved.

Deep black with a thick brown head. A lot of sticky lacing. Rich coffee and chocolate aroma, some fig and plum. Taste is dark chocolate, toffee, vanilla extract, and some alcohol. Really silky mouthfeel. Very, very good. Planning on picking up a few bottles for cellaring when it shows up this year.

In honor of Columbus Day, I liberated this from the extreme stouts section of the garage beer fridge. It delivers on the marketing language with huge amounts of malts and hops creating a monstrosity of flavors. Malts win out on the entry and the bitter hops almost even out the sweet finish. Its a one-and-done beverage because of the oily weight, but it is a delightful one.

Bottled in 2011
Poured a black/ dark brown with a slight mocha head. 
Sweet chocolate, caramel taste up front but had a hoppy bitter finish.  
Overall a very good stout I am going to add a few to my beer cellar and try again in 6 months or so to see if the bitter finish fades.

Pours jet black with a thin brown head. Thick like motor oil. Aroma of bitter hops, dark chocolate and strong roasted coffee. Taste follows, vinous, roasty, hoppy with bitter semi sweet chocolate. So thick and chewy. This is sooo nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 12ounce bottle. The aroma is spicy coffee, chocolate, and a fruitiness, perhaps from the hops. Chocolate, coffee,and roasted malts dominate the flavor. There is also some fruits, dark stone fruits. A solid beer.

Pours a black motor oil. Smells of sweet dark fruit. The taste is unexpected and welcome, coffee undertones. Absolutely wonderful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy Deez nuts

Black with a nice tan head.  Great retention and lacing.  Smells of malt, chocolate, and oats.  Taste is a lot of malt, chocolate, coffee and a hop kick. Delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Has big time malt, chocolate and an almost like templeton rye scent. Flavor is very similar to scent with a great whiskey kick, much different from the Kalamazoo.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The malts are intense, wonderful quality. The scent is top notch. The roasted malts & hops give this beverage a great finish. Its nice to have a good stout where coffee & chocolate dont overwhelm the other flavors.
excellent stout tastes of decadent chocolate. thick rich creamy with a warm burn of alcohol. strong sweet and delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 09/19/2011 vintage. 12 oz bottle into a DFH signature glass. Reviewed on 08-27-2012. Thanks a ton apocolypsezombie!

A - Pitch black body with a two finger high mocha head. Super sticky lacing and retention. 4.0/5

S - Charred malts, milk chocolate, and some faint ripe dark fruit notes. Somewhat simple. 3.5/5

T - Very roasty with some sweeter notes of chocolate and coffee. Aftertaste is a tad bitter with a warming alcohol presence. Again, rather simple. 3.5/5

M - Pretty amazing mouth feel. Super thick and silky with decent carbonation. Sticky and coating which really works with the basic flavor profile. 4.5/5

O - A very standard but delicious RIS. The flavor and nose are somewhat boring for the style but the mouth feel is one of the best Ive had. Excellent beer. 4.0/5

Batch 9512 - December 18, 2009. 12 oz bottle into a tulip glass. Reviewed on 10-05-2012. Thanks to Rempo for this killer extra.

A - Same as the 2011

S - Seems a bit less roasty than the fresher bottle. Ripe dark fruits, chocolate, espresso beans, light smoke and a touch of booze. Excellent aroma. 4.5/5

T - Dark fruits and milk chocolate. Some coffee and hop bitterness. Really rich and smooth. 4.0/5

M - Again, just excellent. Super thick and coating as all hell. 4.5/5

O - Age did some pretty amazing things to this beer. Much more layered and well rounded. Super solid RIS. 4.0/5

To celebrate my first year on the site. 
Pour pitch black, with a small mocha-brown head.
Aroma is packed with chocolate, vanilla, oatmeal, chocolate brownie, roasted malts, slight coffee, slight licorice, figs, raisins, some slight hoppy notes as well, like grass and spruce... Also some toffee and perhaps some slight leather in here as well... No doubt, a lot is going on...
Taste is rather sweet, with some roasty and hoppy bitter notes. Well done.
Semi-full bodied, with a rather flat carbonation, which suits this beer very well, since theres still some sparkles on the tongue. Slight heat in the throat, but nothing dominating. Thanks to Tom for sending me this.

A-- Dark, thick, sludgy motor oil black. No light penetrating at all. Nice reverse cascading head that was dark leather, want to say black in color. Got to one finger in height and stayed at above film through drinking. Good attractive head. No obvious carbonation on sides of the glass. Just a lot of gurgles in the head. 

S-- Dark chocolate, coco powder, coffee, rich thick malt, tobacco, and very strong ABV nose. Very complex and very nice. 

T-- Chocolate, malt, coffee and very straightforward but not near as good as the nose was. Thick and sludgy. 

M-- Thought Event Horizon without the barrel. Not as complex but quite hearty. Big, thick and chewy but very one dimensional at times. Touches of silk but really somewhat flat in a way. 

O-- Good but not that great I thought. Massive, big sipper with a great look and nose but falls a bit flat in the taste.

Bottle (12 oz) bottled in 2010. Huge thanks to pushkinwow for this one! Pitch black with a small thick creamy brown head and good lacing. Aroma is very complex with chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, caramel and toffee. Taste is so sweet with explosive caramel/toffee notes, roasted malt, vanilla and alcohol. Its almost a 10/10 here. Slight bitter finish. Mouthfeel is so thick that you almost have to chew the beer. Definitely a 5/5 for the palate. Full bodied. Warming alcohol. One of the best beer Ive drank so far, its hard to get any better than this. Wow!

Bottle 355ml. [2010]
Pours black with brown head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, caramel. Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, caramel, sweetness, alcohol, bitter finish. Palate: FULL bodied. Creamy mouthfeel. Overall: Warming alcohol. Incredibly tasty beer. Awesome mouthfeel. A masterpiece.
Heavy dose of malts underscoted by floral hops. Viscous mouthfeel... like golden motor oil of fermented goodness. Wonderful beer perfect for cold days or late night relaxing sessions.

Bottle from westlake in Chicago. Nose is chocolate, rich. Really nice beer, balanced and robust. Reminds me of brooklyn black chocolate stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From a 2010 bottle purchased at Arrowwine in Virginia. Beautiful dark color with a short lived tan head. Caramel and chocolate in the flavor. Bitter finish but nicely balanced. A gorgeous beer.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 Black pour with minimal head. Aroma is sweet malt with hint of roasted malt. Flavor is huge, intense, sweet malt and massive hop presence; far more than is typical for the style. Cough medicine comes to mind. To me, this is way over the top and too out of balance, but really glad to have tried it. Thanks, LEMONHEAD for sending this. Update: sample cellared 3 years and mellowed out really nicely. All the same flavors, but working together with just the right amount of intensity. Fantastic!
Nose is raisin, chocolate, coffee, malty roast..Taste is dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, dark fruit, roasty malts..palate is bold with chocolate roast

Overall, I love this stout. This has a nice kick with a 10.5% ABV. If you like the thick, strong, complex type of stouts, you gotta search this out. I know I will be buying this every year it comes out

Pours pitch black with a medium mocca head. Very rich beer with tonnes of chocolate, coffee, vanilla and a fair amount of burnt notes. Quite vinous with raisins and a solid sweetness that is balanced by a good bitterness. Altogether very well balanced and very good imperial stout.

Bottle to oversized snifter (from notes).  Looks good; pitch black with thin lacing.  Smells nice; sweet and malty.  Tastes good; like it smells (only better) with notes of vanilla too.  Pleasant on the palate.  Good stuff!
A well beloved beer I dont get as excited about. Taste is quite viscous  and the alcohol is too present

12 ounce bottle into snifter, bottled 11/11/2010.  Pours very dense pitch black color with a nice 1-2 finger dense brown head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some nice soapy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of huge very dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, caramel, biscuit, toast, char, molasses, vanilla, toffee, earth, wood, and light herbal hops.  Fantastic aromas with great complexity, balance, and strength.  Taste of big dark chocolate, roasted malt, char, coffee, molasses, caramel, toast, tobacco, biscuit, earth, pine, citrus, and light herbal hops.  Decent amount of roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, caramel, toast, molasses, citrus, and herbal on the finish for a while.  Fantastic roasted flavor balance and complexity.  Medium carbonation and very full bodied; with a very nice creamy, slick, thick, and lightly chalky mouthfeel.  Alcohol is very well hidden with almost no warming noticed at all after the finish.  Very smooth to sip on.  Overall this is a fantastic Russian imperial stout.  Huge complexity and big robust roasted flavors; and very smooth to sip on.  Extremely impressive.

bottle thanks to secret santa! thanks bro!  pours a jet black with a tan head that fades quickly.  aromas of cocoa, some coffee and some bittering hops.  taste follows suit... very hop forward  followed  by a heavy paddeling of thick malt.  very good.  drinking this back to back with a black buffalo has got me quite a buzz...

2007 version on tap at the Prohibition Taproom.

A: Pitch black body with a thin dark tan head.

S: Smokey, figs, and almost burnt malts.

M: Thick and syrupy.

O: Really good for what it is, but Im not huge on the fig notes.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2016 Pours pitch black with a tiny dark brown head. Aroma of chocolate, liquorice, vanilla, fudgy cake, earthy coffee, burned malts and an overall mellow balance. Taste is strong liquorice, bitter coffee, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate cake, cocoa, earthy notes and light salty. Intense impy. Great things going on in this! 
Got a 13 of this down the road. pretty much as I remembered this. Very roasted and with lots of liquorice, fruity coffee and just overall a nice and killer-ass non barrel aged imperial stout!

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2014 2010 bottle. Thanks to RasmusOtt! Pitch black beer, small brown head. Already from the smell, you can tell that this is going to be mad! Smells like port wine, burned sugar, licorice, chocolate and vanilla. The vanilla and the licorice is the most prominent ones. The taste is really intense. So much taste! It contains brownie, port wine, licorice and a wonderfully large amount of vanilla. Very creamy beer. The balance, intensity and complexity in this beer is amazing. 9/5/10/5/18 = 4,7 was original rating.

Re-rate from 2014, 2013 bottle in head to head with Black Note Stout. Only side notes and adjustments: More dark, dry chocolate than i recall. Lots of bitter roast, coffee and chocolate. Still an excellent beer, but i have to turn it down a notch. (9/5/9/5/17)

32 oz. swing top growler.

Fabulous appearance. Deep, jet black with a thick, beige head that leaves a generous amount of lacing cascading down the sides of the snifter. Grandiose aroma of molasses, malt, charred roast, dark fruits. Dark fruits really emerge as the beer warms. Lots of charred, roasted malt as well. Full bodied, though not viscous or syrupy. A really solid beer, though there are several other imperial stouts I prefer to this.

Bottle generously split with mcberko (youre welcome). Pours clean black with a fine tan ring of head and virtually no carbonation. Aroma of roasted malts, ground fresh coffee, dark chocolate, earth, some subtle sweetness. Flavour as above, very roasted, hints of vanilla, charred flavours towards the end lightly sweetened to balance. Smooth mouthfeel - slightly tingly, rich, roasted, dark. Aroma suggests more sweetness than present in the flavour. Very nice indeed.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2013 Draft at Khyber Pass. Powdery black pour with a thick black head. Gigantic flavors. Burned coffee. Charcoal. Flaming marshmallow. Charred meat. Smoke. Ash. Basically a whole campfire pounded down to a fine dust then rehydrated with alcohol. Great stuff! Bitter, sweet and creamy. Big ABV wallop. Better as it warms. Fantastic Russian Imperial!!!

Pours a murky pitch black with a ruddy brown head. The faintest hint of lacing. Brilliant boozy scent, with just a hint of walnuts and banana. Well-balanced buttery taste, and I also get some rosewater and pepper. Creamy mouthfeel and extremely long finish.

Bottle, from the wicked-awesome Alberta Pipeline. HUGE thanks to Savvy for this gem! Viscous dirty-oil pour. Dark brown head. This is an incredibly complex beer that I had to break down into its essential components: smokey elements (cured meats, burnt cedar), hearty elements (fresh ground espresso bean, fudge, light vegemite/beef broth), rustic elements (leather, earth, cigar box), and sweet elements (burnt marshmallow, molasses, figs, whiskey). Velvety, complex, completely satisfying.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: thick milky black with basically no head. Some anise and roasty notes on the nose. Flavor is an amazing combination of roastyness. Roasted toffee, chocolate and coffee. Finishing flavor is all dark, bitter chocolate. This is one incredible beer.

Poured on a tulip. Looks really dark and a brown thin head. The aromas come in the form of chocolate, caramel, vanilla some alcohol warmth, small amounts of coffee. Up front it tasted like some dark fruits, vanilla,, also some chocolate  and at the back coffee. Mouth feel was very creamy, solid, and lots of chocolate textures also has a small to medium carbonation . Overall an excellent beer.
A lot of dark roast, chocolate and coffee, with a well hidden alcohol flavour.

On draft at Prohibition Taproom.  Keg from 2007.  Pours jet black with one finger of fluffy chocolate head.  Aroma is chocolate and dark roasted malts.  Full thick mouthfeel  with roasted malts and chocolate, extremely smooth.  The cellar has treated this well.
Hell of an imp stout.  Dark chocolate, some coffee, and alcohol is invisible.  Pretty awesome and worthy of praise.
Pours a thick black with small tan head. Dryish stout. Alcohol is hidden well. Chocolate and some smoked malts, but I dont detect the complexity that others are raving about.

Bottle from Pizzeria Paradiso in Georgetown. Pours opaque black with nice tan head and lace. Aromas of Rum plum figs liq roast. Full body, light medium carbonation. A pleasureable experience. Piney hops lightly balance the big complex body and you just want more.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2016 
35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 06.11.2011
Aroma was not what I expected  a bit weird with cocoa powder and hints of smoke. Flavour has ash, salmiac and some cocoa powder. A disappointment, but good still. Maybe a bad bottle?

8-4-8-4-17=4.1

35,5 cl bottle @ home, bottled 06.11.2015
Sweet aroma with cocoa and licorice. Flavour has coffee, licorice, cocoa, some saltiness and oaty notes. Yep, it definitely was a bad bottle back then. Now the only flaw is saltiness here, which is a bit over my limit. But just a bit. Didnt remember that this is so rich  on both palate and flavour.

9-5-8-4-17=4.3

Well, This one is a Keeper. Very nicely done RIS, could of scored even higher if the bottle was allowed to age a bit. as the alcohol was a tad upfront yet. Im going to get my hands on more and cellar it. A treat!

12 oz. bottle batch # 10105. Originally bottled Dec. 2010. Pours a thick, oily black with virtually no head. Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, coffee and just a hint of booze. Tastes like dark chocolate. Slightly bitter finish. Worth the 100 point rating.

12oz bottle. deep deep brown in appearance, looks black in your glass. frothy tan head sitting on top. aroma is of roasted malt, dark fruits, dark chocolate, and coffee bean. taste is almost overwhelming on your tongue. lots of flavors here; roasted coffee, chocolate dominate. smooth, slightly bitter finish. full bodied liquid, pretty complex. good stuff here!

Bottle. Caramel smell. Black with brown head. Some alcohol burn but nice. I would love to have these aged. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

jet black color, dark khaki head, aroma of bitter chocolate, fresh coffee, vanilla, booze, flavors of bitter sweet chocolate, coffee, vanilla, pine, roasted marshmallows, dark fruits, booze, dry bitter coffee finish, thick silky, creamy texture, nose is not to exciting but the taste is great and complex, incredible brew

Bottle purchased at the source. Pour is dark almost opaque colour like a pitch cola colour with a creamy tan head and dollops of lacing. Smells like subtle malt and sugary cream. Tastes quite sweet malt, bitter on the tongue. caramel, sugar, sugar, sugar. However there is this slight taste of aspirin in there too. Good stuff.

Glad I didnt rate this the first time I tried it, because its way better than my memory serves me. 12 ounce bottle poured into a snifter. Nearly black in color, with the aroma being the setback to a higher score. Tastes of hops lead to a bittersweet chocolate finish. Amazing creaminess and mouthfeel. Just put two in the cellar for a couple years, cant wait to see how they turn out.
A great imperial stout.  Alcohol is evident in after taste.  Smooth mouth feel, goes down easy.  Appearence is very dark, almost black. Perfect for the dead of winter.

Bottled 11/01/11 poured into a tulip glass. Pours black as night with a thick 1" tan head. Nose is very hoppy, bitter chocolate, alcohol, roasty malts. Taste is cocoa, hops, a little earthy. Very good stout, a massive beer!

Originally reviewed: 6/1/09. 2008 Vintage

Pours a deep dark black with the thinnest of tan heads on top. This dissipates to just a ring quickly. Some lacing, but very little. Smells like coffee, alcohol, roasted nuts, cheerios, and wine. 

Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Very soothing and soft as this is consumed. Flavor is of roasted malts, some booze quality, and finishes like powdered cocoa. This is a very good RIS. I had some aged bottles but traded them away. I think I need to re-age this beer and check it out in a few. Recommend.

12oz bottle from March 2010. Pours an oily black. Aroma is a bit lacking, strongest notes of roasted malts with sweet fruit and alcohol. A nice mouth feel, silky. Taste is complex as advertised. Alcohol comes through as a warming back note to the malt profile. Minimal to no lacing.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2013 Pours a dark, almost black from the bottle, with nice lacing on the glass. Notes of licorice and coffee, but both understated by the bitter hops, chocolate, and slight booze and fig you taste. Smoky, almost ashy finish. A great beer for someone who wants to only have one or two for the evening.

330 ml bottle bought @ The Cracked Kettle about 1 year ago. Shared at tasting. Pours oily pitch black with a bog frothy and creamy dark brown head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of trace and lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet with roasted malts, bitter chocolate, vanilla, wood, dried dark sweet fruits, asphalt and alcohol. Taste is intense, sweet and slightly bitter with roasted malts, chocolate, wood, coffee, prunes, raisins, vanilla, tar and hints of black pepper and liquorice. Mouthfeel is smooth, silky, very tiny tart, balanced and full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with roasted malts, coffee, bitter chocolate and hints of pine and liquorice.

Bottled GIL
Pitch black with a medium, creamy beige head.
Vinous, warming chocolate in the aroma.
Milky chocolate, vinous, fruity, earthy
Sampled at Larsniclas testing. Pours pitch black with a big brown head. Smells coffee, sweet roasted malt. Tastes sweet barry, coffee abit chocolate malt.
Nice and dark....great stout with full flavor.  This is a cant miss stout....nice an creamy with a pretty strong alcohol finish ....great stuff!

Pours a thick, opaque black with red small  tinged head that quickly dissipates. Strong roasted malt flavor with espresso. Moderate pine hops that well complements the maltiness.  Taste starts with mild sweetness that then switches to moderate bitterness with a very long bitter finish.  Moderate carbonation with moderate to thick body. Clean on the palate.  This is a great stout!

Black color with a small brown head. Aroma is  roasted malt, dark chocolate, candy sugar, dark fruits . Flavor bittersweet, dark fruits, coffe, milk chocolate. Body is full, texture is viscid, carbonation is soft, bittersweet finish with long duration. Very balanced, superb...

Draft at Local Option.  Black pour with aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and dark fruit.  The taste is very well balanced between the roast and dark fruit sweetness. By far one the best non BA stouts Ive ever had.

12oz bottle dated 1/18/12 poured into porter glass
Aroma:  lot of dark fruits, some malt, caramel, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and a bit of alcohol
Appearance:  completely black.  thin layer of milk chocolate head that faded within a minute.
Taste:  medium sweet and medium bitter.  maybe a bit of mild sour.  coffee and chocolate flavors coming out now.  
Palate:  Carbonation is average but good.  Slight burn from the alcohol on the finish but the 10.5 abv is extremely well hidden.  Medium body and slick texture.  Maybe even a little thin.  Very light bitter finish and lingers on the tongue for a short while.
Overall:  This is a great imperial stout.  I am trying to compare this to founders breakfast stout for my personal notes and I feel like the aromas and taste are better on the expedition stout but the higher alcohol and the fact i can sense it brings it down a bit.  The Breakfast stout hid the alcohol well and had a better mouthfeel but had less flavors/aromas.  Either way they are both outstanding and I dont think i can pick a favorite.  Will cellar a few of these bottles and look forward to picking this up again next winter to compare them.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Spritty aroma, roasted stuff, quite well blend of notes. Complex. Woody notes. 8. Flavor is roasted malts, sweet malts, brown sugar, woody salty note. Very solid flavor. Aftertaste is roastted, dry and long lasting.

Aroma torrefacto, complejo con notas de madera. Sabor a maltas torrefactas, dulces, azucar moreno. Exquisita.

Rich dark brown/black color; Heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, chocolate, coffee, & some licorice; Flavor of roasted/burnt sweet malt, caramel/syrup, espresso, dark bittersweet chocolate, hops, and some vanilla; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced & quite complex; Overall, thick palate - really good stout.

Pours darl black with a brownish color head. Aroma of liquorice, dark fruits, and roasted malts. Taste is very complex with espresso, coffee roast,  chocolate, and dark fruits with a strong alcohol burn at the end. Full bodied.

Pours pitch black with a light brown head.  Aroma is quite hoppy, with roasted malts.  Taste is a great mix of pine hop and roasted malts that balance oh so well.  This had a year on it which made the flavours meld together.

Last years batch.  Pours like motor oil.  Thick and black.  The filthy polluted brown head can only mean one thing.  Decadence.  It dissapates quickly, leaving a thin film around the edge of the glass.  Heavy scent of soy sauce, licorice and chocolate assault the nose.  Peaking through are hints of coffee, wood and grassy hay notes.  Flavor is perfect balance of massive sweet and enourmous bitter.  The taste is larger than life.  Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy with just enough fizz to give it a bite on the finish.  Heavy body with a long aftertaste makes this one worth savoring.

Tap at Local Option.  Dark black pour with a one finger brown head.  Not much vpcarbonation but the head thins to a film that stays until the beer is gone.  Aroma of burnt wood.  Taste is char, black licorice, and coffee.  Full in the mouth.  A very nice, roasty stout.

Smokey molasses aroma with a strong smokey taste and hint of sweet. Red in color. Overall this is the most delicious stout I have ever tried. Only one place around me that serves it, they might be seeing me more.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black and thick, thin brown foam.  Smells slight nutty. Super thick pallette. Creamy, coffee taste.  Can't taste the high alcohol at all. One of the best of this style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 Aroma of malts and alcohol are strong. Pours jet black. Oily mouth feel starts slightly sweet and finishes bitter. Should be drank on a cold day.

Bottle into chalice. Pours thick oily black with a two finger head after an aggressive pour. Decent lacing. Smells of roasted malt, caramel and espresso with a touch of sour fruit and a bit of booze. Taste is heavy roasted malt and carmel with a good balance of hop bitterness and almost no presence of alcohol. Good, light carbonation with a smooth crisp hop finish. A perfect balance between the sweet malt and bitter hops. Great imperial stout.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2012 Bottle. Batch #9971, bottled on 9/13/10, drank on 3/13/12, 18 months old. Chocolate and malt scent, mellowed and thick, with a black colored pour that had zero head at first but then about a fourth inch head raised up momentarily before quickly dissolving. Thick bodied palate, grainy textured - wonderful! The taste hit hard first with a malty dark fruit resin then chocolate and finally, a coffee aftertaste. So complex, so delicious. 

****Batch #9971, bottled on 9/13/10, drank on 10/14/12, two years, one month old. Dark chocolate, black licorice scent and taste. This must be the year of black licorice for this guy. Still a lot of carbonation and a great foamy head. Impressive after two years. Id like to see the licorice tone down and the chocolate come out a little more. Maybe in year three!

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Awesome beer.  Theres really a lot going on here, and it makes your tongue, nose, and throat work hard to interpret it all.  I could have floated a quarter on the dense head.  And the rich color tells you that something tasty is about to hit you.

Great stout!! Aromas of chocolate licorice caramel and Malts. Pours a dark black with a tan head. The caramel chocolate flavor is second to none. Also great bite from the hops keeping everything well balanced  I would highly recommend this beer to anyone. 

---Cameron
Bottle pours dark taste chocolate sweet dark very good beer wish I had more

Pours dark black into a glass with tan colored head. Smells like chocolate, smoke and molasses. The flavor of molasses in this beer is one of my all-time favorites. The roasted malts are wonderful and add great balance and depth of flavor to the chocolate and smokey notes of the beer. One of my all-time favorite beers.

12oz bottle.
Pitch black pour with lots of tan head.  Aromas of coffee and dark fruit with tons of chocolate.  Flavor is very chocolatey as well with some smoke and a bitter finish.  Cant wait to see what some age does to this.

355 ml bottle @ Laiti.
Rated on 20101106.
Aroma of liquorice, dark roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla and coffee. Flavor of coffee, vanilla, caramel, liquorice, roasted malts and some hoppy fruits.

Pours a dark black with a brown head and aroma of malt and chocolate. Taste is sweet and smokey, of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and mocha with a nice, smooth and bitter finish. Great stout, a lot of flavor in this one.
Aroma is mostly boozy.  A typically beautiful looking imperial.  Hops are quite predominant, which I dont particularly like in beers, but the strong malt flavor balances it well.  Great brew.

Pours deep, dark and opaque black. Nice wispy mocha head. Aroma is hoppy and sweet. Taste is coffee, chocolate with some bitterness in between. Taste is full of flavor, which is the ultimate pinnacle. Finish is lasting. Great stout from a premier brewery. Quaff Score ( drinkability with hearty enjoyment ) 8 / 10

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 Bottle from Bells brewery, bottled Sept 2011.  Pours thick and black like motor oil, with a dark brown head.  Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, and some licorice.  Taste is "intense stout"... hard to describe beyond the usual terms: chocolate, coffee, earthy, etc.  Never sweet, with an intense bitter finish.  Big thick mouthful.  A good imperial stout, but I feel it could be better.  Will let my second bottle age for a year or two.  Update: after aging it for a year, opened my second bottle.  Taste was fantastic; would rate it a 10.  My score here reflects the average of my two tastings.

From notes.  First reviewed 1/26/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass. Batch 9435 (Nov. 11, 2009). Part of a side by side with Great Lakes Blackout Stout and Storm King.

This pours a thick mahogany color all the way through, with a surprisingly ruby and brown head that is creamy and huge. Solid retention, and lace splatters all over the glass.

This actually has sort of a subdued aroma. Raisins, espresso, roasted malt, cocoa, and a bit of spicy hops.

The taste flows so well together it confounds me. It starts with light chocolate and espresso flavors, which slowly build over the sip, but they encounter anise, sweet molasses, and roasted malt, before finally encountering some spicy and lightly earthy hops. The ABV sneaks through toward the end, impressive consider it is 10.5%. The finish has more espresso and a bit of molasses. The lingering aftertaste is a coffee bitterness.

There is a syrupy quality to this, but damn is it silky smooth. I cannot remember ever having a beer with this kind of silky feel. Syrupy, chewy, and very full bodied. 

With how insanely silky smooth this stout is, the taste could be bottle sludge and I would love it. Ok, maybe thats a little bit much, but the taste is damn solid. This beer definitely deserves its accolades.

Thanks Jeff for saving this for two years!  Extreme dark brown body with bubbles!  Sweet coffee aroma, elements of smoke, burnt marshmallow and soya sauce. Taste is the same! This is high quality shit! This is a massive beer, flavor everywhere. Bitter chocolate dominating finish.more soya sauce.more stuff with flavors that have names.  Roasted malts everywhere. Great beer!!! Thanks jeff

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter

Aroma: Smells of roasted malt, raisins, chocolate, and anise.

Appearance:  Dark tan two finger head, oily black beneath.

Taste: Slight chocolate roasted malt finishing in a pleasant burnt light caramel sweetness accented by the heat from the abundant alcohol. 

Palate:  Viscous and very creamy especially for an RIS. Appropriate level of carbonation.

Overall : A solid offering. Wish the flavors were a bit more bold and robust.

Bottle 33cl, nov 2011, black as hell. Aroma chocolate, coffee little bit of hops, vanilla. Appearance black oil min brown head. Tatse heavy, light bitter. Palate fulle bod, soft carbonation. Very good Stout!!!!!

Only brewed in the fall & winter of each year, this is one of Bells Brewerys most absolute potent stouts, and it has the flavor to back it up. I had my first taste of Expedition last October and I have been in heavy search of it wherever I go since. Dark and complex, this is a near-perfect beer (aside from some of the bitter aftertaste) that will delight the senses. Bells is one of the most diverse and consistent breweries in America, and this is one of their royalty.

Batch 10105. First time Ive tried this with some age to it. Pours the blackest black (super dark ruby if you can catch it in the light), with hardly any head: some brown that settles quickly to nothing. Nose is powerful: molasses, dark roast, some of the licorice, toffee, slight vanilla, chocolate, and some toast. Taste is nice and sweet but balanced. Palate is big, velvetty, smooth, sticky, solid. Ive had this fresh and the big hop bitterness and alcohol heat have subsided considerably after aging. I mean, hell, this is stellar. Happy Mardi Gras to me.

Bottled on 9/19/11. Poured into a sniffer, room temperature. Black with a finger of tan head that dissipates after a minute. Aroma of alcohol and roasted malt. To me the mouthfeel is kind of airy, does not coat the mouth like other imperial stouts I have had. Taste of roasted malt and alcohol. I really did not like it as much. Cant really explain why. I will let the other bottles I have sit for a couple of years and try it again. Should be better, I hope.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2012 Pours a viscous black with light head that just seems to stick around.  Faint nose of roasty coffee and dark chocolate flows into that first delightful sip:  thick malty liquid coats your tongue and brings forth flavors of rich chocolate, a hint of coffee and the tingling of citrus fruits.  Finish is long and strong and down to get the friction on.  Perfectly balanced and a body that could make a black malt blush.

Doesnt really taste like a Russian Imperial Stout

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nov. 2011. Bottle from Savvy1982 way back in February. Pours solid black. Tan head. Aromas of rich chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, burnt malts and dark chocolate. Taste is similar. Lots of mocha,burnt notes,chocolate and coffee. So smooth drinking, its dangerous.Bitter aftertaste. If I could buy this here, Id be broke.
Very solid Stout with coffee flavor.  Has all the characteristics you would like to see in a Stout, enjoy!
Great malty imperial stout. Very dark very smooth. Alot of coffee notes and roasted malt goodness.
bottle. pours thick black with massive red head. aroma of coffee nuts and burnt sugar. massive roasted nut flavor and slight bitter from hops

My favorite stout to date! Viscous enough to completely coat your entire mouth. Dark chocolate, black strap molasses, leather, coffee, toffee and vanilla creme pretty much sum up this brew.  You dont get the the heat either. Try it over some really good quality vanilla ice cream, I dare you to go back to rootbeer!

BOTTLE at Darkness Day 2011.
This bottle was 4 yr old. 
Roasted malts, chocolate, coffee. Full flavor.

Well I figured I should try something big while watching the Super Bowl. 2010 bottle into snifter. Pour thick and syrupy with almost no head, just a little reddish brown foam. Tons of awesome espresso and chocolate. A bit of molasses too. Finish is very distinct as it quickly turns a bit sweet of fruit. World class beer that lives up to the hype.

Pours a very dark motor oil-like brown with a medium creamy tan head.  In the glass, it appears opaque black.  The aroma is rich, smoky roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  The taste is a complex blend of bitter dark roasted malts, sweetened espresso, and dark chocolate.  The mouthfeel is very creamy and lasting.  Id like to try a vintage bottle to see how well the flavors have mellowed after a few years of aging, but its damn good when its fresh.

Bottle.  Pours black with a small brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and caramel.  Flavors of chocolate, coffee, caramel and dark fruits with a smokey hint.  Smooth finish and the alcohol is well hidden.  Great imperial stout.

Pitch black, opaque beer, creamy strong white head. Sweet malty aroma, coffee, milk chocolate, light vanilla, candied red cherries and fudge. Sweet malty flavour, some burned malts bitterness, roasted flavours. Reminding of Spanish cocoa. Thick silky, oily slick mouthfeel, malty roasted finish.
(From 35cL bottle shared with friends. Bottle from mikem409. Thanks!)

Weird I havent rated this. Batch 9554. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Nose is  chocolate, roasted malts with touches of dark fruit. Flavor is bitter chocolate, some coffee, dates and fig, some vanilla. Very rich and viscous. Light traces of alcohol.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2012 My 500th rating! RBAG 2012. Courtesy of Savvy. The morning after RBAG 2012 I just woke up and was cleaning up the house after hosting about 10 of Albertas finest citizens for what I am sure is one of the most magnificent beer tastings to ever happen in Wild Rose Country. I had a pot of coffee on the go and commented to Kyle that it was a shame some real gems would be going home unopened. Kyles generous response was to pop the cap off his Bells Expedition. So this became my breakfast and the perfect way to see off a very successful inaugural Ratebeer Alberta Gathering. Pours a midnight black with virtually no head. Surprisingly the head grew as it settled to a little less than a finger. The aroma is laced with dark chocolate, espresso, and charred firewood. The flavor has chocolate, a hint of vanilla and lots of dark roasted characteristics. The mouth feel is basically perfect. An excellent overall beer even if Im drinking it a little cool.

Black beer with foam tan head. Pine hop aroma mixed with some roasted malts. Bold burnt toast and licorice wrapped in oily leather. Good body and well balanced finish. Cant wait till this comes to Nevada.

Bottle. Med-low carbonation and thin, dark brown head. Dark caramel malt and resiny hops. Very sweet, but still balanced. No hot alcohol and little ester flavors. Huge body with a viscous, oily texture.

Bottle at Petrol Stations bottle share. Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head leaving sticky lacing along the glass. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a roasted malt chocolate and nice light bitter finish. Really enjoyed this one, an impressive imperial stout from Bells.

About as good as it gets for me, as far as imperial stouts that have not seen a the interior of a barrel go.  Chocolate, roasted coffee beans, resin, floral notes, dark dried fruits, and soy sauce are all present in the aroma.  The head actually rose several seconds after the pour ceased, a frothy brown pillow that took several minutes to recede.  The ale itself is deep brown, bordering on black.  Aromas are revisited upon tasting, which begins sweet but quickly turns bitter from what I presume is substantial hopping.  There may be some of that umami thing going on, as well.  It glides across the tongue effortlessly, full bodied, creamy, thick and sticky, it is softly carbonated, and finishes long and bitter.

Bottle. Pours gluggy black with a dark mocha head. Sharp vanilla and cocoa surround the aroma. Salted dark chocolate and a touch of burnt wood as well. Very sweet. Huge dark chocolate, salted peanuts and vanilla essence. Loads of sweet cocoa and a small touch of coffee. Thick and oily mouth feel but finishes a little too quickly for me. Very good either way

Pours like oil with a creamy brown head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is Smokey with notes of maple, chocolate and coffee. Taste is boozy with bitter chocolate, rich coffee and burnt wood. Finish is almost like that of a dry red wine.

Bottle.  Pitch black, very syrupy with a thin brown head.  Sweet aroma of raisins, coffee, smoke, chocolate.  Taste is sweet, bitter, with coffee, roasted/burnt malts, and smoke.  Ends with a strong roasted bitterness.  Very full bodied, oily/creamy, with soft carbonation.
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2012 12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Standard stout aroma of coffee and chocolate with a hint of malts.  Taste is the same.  Love this beer

From a bottle I purchased at RBWG 2011 in Phoenix.Pours as black as the night with a frothy yet subtle quickly dissipating tanned leather head that leaves a nice little ring around the edges. Coffee and chocolate notes with a hint of molasses and brown sugar. Fantastic taste. Chocolate and coffee with molasses. Palate is nice. Thick with sweetness that gives way to a stinging bitterness.

Bottle @ bir & fud bottega.
First of all, if you are a brewer or own a brewery, be my guest, and try to clone this beer if you want, but you are inevitably going to fail. Thats a masterpiece. my perfect 100th rate (and ive been thinking A LOT what beer could be the chosen one. The beels 10000 would have been just a practical joke of mine)
appearance: wow...used motor oil, black solid color, brown tall rocky/creamy cappucino head. Aroma: OMG! Extremely intense roasted malt. chocolate, coffee, coffee sediments strong herbal notes, a little bit of vanilla, even some hops. Taste: WTFAYKM? this beer is a punch in the face. the roastiness prevails all the rest but youll never get annoyed. also a lot of coffee and cocoa beans, dark fruit, herbs (erica) and hops.Full body, Intense mouth feel and bitter finish. Not so easily drinkable as the KBS for instance but definitely enjoyable. unbelievably the booziness remains almost hidden in the background
It seemed to me a roasted version of the Kaggen! or a better balance Darkness. I left just 0.2 point because i can only imagine what the BA or coffee version of this beer may be.

Thx to polomagnifico !! 
Head: huge, thick creamy espresso head 
Colour: black 
Smell: alcohol, lots of roasted malts, bit of coffee, lots of dark chocolat, somewhat bit grassy hops, spicey 
Taste: start is very bitter, lots of roasted malts and coffee biterness in the start, then comes a more boozey "hot chocolat" taste based with some nuts, after comes a hopy fruity taste , end is very dry with an earthy aftertaste , nice !

Bottle- Pours a deep brown color with a nice tan head and lots of lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, bit of chocolate sweetness, trace of vanilla and dark fruit. No hint of the alcohol. Taste starts with bittersweet chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. There is an earthy bitterness that lingers just a bit. Full body, smooth and very well balanced. As it warms it seems to develop more character. Excellent sipper. The perfect beer on a cold winter night.

1 year old beer that pours dark brown, medium fine head,  a good looking stout. Aroma up front  is malty dark fruit with strong alcohol, the roasted malts come in at the end.
Taste is a huge mouthfeel, this is a big ass beer, malty, alcohol, some sharpness which is a warming alcohol. With hop flavor as well. Roasted malts which go very well with chocolate desserts.  I have this as a desert beer with chocolate ice cream or desserts often. try this with Ben and Jerrys New York Super fudge chunk.
Great beer one of the top ten I have had made in the US if not the world.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2013 A - pours deep brown with 2 finger deep tan head. T - Aromas of burned malts,coffee, toffee, caramel, cinnamon, and some bourbon. M- syrupy strong body with low carb. T - Tastes of dark chocolate/bittersweet chocolate on the nose. toasted malts light bourbon caramel toffee. Chocolate toffee caramel malts and dried fruits on the palate, nice lightly bitter floral hoppy ending. O - Good complex stout with nice bitter hoppy ending 9-

Roasted malt aroma with a sweetness about it. Chocolate and slight vanilla as well. Opaque black with brown head.  Roast throughout. Chocolate. Very nice bitterness balancing well with the roast and malt. Full mouthfeel fallows through on the finish with floral. Alcohol is pronounced at the finish.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a beautiful beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, light smoke and vanilla. Quite heavy flavour of roasted malts, vanilla, smoke and ash. Quite heavy hops as well, but it doesnt come through too much. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel with a long, rich and roasty finish. Excellent.

355ml bottle from Cracked Kettle

Pours pitch black with a light brown head. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, vanilla, oak, chocolate and wood. Taste is slick and smooth with roasty and vanilla notes. Finish is slightly bitter, roasty and warming with dry and sticky notes. Well balanced and tasty imperial stout.

Bottle 355 ml. Pours as black as it gets with a minimal head. Aroma contains roasted notes, chocolate, coffe and raisins. Taste is complex with chocolate, coffee and raisins with a balanced level of bitterness. Fantastic Imperial Stout.

A beautiful, pitch black pour with a creamy brown head and excellent lacing.  The slightly roasted aroma is full of malty dark chocolate.  The full body has a silky texture with average carbonation.  It has a roasted taste that is not overpowering, followed by a smooth finish.  The high alcohol is completely hidden.  This beer is amazing.

On the ninth day of Christmas 2011.  Pours deep dark black with a reddish brown head.  Aroma is dark fruit, roasted coffee, caramel and dark chocolate.  Taste is sweet with roasty bitters.  Medium mouthfeel with a sticky texture.
Perfect balance between hopiness and the original taste of chocolate, makes it perfect even on sunny day. Beautiful product!
Excellent hoppiness, pronounced, but mellow with chocolate smokimess. Outstanding drinkability.

12oz bottle.  Ive had this beer on numerous occasions but have never rated it.  Deep darkest shade of brown-black.  Massive creamy beige head.  Wow.  Really nails it.  Big-time chocolate notes, rich and creamy.  This really is a great example of the style, on the better beers out there for sure.  Dessert in a glass, rich, bold, thick body.  Perfectly executed, this one raised the bar.
I loved this stout. Dark fruit flavors, slight raisin, and prune flavors with a deep nuttiness. Malt body on this one was very full. An incredible experience.

35cl bottle 3 years old shared with friends.
brown head.  deep treacle colour.  Gorgeous!!!  Very smooth
Pours pitch black, thin head.  Roasted malt nose, with some coffee.  Very complex taste, has lots of roasted malt taking on coffee.  Seems to have kind of a dark fruit finish.  Fantastic beer.
Good stuff!!! Great smoky taste of caramel, chocolate. Big taste from start to finish. Another big win from Bells!!!

12oz bottle.  Must let it warm up to really enjoy.  Pitch black pour with nice thick Mocha head and some nice legs for the style.  Nose is all the usual suspects like coffee, molasses, and chocolate.  A tad bit metallic.  Taste follows the nose and really improves as it warms up and breaths a bit.  Pretty damn good.

This beer lives up to the hype...well balanced between the sweetness of carmel and chocolate, and the smokey taste of roasted coffee beans and toffee. Not much of an alcohol burn. Nice lacing and an excellent looking beer in the glass. Highly recommended and at a reasonable price.

Beautiful black pour with a fine chocolately foam head. Aroma primarily of coffee with hints of chocolate, toffee, some faint smokiness and a little alcohol. Heavy body with moderate carbonation. Nice complex mix of flavors that really hang in there. Begins somewhat like bitter dark chocolate with perhaps just a touch of anise. Then comes a short slightly sweet almost caramel taste with a little smokiness at this point. Then a touch of hop bitterness comes through for a bit right before finishing off with some mild alcohol warmth which lingers for a bit. This part is not overwhelming, but the nicely hidden alcohol does make its presence felt. An excellent well balanced stout with a nice complexity of flavors.

Pours black with low head.
Aromas of coffee, hints of chocolate. Burned oakiness.
Palate is creamy with great bitter ending. Filld your mouth perfectly.
Taste almost the same as aroma. Feels very naturally brewed. Great stout!

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2013 Re rate: pours black as night with awesome dark brown head. Thick. Aromas are black licorice, dark chocolate, dark chocolate liquor, malts. Flavours are some smoke, dark chocolate, a bit of strong coffee, and hops at the end. What a great beer.

An opaque black beer with a medium tan head.  The aroma is anise, wood, and alcohol, but also some fruit and floral hops.  The flavor is wood, vanilla, and lots of alcohol with a floral finish.  Great body but a little strong alcohol flavor.

Black colored with little beige head. Rich roasted, licoricy, vanilla, strong roasted-coffee, vinous and slight alcohol notes in excellent aroma. Full bodied, velvety-creamy palate. Strongly roasted flavor with coffee beans, vinous note, dark chocolate and mild alcohol here too. Straightforward, excellent IS.

Bottle to tulip glass. Notes of coffee and chocolate on the nose. Also hints of booziness. I absolutely love this aroma. The pour is a dark black color with a small beige head.  Taste has a nice  bitterness, much similar to dark chocolate. Heavy body with medium carbonation. 

I really like this beer. It is actually the first time Ive had this beer and I love it.

Pours as close to black as you get.  Rich appearance with limited tan head that dissipates quickly.  Lot of caramel, chocolate, and roasted coffee.  Very smooth, sweet taste.  Even finish.  Top notch stout.  Right on par with Founder B-Fast stout.

1. Look  A black color stout with a large frothy brown head.
2. Sniff  This imperial stout has a intense chocolaty nose and roasted malt aroma as well.
3. Sip  This full bodied stout has a warming mouth feel with a bold chocolate flavor that is mildly sweet.  Also, there is a soft bitterness finish and alcohol taste, but for the most part the alcohol is disguised well. 
4. Another Look  This is an excellent looking stout with a long lasting head and great lacing.  
5. Evaluate  Overall, this is a great beer for the winter months.  It has a many bold flavors and packs a punch.  I would absolutely recommend this stout to those who can enjoy and appreciate huge beers and are fans of the imperial stout style.  I think I may have found a go to imperial stout for the foreseeable future.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2012 Pours a black velvet with a thin head.  Smells like roasted coffee beans with alcohol.  Full bodied, thick and slightly bubbly mouthfeel.  Very roasted flavor with coffee and I can tell a lot of alcohol is present but not in a bad way.  This is truely an amazing stout and definitely in my top 10 beers Ive ever tasted!
Remarkable.  That is nearly all that can be said about this sublime stout.  Words cant describe it, go find some!

10 oz pour from Craft Ale House. Black as night with a thick mocha head...looks like a winner for sure. Digging your nose(lines are slightly cold) in the glass brings out dark fruit, turbanado sugar, and roasted malts. One of the great American imperial stouts for sure...perfect full body filled with a complex pairing of sweet dark fruits and a variety of roasted malts. A perfect addition to the cellar, no doubt.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2011 Its simultaneously robust and subtle.  Thick and creamy.  Notes of black liquorice and chocolate.  Medium bitterness with a short sustain.  Its on the sweet side for an Imperial stout.  Very good.

Pours pitch black with a small white head and a little bit of lacing. Aromas are licorice, alcohol, and chocolate. The taste is sweet dark chocolate, tobacco, cherries, and a touch of hops. The mouthfeel is creamy and delicious. Its an amazing beer. Its not too bitter, a little sweet, just a great stout. One of the best Ive ever had.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. Very dark with a nice head. Beautiful mahogany colour. Sweet and hoppy. A lot of depth.

Black pour with a foamy tan head that persists.  Aroma of molasses, coffee, toffee and a whiff of spice.  Initial flavor of chocolate and dark fruit quickly followed by a substantial lingering bitterness.  Thick mouthfeel with subdued carbination.  Noticeable astringency and ethanol heat.  An excellent stout that should mellow and gain complexity as it ages.  A stout to brood over.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2015 2011 rating. Bottle. Dark black colour with chocolate-milk-thick-brown head. Roasted aroma, citrus. Taste is coffee and hops, roasted malts, a little sweet, dried fruit, caramel. Excellent stuff. Re-rate 2015. 2011 bottle. Dark chocolate and cherries. Dark roast. Thick creamy malt. Nice.

Poured a dark black color from a a12 ounce bottle.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate, caramel and booze.  Flavors are a nice balance of the aromas, where one is not overpowering the the other, also had an added flavor of roasted malt.

Pours deep black, tan head, good lacing.  Aromas of chocolate, soy, and mild vanilla.  Sweet, malty,  light alcohol, mild bitterness. Big beer.  Overall, great sipping beer.  Nice big flavor and warms the tummy, but alcohol hidden fairly well.  Another good one from Bells.

Bottle,  batch 10699. Pours jet black with slight head and lacing, nose is coffee,  slight fruity ketones and roasted barley. Firs sip is bittersweet chocolate, malt, and other roasted flavors, finish is slightly bitter. Great beer.

Nice aroma of coffee, choco, roastiness and some fruit. Pours opaque black with thin head. Quite sweet, with roastiness. Alcohol is prominent as well as a strong vanilla finish. A good beer but could probably use a couple of years in the cellar.

A really good beer.  A really expensive beer too.  Not too bad, it can be cellared, so the initial price of 16 dollars spreads itself out.  10.5 percent makes it a heavy hitter.  That being said, it reminds me a lot of the Java Stout.  Mostly coffee, a little bit of burnt and charcoal ash flavor.  I think there is also some dark fruit and vanilla in there.  The hops are barely noticable.  Its aroma and flavor are very complex, makes a lovely beer and its easy to let it cellar!

Bottle @ home. Aroma is molasses, deep roast, nuts and some hops. A bit musky. Flavour is sweet, but not cloying, loads of molasses with a subtle spicy sidenote, hard to describe, but very nice. Also notes of chocolate, tobacco and hops. Nice one.

Bottle, thanks for sharing dEnk! Pitch black pour, solid tan to dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, freshly baked bread, fresh fruits and fresh floral hops. Flavor is quite sweet, roasty and somewhat strangely fruity. Very nice balance. Very decent stout.

Amazing coffee and chocolate aromas, roast malts, coffee, caramel, rich and slightly sweet, touch of booze.  Pours inky black, massive tan/brown head with great retention, leaves plenty of lacing.  Flavor is near perfection - rich malt and chocolate with moderate sweetness, balanced with just the right amount of hop bitterness, alcohol, and carbonation to keep it from being overly sweet.  Roast and coffee with minimal astringency, velvety chocolate flavors are outstanding, a bit of warm alcohol in the finish.  Full body, medium carbonation, silky mouthfeel.  Amazing stout - love that I can get this off the shelf year-round.

Pours jet black with a beautiful chocolate head, smells of chocolate, coffee, cherries, sticky dark fruits, brown sugar and a bit of alcohol, taste follows the nose, quite a lot of complex flavors but they meld together well, its like a team of all-stars that work great together. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, slightly warming due to the booze, overall this beer is nearly flawless and is one of the best stouts Ive ever had.

The following review is of a 2 year old bottle

Aroma is of molasses, burnt sugar and tons of roasted malt. Also some prune/fig and a hint of soy sauce. Finishes with a bit of hops and some alcohol but the aging helps damper that. 

Appearance is pretty lackluster. When first poured, produced about half inch head but quickly disappeared. Body is pitch black and lacing never appeared.

Taste is pretty good. First flavors are sweet molasses, burnt malt and some espresso.  For almost 11 percent, alcohol is present, nice and warming almost like a port wine but not as complex. Finishes with some chocolate covered raisins and slight bitterness.

Palate is above average. Carbonation is good, just enough to level out the thickness of the beer making it not so syrupy. Only complaint is that there was no head throughout the beer which is a pet peeve of mine.

Overall this is a pretty good beer. Wasnt overly impressed with it when I tried a 10 month old version acouple years ago, but two years aging definitely smoothed it out. Too bad its not available in Colorado, not quite good enough to go outta my way and trade for it.

Served on-tap at Als of Hampden into a nonic pint.
A - Pours dark as can be with a thick, pillowy, one finger head, dissipating down to a thick film of head, leaving thick rings of lacing down the glass.
S - Rich, chocolatey, nose with a bit of lightly roasted dark malt. Chocolate is quite bitter but not to the point of being overpowering. A bit on the sweeter side compared to others in the style. More and more roast comes thru as it begins to warm.
T - Lots of dark, roasty, flavors in this one. Plenty of bitter chocolate up front giving way slowly to a mix of sweetness and rich roasty malt. Finish is very roasty that lingers long after consumption. Alcohol is ever present, unable to hide in the shadows for long, offering a warming sensation on finish. Not the best I have had but still very nice.
M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Fairly creamy feel with a very nice balance of flavors.
D - Fairly high. I really like this one a lot but it can become overpowering after the first glass. I could have one or two of these but that would be about all.

you are a delight! Ive only read about Bell beers b/c they dont distribute here, and now Im mad, because I want more. Like theres some extra ingredient.... CRACK! Thats it. Crack.Sweet, smooth aroma, has some gentle sweetness on the nose, followed my something a shade shy of smoke; something gentle like peet. A cool mouth feel for a stout, considerably so, but in a refreshing manor that gives way to the sweet maltiness, with ever-so-slight dark cherry hints. A slight lacto-middle; creamy and smooth, and then leaves you with hardly any bitter at the end that so many stouts out kick their coverage with. great stout. great. Thanks God,... and Michigan

Black with super creamy brown head. Nose of coffee, licorice, dark dried fruits. Viscous and perfectly carbonated. Tastes of more coffee that gives way to plums, dark cherries, figs. With each sip it evolves for the better. Lasting slightly boozey finish, with all the flavors Ive grown to love in the taste. Epic.
A near perfect stout in my opinion, the head is good looking, with a tast to match the aroma and the gravity to statisfy

Bottle from andersons general store. Pours black with a half inch of luxuriant khaki foam. Silky mouthfeel. A bit of raisin on the nose. On the tongue the maltiness is incredibly rich balanced out by a nice amount of bitterness. This is a big beer, one to savor next to the fire.

On tap at Bells Eccentric Cafe. Pours very dark with no head and excellent retention. Love that super dark promise! Aroma is anise, overripe fruit, sweet fruits. Very vinious/grapey. Taste is syrupy thick. Licorice, molasses, fruit, bakers chocolate. Some alcohol presence. Finishes smooth with a lot thickness and multiple layers & flavors. It is a very nice beer with a lot of complexity - perhaps too complex for me to fully appreciate.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2017 re-re-re-re 2/17.  stand by the 4.6.  greatness  2 years of aging                     re-re-rerate 03/15  another 12/27/12 bottle.....love this stuff.  dropped aroma to 8 - more alcohol than anything.  perfect scores for app and palate.  9/10 for taste and 19/20 overall.  just GREAT stuff....loveit!..overall went from 4.5 to 4.6..........................................Re rate 1/15. Bottle was 2012 so 2 years old. That is the sweet spot.  Left rating at 4.5. Impossible to have a better palate. Taste is wonderfully complex drinking it warm. Alcohol slightly noticeable and blended perfectly..................11/14 rerate  bottle dated 7/13 - bumped UP from 4.2.     damn near perfection  5 for palate and app.  9 for aroma and taste.   just a great blend of roasted malt coffee and chocolate in both aroma and taste.  no carbonation; creamy...  maybe a tad much bitterness (coffee or hops) at end - will let age a few more months but wowowow!!............................... in PHX; wow - great beer - aroma of dark chocolate and roasted malts; darrrrrk pour - great (5 of 5) thick palate - flavor like aroma with hops to balance.  want more!!                                                                                                                         
                                                                                      re-rate 11/2011 had one in cellar for 1+ year - bumped slightlyfrom to 4.2 - great stuff.  aroma has everything - plenty of roasted stuff, chocolate, a little vanilla, slight alcohol.

Bottle.  Chocolate, coffee, and peat aroma. Black brown, small brown head, and nice lacing.  Very complex flavor. In the first sip I detected anise, which faded into chocolate, coffee, cream, and then finished with a slight hops bitterness.  Full bodied and creamy, slightly dry finish.  Top notch imperial stout!

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  Very strong abv taste, along with licorice and chocolate.  Completely black and with a decent foam head.  You really have to take this one slow since its such a potent taste.  It was an adventure drinking it, but I dont think Ill take this expedition again.  It tasted a little too much like hard liquor.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 36cl, as Bells Expedition Stout, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex Stout, roasted/bitter and slightly fruity/sweet, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, good head, top class!, yet expensive!

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2013 Growler (02/22/2013) pours opaque black with creamy dark beige head and decent lacing. Nose is coffee, milk chocolate, alcohol and dark fruit. Flavor adds roast and resin. Very dry. Complex bitterness and light sweetness. A sipper of a beer. 

(re-rated due to lost notes from 2010)  bottle in a pint glass.  pours black with brown head and providing lacing.  Nose is hops and plums.  Aroma is chocolate/coffee malts, hops galore (resin), alcohol and way roasted malts.  Finishes very dry.  Taste is bitter and sweet.  Feel is thick and almost gritty.  Aftertaste is coffee grinds.  Definitely a sipping beer that needs to be accompanied with food.  Very powerful.  9/4/8/3/14 3.8 on 9/27/2011

12 oz from Cameron "The Beard" Bishop in Tenn.  Opened in San Diego into sniffer.  Smells like dark chocolate and strong.  Looks very thick and black.  Brown small head.  Tastes clean thick and dark chocolate at first then a light complimenting hop bite.  Oh my gosh the chocolate malts!  Some coffee mocha thickness.  Overall 9.5 of 10.  Such a good double stout!

Bottle, huge thanks to thome50, packaged Jan. 27th 2010.  The beer pours dark reddish brown and viscous, black and opaque in the glass, with a small, creamy dark brown head that recedes to leave a thin ring of mocha lacing around the edge.  The aromas are oak, light bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, port, dark fruit, and plum/raisin/toffee.  The flavor is toasted oak and bourbon, sweet toffee and sugar cane, cocoa, lightly tart berry and raisin, and plums.  The finish brings buttered toast and jam, mocha, bitter coffee grounds, tobacco, and alcohol.  This is rich, with a thick mouthfeel; creamy and warming.  Really, really delicious, very complex, and a great sipper.  Thanks man!  [813]
La perfezione delle imperial stout. Cosaltro volere di più? Averne unaltra subito.

Bottle to pint glass. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Appearance dark black with rich golden brown head. Taste of roasted malts, slightly sweet too. Palate was clean and smooth with slight carbonation at first. Overall very tasty and appealing Imperial Stout, absolutely worth a second and third helping!
loads of chocolate in the aroma and flavour. coffee was noticable as well. some alcohol burn. very creamy. loved it

Maybe had a bad bottle... This one didnt live up to hype... Smell was ok, appearance was jet black, taste was just horrible.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Date: September 6, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Casanova, Hudson, WI Appearance: Opaque black, slight head and lacing. Aroma: Roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, thick bodied, and an alcohol and bitter finish. Other: This is a big, bold in your face beer and well done.  I think it might even be better if I let age, so will have to try again.

Another solid beer from Bells. Part of my love for this beer is that I can find it all year long. The only slight detractor is that at $16 a 6 pack its a touch pricey. Pours a nice silky black with off white head. The nose is hoppy and malty when fresh and malty to bready when aged. When fresh I do not find this beer to be at its best, if really seems to balance out IMO after about 8-18 months. If your new to the world of stouts and can find a single of this I highly recommend picking a bottle up and taking the journey!

This is the best imperial stout Ive tasted.  It pours almost black with a small tan head, and a think oily texture. Very rich and strong aromas, a lot of roasted malts with a lot of coffee balance with some hops.  The flavors do mirror the aromas, but are stronger.  There is some roasty malt, some cocoa and a lot of coffee flavor.  There is a quick hint of hops on the finish, which balances the flavors perfectly.  The body is very thick, this is a very well done beer.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2016 Third update... Pours a beautiful black with low tan head. Aroma is wonderfully complex, chocolate and coffee, molasses and dried fruit, roasted malt and German sausage. Taste is mellow sweet with a long and lingering complex finish thats initially bitter and then sweet. Rich and creamy body with soft carbonation.

Pours black with about a finger and a half of foamy, beige head.  Brown sugar and burnt toast in the nose.  Very sweet taste, maple syrup with some dark fruit that goes into a sort of syrupy bitterness aftertaste.  Strong hint of alcohol throughout.  Its practically an imperial stout with how thick it is.  Its good if thats what youre looking for.

Please start export this to Sweden, Bells. Pours a thick black with a oily brown head. Flavour is packed with dark chocolate along with some smooth coffee notes, a bit of caramel and a hint of red berries. Medium-strong but smooth roastiness that follows through from the first sip to long after youve finished the beer. Theres a very quick notion of chocolatey sweetness before the roasty bitterness takes over completely and builds up itself. There is no alcohol in the flavour whatsoever, only a very slight warming sensation which makes this beer very drinkable. I still took over an hour to finish a 12 oz bottle but only because I wanted the goodness to last for as long as possible. Just a notch above almost every imperial stout Ive ever tried.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2015 The beer pours a deep black and develops no more than a finger of milk-chocolate head. The aroma is massive amounts of chocolate and bold hoppage. For a beer whose ABV is in the double digits, the Expedition Stout restrains its own alcohol character so well that, were it not for the warming sensation you get a few minutes after you drink the whole thing, you wouldnt even know you were drinking alcohol. The taste is bitter and sour, with some sweet character coming from the exquisite chocolate notes. The hops and the roasted malts really come through, but the protagonist here is the chocolate. The palate is extremely creamy, with soft, delicate carbonation and a thick body that doesnt feel oilyjust extremely pleasant. As the beer goes down, surprisingly, the alcohol doesnt show upits just bitter and delicious, and it leaves a sour sensation all over your mouth. Quite an intense brew, more so than many other impy stouts. I love it and wish Bells distributed it to Texas.

This was really good, Real thick and dark, big huge malts and toffee. Also had nice coffee and chocolate flavors. Had a very bitter finish to it which was just a little too much, and pulls this one down a couple notches for me.

12oz bottle from Picks poured into a snifter. Batch 9554.

Pours a dark black with a small amount of dark brown head. Aroma is very malty. Chocolate, coffee and caramel. Slight bitter hop aroma. Taste is light sweet and light sour and medium-heavy bitter. You can taste the chocolate and coffee very strongly. Full bodied with a thick creamy texture. Soft carbonation and a long, bitter and alcohol strong finish. Overall, this is a damn good stout. I can see why it rates 100. Definitely something I will drink again when the temperature outside cools off.
UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Very roasty..... not too boozy..... very well balanced. This is a great beer.

Aroma of chocolate, dark coffee, a salty sea smell and roast.  This is.going to be heavy.  Wow.  Tastes of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and a salty sour hop taste that dominates.  This is truly an exceptional stout.

Note: Bottle is from 9/08.
Ar: Licorice, raisins, dark malt and currants.
Ap: Deep, opaque black with brown highlights - very minimal brown coffee colored head with little retention except for a thin brown ring.
T: Deep dark fruit profile up front - raisins, currants, plums - also some orange - sweet roasty flavors then take over, with coffee, ash and some soy sauce. Finish is warm alcohol and spicy hops with a nice grip of bitterness. A touch of sherry is noticable on the finish as well.
P: Oily and rich with substantial mouthfeel - yet finish is relatively dry.
O: A Russian Imperial Stout deserving of its status as a benchmark, and prototype, for the style; complex, luscious, and pretty to look at.

Courtesy of fonefan. Black with a big dark brown head. Aroma is quite sweet, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla and alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter finish. 260711
Bottle from FOneFan. Black with small brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, liquorice, vinous, bitter, thick and a little burned malt.
Bottle courtesy fonefan. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, coffee, chocolate and hops.

Aroma Black with minimal brown head. 
Appearance: Chocolate and coffee aroma. 
Taste: Chocolate and coffee again, some roast. Sweet but well balanced with significant hop bitterness. Some bread maybe.
Palate: Full, thick and creamy. Very light carbonation. Very long finish
Overall: Nicely complex and assertive. Great for a cold night.

RBSG 2010. It is black. ooooooo. Incredibly oatmeally, dark fruit, thick everything, cherry, meat, huge chocolate, roasted malts, booze, molasses. The taste is creamy and big dark fruit, solid citrus, chocolate, raisins and background coffee, milk chocolate, solid bitterness, licorice, slight ash, maybe mocha. Big and smooth with a permanent finish.

Black pour with a generous creamy, tan head. Dies down a little, but its hanging in there. Leaves a little bit of lacing in its wake. Big chocolate and caramel aroma. Roasted grains and coffee. Caramel and vanilla in the taste department too. Sweet roastiness. A slightly bitter backend. Chocolate throughout. Alcohol is hidden very well. Very good beer.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 Bottle.  Pours a thick black with a small tan head that goes to a ring rather quickly.  Smells of dark roasted malts, sweet and dark chocolate, coffee and a little alcohol.  The taste is medium bitterness with a wallop of roasted dark malts, coffee and a bit a chocolate.    Absolutely a great beer and I appreciate it even more that it is readily available.

At MesandSims for my 1000th tasting. Up against some very stiff competition in this category (and indeed this evening), this isnt the best in my opinion but this is still a truly great beer. Easy to drink but well worth savouring. Masses lof lovely chocolate malt, vanilla, less coffee tyan some of its style. Not saying thats a bad thing. Its beautiful. Stunning.

Pours black with a medium brown head. Aroma is roasted malt with chocolate, toffee, and caramel notes. Flavor is bold and complex: dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, toffee, roasted malt, biscuits, wood, charcoal, and underlying hints of alcohol. Medium to heavy bodied with a warm, smooth mouthfeel.
