Amazing brew.

Pours an oily black with just a bit of head and no real notable lacing. Smells of chocolate, light roasted malts, and coffee. Taste follows the nose. Nice chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, hop bitterness. High ABV is fairly well hidden. Thick and lightly carbonated but goes down pretty well for a thick brew. Drinkability is fairly high for the style. I could drink a few of these before the ABV catches up.
Pours black as night.  Gorgeous head with exceptional retention.  Very complex flavors that do the nose complete justice.  Continues to be a favorite.

Black pour with a than head. Thick consistancy. Aroma of coffee and dark chocolate. Heavy and bold flavor of coffee, chocolate, dark fruits and roasted malts. Very good and outstanding with nearly 11% alcohol.

Süßlicher Malzgeruch. Das Bier ist klebrig, honigartige Aromen verbinden sich mit der voluminösen Malzigkeit, dabei schmeckt es leider auch leicht alkoholisch, was jedoch weniger stört. Im Nachgeschmack weiterhin sehr malzig. 	 
Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 12,12,9,14,10,12 - 11,75

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Totalement noir avec une tête brune mocha texture lait frappé. Les premières arômes nous préparent à une présence goudronnée dominante. Dès la première gorgée, le chocolat au lait envahi nos papilles, rapidement tabassé par le cuir, le tabac et la mélasse jusquà lamertume du houblon. Le tout est complexe mais bien fusionné. En bouche cest visqueux, épais et couvre le palais jusquà ce que leffervescence active nettoie les dégâts. La finale fumée donne une tournure vraiment intéressante. Impressionnant et unique.
very good, recommended, oily, thick, very sweet, bitter, cereal, bready, molasses, dark, mahogany, headless, Thick pour, nice carbonation with a pleasant mouth feel.

12 oz Bottle @ Liberty Street Tavern, Allentown, PA.  Pored into a pint glass. Pitch black, small tan head with some decent lace. Aroma of rich roasted malt, chocolate and light coffee.Sweet chocolate/roasted malt flavor. So much roasted flavors that it is sweet. Finish is light alcohol, lightly bitter, and light dryness. Lively carbonation with a smooth creamy mouthfeel. Over all a lot going on in this stout, has complexity and very drinkable for the high ABV. It went down easy for me. If you are a stout lover, get your hands on a bottle of this!  I would drink this stout any day of the week.

Pour is jet black with a coffee colored head. Nose is of chocolate and some malty tones, though rather nondescript. Taste is of coffee notes with a light chocolate taste. Not a 10%+ taste or feel at all.
Alot going on here. There is an oakyness to it and it is really black. Fizzy, but enjoyable. This one really open up your nose. Seriously a lot is going on here. Roasty and Toasty.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle. It pours jet black with a thin fizzy tan head. The nose is cherry, beef gravy, toffee, caramel, horlicks, milk chocolate, biscuit and sesame seed. The taste is wood, charcoal, liquorice, burnt sugar, sesame seed, caramel, toffee, astringent, dark chocolate, molasses, treacle and tobacco, with a long roasty-bitter finish. It is sticky, viscous and has alcohol warmth in the finish. It is overall a bit too savoury for me, I would have preferred some more sweetness to come through to balance the bitterness for this style. Decent, but in my opinion doesnt live up to the massive hype.

[355ml bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] Black, with a deep brown head. Roasty aromas of rich alcohol, together with a sweet oaky, bourbon edge. Thick, chewy imperial on the palate from start to finish  really roasty at the end, with almost a peppery finish. Very well-balanced coffee and bitter malt flavours throughout. Very nice indeed, I can see why this is so highly praised [02062011]
Pours from the bottle an oily black with a thick tan head. The hop bitterness is in perfect balance with the whisky finish. Dark chocolate notes and not too sweet for the abv. A lovely beer.

2 June 2011, bottle at one of CGarvieuks legendary tastings! black, syrupy and thick frothy head. lovely aroma! smells more like a barley wine than a stout. sweet, oaky, and bourbon. full body and syrupy. really is more of a barley wine. not dry and bitter like a stout. very sweet and syrupy. there is certainly a bitter dark chocolate finish but the front is delicious and bourbony sweet!

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2012 Bottle. Pitch black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma: chocolate, roasted malt, licorice. Taste: chocolate, coffee, licorice, some salt/soy sauce, medium bitter, liqueurish, some kind of candy. Full-bodied, soft, liqueurish. Really nice and balanced. 
2010 bottle, had Nov 2012, thanks tstockstrom!.
Aroma: chocolate pralines, moccha and coffee, creamy.
Taste: chocolate mousse, licorice, both Bassets Allsorts and light salmiak, creamy, dried fruits.
Full bodied, quite high carbonation.
Great, great stuff!

Bottle. Pours a deep black with slight hints of red. The head is a medium brown that dissipates rapidly. Smell is big of booze, chocolate, coffee and hints of dark toffee. The flavor is definitely similar with lots of dark toffee, chocolate and a velvety smooth mouthfeel. Lots of coffee and burnt toast linger as I swallow with the slightest hint of a chocolate covered cherries. Really a great beer.

Imperial stouts are my favorite style so I was very happy to get a bottle of this.  I definitely enjoyed the bottle but i have had many better beers of this style.  Poured exactly how you would expect an Imperial stout to look.  The taste was very rich with a surprisingly nutty finish.  There was something a bit off to me about the taste.  I got a strange buttery flavor and not much roasted character.  Im looking forward to trying my second bottle to see if I had a bottle that was a bit off.  I still enjoyed it just a bit less then expected.

Bottle from the brewery. Poured dark black with dark tan head. Very unique imperial stout. Strong malty backbone with notes of alcohol in the taste. Very drinkable for the high abv. Will have more for sure.

Bottle pictured. It poured a nice creamy/oily black colour, nice dark head to compliment the dark malts. The taste of this one was really nice it was really quite something. Very drinkable. Will have more of this one.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2011 The depths of this stout seems to know no bounds.  Thick, rich, and 400 calories a bottle, Expedition Stout is a meal in and of itself, a chunky and viscous of a beer as you can find.  Chocolate and coffee and dried cherries meet up somewhere in the middle of a field of toasty hops.  I think.  By the time I had the flavor figured out, the ten percent ABV kicked in, and I forgot what I was doing and watched What About Bob? instead.  (10/08)

This baby is what they were thinking about when they coined the term stout. If youre a stout fancier its right up your alley, but its not for the dilettante or faint of heart. Has a BIG flavor, Will put hair on your chest. I love it, but no more than 2 at a time.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2014 Bottle at Monks Porterhouse, Stockhom.  Pours black with dark tan head.  Full aroma with chocolate, coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor matching with some vanilla.  Complex and beautifully balanced beer and one of the best imperial stouts I have tried. (Rate offline 2011/04/20)

Draft at Mellow Mushroom in Myrtle Beach - Pours a very dark and thick black brown in color with a small dark tan head that stuck around to produce a decent amount of lacing on the glass,  Aroma is of darkly roasted malts, plenty of chocolate and some espresso.  Flavor is heavy of the chocolate with coffee in the background.  Some lingering woody notes and, surprisingly, not very bitter at all.  Palate is very smooth... one of the most amazing I have experienced, actually.  This is a truly awesome beer!!

12 oz bottle from Horrocks Farm Market in Lansing, batch #10105. Served in a tulip. Pours dense black with a small-medium tan head. The head fades to a small remnant and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The nose has huge notes of roasted malts, along with chocolate, whiskey, smoke, caramel, molasses, earth, peat and a touch of espresso. The flavour is moderately sweet, with chocolate and caramel coming through. The malts are very complex, carrying through many elements from the aroma. It is sweet and roasty, with caramel, chocolate, dark fruit, earth and piney bitter elements. The finish is incredibly long, with roasty and surprisingly bitter notes. Overall, this is one of the best imperial stouts out there. Well balance and very complex with a beautiful malt profile. I wish I had a few more bottles to age! 2011-05-19

Bottle This beer is top notch. Sitting on a bottle for this winter =) Very strong beer and I think it would be a helluva lot better if it was just a little more mellow. Not that Im complaining cause this is very drinkable. =)

This is a really good beer but not great.  From everything I had read before I tried it I expected it to be in Old Rasputin, Plead the 5th, and Speedway Stouts class, but it was a clear step down for me.  It was a good beer, its not one I will pass on, but if its sitting next to some of those other RISs I am going with those which I liked better.

Ridiculously good beer, and perhaps the truest symbol of the sheer folly that is the limited release imperial stout.  This beer, aged or fresh, is as good as or better than almost every single limited release or one-off stout Ive had.  It has the complexity that I look for in an imperial stout and is drinkable and filling and rich.  Great fudgy quality with some sweet raisin character, a bit of roasted coffee.  So good.
Enjoyable beer with great nose. I highly recommend you cellar this baby. I tried it fresh and after 1 year. Letting it sit enhances the palate and tatse. Pours thick and has a dark foamy head.

shared by plovmand.  pitch dark, smooth creamy brown head. 4. Spritty aroma, roasted stuff, quite well blend of notes. Complex. Woody notes. 8. Flavor is roasted malts, sweet malts, brown sugar,  woody salty note. Very solid flavor. Aftertaste is roastted, dry and long lasting.
fra flaske, dufter super dejligt ! en fantastisk øl! en rating 200 øl givet af Plovmand! takker ! :) alt i alt en super lækker øl........

330 ml bottle in given to me by shubber85 in Germany at home. Is a pitch black color with a thin dark tan head. I know that this is beer that most others like but it just did not do it for me. Although it was good, because of its style, taste and palate its will not get the superior or excellent ratings that others give it. Aroma is tar, pine oil, coco and rosted nuts. Taste is is smooth and runs you through the same flavors as the aroma. The palate is pretty hard for my tender Bavarian taste cells to handle. Mostly tar, pine oil and dryness. A well made beer but not for me.

12oz bottle. VERY black, with a minimal dark (even for stouts) brown head. Aftertaste enhances aroma halfway through, bringing the fascinating aroma out with even more power, which is a very welcome feature.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2011 Damn this beer is insanely awesome. For all of the special release, limited edition impy stouts, there is this widely available imperial stout . This beer kills, dark fruits, dark bitter chocolate, coffee, along with alcohol undertones. Thick bodied, but not syrupy either.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2012 Apr 30 @ DLD. Pours pitch black with a thick creamy dark brown head leaving lacing. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, nutty, port wine, vanilla, malty and sweet. Flavor is roasted,vanilla, chocolate, malty, caramel, and coffee. Palate is velvety fullbodied. Finishes tart bittter with nice vanilla and malty touch. 

Apr 21, GIL. Intense and so good all the way from rhe very beginning to the end.

This one was a nice find, poured from a bottle. Id have to say this is the thickest pour I have ever seen. It was very dark, looked slick even, like liquid tar. There was no head, but little lacing. For an imperial stout it smelled very sweet, not too bitter. There were notes of coffee, coco nibs, perhaps even maple. The sweet half of the scent made it smell like a caramel cappuccino. The first sip was intense, the carbonation and thickness seemed to lengthen the flavor. Instantly it tastes like a cold coffee, but then is washed away with sweet chocolaty malt and the warmth of the generous ABV. As the carbonation leaves your mouth, you are left with a taste of dark chocolate, and your lips sticky (if you enjoyed it as much as me). This beer is very complex and enjoyable, goes down hard, yet smooth at the same time.

Let me start out by saying that I am rating the best bottle I have ever had, a bottle from batch 8728, though I will include some qualities from other bottles. Let me also say, that this is my favorite beer ever. Not because its the best beer I have ever had, but because its the best accessible beer. Its also pretty darn amazing. The appearance is luscious, dark, with a towering cream to tan colored head that leaves some pretty good lace, if you have the right touch with the pour. Aroma ranges from rich dark chocolate and vanilla extract, to graham cracker smores, to roast. Some of the newer bottles can have a bit of olive, which is why I suggest aging this one a bit. Taste is incredible with more of the chocolate smore taste. Roast, sometimes some caramel, vanilla extract. Palate is awesome. Thick, oily, rich, full-bodied. Everything I want in my stout. Lets just say Ive had some moments with this beer. Hot. Damn.

Pours jet black with a caramel brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, dark fruits and licorice. Great roasted malt flavor with notes of coffee, chocolate and hops. Very smooth mouth-feel for the style. Excellent brew.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2011 Wow. Pours opaque black with a chcolate-tan head. Aroma is very complex with vanilla, dark fruit, coffee, and a crisp hoppiness. Flavor is strong and lasts for days. Alcohol, coffee, caramel, fruit, bread, bourbon, and a big bitter chocolate kick at the end. Heck of a beer. Interested to see how well it ages and would love to try the bourbon barrel.

Bottle courtesy of Styles. Batch# 7205. Pours jet black with a thin brown head that dissipates to a thin ring. Aroma is sweet chocolate, coffee, black licorice, with hints of vanilla. No perceptible alcohol heat. Flavor is much the same. Body is full, and smooth as silk. Absolutely fantastic!

12oz bottle.  Pours extremely dark brown and opaque.  Looks like motor oil.  Thin brown head with little carbonation.  Besides the obvious chocolate and coffee, licorice is coming through on the aroma, along with fig.  It is full bodied and both oily and creamy,  Taste is brown sugar, a lot of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Roast and smoke are pretty prominent.  It is fairly sweet but thats balanced out by quite a bit of bitterness.  Very complex beer and at $2.99 a bottle, pretty reasonable.  Glad I got to try this.

sharply roasted malts, coffee, almost like burnt espresso, chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, fruty, some warming alcohol in the end. Looks almost thick as oil, very dense and very dark shades of black, small brown head, looks like an imp should! Extremely rich and roasted, smoke and smoked meat, coffee, and chocolate, heavily roasted ending in a warming finish. Mouthfeel is smooth with small soft bubbles. 
This is a huge and very well executed imp. The only thing I dont like are those notes of smoked meat that you sometimes find in these kinds of beers.

Bottle into Tulip.  Not very impressed with this one.  Tastes like a lot of other stouts, like a slightly bigger version of Founders Imperial Stout.  I guessing it probably need a few years to get good, fresh its just average.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2016 Bottled. Pours opaque black with a small tan head. Aroma of  roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and  licorice. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry with bitter notes. Oily to creamy texture, full bodied and soft carbonation. Great.★★★★
Black pour with small tan head. Aroma of sweet chocolate, malts and hint of raisins. Taste is coffee, chocolate, unsweetened cocoa. Flavours balanced out nice as it warmed up. Good beer.

Bouteille de 355ml. Bue en compagnie de 5 autres Imperial Stout de qualité. Cette bière est brune très foncée, peu de mousse se forme et en plus elle disparait rapidement. Le nez est ouvert avec des arômes exubérants de mélasse noire, treacle, jai trouvé le nez un peu unidimensionnel où tout est concentré autour de cette mélasse. La bouche a une texture incroyable, elle est huileuse, grasse. Cette bière est bien sucrée, elle est longue, très longue, les saveurs emplissent la bouche. Les saveurs rôties sont bien agréable et présente. Lamertume dalcool en finale pique la bouche.

I was excited to try this one out.  Basically no head and the color is pure black.  Has a big roasty chocolate nose.  The texture is slick and oily.  The taste is cocoa malts with a little bit of sweetness.  I got a hint of raisin.  Covers the alcohol pretty well, but it is still apparent.  Finally a nice finish of hops.  Lives up to the hype.

(Dakujem blankboy)  Le liquide a une robe très foncée, à la limite noire.  Le col mousseux sefface avec rapidité.  Le nez est très confortable : les notes rôties et les effluves de café samincissent au contact dune mélasse forte et fruitée qui simprègne dun caramel et dun chocolat amer.  Lalcool me semble bien en retrait derrière la somptuosité du liquide.  Les saveurs abondent dans le même sens : les grains foncés laissent beaucoup de mélasse aux papilles tandis que des saveurs de fruits émergent dans un subtil fracas.  Les houblons sont en sourdine.  On pourrait croire quil sagit dune bouteille qui a été mise au cellier.  La sensation en bouche est exceptionnelle.  Une incroyable réalisation architecturale : son corps est solide, lourdement charpenté.  Sa douce effervescence est parfaite, capable de souligner lintensité des flaveurs.  Sa texture est onctueuse, un peu collante, englobante, palpable.  La finale est un spectacle sensoriel, le réveil dune amertume chaude et chocolatée qui sinstalle longuement et majestueusement derrière la langue.  Colossal et intense.  Jusquà maintenant, en ce qui me concerne, dans mon parcours de dégustation, un stout pleinement unique et qui mérite, de ce fait, une évaluation forte et assumée.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2011 bottle from mansquito, very excited about this one.  Pours pitch black motor oil with nice dark brown sustaining head.  Very rich nose, with deep roast tempered by a malty sweetness, tones of burnt chocolate.  Full bodied, thick and oily, yet very smooth, no notice of the alcohol.  Flavor of rich, dark chocolate, deep roast, and a finish which I can best describe as an evolving bitterness, featuring notes of rich, dark chocolate, espresso, and hop bitterness.  As it warms there are very subtle fruity tones which are barely noticeable, but I get them.  Overall this is a great imperial stout, one which is big and bitter, combing espresso malt / hop bitterness, but that still retains a dark chocolate sweetness.  Quite nice.

Opaque black with a thin, tan head.  Aroma is powerful and packed with roasted malt, coffee, slight chocolate, and burnt toast.  Velvety, low carbonated mouthfeel with a boozey, intense roasted flavor profile with more choco/coffee balance.  Starts with a mild sweetness before giving way to a crazy bitter dry finish.  Wow.

Black pour, brown head.
Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, sweet and malty.
Flavor is chocolate, espresso, intensely. Alcohol. Bitter.

12 oz. Birthday beer pours black as oil with a 1/2 thick brown head that quickly demished. Wonderful on the nose, coffee, cocoa, soy sauce, leather and tobacco all come out in this complex imp stout. Very nice coffee bitterness comes through as well as the cocoa and the hops this thing is awesome. Mouthfeel is just as I had hoped thick and oily.The finish is long and very intense and the bitterness just hangs nice warming effect right near the end. Spectacular beer!

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours opaque coal black with extemely small dark brown head.  Body is thick and syrupy, almost no lacing,  Taste is deep chocolate, coffee, finishes bitter, and the alcohol is pretty well covered.  2012 some harshness, but more favor.  2010 sweeter, but less taste.

Gift from Huhzubendah, thanks Matt. Beer is black and forms a minimal head with some lacing on the glass. Carbonation is low.

Aroma is strong, very strong, a little boozy. Almost liquor like in aroma. Very strong. Pretty sweet. Its a little bit of a turnoff.

Very full bodied stout, finishes brighter than it starts. Pretty roasty, kind of bourbony in the mouthfeel and forward flavors. Its a big big beer. I didnt realize the ABV on this until I started writing this review foolishly. I will pay for my ignorance for sure. Its pretty drinkable especially if Im grading on a curve. I had the 2005 recently, also a gift from Huhzubendah and it had began to turn. Strong plum flavors and other characteristic oxidized notes in the palate. A good beer but i think the shelf life is around 3 - 4 years max. I enjoyed it.

Serving type: bottle

12 oz Bottle.  The beer pours a viscous almost syrupy consistency - kind of like motor oil with an appearance that is deep black with beige head that quickly disappears.  Aroma is heavy on the chocolate and coffee.  Underneath theres some hints of nuts, roasted cereals, and a slight flavor of dried fruits.  This beer is very heavy on the palate and needs to be sipped over the course of an evening.  The alcohol content is noticeable but not distracting like in some stouts.  Great beer!

10 oz bottle from Sun Devil Liquor in Mesa.
Opaque liquid, very thin caramel colored head, no lacing. 
Aroma of toffee, molasses, licorice, coffee. 
Flavor starts sweet, coffee, molasses, licorice and finishes with a nice balancing bitterness.

Bottled355ml. -Trade with shrubber85 (thanks Roger!)
Batch No. 9971. Black as night, small dark brown head, chocolate coffee nose. Roasted malt, dried fruits, chocolate and coffee with well balanced alcohol notes. Bitter hops and alcohol in the finish. Also some hints of tar. I think we tried it too early so Komodo Dragon Fly was better at the moment.

Pours pitch black with a thick, quickly dissapating tan head. Lots of lacing throughout the drink. This beer has a very complex taste. First, it has a roasted caramel aroma with a hint of something fruity or sweet. The taste is a cornucopia of caramel, deep chocolate, roasted malt and smoke. It is a very intense beer. I could only drink one at a time but this is a real treat. VERY good beer.

Bottle.

Picth black with a nice tan head. The liquid was thick as oil a good first impression I must say. Very nice aroma and taste. Bitter dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, vanilla and sweet licorice. Some alcohol but it is well hidden. Creamy and full mouth feel, an excellent and long aftertaste.

Not a magnificent beer, but very, very good. Would love to have some bottles in my cellar.

Pours dark brown with thick notes of caramel, cocoa, and coffee.  The notes are mingle to provide a very complex stoudt as it changes temperature.  I agree, this could age and change over time.  The finish drives home the sweet notes of caramel.

On Draft at Atomic Coffee Poured into a pint glass.  Pours a very dark blackish brown color you can loose the light in this beer.  Smell is of dark malts and chocolate.  Taste is delecious to say the least.  Taste of toffee and liquorice with a bitter finish. This is a super thick beer and it really makes you want to take aother sip super complex.  This is an all around great beer,  if you can find it this is a must try.

Bottle served in a snifter. Old engine oil in color with a short brown top. This one is big and rich on the nose and palate. Sweet aroma of chocolate, molasses, coffee, and motor oil. There may be a hint of hops that works its way through the sludge as well. Medium sweet, medium bitter flavor. Full body, ultra-creamy and thick texture, decent carbonation, with a long, very hoppy, roasty, sticky, sweet finish. Fantastic!

A: Poured into a snifter. It poured a deep, rich blackish brown, allowing no light to pass through it. Head is a deep brown/beige that starts from the pour and rises about 3/4 of an inch. very nice lacing.

S: Rich malts, chocolate, coffee, yeasts & toffee. Beautiful aroma with this beer.

T: Strong toffee off the bat, with a quick flavor of liquorice to take it away. Strong presence of alcohol in the taste, but good. Decent bitterness on the ending of this.

M: Definitely thick and syrupy...extremely complex on the palate.

D: delicious, strong and reasonably priced...what else could you ask for. Get it if you can.

Caramel, chocolate and just a pinch of roasted. There is also a punch of alcohol. Pitch black with a dark brown head.Fairly sweet with a little bitterness. Thick with a quick finish. I like it, but I am not crazy about it. Something tells me that it would be much better a few years down the road. This one is fresh off the line. I would buy it again.

Whole Foods DC six-pack ($18): Pours a black color with a relatively small brown head. Aroma is of burnt malts, chocolate, coffee, some vanilla, and a few other things for good measure. The burnt malt taste stands out most in my mouth. It covers the alcohol and makes it a little bit rougher than the really creamy sweet Imperial Stouts. Good amount of bitterness from the hops to accentuate the malt character. As it warms up the chocolate finally shines through. Coffee of the espresso variety is there throughout. Imperial stouts are not really my style of beer, but this is a beer that I thought I should have at some point. Craft at a very high level it is.

The beer is black with a medium tan head that has lots of retention and great lacing. 

The aroma is very malty, lots of sweet chocolate with vanilla and hops right at the end. 

The taste is off from the aroma with lots of coffee on the front and big hoppy finish. 

The feel is very heavy and viscous with a decent drinkability.

Pours very thick and black with at touch of burgundy somewhere in there... Big roasted malt nose mixed in with some piney hops in the background.  Equally big roasted malt flavor, kinda like drinking a Nestle Crunch bar made of deep dark chocolate.  Thick and viscous on the palate.  Overall, a solid beer that deserves the reputation it has...

Bottle from ogivlados trade with shrubber85 (HUGE thanks!). Batch 9971 POured an almost black body, only slightly tinged with red and a brown, relatively big head that went away, again, relatively slowly. The nose was, as expected, strong and aromatic, slightly sticky coffeish and sweet but with an unfortunate ethanol note. The taste started of similarly and I was left doubting the sanity of people who took this to 4.3s.  Treacley mouthfeel, full, sweet maltiness but with a strong clear alcohol hit, later balanced on with some notes of orange turning into a roasty finish. As it got warmed it definitely got better though, and I grew to respect the beer, that persistant presence of orange keeping the soft mouthfeel fighting with the roastiness at bay... And then the alcohol hit gain. And it was gone. An ever so sligthly crude hoppy bitter profile formed in the finish and in the aftertaste.... Man,  I do respect this beer and its definitely good stuff. Only it wouldve been great stuff if not for random strikes of alcohol, which I just dont like. No, which I just hate in my beers. The batch is fairly fresh (13.9.2010), so I guess we shouldve waited some more time, and Id just love to try an aged bottle to try. As it is right now, I liked their other stout better and this just didnt sit with me right. Yes, I will rerate one day. One. Day. Right now it gets the same rating as the Upland Komodo Dragon Fly weve had before that because it simply wasnt any better.

Very dark, dark brown nearly black color with a small dark, chocolate milkshake colored head.  The head was "tight" and mostly creamy.  Did have nice retention and left some real strong lacing on the glass.  Some very nice coffee, espresso notes that smelled somewhat burnt in the nose.  Robust.  Some noticeable dark chocolate in there also.  Smells nice and toasty and malty.  I kind of get a vanilla bean aroma also.  Slight alcohol fragrance, but nothing off putting.  The taste was very similar to the smell.  Robust, roasty coffee and chocolate.  Burnt flavoring with a splash of vanilla.  A stronger touch of alcohol in the flavor, but welcome.  A nice little burn.  Medium/full to mostly full.  Smooth.  Dry.  A lot of flavor left on the palate.  A considerable warmth from the alcohol.  Chewy and slightly oily.  Slick feeling.  This Stout is extremely nice.  Its strong, so that may exclude some from liking it and it may hurt with overall drinkability, but its still very, very good.  Worth a try if you are a Stout lover.  I know I am so therefore, I do love this beer.  This beer would be perfect on a cold night by the fireplace just sipping.

aroma ischocolate  coffee, and a bit of hops. nice thick and creamy palate. taste is about the same, chocolate and coffee, bitter coffee thanks to the hops in this, great balance of bitter and sweet. got one held back  that im going to open in a year or so to review again.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2015 12oz bottle batch 9459 bottled November 19th, 2009 so almost 6 y/o !!
Appearance : Pitch syrupy black with almost no head. No lacing.

Aroma : Big rich spirit-y chocolate with coffee. Hint of oxidation but quite minimal. Sweet overcooked caramel. Light vanilla, some spices.

Palate : Very soft, almost flat but still a nice smooth fizz. Velvety and pillowy. Body is oily and sweet but not cloying. Some dryness that might be the result of the ageing. So smooth and creamy. This is one of the best mouthfeel Ive ever experienced. Oily.

Taste : Chocolate, coffee, coffee spices, burnt caramel. Resinous hops. Finish is very persistent with oily resinous hops notes with coffee and chocolate. Quite hoppy. 

Overall : Wow... I dont remember having a 6yo beer that aged as good as this. Mouthfeel is amazing. Very elegant overall. Packed with flavour but very well rounded. Finish is amazingly persistent. I would rate that bottle 4.5 and maybe over but Im just going to bring my original rating up from 4.0 to 4.2

12oz bottle thanks to blankboy. Bottle is at least one year old.
Appearance : Pitch syrupy black with almost no head. No lacing.

Aroma : Very rich and thick. Syrupy with notes of licorice and molasses. Some raisins too. Lots of coffee and roasted malt with resinous and oily hops. Very complex.

Taste : Lots of coffee with roasted malt and resinous hops. Lots of licorice and molasses. Nice dark chocolate on the finish with resinous hops and coffee. Syrupy. Very low carbonation. Very long finish. Not much alcohol.

Overall : Ok this is a big guy. Very complex nose, nice coffee, nice molasses and rich sweetness mixed with the resinous hops. A bit too much licorice for my taste (quite sensible to this). Finish is very nice and complex. Rather well balance even if quite powerful. Carbonation could be a tad more present. Im sure I dont appreciate this as much as many because Im not such a big fan of licorice... Still I can appreciate the complexity and I find a lot of great flavours all around. Maybe a fresh bottle would be more hops and less licorice...Rating 2011-03-17 8,2,8,3,19;4.0
Just another reason to love Stouts.  Dark, balanced and dry, it hides the high gravity so well. Best for an evening in, lounging about the fire as you might not drive well after two.

Bottle. Trade from rgtravers, thanks. Black body with a forever lasting brown head. Aroma is coffee, light hops, roasted malt, chocolatr, toffee and alcohol. Flavor is heavy bitter coffee, chocolate, hops, vanilla, caramel, roasted malt and light alcohol. Nice lacings. Wouw, great beer.

Bottle to snifter.  Enjoying this with an average cigar (Gurkha Grand Reserve, which goes nicely, btw).  Pours motor oil black, viscous. Low carbonation.  Very small mocha head where it touches the glass.  Smell is of coffee, chocolate and licorice.  Taste is dark chocolate, a bit of coffee.  Sweet.  No hint of alcohol for me.  Very oily and sticky on the palate.  A bit of a hoppy, bitter finish, but very sublte.  Outstanding.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2015 777th rating. Almost pitch black getting out of the bottle. A bit of a reddish shine when holding to the light. Nice sized, good holding and sticky (to the glass) brown head. Smell is sweet-burned/roasted malts, coffee, chocolate. Very full body and taste, oily mouthfeel like I love them. Sweet-bitter chocolate, roasted malts, good hops gets trough and makes it a good bitter aftertaste where the sweetness also still gets trough. Good balance between sweet, roasted, bitter-hops. Edit: had to add some points when retasting.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2011 Well balanced, hoppy, kinda boring im afraid to say given the hype. was beat in a blind taste test, :(
Rerate: just hoppy and malty. Not charming and really anything enjoyable in this beer. Meh, I just think its the best beer Casual beerists drink, thats a shame.

I poured the brew into my pint glass and it came out a very inky black color.  A brown head sat atop the brew and actually left a really good amount of lacing on the glass.

The nose is packed with mocha scents and a lot of roasted malts.  Hints of chocolate and coffee come out as well.  And you get a little bit of the alcohol in the nose.

The taste is a lot more of the same that was present in the nose (man I hate having to say that) but there is a nice lactose taste there as well.  It also has a very creamy consistency and mouth feel to it.

Bottle purchased from beer store in Orlando. Happy this one survived the flight back to Jersey. This stout pours thick and black with no head except for a small brown ring around my glass. The aroma is big malt, vanilla, roasted nuts, and alcohol. At first taste the alcohol was evident up front with some bitter coffee bean which mellowed out through the finish. Dark chocolate and dark fruits also well incorporated. The hop flavor is slightly present and nice in this one. All these flavors combined and balanced make one harmonious stout. Nice creamy mouthfeel with a bit of afterburn from the alcohol.

Like a friend youve known for years but havent seen in a while, the Expedition stout has a surprising first impression but then a familiar second one. The aroma is dry and roasted like strong coffee but the taste is thick, viscous, and sweet. Theres my old friend.
Pours deep, dark black. Aroma of roasted nuts, coffee, chocolate, vanilla. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, and molasses with a bitter grassy hops in the finish. Just beautiful.

Bottle:
Nice brown head on top of a pitch black beer.
Smell tar, cream, liquorice, paint, dark fruits, hops, roasted malts.
Taste is a full soft coffee mix of: espresso, coffee beans, bitter, dark chocolate, liquorice, hint of alcohol, light grassy and hints of dark fruits, raisin.
Heavy dark bitter aftertaste. Spicy hint of alcohol burning.
Soft mouthfeel, full body and low carbo. Strange brew.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle. Glad I was able to pick this one up. Aroma was heavy chocolate and coffee with a bit of the sweetness of fruit. Also had a metallic smell to it. Very pungent and complex aroma. Flavor is rock solid and full of coffee, caramel, chocolate, hops, and malt. Definitely a burly stout. Pour was beyond black with a small coffee colored head. If you like nice, bold, flavorful stouts that are still easily drinkable then this one is for you.

Tap. Jet black. Aroma is vanilla, roasted coffee, dark chocolate and a slight hint of alcohol. Taste is upfront booze, followed by lots of chocolate and roasted flavors. Lots going on here. Finishes with a nice alcohol burn that in conjunction with the flavor is very pleasant. Subtle vanilla and tobacco. Low carbonation. Phenomenal.

This has to be one of the best Stouts Ive ever tried. Almost like a dessert in a glass. Good stuff.

A: Pours dark as night with a tan milky head that, after dissipating, leaves a nice tan film over the beer. Same colored lacing on the glass.

S: You get a ton of roasted malt from this. I cant smell the espresso, but the chocolate is evident. You can smell the alcohol a bit, too.

T: Almost tastes like a boozy chocolate milk at first. Finishes with a little bitterness from the roasted malts that were in the smell. A little bit of burn from the ABV.

M: Very creamy and smooth. There is a bit of carbonation, but it does nothing but enhance and deliver the creaminess.

D: You dont want to drink this quickly not just b/c of the high ABV, but b/c it tastes so damn good. I couldnt believe this was 10.5%. You can taste the booze, but I had no idea it was that high. This could be a dangerous one.

12 oz bottle purchased from the Bells General Store.

Pours into my pint a dark black with slight ruby edges when held to light. The head is thick and creamy and large. It is brown/tan and leaves thick lacing behind.

SMell is very carmally, also some molasses, nuts, maple, brown sugar, coffee, and cocoa.

Mouthfeel is extra thick but the alcohola nd slight carbonation do bite the lips. It tastes chocolatey and fruity, with a definite alcohol bite. It is pretty sweet and bittersweet but it doesnt reach cloying levels. This is one of those big ass beers that you drink to warm up. They could have bumped it up to 12% though considering the strength of the alcohol already on the palate.

This is a big and bold Russian imperial stout, but for a true Michigan jewel I recommend the Dark Horse Plead the 5th.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-08-2010 03:48:02

12 ounce bottle purchased at Bruisin Ales in Asheville, NC ($3.25) and enjoyed while at my fiancees place in Knoxville.  Pours a thick black with thing layer of nice brown foam.  Aroma of smoky dark roasted malts (some leather / bacon) with lighter notes of chocolate, soy sauce, and some hop-derived fruitiness.  Flavor of smooth dark roasted malts with nice bittersweet chocolate, some earthy dark coffee, molasses, and some noticeable semi-sweet fruity hops (but not bitter).  Nicely earthy and far from sweet...the smoothness really stands out in this one.  And the high ABV seems to be completely concealed which makes this one of the most easily drinkable big impy stouts around.  Great brew and very happy to have finally come across this (currently #12 in the world on RateBeer).  (1987, 464)

Aroma of wood, butter, marzipan, and fine liquors. Smooth texture, light body and quite sticky. Flavour has a lot of wood and roasted nuts along with a creamy mouthfeel, subsiding to a bitterness. Looking forward to trying this after its been cellared.

Poured from 12oz bottle.  Pours nearly black with loads of brown head.  Smells of alcohol, soy sauce and liquid smoke.  Tastes much like the small, only with a bunch of bitterness in the finish.  I was hoping for something a bit sweeter.  I will hang on to some of these for awhile to see if some aging will mellow out the hoppiness/bitterness.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Cigar City snifter. Bottled on September 13, 2010 per batch number 9971 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours a thick motor oil black with a 1/2 finger mocha brown head which dissipates quickly.

Smell: Chocolate, molasses, alcohol and a hops.

Taste: Molasses and dark chocolate up front followed by roasted malt and coffee in the middle before ending with a burst of bitter hops at the finish. The alcohol is obviously there, but it never overpowers the flavor. Aftertaste is a mix of burnt toast and hoppy bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied and with a decent amount of carbonation. This is a thick beer that still goes down smoothly.

Drinkability: High drinkability. This isnt a beer to be rushed by any means. Drink it slowly and savor the flavors because youre probably going to be done after one.

Overall: Very good beer overall. One of the better Russian Imperial Stouts that is widely available. Another fine offering from Bells.
Pours deep, dark black. Aroma of roasted nuts, coffee, chocolate, vanilla. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, and molasses with a bitter grassy hops in the finish.  Just beautiful.

Pours a dark, deep brown with rich brown head. Aroma is roasty with hints of dark chocolate, molasses, currants, and a bit of anise. The flavor is full of complexity and adds coffee to what comes off the nose. This beer is thick and leaves a slightly bitter finish. Fresh bottles dont hide the almost 11% very well but that quickly changes with a little age.

Bottle (35 cl) from the Cracked Kettle. Black with a small beige head. Wonderful roasted aroma with loads of chocolate, coffee, and some dark berries. Full bodied and smooth. Very well balanced, long bitter finish.

A: The pour is viscous and lightly carbonated with a thin layer of mocha colored head.

S: Even after a little more than 4 years, this beer is still a little bit boozy. Alcohol notes come through immediately with lots of dark fruits and licorice. Dark chocolate and burnt sugar fill in the back end along with a strong roast.

T: Surprisingly bitter with lots of roast and coffee notes, particularly on the back end. Dark chocolate, licorice, burnt sugar, and dark fruits make up the bulk of the flavor profile. The booze is a bit more subdued than I was expecting.

M: The body is medium to full with a low but ample carbonation.

D: I think one bottle is enough, but this is a fine beer indeed. One that can certainly hold up to (and in some cases, benefit from) again.

12 oz bottle acquired via trade quite some time ago and consumed on my 30th birthday this past November. Yeah, Im pretty far behind in reviews, but so what? Too damn busy drinking beer over here! Pours pitch black with ruby red highlights on the edges and an inch of mocha colored head. Big whiff of chocolate and coffee initially, fading to a light bit of licorice and more roastiness. Taste is big of chocolate and coffee as well, quite a bit of roast and a light touch of licorice. Not the most complex IS Ive ever tasted, but just a solid winner all around.

Nursed a goblet or whatever its called of this at Bells Eccentric Cafe.  You can send your tongue in pretty much any direction and find a new hidden taste in this one.  Fair Trade Organic Venezuelan cocoa with some coffee and some sorta nuts and some caramel and some burnt-out barley and toasted barley and smooth sweet barley.  If that sounds gross to you then you havent had this brew.  All the hops in the world seem to balance out all the malts really well.  This beer tastes like it has more shit in it than any brew Ive ever had.  I want to move to St. Petersburg or Copenhagen and spend a winter living off of this shit.  I bet Id be hairier and have bigger muscles. Without a doubt the best six dollar bar draft of my fucking life.

Pours a solid black that lets no light through. Tanish head that dissipates quickly, but leaves lots of marks down the surface of the glass. Aroma is wine like, with roasted malts, licorice, some chocolate and coffee too. Taste is sweet. I pick up some dried fruit, molasses, some roast and some faint hop or roast bitterness in the end. Mouthfeel is thick, and a bit sweet. Almost leaves my lips sticky like my kids with candy. Not your average Imp Stout, but I love this stuff. Bells continues to impress me!!

This beer has a great smell but is not very strong.  It poured with a nice quarter inch head that stuck around for half the drink.  I tasted this beer fresh so have not aged it yet but I really like it already.  Its a creamy drink that has a sweet initial taste that gives way to a lingering bitter flavor.  The bitter is a coffee bitter but very pleasant.  I look forward to trying this after it has aged.  This will not be the last time I get this beer.

This beer is awesome!  Pours black with a thick tan head.  Roasted malts in the nose and on the pallet.  A very thick mouthfeel, almost like your chewing on a nice thick slice of bread.  One of the best stouts I have ever had.

I cant believe I have never had this before, 12 oz bottle, Batch #9971, great dark, pour, crazy dark. Great lacing on the head, it sticks to the edge of the glass like spiderwebs, Its like begging to be drank. Aroma of burnt coffee, chocolate, extremely complex, excellent. Im getting a bit of an alcoholic burn on the back of my throat as im finishing, thats been the only hint of the 10.5%. Im going to take a few of these and bury them in the backyard, I few years would do wonders.

Black with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, malt, and more hops than usual in a stout.  Taste is of immense chocolate, incredibly smooth, some milk-like sweetness as well.  Incredibly overall.

From the bottle this stout completely blacks out my snifter. Minimal brown head that fades quick leaving almost no lacing but maintains a ring around the edges of the beer. A fantastic aroma on this brew. I could simply sniff this stuff and be satisfied! Chocolate, smoked raisins with a touch of alcohol and soy just makes my nose happy. Nutty sweet with lots of espresso strong coffee flavors. Finishes with sour, ripe grapefruit and a little alcohol burn. Warms the belly and almost buzzed off the first glass. A bit more bitter than expected...gonna cellar a couple bottles for six months or so and see if it mellows. 1-24-11
Bottle.  Often.  Pours black.  Not as oily and viscous as I would like and slightly more alcoholic.  Still, a great stout with plenty of dark chocolate notes.  Great beer.  One of the best.

Ive had this beer several times and its always so amazing. This is a bottle I had for about 8 months now. It pours black and creamy with some head. Aroma is molasses and toasted malt. Flavor is bitter chocolate and hops. Palate is full bodied and creamy with a bitter hops finish. This is one of my favorite stouts.

Pours black but smoothly (not syrupy).  Thin tan (almost brown) head.  Given the minimal head, it laces pretty well.

Aroma is big malt sweetness with roast notes.  Molasses, oats, chocolate, and the alcohol.  Sweet and rich scents.

Taste is a balance of big roast and big sweet flavors.  Carbonation rests well on the rich body of the beer.  Dry flavor, oaty and a dry, coffee and licorice finish.  Roast enhances as it warms.  Rich and complex sweetness to offset it, though.

Easy to drink and so rich that it completely hides its high abv.  Drinks slowly from the richness, not from heaviness or alcohol.

Pitch black with tan head.  Aroma of coffee, brown sugar, black cherry and dark chocolate.  Full bodied.  Bakers chocolate, spicy hops, dark fruits and coffee flavor.  This seems hoppier than I remember, or it could be that this is just the freshist btl Ive ever had.  Excellect Imp Stout.
basically black in color with caramel lacing and head. Unami out the wazoo, medium bitter, medium sweet,  lively on the tongue and roof, long lingering finish.

12oz bottle. Big murky black beer with a beautifully cascading head in nice chocolaty tan. I rarely give a full score for appearance, but this definitely gets one. I dont really feel like typing up a huge report on this beer, because Im too busy enjoying it. Suffice it to say that this is just about everything I could want in an imperial stout. In a beer, for that matter! Its really, really excellent. If you havent had it, seek it out.

20th January 2009 Opaque brown - black stout. Rich sumptuos beer. Smooth, thick and silky. Fruity note in the mid of sweet cherry and a trace of peach. Finishes with a smooth mildly roasty malt and a slightly bitter aftertaste. All very smooth! The fruity mid really makes this stout.

Pours dark brown, minimum head, no lacing.  HUGE taste of glazed caramel and bitter chocolate that is joined later by light licorice and prunes.  The finish has minimal carbonation with mild bittering.  Goes warm down the throat.  This is for anyone who enjoys a big taste in a brew.  Even though they arent the power-pack this is, I prefer Bells Kalamazoo Stout and Rye Stout.
Complex and deep in flavor like a good imperial stout should be.  Needs to be almost room temperature to taste like its supposed to.

12 oz bottle, pours dark black, with a big tan head head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee.  Sweet with just a little bitterness, with a long lasting flavor in your mouth.  Complex, just a lot going on, but balanced perfectly.  Excellent

Dark pour
Medium body
Dark roasted malt (tasted almost burnt to me)
Bitter hops and chocolate. notes of alcohol Fairly dry.
Drinkable but probably would be better aged. I dont see what the big deal is.

Bottle. Darker tan head that dies fairly quickly, on a truly black body that is very dense...very heavy and viscous pour. Balanced, but really nice aroma that features dark roasted malts, some plum-like sweetness, espresso, and a hint of chocolate.  Very roasty taste, but nowhere near overkill or acrid, bitter iced espresso, dark chocolate, and back to roasty malts in the finish.  Very dry, and love that it shies away from the sweeter side of things.  Viscous and thicker with nice tight carbonation to keep it livelier.  Really great stuff.

When I poured this beer out of the bottle, I simply couldnt believe how dark it was. I actually held it up to a light to see if any shined through (none did). This was a dark, roasted beer with tastes of chocolate and coffee. Every sip brings about new flavors.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2011 Head comes so slowly out of the beer and dissipates as quickly.  Soy sauce, vinegar, molasses, chocolate in the aroma.  Soy sauce seems to dominate.  Flavor is crazy rich. Salty, sweet, some sour, but the least is bitter.  Although the thoroughly roasted malts cut the sweetness somewhat.  Still puzzling over this.  Finish is warm alcohol.

From notes 10/2008. Ive enjoyed many of these over the past few years.

Pours opaque black. Vigorous second pour yields a burnt umber head, beautifully dark.

Smell is rich; fudge, espresso, caramel, and the smallest presence of earthy hops. Molasses on the tongue. Roasted malts. Ineffable balance. Sweet and delicious with a slight spice finish.

Thick, chewy, fill-the-mouth fullness. Creamy. Perfect.

There arent many words for this one. August. Ponderously thick. A glossal emollient. Mellifluous. Prodigious.

Toothsome, this one could convince even the most ardent teetotaler to abandon his principles. My go-to "budget" RIS, and she ages like a champ.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2012 12oz bottle, batch 9459, bottled Nov 19, 2009.  Over a year old.  Served cellar temp in a New Belgium globe/snifter.  Ive enjoyed this a few times in its youth but wanted to wait to review til it was over a year old.  Pours black with a two finger brown head that leaves some pretty lacing and holds a small cap.  Aroma is rich roasted malts, chocolate, anise, coffee, vanilla, dark fruits of plums, figs, cherries, and raisins, some alcohol.  Great strength.  Flavor is also very rich much like the aroma with chocolate, coffee, dark roasted malts, cherries, plums, figs, raisins, vanilla, there is still a noticeable alcohol bite/burn which is to be expected for the ABV but I thought it would have diminished more over a years time.  Still, cant really fault a big Imperial Stout for being a touch hot.  Mouthfeel is full, creamy, medium carbonation.  A world-class Imperial Stout for sure, so very rich and decadent.  Cant wait to try some of the 2010 batch.

EDIT: By FAR my favorite non-barrel aged Imperial Stout. Just cant get enough of this magical brew. Numerous batches, numerous years at a variety of ages and theyre all fantastic in their own way. Age certainly benefits this one as well and I cant wait to try some extended aging well beyond 2 years on this one.
Big black beer with a giant fluffy brown head.  Roasted malt and cocoa dominate.  Somewhat syrupy, with burnt and bitter end.

Perhaps one of the best bodies on an imperial stout in my book. Great balance of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, slight dark fruits, and a nice creamy blend of flavors. Little head and dark colored head.

Smells most clearly of chocolate initially, more coffee as it warms. Pours dark brown, opaque with less than a finger of dark brown head which dissipates quickly. Chocolate and coffee stand out in taste; both are balanced well. Noticeable bitterness from hops, pleasant bittersweet finish. Only complaint is that it may be a bit too sweet for my tastes. Soft carbonation; thick, oily body.

Bottle.  Pours darkest brown with 2-3 finger head.   Wanted to drink fast but glad I sipped as the alcohol really comes out as it warms.  Coffee, roasted nits and small hints of chocolate.   Been after this brew for a while and it was worth the chase.   Very well done Bells

on draft and loved every sip of this one. very dark pour and creamy goodness.  mild flavor of coffee with hints of chocolate and roasted malts work wonderful in this beer.  let it warm up some before sipping this one. there is a good alcohol over tone. if you can find it on draft grab a few and enjoy.

12 oz bottle brought back from MI by our summer intern David. Thanks buddy! You are lucky to leave half an hour from Bells and Founders!
Poured jet black with a one finger, creamy, thick espresso tan head. Nose is amazing...sweet tobacco, bittersweet chocolate, roasted malts, warmed caramel, fresh coffee, and spicy hops. The taste is exactly what an imperial stout needs to be...this is THE standard. An array of baking chocolate, roasted dark malts, slightly smoky, warmed caramel, espresso, and a finish of big hops, more bittersweet chocolate, slight coffee, and smoke. This is a superb imperial stout! Mouthfeel was perfect, partially viscous and thick but not overwhelming and great carbonation.
Pours pure black in color.  Aroma is loaded with malts, roastyness, some dark fruit, and oak.  Flavor is of malts, coffee, big roastiness, and chocolate.  Has a coffee malt finish.  Great stuff!

Bottle poured into a snifter.  Appearance is black and oily, with the beer nearly climbing up the sides of the glass.  Very viscous with a bit of lacing.  Aroma is great with toasted malt, hints of chocolate, and alcohol.  Here is where I disagree with the beer...the taste is (my opinion mind you) an unbalanced mix of malts and tobacco that kicks me in the face a little too much.  It does however get slightly better as it warms.  Could just be a bad bottle.  This definitely needs some time to age a little.  Will re-rate later.

Terrific beer. Not a strong aroma, slightly smokey. Pours pitch black with little head. Strong smokey, chocolate tastes with a bit of caramel and bacon. Very well balanced. Contender for the lists of beers to bring to a desert island.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2012 Rerate: 3/8/12  Aged over 1 year in cellar.  Bottle, built up to a medium head.  Full aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee.  Light sweetness Light bitter.  Wonderful creamy palate (slightly chewy) with a nice warming alcohol sensation.  THIS GETS BETTER WITH AGING.  Not for the faint hearted.  I need more of this stuff...   
Poured black with a brownish modest head, dissipated some.  Aroma of cocoa, toated malts, and alchohol whiskey-like.  Taste is lite sweetnes of malts with a bitter aftertaste that kicks in at end and also an alchohol punch at the end.  Faint taste of hops too.  Creamy texture, full bodied, chewy.  This is a good sipping, high potency stout.  I just had Samuel Smiths Imp stout last night and the SS is a bit smoother, but this packs more punch and flavor.  Complex.  Great Beer.
Wonderful aroma,  Hazelnut, bonfire, cider toffee. The body doesnt manage it though with the aggressive hopping seeming to override the promised  flavour

I have been waiting a long time for this one, the wait was well worth it. Jet black pour with brown, frothy head. Strong aromas of dark chocolate and caramel. The taste is strong of coffee, dark chocolate, and bitter chalk notes. Hoppy, bitter aftertaste. I was expecting something sweeter, but this did the trick. Masterfully crafted, sweet dark chocolate beer with a bitter finish. Very creamy, and very delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2012 Pours a typical imperial stout with a nice light brown head. Aroma of bittersweet chocolate. Taste is a wonderully thick blend of roasted malt, bakers chocolate, cream, nuttiness, espresso malt. Lingering finish with the slightest bit of hop bitterness. This is a deep, dark stout, but it is creamy. Pretty good beer, but missing something to elevate it to elite level. At its best with age, without a doubt.

Bottle: poured a dark, almost oddly glossy black with a 1/4" fast-dissipating chocolate head. Aroma of roasty malts, grain, molasses, and chalk.
Flavor is very dark and somewhat sweet with the roasted malts giving way to 
the slightly hoppy finish. Tastes somewhat like toffee and chestnuts. 
A very dark and complex stout, would fare much better if aged a couple years. A great stout if youre looking for something off the beaten path, but not developed enough to be the best stout. Cellaring may be the answer.

Pours pitch black with a dark brown full head.  The smell just fills the room once the cap has been cracked...phenomenal.  Rich aromas of bourbon, tobacco, sweet and bitter dark chocolate, copious amounts of coffee.  There is also a bit of a hoppy bite in the aroma.  The flavor is just spot on.  Rich oily mouthfeel gives flavors that are close to the nose.  Bitter roasted coffee and dark chocolate are the most accessible flavors with those heavily roasted malts coming across with such brilliance.  Tobacco and toffee combine with molasses to give an incredible complexity.  This beer also has that raw edge that I love in stouts so much.  The finish is long, dry, and lingering.  This beer provides everything I look for in a  RIS and leaves nothing undone.  This is just wonderful.

Pours a deep, dark black.  Thick and oily medium head the color of brown sugar.  Flavor is powerful - loads of roasted malt and plenty of bitterness muting complex elements of dried pit fruit, licorice, and bitter chocolate. Oh, and also alcohol.  Absolutely perfect for cold winter sipping.

Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Pitch black with a lasting brown film. Alcohol, dark dried fruits and roasted notes dominate the nose. More roasted notes and sweet liqorice added in the mouth along with bitterness and alcohol. Full bodied and oily, the finish is dry with roasted bitter notes. An absolute delight.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Pours pitch black with no head at all. Aroma of dark burnt malt, berries, lots of alcohol, thinner and rubber. Taste is full and rich, strong alcohol, fruit, mint, liquorice besides the rich malts. Full and thick oily body. Extreme but good in a strange way.

Thick, smooth, deep black beer with dark tan head.  Aroma combines malt, coffee and is encouraging.  The alcohol induced warming continues to build after you sip but does not overpower when you drink... good balance.

355 ml bottle, kindly shared by gunnar. ABV 10.5%. Pitch black colour, low head. Strong and intense aroma of heavily roasted malts, cigar box, burnt caramel and oak. Equally strong and intense flavour, again heavily roasted malts, burnt caramel and oak. Pretty impressive stuff.

Bottle to chilled dimpled glass mug.  Pours a very very dark brown, or black.  Opaque.  Not much head, but what I see is a nice dark yellow / orange color with minimal lacing.  Lots of good IS flavors going on, including coffee, dates, prunes, etc.  Very rich.  Very thick.  10.2 ABV is masked very well in this fine beer.

12 oz. bottle from Johns Grocery, Iowa City

Ar:  Exceptionally complex.  Not as much coffee up front as I expected.  The flavor leans more on deep dried fruit flavors than other Impy Stouts Ive had.  The alcohol is prevalent, but is masked by date, black fig, coffee, and bitter chocolate.
Ap:  Wow is this gorgeous.  It pours an oil black with a thick 1" head of beautiful cinnamon bubbles.  The head sticks around for quite some time too.  This is the kind of beer you just want to look at for some time before drinking.  Great lace as well.  This is absolute beer porn.
T: Light black fig and molasses up front, with a significant malt sweetness.  Coffee and bitter chocolate dominate the heavily bittered finish.
P:  Exceptionally thick, creamy body with mild carbonation.  The viscous body coats every part of my mouth, and distributes flavors exceptionally well.

O:  What more is there to be said about this beer that hasnt already been said?  This is awesome.  Phenomenally complex, phenomenally rich, and drop dead gorgeous.  The aroma is just a bit confusing, but given a few years the flavors would probably meld together.  Thats just a nitpick though.  Simply put, this is without a doubt one of the five best beers I have ever had, and its less than $18 for a sixer.
On tap at Zenos.  Jet black with a thin brown head.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Aroma and flavor of chocolate, some coffee, malts, and hops.  Very solid stout.

Apr 26th, 2005 - batch 6811 - opened Nov 28, 2010.
Has the thick smokiness the expedition is known for. Not overpowering, but very inviting, promising sweetness and smokiness. The appearance of this beer is simply beautiful. Small caramel colored bubbles sit on top of a thick pouring black body. Heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness. Full body with a thick texture. Very nice soft carbonation.

I am alone among ratebeer participants in that the imperial stout ranks among my least favored styles. Still, this is a great brewery, so I was eager to try this as a nightcap during the holiday weekend. I cellared the bottle for about a year (batch 9459), and certainly was not disappointed when I opened it. This poured thick, viscous, and reddish-black into a snifter, with a single thin line of foam that reduced to the tiniest of lines of lace. Deceptively light in your mouth, this greets the nose and tongue with notes of espresso, bourbon, and fennel. A delightful beer that proved well worth the wait.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2010 I HAVE BEEN LOOKING FOR THIS BREW FOR SOME TIME NOW IT HAS BEEN HIGHLY REGARDED AND IS SEEMINGLY UNAVAILABLE IN MY AREA, I FINALY RECIEVED IT FROM A FRIEND TRAVELING IN BALTIMORE. (THANKS SON!!) THIS STOUT POURS A THICK BLACK WITH A DARK BROWN YET THIN HEAD AND A RICH CHOCOLATE AROMA. ITS COMPLEX CHARACTER SMELLS SIMILAR TO A BARLEY WINE BEER AND FROM ITS SMELL, ITS ALCOHOL CONTENT IS APPARENT. THE FLAVOR IS PRETTY COMPLEX ALSO, IT HAS A NICE BITTERNESS WHICH COMES FROM ITS ABUNDANCE OF HOPS YET IT LACKS THE CITRUS FLAVORS THAT USUALLY COME ALONG WITH THAT MUCH HOPS, TO ACCOMPLISH THIS THE HOPS MUST BE ROASTED TO NEAR PERFECTION. THE MALTS ARE RICH IN DARK COFFEE AND UNSWEETEND CHOCOLATE FLAVORS AGAIN ACCOMPISHED BY A SLOW ROASTING PROCESS. THE COMBINATION OF THE INGRIEDIENT AND ATTENTION TO DETAIL NOT ONLY MAKE THE FLAVORS OF THIS BREW COMPLIMENT EACHOTHER PERFECTLY THEY ALSO SEEM TO MAKE THE DRINKING EXPERIENCE SO ENJOYABLE THAT THE ALCOHOL CONTENT OF 11% IS NEARLY UNOTICABLE. THIS BEER IS WONDEFULL AND IS A TRUE IMPERIAL STOUT.
bottle at Publican in Chicago...great beer menu....dark as motor oil; great hoppy nose which is a plus for IPA junkies like me....this one was NOT an aged bottle so should even age out better.

6pack of 12 oz. Bottles. Pours the typical pitch black. Thick but not as thick as...say Ten Fidy.  Aroma is very telling of the style, roasted, smokey, chocolate, coffee, and molasses.  Taste is an abundance of thick syrupy malt and coffee which ends with a small but distinct syrupy sourness, which is rare for the style.  Sits pretty heavy on the stomach.  A definate sipper. Definately a beast of a beer, but there is some contrast at the finish  where you expect the chocolatey malts to linger but something sour Im beer quickly takes that away leaving an odd finish.

Good beer, all the flavours there, that one would associate with an imperial stout, coffee chocolate, roast. Hoppier than most stouts though. Got a bottle to age, will try after some while. Would have this more often for sure if it werent so hard to come by.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap in Bloomington, IN earlier this year. Served in a snifter.

A: Very, very dark with a massive brown head.

S: Quite good, but a little muted compared with the taste. Hops, chocolate, coffee, cherries, slightly-burnt espresso.

T: Same as the smell, and utterly fantastic. I taste the most from the espresso with a little bit of the cherry.

M: Very thick. Chewy and creamy.

D: Highly, highly drinkable. Grab two of these and sip em for the rest of the night.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 12 oz. bottle sent from Glouglouburp, pours deep black with a thin coffee head. Unbelievable rich aroma of dark chocolate, rich roasted espresso, wood and burnt caramel. Hard to beat the complexity on this - somewhat sweet, dark chocolate upfront, with burnt caramel coming through the middle and espresso on the finish, with an every so slight lingering bitterness. What a beer.

Pours black with a large coffee colored head that has very nice retention. Close knit carbonation bubbles. Aroma of coffee, caramel, brown sugar, dark chocolate, and a touch of alcohol. Taste of bitter chocolate, coffee and a touch of sweetness, with a pinch of alcohol in the finish.

Tasted from a 12oz bottle obtained in a trade.  The Batch number is 8311, which the Bells website tells me was "was packaged on February 7th, 2008."  The pour is motor oil black with a huge brown head that slowly recedes, leaving thick lace both on the beer and the inside of the glass.  The nose is molasses and bitter dark chocolate with a slight coconut creaminess, vanilla, and espresso grounds.  There is just a bit of oxidation beginning to show with a just a hint of nuttiness and soy beginning to peak through.  The flavor starts off sweet with the molasses, vanilla, and coconut, but it is balanced very well with bitter dark chocolate, coffee, and a resinous hops flavor.  The body is massive, thick, and sticky with average carbonation, and a super long, molasses sweet and bitter coffee finish.  This beer is dangerous, as the alcohol is hardly present.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2011 Bottle to snifter (Batch 9971).  Just shy of room temp.  Pours dark, dark brown.  Nice mocha head, fades to a nice light brown ring with very nice lacing.  Nice pattern of carbonation on the surface.  Aroma is chocolate, toffee, malt, some dark fruit, a touch of alcohol.  Lots of flavors here...starts with great dark malt, coco, a bit of coffee, fading to dark fruit, followed by a big hit of hop bitterness.  Some warming alcohol on the end detracts a bit.  Quite smooth and creamy, but again the alcohol makes it a little harsher on the tongue than I like.  Overall, a great beer, 
but one that will get even better from some time in the cellar. (7.5.8.4.15)

RERATE: After using this beer to get me through some snowstorms in MN, I have realized that my 15 overall is an affront to the beer gods.

Poured from the bottle, this one was a darkest shade of  brown possible, with a medium-dark brown head that clung to the side of the glass. The aroma has an up-front alcohol character that seems like a licorice liqueur along with some underlying sweetness. The flavor is roasy, sweet, and almost tangy, featuring the same licorice character found in the aroma, with complementing characteristics of charred firewood and bitter chocolate. Texturally, it is mouth-filling and resinous, but not to the point of being syrupy.

Bouteille de 355 ml. Merci beaucoup David! Arômes très complexes de chocolat noir et de fruits confis. Robe noire et opaque, légère dentelle moka et effervescence faible. Très sucrée et épaisse en bouche, elle montre une belle complexité de chocolat noir, de céréales et de fruits mûrs. Le côté rôti, bien que présent, demeure discret pour une Imperial Stout. Une forte amertume de houblon résineux tente déquilibrer le sucre, sans totalement y arriver. Lalcool nest absolument pas apparent. Une très bonne bière, particulièrement décadente.

Smells of cherries, and burnt wood.  Almost no carbonation.  Head is a dark brown color and delicious in itself.  This beer just about pours the same as vodka thats been sitting in the freezer.  Probably the most viscus beer I can remember.  Maybe this should be called Old Engine Oil.  heh.  It is very warming which is understood coming from Michigan.  I get a lot of woody flavors, all the way up to citrus which I would assume is from the healthy backbone of hops.  Very strong hop aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2014 Re-rate. Bottle @ Casa de Brad. Thick black appearance with a thin dark brown head. Heavy anise, rich dark chocolate, a but burnt aroma. Thick, gooey mouth feel. Booze is a but heavy. Flavors of prunes, figs, piney, bitter hops, dark chocolate, rich raisins, and smoke. Lots of anise. Finishes strong. Not nearly as good as I remembered but still enjoyable.

I have previously stated that Samuel Smiths and Old Rasputin were my favorite imperial Stouts, and while I dont totally retract that statement, I do recognize that I forgot to account for Expedition Stout becoming the father in my imperial holy trinity. This stuff is serious. Poured black as night into a snifter, and was amazed that absolutely no light could penetrate the darkness. It was totally opaque. The head was full and left wonderful trails. I had refrigerated the bottle, but let the poured Expedition breathe in the snifter for a few minutes before drinking. The flavor blew me away. The first word that comes to mind is dark. Dark dark dark, and heavy as can be. This is not for the faint of heart, but for anyone who carries an appreciation for the imperial stout, this is nothing short of mana. I would recommend savoring one of these at a time and leaving at least a couple from the six pack or whatever to age in refrigeration. I drink most stouts at room temperature but this one actually packs more flavor than most stouts in prime drinking conditions while still being quite cool. Brilliant. Bells is one of the best in the game.

From batch 9971.  Pours motor oil black with dark and foamy tan head.  Aroma is earthy and malty with a hint of sweetness, but lacking in intensity.  Tastes full of oats malts, and a decent amount of hops.  Thick, syrupy, and full bodied with a lingering bitterness.  Pretty much exactly what it was going for, which is good, but I prefer my imperial stouts less hoppy and more on the coffee, chocolate side.

batch  8311.  For being two years old this one was holding up very well.  Hops were still present as was also alot of bitter dark chocolate.  Black as night pour minimal head.  Nose was overpowering dark chocolate, roasted malts, coffee.  Quite the bitter beer, I was almost expecting this one to have mellowed out.  I think this will get even better in another year.  Very well done.

Batch 8864 Bottled in December of 08 consumed on 2/11/10.

A-beautiful jet black, great head. same as below review.

S-the nose is actually quite nice on this batch. lots of molasses, hints of dark chocolate, a touch of roasted malt.

T/M-full bodied, quite thick. extremely smooth and chewy. some roasted malt up front, touch of molasses, big dark chocolate taste. sweet malts next with dark fruit of dark cherries and a touch of ripe plum. the finish actually still shows a note of hop bitterness and a touch of crispness.

D-this is very good, I love it way more than I enjoyed the previous bottle. Im so glad I found a case of this. The taste is huge, the body is great, this is spot on and right up there!

***

A-Pours a thick creamy dark brown head that is quite large, i did pour aggressively and it went crazy. the color of the beer is jet black and even a mag-lite cant get a shimmer of light through. the head has solid retention and is slowly leaving huge lace on the glass. this is an amazing looking beer.

S-the nose is very light and im not getting a lot. i get the typical smells of some roasted malt, hints of molasses and a faint touch of dark chocolate with some medicinal alcohol notes and some sweet citrus coming in last.

T-the taste starts of with the roasted malt and then fades to some molasses flavor accompanied by dark chocolate, a sweetness comes in next with some dark cherry blended with citrus finishing slightly bitter

M-not huge body but it is relatively full, extremely smooth and very low levels of carbonation. a slight, very slight, burning of alcohol on the back of the throat but the alcohol is extremely well hidden.

D-very tasty and well hidden alcohol. nothing huge here so it isnt a top RIS; but definitely a solid choice.

Tasting of the same batch on 10/30/10

S-the nose is nice, extremely malty, lots of roasty malts, molasses, rich chocolate rum cake, hints of licorice light bit of booze.

T-follows the nose, very rich and creamy taste with tons of roasted malts and very little sweetness. chocolate rum cake, licorice, notes of plums hints of booze but still very nice.

M-full bodied, soft and creamy, perfectly carbonated with a very inviting feel.

D-this is well balanced and very tasty.  very little sweetness in the back but present and well done.  creamy and rich beer!
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 Kalamazoo stout gone wild! Very smooth, but the alcohol has a bit of an afterburn. Beyond that, expedition stout is a tasty beer. For normal driking, go Kalamazoo.

I picked this up at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL, enjoyed on a Friday night at home.  Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, dark roast coffee, and a little bit of hops that if anything adds a hint of spices.  Appearance is pitch black with a very small tan head.  Taste is very creamy and rich.  Very rich in dark chocolate and coffee, hops are somewhere in there and provides a hint of bitterness, its not flat but not carbonated.  For a 10.5% ABV it doesnt taste like it packs the punch it actually does.  Its a cool Chicago night and a great one to enjoy this.

What can I add about this perennial All-star that others have not said already?  Is right up there with the Rasputin in terms of consistency year after year, and that is the best you can hope for.....consistency!!!

Oh man, I didnt realize Bells was so good at stouts.  Aroma is what youd expect - malt sweetness.  Pours black with a brown head with heavy lacing.  Taste is a refined malt, coffee, dark chocolate.  Body is thick and pleasant.  Wow this is delicious, and just think that a few months ago I hated stouts before I had my awakening :)  A really great beer.

Poured into a tulip glass. Appearance is black as black can be with a brown head that does not go away. Nice lacing. Aroma is black coffee, dark chocolate, and a hint of hops. Taste follows suit with black coffee and dark chocolate up front and hops in the background. All I have to say is daaaaaaamn!

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Aroma is of alcohol, and chocolate.  Appearance is beautiful, black as night, syrupy, and a small brown head that does not stick around.  A bit of lacing as you progress through this monster.  Taste is very typical to style, big malt and hops balanced well.  The palate is thick like syrup, and not much carbonation, but the finish is quite long and complex.  Overall, a nice beer, but not a regular in my rotation.

Bottle: Pours a syrupy jet black with a nice tan head with good retention and terrific lacing as well. Aroma is a bit curious; a combination of heavy malts and an interesting hint of fruits, depending on when i give it a good smell test. Big brew here to be sure, nice and thick, hop bitterness at the end, but it blends well with huge chocolate, coffee, malt elements. A bit of booziness is present as well - fantastic.

A wonderfully made stout with a punch that could stagger Old Rasputin, if only for a moment. The earthy aroma is much like 8 oclock Coffees Columbian flavor. Only the slightest hint of bitterness alerts you to the fact that it beholds an alcohol content of 10.5%. Otherwise, it goes down smoothly, lingering for a time on the palate. Definitely something to end your night with. Respect this Bell, or your head will be ringing in the morning. (Im sure that pun has been used, but its true.)

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2016 I love Bells brews. This is full of alcohol, so strong, a real great Imperial Stout.

Second Rating, 7/10/2016. As good as I remember, except even better.

12oz 2009 btl. Pours inky, thick and black with a deep brown head. Smells stongly of malty chocolate. Great balance of malt and hops. nice smooth start, mild hops in the mild, and awesome sweet chocolate finish. Great, great, great.

12-ounce bottle courtesy of me.  One of my first few imperial stout ratings.  I must say imperial stouts can be a taste-overload for my untrained palate, but I agree with the rating populous.....this is a fantastic beer.  But, definitely a sipper for me though.  Ill definitely keep a bottle or two in the cellar and revisit next year.

Dark as can be, blackish brown with a minimal brown head. Oh, so deep in flavor. Complex roasted malt with hints of dried fruit, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and a bit of earthiness as well. Warming. Good.

Pours a rich, thick, darkness.  Pour in a light room because this bear will cancel out a good deal of ambient light.  Like a black hole.  Slighlty sweet chocolate and caramel notes mask a heavy alcohol content.  If this beer wasnt so thick, it might sneak up on you.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours pitch black with a nice brown head, aroma is very sweet with hints of coffee and chocolate, the taste is extremely smooth and has the perfect amount of malt with chocolate and coffee notes.  It actually hides the 10.5% very well because there is hardly an alcohol burn to it at all.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2010 Bottle, bought at Cracked Kettle by the Reakt and consumed with Reakt and Dsg.

This beer is complex, balanced, smooth, great bitterness, not overtly aggressive in the texture, excellent medium finish of chocolate and coffee, excellent grainy coffee texture, lovely dose of expensive cream, this beer is a world class winner. 

Wood. Damn it gives me wood. 

Thanks Reakt and also thanks to Cracked Kettle for getting this in. Nice.
I am not going to be a snobbish academic rater. This is complex, balance of chocolate, hint of coffee, with a sweet  aftertaste beer, that is the best beer I have ever tasted in 41 years.

Really, really good stuff.  Thick and rich and flavorful.  Probably as good as it gets this side of Dark Lord.  this was somewhere between 6 and 9 months old when I drank it.  Lots of coffee in the nose then coffee and hop up front and through the palate.  Get hints of chocolate and vanilla.  Has a full body and long, lingering, smooth finish.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden in palate.  Highly recommended.

12 oz bottle - 2008 vintage - pours a deep black with a light brown head. Nice lacing on my Lost Abbey glass. Great nose. Has an aroma of coffee, caramel and plums  Starts off with deep malty flavors and a toffee sweetness, then finishes with a dry, coffee flavor. Beautifully complex.....,a terrific stout that really improves as it warms up. Nice!

Bottle with no batch number but I am pretty sure I got this a year or 2 ago. Pours a dep dark brown/black color with a farily thick 1 finger head.
