Aromas of some sweet malts with dark fruit, coffee, and bittersweet chocolate. The taste is extremely layered with a nice thick and creamy heavy mouthfeel. Sweet dark chocolate up front followed by roast coffee and leather. Big and chewy.

I may be a little finnicky about my ratings and its hard to get perfect scores unless I think its an absolutely perfect beer or "wows" me in a specific  catagory.  This beer has been all in all, damn near close to as good as it gets but I still have a hard time giving perfect scores.  Thanks Bells for giving me another beer to smile about.
Tons of malt well balanced with the right amount of hops.  Tastes like the smell of freshly cracked malt.  Slight coffee flavor with an earthy finish.  Let it warm up to about 50 degrees.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2015 quite simply, a beer deserving of all the hype. had this after a Kalamazoo, which was good, but not akin to being ranked 52nd out of 21,000+ beers (probably around #200 for me) so i was a little worried for this one...just a little. Anyway, no worries. This beer is simply amazing. Rivals the best of the best Imperials (Stone, Yeti, Speedway, TenFidy). Reminds me of Yeti more than anything else with the initial blast of hops then tempered with roasted malt, and even the sweeter rum-soaked raisin aspect (many "good" stouts have one or the other, but not all these aspects. perfectly balanced here, with a warming, but not "hot" finish. full and smooth. One of my top 10or so beers of any style. courtesy of bluesandbarbq."

2009 bottle. jet black with a brown frothy head. as it warms the roasty aroma comes through, but so does the alcohol. Flavor is thick, smoky and dark malts. Rather unpleasantly sweet though. Really not my thing at all. Thanks to b- for the opportunity to try this though.

A solid stout that is tough to beat.  Aromas of roasted coffee and chocolate
Very easy to drink, and enjoyable stout.

12 oz bottle Pours to a deep dark brown black with a creamy brown head. Aroma is heavy malt, roasty and toasty. Taste is very sweet with a hint of bitter. Lots of chocolate and java, mild nut flavor also. Body is full and creamy. soft carbonation and along full finish. Overall a very good stout. Well crafted and very complex. Give it a try.

(bottle, courtesy of Andrew; sampled 4/10/10). Black color. Medium tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Moderate roasted malt aroma, with moderate chocolate.  Sweet chocolate/roasted malt flavor. Avg duration. Finish is light alcohol, light bitter, and light dryness.  Slick texture. Soft to moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

8/26/10 notes, early 2010 bottling.  Blew away high expectations.  Color is deep brown with a lingering dark foam head.  Aroma blasts with espresso, black roasted malt, almond and dark chocolate.  Palate has round, full, perfectly carbonated with a long finish.  The flavors has just a tremendous assortment of melted gourmet dark chocolate, and ash, mocha sweetness in mmiddle, then more coffee and roasty bitterness towards the finish.  This is the epitome of a balanced, complex, massively flavorful stout; decadent.

Bottle.

A - Deep dark black with a large creamy, frothy, thick, meringue-like, dark tan head. Really good retention that settles into a nice thick, creamy lace.

S - Good amount of chocolate and some black coffee. Roasted malt is very prominent. Some dark fruit tartness and hints of licorice and soy aroma. Some caramel as well. Tartness is fairly strong (for the style).

T - Rich and fairly complex flavors. Dark chocolate and roasted malt are the strongest flavors. Has some burnt sugar and coffee flavors as well. Some dark fruit, although none really stand out much. Also a bit of anise and soy. The tartness in the aroma is also there and mixes along with some roasted bitterness. Alcohol heat is also present. Usually the tartness is toward the beginning of the taste with more of the chocolate and burnt flavors and alcohol mid to finish of the sip. Hints of citrus hops in there.

M - Full thick feel with a good amount of carbonation. Very thick and creamy feel.

D - A little much to want to drink a lot or to have it on a regular basis. Very much a sipper, with the alcohol heat and slight tartness and bitterness making it a bit less drinkable. Wasnt quite as balanced as I would have liked.

Notes: Batch 9554. Decent stout, but not my favorite. Seemed just a little off balanced. Not bad overall and I would drink it again, but for the price there are others that are better.
Aromas of roasted coffee, chocolate and caramel.  Flavors of dark chocolate, caramel and dark fruit.  Overall an outstanding stout.

deep roasty aroma with chocolate milk, licorice, green olives, sour milk, soy sauce, dough, and alcohol.
pours opaque brown with a huge frothy brown head.
excellently balanced flavor bursting with sweet, sour, and bitter.
thick and chewy with lively carbonation and long bitter floral chocolate finish.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 Pours opaque black and thick.  Heavy pour results in no head at first, but then comes exploding out of solution in a deep orange yellow color.  Aroma is toffee, caramel, molasses, vanilla, a hint of cinnamon, mild coffee.  Flavor is very robust.  A little sweeter than I expected.  Well-rounded thick palate.  Mild lacing.  The real deal.   Re-rate:  Hop heavy fresh.  Needs aging.  Big roast/burnt qualities.  Still top-notch regular impy.  Reality rate -0.4.

Thick oily black pour, one finger tan head.  Roasty, leathery, chocolate, coffee aromas.  These tastes are so well integrated, the depth is there in every sip without the beer feeling like too much.  No cloying aftertaste or acridness, which is truly impressive.

Its black cant see thru it.  Has a woody leathery nose.  Very bittersweet roast coffee, and fudge chocolate favor.  Rich and chewy.  Lacks some hop balance, and silkyness, which I like.  Bitter finish.  Damn good, but too roasty.

Batch 9512. Bottled Dec 18 2009. Thanks to Bells batch Finder! This poured like a dark motor oil. Thick tan head with nice lacing which stayed on the sides of the glass. Taste of espresso, some hop bitterness, chocolate and roasty malt. The alcohol becomes more evident as it warms. Would love to taste this after a few years of cellaring if only I could keep my hands from prying off the cap!

From a 12 oz into a pint.  Pours like crude oil directly from the Gulf.  Dark gray/brown head; about one inch worth.  Not much lacing.  Aroma of coffee and licorice.  Mouthfeel is about as thick as it looks, damn near pudding consistency.  Taste is like having a pound of espresso beans pressed into a pint glass.  Tons o coffee, licorice, cough syrup, plenty of alcohol.  This stuff is the real deal.  High powered and good to the last drop.

(12oz. bottle).  Pours black like oil with thin brown head.  Aroma of alcohol, some roasted coffee, dried cherries?  Taste is fairly hoppy/dry roastiness along with some sweetness.  Full bodied with creamy/oily texture.  Finish is slightly bitter/dry, but not over the top.  This beer is well balanced.  I would like to try this aged as the hop edge should lessen and allow the creamy richness of the beer to further develop.

Appearance:  oily and viscous, black like coffee; virtually no head and a hint of dark brown lacing.  Aroma:  molasses, figs in heavy syrup, dark bitter chocolate, alchohol is well-hidden.  Taste:  bittersweet dark chocolate, coffee, prunes, bitter hops.  Finish:  lingering, very dry bitterness and alcohol.  Notes:  A little too strong and a little too bitter to enjoy fully. However, the flavors did mellow and simultaneously come out as it warmed.  At the start, it was a 2.5; after 45 minutes of careful sipping, it was a 3.7.

Apperance: Pitch black with a big, beige, head and lots of lacing.

Aroma: Roasted malts, Chocolate, Cookies, Molasses.

Taste: Espresso, Chocolate, Roasted malts, Dark sugar.

Palate: Thick and very heavy. Massive chocolate/espresso up front and ends with a lingering bitterness.

I dig this. Not as complex as some other stouts but thick and kickass like a stout should be.

Interesting aromas of coffee, hops and dark fruits.
Anyway this is an unbalanced brew. The alcohol dominates and overshadows other flavors. Not memorable

12oz bottle, poured black with a one finger dark brown head. Aroma is chocolate, roasty, caramel, maybe some coffee. Flavor is all over the place, big malt flavors of molasses, chocolate, whopper (malt balls, not the burger!), a little bitter back bone and some alcohol on the finish. I was disappointed when this bottle was gone, luckily I got one more in my trade!

12 oz bottle.  Pours a pitch black with a small chocolate head leaving significant lacing on the glass.  Strong molasses smell with a hint of chocolate and alcohol.  Taste is molasses, chocolate, and warm alcohol.  Heavy mouthfeel.  Great beer, but a bit heavy on the alcohol.

Pours pitch black with one of the darker brown heads I have seen. The finger head quickly fades do to the high ABV. Carbonation seems a little on the high side of the style.

On the aroma I get a ton of roasted malts along with dark fruits and molasses. Some alcohol present as well. On the palate I get a ton of chocolate - something I didnt get from the aroma. Up front some of the dark fruits are present before the chocolate takes over leaving a lingering somewhat sweet finish

Bottle expensively procured from the Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Black pour with a tan head. Nice roasty, toasty nose. Plenty of toffee, coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa, butterscotch in there. Good, rich flavours of vanilla, dark chocolate, dark roast coffee and brown sugar. Dry as a bone finish with an underlying smoky feel. Yum, yum!
UPDATED: APR 14, 2012 Bottle. Pours pitch black with a mocha head and lots of lacing. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, vanilla.. reminds me of espresso. Fantastic.

Pours a dark dark motor oil black with a small brown head.  Smells of chocolate, coffee, caramel, toasted hops, and more coffee.  Delicious aroma.  Initial thoughts:  creamy body, dry finish, roasted coffee aftertaste, chocolately taste, and some alcohol in the finish.  Has a nice blend of the creamy texture with the dry finish. Taste is very rich and delicious.

Poured black with a medium sized tan head.  Very chocolatey aroma with some vanilla and coffee.  Flavor is strong of chocolate malts.  Bitterness is balanced out by a sweet vanilla creamyness with some dark fruit.  Finish is a bit dry and bitter.  Alcohol is well hidden.

12 oz. bottle.
A dark, thick deep beer with strong tastes of  chocolate . It also tastes like something was burnt malt with a hint of some coffee as well. 
Grabbed one of these by accident from my son in laws fridge when I was mowing at his place.
Drinking this while mowing in 93 degree heat is not a best practice!
It really knocks you down - LOL (with its 10.5% ).
A very fine pour. Well done Bells. Not too refined. Pure.

Batch 8726

Poured into a pint glass. Pours a dark brown head that leaves an incredible lacing. Color is dark dark brown, almost black.

Smell is a toasted malted chocolate. Very toasty that is. Taste is quite similar very very chocolaty. It also tastes like something was burnt. Some dark fruit notes in there. Maybe some coffee as well.

Mouthfeel is very smooth, just a little crisp. After it lingers around enough, the 10.5% abv shows. Full bodied with a nice amount of carbonation.

Overall, this is a great RIS. Not too expensive for a 6er and at 10.5% you really cant go wrong. I will be getting this every year. If you see this at the stores, do yourself a favor and buy some!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-22-2008 01:49:38

July 2010 - Poured this into a broad-mouthed Coca-Cola glass producing an opaque dark brown body with a dense, light tan 3/4 inch head reminiscent of Guinness. However, thats where the likeness stopped. This stout had flavor, rich thick taste and style. The aroma of chocolate, roasted grains, and maybe some licorice. The flavor was chocolate thick, faintly sweet, pleasant. The faint alcohol trailed in last, about the same time the 10.5 hit my head! My one complaint was that this was the only bottle in a gift "6-pack sampler". I will definitely seek this beer out again! Wow!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark brown/black body with a thick brown head that lasts breifly before turning into a nice film... Significant  lacing...

S: Rich roasted malts... caramel/chocolate/coffee/molases/wood/roasted grain.. nice bitterness from hops. 

T: A bold, robust coffee-chocolate-caramel malt blast... a nice bitter hop finish is paired with a smooth vanilla oak (almost bourbon-like) finish.. alcohol is present in the taste.. Exceptional depth and complexity.

M: Smooth transitions with a sharp dry bitter finish.

O: on occasion this monster may suffer a bit  from its own success... its bold and assertive and I can only drink it when I am really craving a stout.  But when I do, there are few comparables out there.
Pours black with a lacing tan head.  Chocolate, cherries, coffee, and roasted malt notes.  Full bodied.  Very nice.

I paid $18 for a 6 pack of this, but it was worth every penny.  Pours a very dark color with a good amount of head.  Extremely complex aromas, dark roast, coffee and hop notes.  Initial dark roast attack with hints of molasses and caramel which fades to a nice slightly hoppy finish.  A wonderful, wonderful beer.

had the 12oz bottle from warehouse wines. pours a dark black coffee pours with little head. aroma is good with dark chocalate, dark fruit, maybe some kind of nut? Malty chocalate taste that was great, and expresso in the backend. palate was good, not as heavy as you would expect but with good warming ability and not too sticky. This is a great imperial stout!

Been waiting a long time to try this. Bottle poured into a small goblet, midnight black with small espresso-like head that reduces to a cap of foam, very little lacing. Nose is well-aged port, lots of dark chocolate, cappuccino, dark fruits. Taste is incredibly smooth, with dark chocolate, milk chocolate, viscous coffee, slight blackberry, leather, wood, and smoke. Finishes very clean, lingers pleasantly on the palate. This is hands-down the smoothest impy stout Ive ever had. A bit more lacing would have been the cherry on top, but this is damn fine.

Bottled December 2009.  Smell is dark coco and vanilla. Color is black with mocha colored head and good lacing.  Taste us roasty coco and coffee.  Palate is thick and smooth almost like milk.  Fantastic.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2011 Black pour light tan head .... smells of chocolate, vanilla and roasted malts smells amazing ..... taste of licorice, dark chocolate, vanilla and roasted coffee/malts with a huge hoppy bitter bite  ..... has a lingering bitterness to it and a dry finish ...... an upgrade from the kalamazoo stout for sure! ...... tons of flavor and no trace of abv
A good, well balanced beer.  Its very enjoyable, but doesnt compare to DarkLord or the the Goose Island Bourbon Stout.  A little expensive for the amount of flavor in my opinion.

Bottle.  Poured a dark black color.  Huge roasted malt aroma.  Taste:  had layers of flavor from the roasted malts and slight bitterness from the hops. They give the stout a bite that you wouldnt normally expect.  great brew

Bottle. Black pour with a nice, light-weight brown head. Aroma of subtle roast, a little chocolate and some mild, bitter coffee, vanilla, a little alcohol, some figs and other dark fruits and berries.Very round and lovely! Taste is also well-balanced and rounded, with hints of liqourice, soy, bitter chocolate and a little coffee. A lovely bitter finish, with some faint hop-notes. Very complex and pleasant at the same time. Velvety soft palate, that softly licks the inside of your mouth, filling it with the excellent taste. Low carbonation, long duration, full-bodied. Excellent brew, slightly reminiscent of the current Dark Lord.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2010 Courtesy of Enjoyit. Bottled. Nice opaque black pour with a fine small dense brown head, more of a rim after a moment. Aroma is thick with chocolate, huge sweetness, dark berries, and hints of hard roasted espresso, vanilla, maybe a bit of maripan and almonds, really delicious. Taste is thick and heavy. Licorice, soy sauce, roasted espresso, not a huge sweetness, but just enough to compliment the more dark tastes. It actually reminds me of Dark Lord. Bitter and salty finish, humungous body. This is an astonishing brew, Im truly amazed. One of the best imperial stouts Ive had this far.

Ive had several vintages of this.  This particular one is 2009.  Very vinous estery, roasted, coffee, molasses nose.  Taste is extremely overwhelming with intense flavors.  I cant relly detect the hops though they are there.  Bitter in the finish.  This is one amazing beer.  People that dont like beer will enjoy this in the morning.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2012 After 500 laps at Talladega, Junior unplugged the bottom of his oil pan and poured this delicious 40 weight into a pint glass.  A small (less than a finger) head topped this go go juice.  The nose is blasted with aromas of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and a hint of coffee and molasses. This amazing stout hits your palate like shaft or dolomite blowin up the big screen.  Silky smooth with just the right ass kickin amounts of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and molasses.  Perfectly balanced this bad boy begins with just the right amount of bitterness and quickly fades to chocolate and malt, leaving your mouth begging for more..  A real freakin show stopper.....

at Savvy1982s tasting - Smells liie homebrew still fermenting - warm and alive. crazy ripe. A good head, seriously dark, some lacing. Just a hint of fruit flavour, ripe wet malt, fades out with a coffee flavour. Palate is same as the flavour but more intense. This was absolutely great. It this was in supply I could pioneer the west. Again.
Incredibly dark and thick with an immensely complex flavor profile.  Brewed specifically for vintage aging in mind.

Oily milk chocolate. Heavy alcohol. Mighty oak. Severe. The alcohol really dominates. Bourbon.

The appearance is deep black with a hint of brown. Carbonation creates a cardboard brown head, lasting for a few minutes.

Dual flavors of bitter burnt cookies and chocolate truffles. Incredibly burnt and bitter. The oaky wood dovetails beautifully with the cookie flavor.

Feels oily and slick. Its a major, hefty, oily, burnt and bitter stout. A one-off sipper, but a beast of a beer.

My second tasting, this time from the bottle.  Bottled on 11/19/09.  Poured the blackest of black with no head whatsoever.  It appeared to have little to no carbonation, but there was some in solution, the perfect amount for this style.  Aroma is an intense array of smells ranging from roasted malts to figs and some booze.  Extremely bold and delightful.  Its viscous consistency translates to a really nice creamy and full mouthfeel.  Top shelf stout from Bells.

Bottle. Pours jet black with a short brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, licorice and had a earthy quality. Silky smooth flavor of rich roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate, roasted coffee, molasses and notes of licorice with a oily & thick mouthfeel.  Excellent imp stout.
For the style, it doesnt get much better than this. Perfectly balanced in every way. Amazing beer!

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2011 After many, many bottles of this beer a rerate is warranted.  Pours viscous pitch black with an expresso singed dark tan head that slowly fades out, laces its way down the glass, and then reappears in a velvet ebb of bubbles with each swirl of the glass.  Aroma is a dense, layered malt profile with chocolate, ash, char, faded hops, licorice, peat, and a soft lingering sweetness buried in the finish.  Quite a complex smell that I can only take a stab at in terms of description.  Taste is roasted malt bitterness and faded hops up front followed by char, leather, licorice, chocolate (both bitter and soft),  some dark fruit sweetness, and a lingering bitterness (perhaps somehops or perhaps the alcohol or both).  Lucscious feel in the mouth with some prickle from the alcohol.  Absolutely unique beer that stuns me with its quality every time.

I have a year-plus old bottle of this (Thanks Matt!) and it pours dark coffee black with thick taupe head. When poured it smells actually hoppy but clearly this hop character has with age receded into a backbone of almost tannic bitterness. Great layers of coffee, smoky tar, and bitter chocolate, some acidic citrus. Huge rising finish of hop bitterness barely tamedt by the intense sweet and roasted malts. Wine like with black dried fruits. Alcohol is warm yet integrated. Glad to try this at fourteen months, and curious what fresh bottlings taste like.

Bottle thanks to Rando7. Pours jet black with tan head. Nose is licorice, booze, vanilla and bakers chocolate. Taste is heavy licorice, dark fruits, vanilla, warming alcohol, chocolate and coffee. Full mouth feel. Oily stout.

Deep brown/black with short, thick, brown head.  First taste is clearly licorice but progresses into a taste much more complex.  Full bodied with creamy texture and perfect carbonation. Like it, alot.

Appearance: Very dark black with a nice 2 finger foam cap. Some retention and great lacing. So far Im impressed!

Smell: Roasted malt that gives off a hint of coffee, some vanillia, and a wood note stand out. The notes are there but are not the most pronounced. You have to dig for them a bit.

Taste: I get bread pudding, roasted malt, some dark chocolate (but nothing like Choklat from Southern Tier), and a hint of anise. Better than the nose!

Mouthfeel: A full bodied brew that is a touch thick and a little flat. I think more carbonation would help in this category and this is the least impressive category for ES so far.

UPDATE 11/29/09: Ive since had this brew several more times and have found more recent samplings to have better carbonation so Im changing my score from a 3.5 to 4.0

Drinkability: Tastes great and is fairly drinkable for a full bodied low carbonation brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-17-2009
12 oz. bottle,  pitch black, light head.  10.5 percent is impressive.  roasty and choclatety.  im impressed with this stout. it surpasssed my expectations.

Extremely good beer.  Complex taste even for an imperial stout.  I would describe the flavor but I think it would suffice to say that if you are a stout fan then this is a must.  Lacing is a brownish almost burgundy color, really adds to the aesthetic value of the beer.  Definately a beer you should let decant for a while to bring out more flavors.

12oz bottle in a pilsner glass.  Pours black with a beige head.  Aroma of coffee and roasted malts.  It has a sweet, malty flavor first.  If I could give this beer over a 5 for palate I would.  The texture is probably the thickest and oiliest of any beer Ive tasted.  Long chocolate and coffee finish.  A very complex stout, and an amazing beer that Im sad is not available in the northeastern states where Ive looked.
Pitch black. Slightly coffee head with piercing burnt nose. Very strong burnt flavor with chocolate flavors. Very lingering burnt flavor.
Burnt roasty dark cocoa.  Nearly no alcohol in the taste.  Badass imperial stout could kill several.
Had with the guys at James and my place. Pour is dark thick black. Thick brown head. Aroma is amazing with chocolate and coffee. Molasis. Flavor is so smooth. Filled with chocolate and roasted malts.
12 ounce bottle-adark pour-brown head -aroma and taste of chocolate, toast, licorice, -super sweet syrupy finish

12 oz bottle purchased individually from Beer Crazy in Urbandale, IA. I first enjoyed this brew with my pal Adam in Palm Bay, Florida. Thankfully, Iowa beer legislation has changed and we can now bring in great beers like Expedition Stout. I didnt wait for my beer to get completely cold before I decided to drink it, and I think that really helped bring out the aroma. This stouts aroma really shows off its malt and hops. It seduces you with promises of indulgent, dirty, no holds barred frolic. My beer poured golden black with a fine but rich head. It is pleasantly bitter, mellowed only by a bourbon / oak woodiness. Full of body and the finish lingers like low voltage a/c running through your mouth. Great beer!

This offering from Bells is absolutely one of the best, if not the best stout I have ever had.  You can easily taste roasted malt and a great, sweet vanilla flavor throughout the whole beer.  In my opinion my friend and fellow beer taster hit the nail on the head when he described this beer as "beer candy."  This brew definitely deserves all the praise it receives and it wasnt even all that expensive either!  I will surely come back to this stout as many times as i can.

Nice pour with motor oil black and dark brown head. Aroma was malty with coffee, caramel and a light floral. Taste was coffee with a light caramel and a medium bitter on the back of the tongue as you swallow. Good mouth feel with full body and nice carbonation. A very good stout which I would readily drink again.

12oz bottle shipped to me from my totally awesome-o brother in law in Michigan.  Batch #9554.  WOW.  The best stout Ive ever had.  Start to finish, I had feelings reminiscent of my first orgasm- new, exciting, addictive and a bit embarrassing.  Words are hopelessly inadequate so Ill stop with that.

Pretty fresh bottle. Pitch black with a fine, thick, tan, oily head that stayed forever. Beautiful. Dry, subtle aroma with berries, lots of alcohol fumes, and something rather unusual for a stout, like bubble gum or rubber, or even thinner. Funky-sweet flavor with strong alcohol, fruit (berries), mint, licorice. Full, thick, oily body. Hot and rather weird but great.

Pours pure black with the consistency of motor oil.  Thin tan head.  Aroma is coffee, dark malts and molasses.  Flavor is bitter coffee, toffee and an off-putting soy sauce flavor in the finish.  Moderate alcohol burn an slightly astringent finish. OK, but I just couldnt really get into this one.

First time trying this, and I havent had too many stouts yet, although I look forward to trying more.  Anyway, this is a thick, black beer with a rather thin, dark tan head.  It was initially a little too cold, but as it warmed up more of the flavors came out.  The previous reviews talk enough about the aroma and flavor, so I dont have much to add there.  It is a good tasting beer, a good one to drink slowly so you can appreciate the new flavors that come out as it goes through temperature changes.  Not as bitter as I thought it would be.  I think it is a good stout, not overpowering.  I was gonna try GI BCS tonight, but was afraid it would be stronger than what I was in the mood for, so I went with this one instead and it was a good choice.  Several minutes after finishing the beer, my face started to flush, but it was smooth going down.  Give it a try.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2012 Bottle split with Pat. Pours a pitch black body with small off white brown head. Aroma is strong chocolate, toffee, slight roast. Mouthfeel is nearly perfect, with great accents of chocolate, malts, and some hop undertons.

12 oz bottle. Pours like pitch having a small, dark chocolate head (killed by the alcohol). Aroma is amazing and strong. Smells like roasted nuts, caramel, coffee, and a little bit of bourbon. The taste is powerful, sweet, and well supported by the thickness of the brew. Its a mix of bittersweet chocolate, caramel, some oak, a nice hint of sourness from the malt, and some alcohol. Finishes thick and a little bitter--coats the mouth so you must drink more. Not quite as overpowering as Bourbon County Stout, making it a little easier to keep drinking.

This is an adult stout.  I would give the aroma an 11 if it would let me...it really smells good.  Has a nose of coffee, chocolate, alcohol, vanilla, and brandy.  It is very full bodied, has a relatively light head, and lingers both in the glass and in the mouth.  

As for taste, it is quite sweet compared to some other stouts I"ve run into, but is extremely flavorful with a  coffee aftertaste that cuts through some of the sweetness.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2010 Bottle pours syrupy almost black with brown medium head.  Nice lacing.  Taste - there is a lot going on here..  Sweet malts, chocolate, coffee, roast with a hoppy finish.  Thick aggressive feel with alcohol very apparent.  Nice alcohol burn.  Theres something at the end of this that tastes almost like plastic.

i accidentally coughed while drinking this and some went up my nose - holy crap.

Going to cellar the rest of this but even without cellaring its a mighty beer.

12 oz. bottle; batch 8183; jet black with trace tan head to the edges; can smell this sucker from across the room; chocolate, chocolate and chocolate; wow, resiny sweet nose with pure chocolate roast; oily booze and coffee; thick, roasty texture with mild astringency that I dont remember from before; booze, tons of bitter chocolate, yummy coffee goodness; burnt malts and tobacco; astringency lightens as it warms and someone this is both a punch in the face and an array of subtle complexity; hot damn this is good stuff  

9/18/08 update - Batch 8311; aromas much more bitter in this batch; smoothness is there and gives off a sticky finish; sweetness less pronounced than batch 8183; just wonderful, but I might have been too eager to try another bottle as a little more time would get this just the way I like it

Original rating 11/22/07: 12 oz. bottle - received multiple bottles via trades in recent months and sampled thanks to after4ever about a month ago; shortly after that taste, I sat down and savored a bottle from batch 8183; pours thick and creamy brown; chocolate colored head fades quickly; roasty and bitter sweet; alcohol is obvious; thin texture and oily smooth, but packs a mouthful; drinks deceptively smooth for a big beer; flavors of coffee, bitter chocolate and sweet fruit; quite a bit of sweetness overall; dangerously smooth and a totally kick ass impy

Pours like used motor oil, with a medium sized, tannish-brown, sinister looking head.  Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, a hint of anise.  Light notes of alcohol.  Heavy on the palate, but very smooth.  Feels lively and dense at the same time.  Wow... this is a very complex beer, it starts with a punch of chocolate, shows you some sweet and silky, then turns on the roasted malt for a bit, and then lets hops come in while they all have a finishing party.  That actually sounds like a bad porn. Huh.

Pours a dark black color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of toffee, caramel, and hints of dark fruit.  Yeah, this is a good stout.  You have the sweet hitting the front of the tongue, the bitters on the back with hints of smoke.  You can also taste sweet caramel and some coffee/toffee flavor.  Ultra complex, but everything is work so well.  A rich beer.  Love it.

Black as the night with a brown head. A whiff of this reveals burnt malty scent and almost a faint smell of dark fruits. This full bodied beer is thicker than a latinas big bottom at the club. Lots going on here, roasted malts, chocolate, raisins, coffee and of course alcohol. This one ill warm ya up on a cold winter night, thats for sure.

This is usually a great stout, but I have had mixed results in the carbanation of the beer. I get a lot of chcoclate and roast malt in the nose, and then the tatse holds the same with some dried fruit too. Most noticable may be the thick and rich  mouthfeel. Its a wonderfully heavy beer that will coat your mouth.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2011 What?  Ive never rated this?  Batch 8944.  Dark burnt chocolate and sticky molasses.  Wet charcoal.  Jet black with a brash dark tan head, clinging to the glass.  Chocolate chip cookies, burnt around the edges.  Creamy milk chocolate meets burnt grain and scorched sugar.  Becomes aggressively sweet and cloying with the sugar getting stronger as the sips add up.  In the debate on how long to age Expedition, I vote for longer.  021111  Another 8944.  2 years old.  More cookie aroma, more burnt sugar.  Very chewy, very dark, seems akin to the rating 8 months ago.

RATING #100!   Thanks to ryan for cracking this 2002 bottle, ive heard theyre among the best.  Pours like motor oil, sticking to the side of the glass, with a dark tan head.  Very little carbonation, but you could barely hear a hiss when the bottle was opened.  Aroma is dominated by roast and licorice, with some chocolate and alcohol rounding it out.   Tastes like dark fruit, roast, licorice, raisins, with a great finish that tastes like bitter cherry peel and malt.  Awesome beer.

355ml Bottle, brought to Adam by GodOfThunder, thanks! Black beer, brown head. Aroma of hard roasted malts, a bit of liquorice, some vegetable notes from the alcohol, berries. Flavour is hard roasted malts, alcohol, vegetable cooking water, lots of brown sugary sweetness, chocolate mousse, coffee, hoppy and piney bitter finish with a coffee aftertaste. Fullbodied, oily and thick mouthfeel. Didnt dig the vegetable notes, otherwise a very good imperial stout. Have another bottle to re-rate.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into snifter. Pours black with a half-finger of bark brown head. Big, big aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, anise, caramel, and just a touch of hops. The flavor is everything the nose promised with the addition of vanilla and raisin flavors. So thick it coats the mouth. Yum.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2012 Pours a pitch black with a brown head.  aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, licorice, anise, and dark coco.  flavor is of roasted malts, dark coffee, licorice, anise, dark chocolate, with vanilla and dark fruit undertones.  has a full body with a amazing creamy, oily mouthfeel and a dry, bitter finnish.  overall, a excellent world class stout.

Picked this beer up at Dirty Johns in Iowa City, IA. Beer pours a dark black color with a thick dark brown head. Smell is of roasted malts and caramel. Flavor of chocolate, malts, coffee, and carmel. Very intense flavor and very intense beer. Not sure if I was ready for this one yet.

Second Bells I have tried.  12 oz. pour from bottle.  Black, deep rich black.  Thick dark brown foamy head that lingers for a short time before ending up in a thin skin of bubbles.  Nice chocolate with roasted coffee notes.  Slightly sweet, with a lingering taste without over powering me.  Fairly high abv but really doesnt taste it.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2011 Bottle thanks to TheJester. Beautiful black body with lasting mocha head.  Aroma is standard IS; coffee and chocolate truffle. Flavor is more interesting. So rich. Heavy chocolate brownies with some grapes and almonds. Somewhat boozy though. Creamy and syrupy palate. Its heavyness makes it less enjoyable.

Rerate on tap: Aroma: Molasses, anise, vanilla and dark chocolate. Lots of layers, I got more complexity than when I tried the bottle. (9) Appearance: Pitch black with a beautiful brown thick ring (4) Taste: Chocolate bomb, anise, bittersweet chocolate and a nice coffee finish. Palate: Full with low carb (4). Overall: Very good and well balanced. (17)

Bottle: 3.8
Tap: 4.4

I should definitly try another bottle.

Bottle 3.8

When I first started drinking craft beers Bells was the first brewery where i made an effort to try as many of their offerings as possible.  I was just 21 at the time, and didnt know much about different beer styles, so i drank my first 6-pack of expo in one night.  

Has a chocolate and fruit like aroma.  Tastes of raisins with subtle chocolate and soy sauce.  Finishes with a small alcohol burn.  Over 5 years after my initial experience with this beer it still remains a favorite.

Batch 9435. Heavy bodied stout. Pours dark with thick foamy head. Seems stronger than its ABV. Aromas of licorice and hops. Flavors of hops, chocolate, licorice, coffee, and alcohol. After taste is long  with a sweet roast caramely lingering sticky on the lips taste that lasts. Very well balanced. Nicely done. A classic for sure.

12 oz. pour from bottle.  Midnight black.  Slick mouthfeel, with a warm chocolate, roasted coffee taste.  Subtle alcohol, dispite fairly high abv.  A big beer that tastes great without being over powering.  Simply fantastic.

I used to smoke marijuana. But Ill tell you something: I would only smoke it in the late evening. Oh, occasionally the early evening, but usually the late evening - or the mid-evening. Just the early evening, mid evening and late evening. Occasionally, early afternoon, early mid-afternoon, or perhaps the late-mid afternoon. Oh, sometimes the early-mid-late-early morning. . . But never at dusk! Never at dusk, I would never do that.

From a beer trade.

Maybe I should stop my american beer quest. Iam always dissapointed in the end. It marks the cultural difference. Maybe european and americans do not look for the same thing in beer. This one is a banal stout for me.

12oz. Bottle from fall of 2007.  This is the last of the first Expedition sixer I purchased from Bells.  Color is black as pitch with zero head.  Nose is fantastic like a rich chocolate dessert with some slightly roasted coffee notes around the edges.  Flavor has a bit of everything and is what sets this beer apart from most.  First taste is mildly sweet with strong chocolate malt flavor that is quickly followed by a strong dose of bittering hops and a dry, roasted and astringent coffee flavor.  Some subtle tobacco, ash and vanilla lurking beneath the roasted malts.  Texture is slick, creamy and utterly fantastic.  Finish is long, relatively dry and roasty.  This is one of those classics that if you dont appreciate you may as well face the fact that you arent really into beer.

12 oz. bottle to snifter. Aroma strong soy chocolate and hints vanilla. Appearance is oil dark brown (black) with nice tan head and minimal lacing. Taste big dark bitter chocolate with hints of vanilla and soy. Palate full slick and dry finish. Overall solid and enjoy very much the taste keeps getting better as it sits.

Ive never been a big fan of the Russian Imperial Stout style because I often find the intense potency tends to overwhelm the palette and makes it difficult to appreciate. Then along comes Bells Expedition Stout - a midwestern example that impressed me more than all other previous examples of the style put together. Its got everything I look for in a great stout: smooth, creamy texture; prominent chocolate and deeply roasted barley notes and its quite drinkable. APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. This beer has a body that could only be described as opaque jet black. Even the head is very dark brown. Its creamy and surprisingly thick for an imperial brew. It lasts for the first few swigs, dies down, but regenerates easily with a quick swirl. The aroma is more along the lines of a chocolate stout with bitter dark chocolate notes as well as a significant alcohol presence. Its surprisingly mild for such a strong beer. TASTEI noticed three separate, but very noticeable, flavor components to Bells Expedition Stout. Up front the beer is thick, creamy, smooth and chocolaty. As it finishes theres quite a bit of heat from the alcohol which is rather dry, but completely tolerable. The aftertaste is almost as strong as the mouthfeel itself with a strong flavor of deeply roasted, or even burnt malts along with dark chocolate. Now thats what I consider a complex palette.What I like about this beer is the fact there is no sour red grape taste and the fact the chocolate is more on the bitter side so as not to be overly sweet the way some straight-up chocolate stouts tend to be. The alcohol is probably a little more prominent than Id prefer, but it actually seems to fade away as the beer warms (usually, the opposite is true of beers like this). I just wish the roasted malts had been more pronounced, since it this flavor was very pleasing on the tongue in the aftertaste. DRINKABILITYWhat impressed me most about Bells Expedition Stout (relatively speaking) was the how creamy and smooth the beer felt in the mouth. As it first enters the mouth, its velvety like a nitrogen-charged session stout but without the watery body. Its thick, but not sticky or heavy. Its sweet, but not overly sweet like candy or a dessert beer. Even though alcohol is quite prominent on the finish its actually rather subdued compared to other beers of the style.Weighing in at 10.5% ABV its not surprising how much heat is generated from the beer, but what is surprising is how hefty the beer is not. Sure, just one bottle gave me a noticeable buzz, but I didnt feel as though I had a watermelon in my stomach the way some imperials make me feel.FINAL THOUGHTSWhile I wouldnt consider Bells Expedition Stout among the best of the best, its quite an amazing beer for what its able to accomplish. Its rare Im able to get such enjoyable taste and true drinkability in a Russian imperial stout. (note: this beer was sent to me from a friend in Michigan since its not yet distributed here in upstate New York. Im not sure of the price, but I would say upwards of $15 for a 4-pack is a good value.)NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KsxB9FHMA_c
Fruity alcohol aroma, thin head (cask).  Very bitter and sweet at the same time.  Syrupy mouthfeel is countered with lots of hop "zing".

Rich and meaty stout! Has a wonderful, warm, harmonious marriage of coffee and chocolatey richness. This beer starts out with a hint of roasted coffee then smoothes out to a bit of sweetness. One of my favorite Bells beers! Also try Third Coast Old Ale!

Aroma has hints of chocolate and raisin. Pours black with very little if any head. A full bodied beer that has a creamy texture. Has a long finish. Overall, I enjoyed this beer from start to finish. It is what I would expect from a Bells product. I would recommend everyone try it at least once.

Batch 7205 pours black with no head. Aroma is rich dark malt, some dark fruit, and hints of  chocolate. Flavor is sweet malts, chocolate, vanilla, light raisin, and light meaty notes. Very creamy mouthfeel with alcohol completely hidden.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2010 Hand pull draft.  Pours completely opaque, nearly black, with a small dark tan head.  Aroma is of licorice, smoke, heavily roasted malt, some dark fruit.  Flavor is all that and some nice bitterness, particularly in the finish.  Thick mouthfeel, mildly astringent.  A delicious stout to savor.

Bottle tasting at work...  wow! It hits you, then hits you again, and sticks around for the followup.  Aromoa is nice, but has a meaty smoked bouquet that I wasnt really expecting.
Huge flavor that goes on and on.  Finishes with a slight sweetness that rounds out the experience nicely.  Plenty of bitterness to acompany this creamy, full bodied stout, but a hoppy presence hovers around the back of the palate.  Chocolate and coffee play around the mouth but the smoke seems to stay with the nose.
  Overall, a really interesting beer that refuses to go away... buy a six pack, drink one, share three, and save back two... too much of this bad boy will bend you over and make you say youre sorry!
12 oz bottle, shared with KW group.  Pours deep, deep brown, almost lack in colour with a modest tan head.  Aroma and flavour are heavy roasted malt and coffee.  Big stout!

At a tasting, thanks, DSG,  no head, almost completely opaque dark, aromas of  bread, coffee, barnyard and brown sugar, flavours of dark fruit, coffee and burned sugar like on the top of a cream broule, smooth and rich but a little bit one dimensional.

At a tasting, thanks DSG, pours black  opaque with a medium chocolate color head, aroma of scotch, vanilla, nuts, coffee, chocolate and orange marmalade, round mouthfeel with flavors of espresso, chocolate, some smokiness, balanced with sweetness, feels zesty and finishes with high  bitterness, sticky and full bodied. Nice Imperial

Pours either a really dark brown or just plain black with a brown head that dissolves rather quickly.  Aroma has scents of roasted nuts, sweet malts, and some cocoa.  Taste follows the aroma, only the 10.5% really kicks in, maybe to the extent of overpowering everything else.  It was really thick and lowly carbonated, almost drinking like a thin syrup.  Because of the relative strength and thickness, I could probably only have one of these at a time, but a good strong beer overall.

Botlle at a tasting: very full bodied, very thick and syrupy, very rich, strong dark fruit sweetness alongside strong very roasted to burnt malt, black coffee as well, a bit one dimensional, as if it was an imperial stout "by the book" but still a very good one, really enjoyable.

Complex aroma and taste make this a very pleasurable Big Stout. Strong alcohol finish reminds you of the 10.5 abv. Dark color and nice head were what I would expect from the style. This beer was my favorite I have tried from Bells....so far.

Id previously only drank this young, but this bottle had nearly two years of age on it.  Fresh, I find the Expedition somewhat harsh, but Im not a huge Russian Imperial drinker (yet).  With age on it, that changes entirely.  Very malty, toasty, and lots of coffee are apparent.  Good, thick mouthfeel.  Tons of sediment was apparent at the bottom of my pint glass.  Im not sure that any American brewer offers a more complete line of stouts.  Great beer, but I do recommend at least a year of aging.

Bells continues to amaze me with the products that they produce.  Black as night and heavier than fog.  The burst of roasted malt, chocolate, peppper, and hops put my tastebuds into sensory overload.  Thick and creamy palate with a sweet hoppy finish.  Kudos to the brewers at Bells.
aroma is very hoppy,roasted malts. One of the hoppiest russian imperial stouts I have ever had. very good beer

Thick, full dark pour, coating the glass with liquid perfection. Dense and creamy brownish head (although the high alcohol content kills this quickly). Its short life is beautiful. Alcoholic nose and very peppery. Bitter chocolate, dark roasted coffee and spicy alcohol. A beast, powerful and strong. I like this brew. A great offering from Bells!

Pours very dark with a thick tan head.  Plenty of lacing on the head.  Aroma is chocolate, malt, hops and alcohol.  Taste is bitter and sweet at the same time with a lot of chocolate and bitter hops.  Very thick mouthfeel and a lingering bitter tongue tingle.  Good stuff.

12oz bottle. dark black pour, small tan head. dark fruits and sweet cocoa aroma. great smooth creamy feel,  big taste of sweetness and chocolate,  finish of roasted malt and hops, the hops coming thru as it warms. the alcohol is well hidden just an excellent stout, perfect for a snowy winter in NY

12oz bottle.  Pours very thick dark black with an amber, tan head.  Smells of alcohol, chocolate, and molasses.  Tastes of alcohol, chocolate, molasses, and some aftertastes of super dark roasted coffee.  Just a little to medicinal flavor for me, but otherwise very good.

As described by George at Redlight Redlight - "Heaven in a glass" and hes right. If you like stouts this is top notch. The flavor of the beer subdues the alcohol very well. None of the flavors in this beer are over-powering and the subtlety keeps the beer interesting to keep picking them out. Fantastic finish as well.

Very creamy for a stout.  On cask at the redlight redlight.  Pours black as night.  Sweet on the nose with a strong coffee and roasted malt follow up.  Alcohol content is well hidden behind the sweet, roasted, goodness of this beer.

some are bothered by the lack of head, but the black color and sticky lacing make up for that part of the appearance; boozy chocolate and coffee flavors coat the mouth without being too syrupy; preferred last years on tap to this years; always consistently good in the bottle

Thoroughly enjoyed in a small whiskey snifter via draft.  The beer pours an opaque black color with a small but fairly long-lasting tan head.  Notes of roasted malt and alcohol to the nose.  The palate carries a fairly complex malt depth:  roasted malt, medium and high English chracter malts, and some alcohol that, rather than being an annoyance, is quite pleasing.  The finish is fairly sweet without being cloying and allows the aforementioned malt character to linger for several minutes.  Overall, it is clear why the beer garners praise.

Cask at redlight redlight.  Pours black/opaque.  nice nose with lots of cocoa, coffee, some molasses, and lots of roasted malts.  very smooth for a high alcohol stout with some boozy notes coming through in the finish.  it begins with the sweet malt flavor up front, then works its way into a good bitter roasted malt middle, and finishes with a great bitter hop content, especially for a stout.  Very creamy and delicious.

Many a years had been spent waiting to see if they would bring it to Jax.  The one time I was in Michigan, with every intent on sipping on this, I was too late for last call, with it laughing at me from behind its translucent, 39 degree encasing. Well, Ive finally found one; and what better beer to drink to my sending-off 6 month stay in Germany for school, as well as my 550th brew. Onto the beer: Pours deep, dark soy sauce black. No sign of light entering or exiting, like a black hole. Head was dark  coffee and soda colored.  Nose is fragrant coffee, vanilla, with lots of molasses and hops. Very clear with each item separated, but not deviated.  Taste is a heavy smack across the palate. Thick, chewy, yet silky and smooth. The first bite is sharp, evening out into an artists palette , with dabs of chocolate, molasses, coffee (colombian), clove, more chocolate, more coffee, a nice abundance of hopes, and some sugar and spice for measure. Vanilla notes lead into frequent earth tones and at some point I felt as though I was describing a wine. No real off-setting areas, other than maybe a tad too sweet. But damn, I hope I can find something like this over here in Germany

12 oz bottle, $17 for a six pack at Total Wine.    Its been a long time coming to Jacksonville, but here it is.  I have searched high and low for this beer for years.   Poured into my CASK Brewclub pint shaker glass.  Small skim of a brown head that doesnt last long, on a deep black beer.   Aroma  of coffee, chocolate, licorice, and molasses... smells great!  I got a sense of deja vu on the smell.  Taste is almost too much to take in at once.  Bursting with flavor... heavy on roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, licorice, molasses, sweet dark malts, and hops throughout.   Very thick and heavy to drink, a real sipper.   The intense flavor completely covers the 10.5% abv, cant even tell its there until you get a buzz.   The realization hit me like a hammer.. I brewed a beer like this 3 years ago and thought I had ruined it by loading it up with too much malts and hops and molasses and other stuff, until it matured about a year later, and then it tasted fabulous.  I still have about a case.  Larry Bell and I think alike on Imperial Stouts!    World class beer worth the wait.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2010 Pours deep black, yes opaque black, with tan head that is similar to espresso crema.  Nose has some chocolate and fresh baked brown bread aromas.  Rich roasted malt on the palate with good mouthfeel, and an appropriately bitter but balanced finish.  Overall one heck of an RIS.

Bottle pours black with a rocky tan head.  Nose is very robust and shows heavy notes of chocolate, coffee, smoke, and roasted malt.  Flavor shows the same and is joined by underlying notes of roasted nuts and vanilla.  Overall body is moderate-full and carbonation is soft.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden and only shows moderately on the tail end tagging along with the hops.  One of the creamiest imp stouts ive tried, as they usually tend to lean on the slick and oily side. I could drink this stuff all night but id probably pay for it in the morning.

Another solid beer from Bells.(slowly becoming my new fave brewery)Smoky,choco;ate,coffee on the nose.Pours deep black with a nice creamy head.Sooooo drinkable alcohol is hidden well and a nice long finish.Tried both draft and bottle and Im on the fence which way was the best.Go get some and drink and enjoy.!!

Bottle, courtesy of Devin.  Pours a jet black body with deep brown head.  Roasty chocolate and coffee grinds in the nose.  The body is so creamy and full with just the right amount of silky smooth coolness to cut the alcohol.  Flavors of rich dark chocolate, dark roasted malts and just a hint of some dark fruit.  This beer is dangerously good.
Pours thick black, faint tan head.  Flavor is very strong.  Bitter coffee notes, but a creamy sweetness comes through afterward.  Alcohol comes through very little.  Top notch, lives up to the hype.

Bottle (thanks to Tweety for sharing)...  Poured near black with a decent head.  A nice chalky, moderately bitter stout that didnt even feel close to 10.5%.  A nice hop bitterness to round out the roasted flavors.  Still a bit of cocoa, licorice and dark fruits aided in this wonderful brew.

on tap, this is one of the better beers ive ever had. i daresay it is perfect. but from a bottle, it falls flat and lacks a number of the interesting qualities that make it one of the worlds best stouts. drink on tap only.

12 oz bottle. Been waiting for the right occasion/celebration to rate this one for awhile now. So today seemed like a good day. This one has definitely been pretty consistent in its quality (probably the forth occasion drinking it), and this one is no exception. Right from the first whiff, you can tell this is something special. Very robust, yet not over imposing, the deep roasted amaretto nutty caramel cereal grains with nice hints of coffee beans, vanilla, and oaky scotch are near mesmerizing. I really could hold this one up to my nose all day without getting bored. The pour is dark, thick, and black. The layer of thick creamy head was reddish brown in color. Its quite sinister looking. Good body overall as well, somewhat boozy through the finish and not as thick feeling on the way down as maybe you would think. The flavor profile might also be a bit more simplistic then I was imagining too, but never the less, very tasty. Roasted nuts and rich malts are all around, nothing overly sweet and well balanced without a strong hop profile (maybe a minor bit of herbal in there), some caramel sugars, light oak, vanilla and coffee. So really the flavors match the aroma quite nicely. To me though, the aroma comes just comes together a tad more perfectly. This is really isnt too far off from an imperial Kalamazoo in my opinion. Definitely world class.

Aroma: Light roasted malt with slight coffee and chocolate overtones.  Appearance is black, with a light brown head.  Taste is medium sweet and very lightly bitter.  Palate is medium body, slightly slick.  Long finish.  This is one of my favorite stouts Ive had.  Really cant recommend it enough.

Pours deep black with a thick dark brown head. Deep rich malty aroma tons of chocolate and coffee and roasted malts. very strong aroma. Very rich and hoppy. Flavour is amazing bracingly bitter with a strong malty flavour. chocolate and roasted malts coffee and a ton of hops. this is the most complex and amazing stout I have ever had. This is everything I want on an imperial stout. this is one amazing  beer. really great stout. you only get the alcoholin the deep end of the finish this is an amazing stout!

Bottle, from trade with theepeeist. Its a black beer with a tiny reddish touch. A dense, tan head sits on top. Slightly cellarish on the nose, with burnt and roasted malts, dried fruits and alchol. Coffee-bitter flavor with dried fruits and alcohol, full-bodied, oily and warming. Burnt, bitter finish. Have to admit I forgot to use my pen most of the time when drinking this, but managed to jot down a few notes. A wonderful beer. 091016

Bottle. black colour with a brown head. Aroma is sweet, alcohol, coffee, chocolate. Flavour is sweet, dry, alcohol, hop, malt, coffee, chocolate, licorice. Long bitter coffee finish. Wow, a very nice beer.

Pours a nice thick, dark black with little to no head. Very smooth-drinking with a nice combination of coffee and chocolate with more than a hint of licorice in the background. Nice smoky, roasted malt aroma. A superior stout.

This is a well crafted ale.  ABV hidden by the immense flavors, real chewy.  Not hidden by the effect.  Nice warming relief after work on a cold winter Saturday.  Drank from a gold-rimmed GuldenDraak tulip, which I stole from a bar.  Watching Titanic at home.  Another lovely gem by James Cameron.  Back to the beer...nice roasted malt flavor, with a solid hop background, which I love about Imperial Stouts.  This one lives up to the hype.  Dont front.

Bottle courtesy of smellysell...thanks Justin.  Pitch black pour with a tan head.  Smells of definite coffee.  Taste is some nice mocha flavor, but you can definitely taste the alcohol on the back of the tongue.  A good beer, dont get me wrong, but I was expecting super-excellence.

Sampled at the awesome Boise tasting 1/16/10, thanks Eric for this awesome beer (#7817, February 2007) 
Appearance: Poured a pure black with a nice tan head 
Aroma: Dark fruits, chocolate, coffee, molasses 
Taste: Roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruits, bitter hops 
This was very smooth and creamy. The hops balance this out nicely between the roasted malts and alcohol. This was my favorite from a night of awesome beers. I savored this as long as I could, wow.
Aged 6 Months, Much better than when fresh.  Think inky black pour, slight medium brown head. Strong coffee hints and very smooth taste. I can hardly wait to see how well more age improves it.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2010 Poured a black/brown with a thin brown head... it could pass for espresso visually. The taste and aroma is a mix of malts, hops, chocolate and coffee, all against a booze background. Good depth and a nice body. Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 A dark black beer with little to no head. The aroma is very fruity, rummy, chocolate cake with fruit. This is a hoppy beer. The hoppiest Imp. Stout? The taste is fruity, very bitter, chocolate, tar & very strong flavored & gets better as it warms. This is a lower carbonated beer. This is good fresh & I bet it gets better with age possibly making its rating even higher. I guess I will have to be patient & find out.

Ive been trying to get into stouts for a little while now and thus, this was a very coveted beer for me. Thankfully a friend bought me a 6 pack for Christmas. Aroma was very nice. I cant say the appearance of the liquid was great as its just solid black however the head is a pretty cool tan color with a nice lace (P.S. dont spill any on the carpet...). Complex taste. Sweet and delicious when its in your mouth, but just SO damn hoppy and bitter when swallowed. Since I dont necessarily like bitterness to the point where my face scrunches, I rated the taste down a bit. If youre ino an absolutely ridiculous amount of bittery hops, then youd give the tatse a 10. Ive got 4 more bottles in my wine fridge. I can only hope that when I crack them open theyll have aged to perfection.

Pours out pitch black and thick with a nice brown head. The nose is roasty, coffee and some caramel as well. The taste is rich, full bodied, little bit of sweetness at first with coffee and roasty flavors and ends with nice hops and bitterness reminiscent of dark chocolate. Great Imperial Stout!
Pours black with a thick brown head.  Fantastic chocolate aroma, kind of sweet and roasty.  Nice smooth mouthfeel and leaning sweet.  Super tasty.

Bottle, pours a thick viscous liquid chocolate tinged w/ auburn, resilient scummy mocha head, juicy aroma rich with vanilla and caramel w/ some notes of dried fruits, flavor matches aroma w/ hop punch @ finish, super thick mouthfeel with a pleasant lingering bitterness, extremely flavorful, complex brew

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 Pours color of espresso, with small brown head. Smells of coffee, malt licorice and chocolate. The chocolate and licorice come through with rich malt sweetness, with a beautiful balanced smooth finish. Excellent beer.

Appearance is black with a tan head. Aroma is mostly malty with some chocolate and molasses. Flavor is somewhat hoppy, mostly malt though. Bittersweet, almost cloying but not quite. Some dark chocolate flavor and some slight alcohol warmth. Overall, excellent imperial stout, aggressive but well balanced. Great for the cold weather were having right now.

Glad I got to try this. Pours like molasses, thick, syrupy, black and stains the glass. Arouma of dark sugars and fruits. Mouthfeel is very thick and smooth. Taste is almost like brandy and chocolate infusion and finishes with a wonderful warm alcohol glow.

My god.  Not much head, but a very thick pour.  A well balanced and powerful stout.  Aromas like a merry-go-round of coffee, roast, chocolate, bitter stuff, ripe fruit.  Oily, sticks to the roof of my mouth palate.  This was aged 10 months, would like to try an older one.  One of my favorites!

Bottle.  Black with hints of burnt mahogany.  Very little head to speak of.  Smells of chocolate and vanilla.  Heavy and sweet on the tongue with a hint of sour.  Perhaps the last is the result of a bad decanting job, but Ill be able to tell better on the next bottle.  Rich and creamy hints of coffee chocolate and oak with a taste that lasts and lasts.

The appearance is a black color, dark tan head, with a vicosity which clings to the glass.  Very beautiful.  The aroma is equally beautiful, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, an earthy quality, and a spicy/soy component.  The flavor is also nice dark chocolate, roasted coffee, vanilla extract, cream, and a little bit of soy sauce again.  The finish was a lovely hop bittering, with notes of pine, grapefruit and resin.  Gorgeous thick, oily mouthfeel.  Among the best.

Picked up in a trade from Exiled.

2007 vintage. Pours pitch black with basically no head. What little head is present is is a brown color. Aroma is strong coffee with some roasted malt and dark fruit. the flavor is heavy on the roasted malt with some smokiness. Some dark fruit and bitter chocolate as well. There is also a slight soy sauce character to the beer. The alcohol has a nice alcohol warming affect. Very thick body and low carbonation. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. This one might have improved with more carbonation.
Pours thick et black with a big tan head. Aroma is chocolate malt roast coffee some caramel toffee. Thick mouthfeel great dark chocolate flavor with very little bitterness. Great stout.
Pitch black pour and thick as molasses. Toasty, roasted aroma along with brown and chocolate malt tastes that are complimented with fruity hop tones.

Pours jet black with a small brown head that sticks around for a while. The aroma is dominated by chocolate and coffee notes. Taste is pretty complex with the strongest notes being bitter dark chocolate and coffee. Alcohol is masked pretty well. GREAT STOUT.
sweet, very rich, dry, a bit much. I actually had no urge to drink after this beer. Switched to water.

355ml: Pours pitch black, deep and marshmallow like brown head on top. Great, complex aroma of black licorice, molasses, chocolate, sour cherries.. seriously brings to mind a black forest cake, right down to the spongy cake. Not sure how an aroma can do that but it is. Flavour is a wallop, amazing blend of that black forest cake with the licorice and molasses promised in the aroma, espresso, all wrapped around a thick, viscous and oily mouthfeel. What a terrific beer, just amazing stuff.

Wow...Pours a midnight black with a thin tan head; motor oil in a glass. Aromas of floral hops, chocolate and dark roasted malts. The taste is fairly bitter with floral hops, dark chocolate and noticable alcohol. A great beer to sip in front of the fire after a long winters day. One of my favorite"big" stouts of all time.

How did it come to this?  Where to begin... this is, to date, the best stout I have tasted.  Caramel and chocolate notes.  Floral hops.  Big, dark and creamy!  Not at all simple... there is something dark and rich here that defies words.  Poured like motor oil with an obnoxiously brown head.  Absolutely beautiful.  Sticks to the sides of the glass like a beautiful oil slick.  Creamy and thick mouthfeel.  Incredible flavor.  A very complex, rich and beautiful stout.

Pours a nice molten black with a minimal amount of tan head.  Very little lacing as a result.  Great aroma with great roasted and smokey tones.

Incredibly smooth on the palate.  Complex character that has hints of chocolate, very little bitterness, and doesnt leave your mouth feeling dry as saw dust like a lot of other heavy, imperial stouts.

Definitely a beer to sit back and savor.

(br-btl cm-lbl, Comstock MI, 6 pack, 10.5%)

opq-bk, th-br-hd, ^full-body, low-co2.

aroma: ^rch ^wrm ^mlsss brnt-crrnt dk-mlt-syrp §sweet-silage.

T1 drk rch thck sweet-rsty-chclt-malt.
T2 chclt sweet-drk-fruit §sweet-chrcl-pills §leafy-hops.
T3 sweet-chrcl crml-§brnt-sgr-syrup §wood-astrgt(tannin?).

incredible, intense, possibly the thickest densest beer ive ever had at 350 ratings, like a sweet chrcl malt shake, co2 is there but it cant escape the density, the thickness and sweetness are a bit cloying alone but make an awesome dessert beer.

Well, I had to get around to rating it sooner or later. The beer pours a beautiful deep black color with a nice big darker tan almost reddish brown head. The beer leaves a little lace on the glass but really it leaves more "sheets" than anything. The aroma is dark chocolate, plenty of floral hops, some toast, some raisins, plenty of earthy and woody notes, there is some ash and some licorice in there as well. The flavor is woody, like new wood. I wouldnt have been surprised if I found out that this was aged in wood. The beer is very bitter with lots of fruity hop notes and is all around insanely roasty. All of this is comprised of or complimented by flavors of chocolate, licorice, burnt toast, and raw coco. A few things strike me as special and unique about this beer first off it seems to be balanced, but not between bitter and sweet flavors as there isnt a lot of sweetness here, but there is a lot of fruitiness seemingly from the hops, which is kind of wild because this seems to balance the bitterness both from the roasty malt and the copious hop content. The palate is full and big without being syrupy, this beer is a kind of feat. I dont mind syrupy or sweet imperial stouts but this is clearly better than almost if not every single one of those.

A - Nice think black color with a small head of foam that fades quickly.  Not a lot of lacing.  Lots of yeast sediment in the bottom of the pour.

S - Roasted malts and chocolate at first sniff.  As beer warms starts to smell like playdough, very odd.

T - Dark malts, slight rum flavor, chocolate, not a lot of dark fruit flavors.  A sharp bitterness on the finish from the amount of yeast in the pour.

M - Nice thick/slick mouthfeel.  Not too carbonated (how I like my big stouts).

D - Given the sharp bitterness, this one is not real pleasant to drink.  Certainly not meant to be a sessionable beer, but the sharp bitter flavor really takes away from the overall experience and is hard for the beer to show any complexity with such a dominating force to compete with.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 i was excited as hell to try this. i dunno if my palette is a little off today or what but this thing is just giving off way too much alcohol for me. i love imperial stouts, but this one reminds me of the the breakfast stout i drank last night with a shot of booze mixed in.. it does look pretty in the glass, and has some nice hoppy notes, but the drinkability on this one of very poor for me tonight. ..

wow, had it on draft tonight and felt that it was very, very, very drinkable. maybe my bottles were aged a bit. or maybe my palate has just really expanded. i have adjusted my ratings. 

updated 4/16/2011: jesus christ i fucking love this stuff. @ $3.50 a bottle there is no better value in beer. absolutely beautiful, dark as night with a stunning dark head. amazing nose, and hard to match taste. bump from 4.0 to 4.5

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2013 batch 7740.  deep chocolate brown body, minimal head, considerable legs, oily, thick and viscous.  nose is bright chocolate coated chestnuts, fudge-like cake and inky black patent malt.  hops are mild but noticeable, but what drives the nose is the dense german chocolate cake and fudge notes - exquisite.  tangy ink and zesty chile-infused chocolate in the approach. chewy fudge and cake across the back.  coats the mouth with a dense and decadent chocolate syrup note.  never tries to do too much, alcohol is mild, sugar level is moderate, the malt drives this one completely.  creamy and chewy in a long-lasting finish.  one of the best imperial stouts in the world.
Jet black hole pour with nice tan vanishing head. Motor oil anyone? Nice roasty malty scent. Taste is wonderful, coffee chocolate caramel....with a sharp finish. Good stuff. Year round please.

Bottle.  Awesome beer.  Thick rising frothy tan head over dark dark dark body.  Aroma of dark roast with a sweet fruity note, very pungent.  Taste of sweet malts, coffee, and a liquorish sweetness/bitterness.  Heavy flavor that stays on the taste buds a long time.  Low carbonation, very thick and creamy.  One of the best from Bells Ive had.

12 oz bottle.  pour was all black, with very little brown head.  Dark chocolate and coffee dominate the flavors. More sweet than expected with soy sauce, but it seems to make the flavor even stronger.  The alcohol is very well hidden.

12-oz bottle. Coffee, soy sauce, prune aroma. Black color with dark, one-finger head that dissipated quickly. Sweet and heavy but dark chocolate finishing notes keep the sweetness at bay. Thick and chewy on the palate. Good carbonation keeps the beer alive in your mouth despite its heaviness. Long finish. A very big beer.

12oz bottle.  a completely black beer under a medium sized, cream brown head.  aroma is a bit vinous with a good dose of alcohol.  flavor has notes of burnt, smokey malts, toast, caramel, lots of chocolate chip cookies.  alcohol is not evident in the flavor like it is in aroma.  creamy body and full.  heavy stuff.  flavorwise, one of the smoothest, balanced, and best tasting imp stouts i  can think of.

Pours like liquified tar w/a tan, halo-ed head from the 12oz. bottle: Full bodied with a thick consistency. And thoroughly smooth in the mouthfeel. Roasted, sweet malts, burnt coffee, licorice, cherry, oatmeal, bitter chocolate, the slightest of hops, and definitely soy sauce!. Warming alcohol finishes. Drinkability: Sweet malted and thick. Rebuy: Yeah. #236 on 03122009 (the day we found out T. Woods officially cheated), DG.

12 oz bottle, aged courtesy of BeerandIT. This beer pours a very dark color with a finger of tan head. Aroma and taste have some significant notes of dark fruit, which has come out a lot more since its been aged. This creates some very strong sweetness from the fig and raisin flavors. There are also some significant notes of dark chocolate which permeate this beer, and keep it from being overly sweet. Caramel malts also add to the sweetness. Though the body is only medium and not as full as many other imerial stouts, this beer ages wonderfully.

Pours black as night with a medium brown head.  Syrupy almost.  Chocolate malts aroma aplenty.  Taste is an aural bombardment.  Every taste bud in your mouth is in overload.  Sweet malts open the way for a blast of bitter hops to an almost smokey soy sauce and booze finish.  This beer was a little piece of Michigan I could bring back with me to Massachusetts.

This is the only beer that I buy to cellar in case quantities, so dont expect anything even slightly negative in this review. This is an 8845 opened at almost exactly two years. It pours an opaque black with a thick, dark brown head. The initial nose is liquorice with a bit of alcohol. The flavor is initially liquoirce with roasted malts following quickly and then dark chocolate. The alcohol is not evident other than as it warms on the way down, and, in my experience it will disappear in the nose in another year or two. Half way into the snifter and this brew is still releasing carbonation and bringing more aroma to the drink. The palate is smooth with a little hops bite. The finish is a lingering alternating roasty bitterness and something bordering on sweetness, but not quite. This is a beer that it is difficult not to drink too many of.

12 oz bottle, pours a dark opaque color with minimal dark brown head, looks like cola. Very little lacing on the side of the glass. Aroma is sweet and alcoholic, most noticeably chocolate, oatmeal, and a little raisin. Very fresh as well. Taste is bitter and sweet and well balanced. Body is very full and sits well on the palate. Really does a good job of hiding the high alcohol content- excellent beer indeed.

Bottled pitch black with a chocolate brown/tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, smoke, and burnt caramels. Also some hop floral notes add unique nose. The flavor is beautiful...smoked burnt coffee, chocolate with a little sourness and light sweetness that prevails at the end with a note of coffee also. Maybe lightly sour (odd) but otherwise a totally awesome brew... answers a lot of questions other stouts cannot.

Batch 8944 (vintage 2008?).  12oz bottle pours thick oily black, but very little dark tan head.  Caramel and chocolate in aroma, some hints of pitted fruit (cherries, prune).  Rich, sweet up front, a bit boozy, then a long drawn out chocolate finish.  Quite bitter, but balanced.  Pretty well carbonated, quite thick and oily and the alcohol and carb leave a bit of stinging on the tongue.  Much better with some warming.

Pours a deep, dense, black color. No light penetration, at all. Almost two fingers of rich mocha colored foam form on top. Retention is decent, which is not unexpected. Lacing is in thick strands.

Mild notes of dark chocolate and coffee, mix with a large presence of (very) dark roasted malts. A touch of molasses. Sweet notes of brown sugar, with hints of vanilla and caramel. Definite hints of a bourbon-like quality. Light presence of dark fruits.

Huge dark roasted malt profile. Nice amount of smokiness. Loads of chocolate flavor. Sweetness of brown sugar. Light hint of dark coffee. Slight hints of bourbon and hazelnuts. It has a mild bitter kick, right at the end, which helps balance this one out. The aftertaste is delicious.

Silky smooth and creamy. Light level of carbonation, which is perfect for this one. Only the slightest amount of sharpness and bite.

Quite easy for me to drink, but this is the style that I search out. As a sipper, this one is excellent. Be careful of the high ABV, though.

came out with barely a head with an aggressive pour. pitch black is an understatement. smells of caramel and chocolate, very earthy and pick up a touch of alcohol on the end. carbonation was lively but didnt degrade its creamy texture...actually complimented it quite nicely. super bitter finish was amazing for a stout. i cant help but want more. what a great brew!

Wow, this is one beer that really is thick in consistency.  It is really aromatic and pours a dark black with no head to speak of. Notes if caramel, chocolate, coffee, nuts, alcohol, butterscotch, and vanilla. The palate is very bourbon barrel coffee in flavor. Needs time to mellow.

Im thinking tar - black with a tan head, good lacing and plenty of carbonation. Not flat like many of the Imperial Stouts that Ive had. Roasted malt, coffee a bit of hops and chocolate. Full bodied and smooth across my tongue. The chocolate, coffee, sweet malt and hops are balanced nicely and theres a bit of a warming alcohol in the finish. A great warmer for those cold winter nights!
pitch black pour, delayed tan head that doesnt quit... rich, creamy mouthfeel...tons of roasty malty flavor, nice bitterness in the finish

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Pitch black pour, long lasting tan head with nice lacing.  Sweet chocolate aroma.  Thick chewy mouthfeel.  Complex chocolate & coffee flavor with some hops tossed in.  Lingering bitter chocolate finish.

Poured pure black with a caramel brown head.  Aroma was kind of confusing.  For some reason (and this was the opinion of everyone I tasted it with) the aroma was lacking.  Not bad, but just not there.  I really couldnt smell much at all until about half way through the beer.  The coffee tones definitely came out and the malts were pretty spectacular.  It had a surprising amount of hops and citrus undertones for what it is.  Enjoyable beer, but Ive had better stouts.

Great, thick head that disappates quickly.  Great dark color for an Imperial.  First aroma that hits is the coffee, very dark coffee maltiness.  Taste is smooth but the palate is below average.  Overall, I like it but Ive had better Imperials.  Worth giving a second chance.
Seeing this beer having a 100 rating score, I expected a lot more. Not bad, but I wanted more. Not a 100 in my book...

This was bottled in Sept 08 and consumed Nov 09. Saved it a year, as I heard it improves the beer tremendously.

Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Pitch motor oil black with chocolate covered head that leaves some very spotty lacing behind.

Huge roasted aroma of burnt molasses, semi-sweet chocolate, licorice root, dark fruit and noticeable alcohol.

The roasted malt taste also drifts toward burnt molasses, with some notes of sweet chocolate, anise and coffee. Ends somewhat bitter and with an alcohol kick. Even after aging a year, still seems a trifle raw.

Very thick and chewy. Low carbonation, quite smooth and extremely warming.

Overall, a luxurious (if somewhat raw) late evening sipper. While not my favorite RIS, it is still quite delectable.

Poured from 12oz bottle into 6oz goblet.

A - Pours black with very little tan-colored head. No lacing whatsoever. Looking at it now, all I see is total darkness in my glass. Dont know if Im good with this or not.

S - Coffee, dark chocolate, some nice bitterness. As I take a few more whiffs, its really hard to get a good sense on the nose, dont know what, but I cant get a whole lot from this one.

T - Alcohol, dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans, bitterness all melded pretty well together. Maybe a little too much alcohol burn on this right away, but Im digging the other flavors afterwards. Pretty dry finish, bitter aftertaste with some chocolate notes. Too much booze for me, needs some cellar time to chill out.

M - Just about right for me with enough fizzy carbonation to satisfy. I would say medium bodied, but a very "light" medium. Def better then the Bourbon Barrel Aged Cherry Stout I just had.

D - I like this one, but if I had to choose a regularly available RIS, Id take an Old Rasputin RIS any day of the week. Will drink again.

Nice aroma, malty, coffee, moderate hops. Pours nice and dark, with a small light brown head. Taste is absolutely absurd. So good. Vinous, dark fruits, coffee, roasty, with a wonderful alcoholic finish. Very well balanced.

Pours thick charcoal. I put my nose to it and my first impression was cherry, which surprised me because its something Ive not ever tasted in a beer.
