Tons of strong chocolates, light coffees, burnt malts, and light hops were all present in the aroma.  also some light vinousnous was present as well.  alcohol was very well hidden.  velvety soft mouthfeel and oh so long finish duration.  very well balanced awesome imp stout.

Pours black with a medium sized tan head into a snifter. Aroma is mostly of roasted malts. Coffee, licorice play nicely with each other with a hint of spice. I also get hints of caramel. A huge stout!!! One of my favorites. Glad I got to try it.

Bottle: Aroma is dark berries and fruits and supermalt. Pours the inkiest, blackest, holy shit-est dark black in the glass with dark brown head. Head dissipates quick but covers the top all the way down. First flavors I got were salty and sweet coffee, followed by boozy licorice and spicy chocolate. As the drink warmed I picked up grapes, figs, earth, grass, caramel, and prunes. So thick, so sweet and chewy! My lips got so sticky when I drank this midnight oil that I thought I was weezing the juice straight from a spigot on a Michigan maple; all the while my tongue was covered in buttery goodness.  Sorry, Celebrator! Found a new number one. Bravo to the boys of K-zoo on the Megastout. Holy shit.
Bottle. This is very hit or miss.  Pours a black dark body with a tan head.  Aroma is malty, etoh and booze,  some chocolate and smoked roasted coffee.  Flavor is very roasted and boozy.  mmmiss.

Pour a thick motor oil black with a tan caramel head. Rich and luscious on the palate with a great balance of chocalatey bitterness and sweetness.

Excellent imperial stout; one of my favourites.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2015 Bottle,  Smells of dark chocolate and roasted molasses.  The head is mostly diminishing and brown in color.  The lacing is pretty good.  Very little head.  Extremely thick dense texture.  Motor oil black color.  Bitter initial flavor with the longest finish of any beer I have ever had.  Full bodied with a syrupy texture.  Soft on the carbonation.  Heavy alcoholic finish.  You would not want to drink 3 of these and drive a vehicle.

Pours a deep, oily opaque, still black.  No signs of carbonation, thin tan head.  Aroma is fairly complex, black pepper corn, smoke, roasted malts, coffee, licorice, chocolate and caramel.  Flavor is sweet and sugary, molasses, caramelized sugar, toast, coffee grounds, dark chocolate and wood.  Very thick on the tongue, heavy in the mouth, a bit of fire from the alcohol and some lasting coffee bitterness.  I really wanted to love this, but Ive had better Imperial Stouts.
Definia\tely a tasty beer!  Chocolate malty flavor with a fair amount of alcohol taste...drinks and finishes smooth but the presence of alcohol reminds you it is 10.5%.  Good beer.

Thanks to KAggie97 for the beer! The bottle looks not so good, too simple I think. The beer in the glass is much better. Very dark, foam also quite dark. Roast-malty aroma. Tastes also very malty, very strong, not as scratchy as other Imp Stouts. Very good!

a nice trip to Florida meant bringing home some Bells!  pours an oily black with a rich tan head.  aroma is roasty and a bit sweet.  the taste is packed with flavor.  black coffee, bitter chocolate, and some dark fruits.  alcohol is very strong in the afterbite.  an excellent beer, though I have to say the presence of alcohol is a bit of a downer.

One of my all time favorites, have never rated it.  Pours black with thin tan head.  Aromas of dark chocolate, dark fruit/cherries, roasted malt.  Flavors much the same - dark chocolate covered cherries, roased malt, dark coffee, and nicely hopped at the finish - incredible.  It coats your mouth so that the enjoyment stays for minutes after  each sip.  An imperial stout that all should emulate.

Thanks to Rusty Diamond for this beer--Poured a deep dark, viscous body with small tan head.  Thick chocolate, malt, robust flavor.  Chocolate mousse in a bottle.  What a great beer.  Love it.  Love it.  Love it!

Just popped the last bottle of this beast from a six pack that I bought this winter. I absolutely love this beer -- black as night (no light passes through), amazing aroma, chock full of roasted malts. Thick, amazing mouthfeel. Smooth, lingering, roasty taste. Great taste upfront, and then it explodes when it hits the back of the throat. Not sure if that makes sense, but one sip of this bad boy is enough to last all night. Ive had this stuff a number of times (on tap and in bottle) and Ive never been disappointed. In fact, its the brew that turned a few of my friends on to the potential of craft brews. Definitely might be my favorite beer. Bravo, Bells, bravo.

Tasted at the Orlando Beer festival.  Awsome.  Great mouthfeel, very dark, rich thick.

Ill be out searching for this one.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2008 WOW! This beer poured like a dream.  Deep dark head turning a lighter tan.  Such a full robust flavor and thick mouthfeel.  Beatiful lacing that hangs on forever.  Excellent brew!!  Bells has notihng but winners.  Ill be cellaring 2 6ers. .... so this rating might just get better on a re-rate.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2008 Deserves every 4 and over rating it gets. One of the more even stouts. A desert in a glass. Smells fresh and inviting. The taste is strong and delicate. Wow ..this is top shelf. I wonder if it took years of trying this recipe versus that..or if luck and happenstance was involved. Truly a great beer. Nothing fights or sours the flavor. This is a fresh beer I am trying,(for a stout of 10.5%abv) Label says 8311..Im guessing a 3 year aging grace period.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Pitch black color with brown, rocky head resembling chocolate mousse. Excellent lacing. Sweet, rich aroma of cocoa, sugar, coffee, and alcohol.  This seriously smells like a dessert.  Very thick, full body with a velvety smooth texture. So thick it is almost like a melted milkshake.  Its initial flavor is moderately sweet, but eventually taken over by a wonderful, heavy bitter ending that seems to refuse to go away. Man, this is a cool beer.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of dark bread, molasses, and dark chocolate, moderate perfume smell for the hops, light earth and broth for the yeast, with raisin, wine and alcohol in the background. Head is light brown, frothy with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is black, but I did see some small particles at the bottom of the glass. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then  the long finish is moderately sweet and bitter, and just a touch sour. Palate is full bodied, between creamy and syrupy, and has a soft carbonation. It finishes lightly alcoholic. Bold in every respect. A great, almost perfect Imperial Stout.

Bottle, gift from mcbackus. Tantalizing pour of thick black with thick tan head. Aroma of fresh macchiato, vanilla bean, and a big slice of tiramisu. Creamy silky mouthfeel. Long lingering big sophisticated and strong body. Filled with whole coffee beans, freshly roasted and ground. Black forest cake emerges later. Superior stuff. A gorgeous brew to celebrate rating #1000!

Very nice imperial stout with an initially hot alcohol taste (as a 1st beer of the night) that becomes more smooth as you get into the bottle.  It has a nice rich and smooth malty taste.  My only compliant is the hot taste but its understandable considering the size of this beer.  I suspect it will be much better in 6-8 months.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2009 Bottle. Gorgeous, perfect tight-bubbled head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate; rich roasted malt and its counterparts. A touch light for the flavor to come, but Im not going to complain it under a 9. Flavor has little bits of everything, in addition to the notes in the aroma (which become stronger in the mouth), plums, raisins, prunes (none too harsh or prevalent), bitter hops (also never override the sweet richness). Palate is on the sweet side, but for me the hops dried it out perfectly for an imperial stout, that is enough to keep it from syrupiness without the hops taking over the flavor profile and not even touching all that richness in the aroma. Absolutely awesome. 9-5-10-5-19/4.8Rerate 4/23/09 Bottle, Batch 4728. Aroma of coffee, lots of molasses, a bit of tobacco, vanilla, big roasted malt, sweet alcohol, chocolate ice cream, smoked wood, citrus...wow. Flavor again big on the roast and molasses along with a dried fruit character that I didnt find in the aroma. Increasing citrus hop notes toward the finish work really well with the chocolate and molasses notes. Everlasting roasted notes with a hint of coffee continue to linger on the tongue. Thick, viscous mouthfeel. Intense and lovely. I sat down to rerate this thinking I would score it lower if I put myself to the task, but no, I really do think its that good. 9-4-10-5-20/4.8

UPDATED: APR 23, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a dark black with the most beautiful dark brown/red head, as thick as a milkshake, man I cant wait to drink this!  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roast, sweet aroma (the aroma is probably the weakest component of the beer).  Flavor of similar chocolate, coffee, roast, light alcohol, sweet sweet malt with a bitter hops finish.  So rich, probably one of the richest beers Ive ever had.  The mouthfeel is just incredible.  Although it is rich, it is fairly smooth and easy to drink.  The best Imperial Stout that Ive had to date--just super awesome and Im so sad we dont get this in NY.
8/5/10/5/18 (4.6/5)
Rerate, batch 8728.  I think my tastebuds have evolved since my initial sampling of this beer.  Now I find it rather boozy with some burnt malt notes.  Plenty of other complexities: roasted malt, light bitter chocolate, dark fruits, prune, raisin.  My overall impression is that this is too boozy.  And its no longer one of my favorite impys.  So I changed the score.
8/4/8/4/15 (3.9/5)

Thanks inkubus27.  Pours black with a fluffy tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee and molasses.  Taste is very creamy and complex.  Tastes like coffee, chocolate, molasses and tart cherries, very rich. Very thick mouthfeel, with a nice biting finish.

12 oz bottle into a goblet. Motor oil color with tan head that disappeared quickly. Bitter malty chocolate smell, very rich. Very complex taste. Some cherry hidden in chocolate, bitter, coffee. Very viscous, thick mouthfeel that you can chew. A beer for the very discerning.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Draft at Jerrys. Black with big, creamy, brown head, good legs / Rich nose of molasses, tobacco, coffee, chocolate, and cinnamon / Full body, chewy, lush, sweet but with excellent hop balance, dry in the middle with fine bitter finish, and alcohol well masked / Flavors of molasses, dark roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, caramel, licorice, prune, and vanilla / Superb.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Pours like motor oil with a small brown head and great legs.  Nose of chocolate, toffee, caramel.  I pick up some dark currant in the flavor with a twinge of alcohol and lots of roasted malt. Full mouthfeel.  Semi-dry bitter chocolate finish, but surprisingly smooth considering the abv.  Simply amazing, and worth every penny.

http://www.ratebeer.com/UserPics/Crosling.jpg

< /> 

Love this beer so much I painted a picture of it.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2009 12oz bottle courtesy of Knightly Spirits. This is one Ive been really wanting to try and I thought I had missed the production for the year. Pours an awesome pitch black with a small milk chocolate head. Nose is incredible. One of the best smelling stouts. Full of chocolate cake, malt and a touch caramel and vanilla. This beer is like a giant coffee and chocolate bomb. Caramel and dark chocolate start things off with a dash of bitter coffee in the middle and the bourbon soaked chocolate cake rounds things off. Super thick and rich palate. Each sips reveals a new malt. Despite the high IBUs this is exceptionally smooth, the only drawback is the alcohol is maybe a bit to high as there is some burn. Its a sipping beer because this has a really full mouthfeel to it, but a good stout is always best savored anyways in my opinion. Truly an exceptional beer from a great American brewery.
Good rich taste like most Bells. Malty very nice blend and Smooth. A little on the alcoholy side but not enough to be distracting.

Thanks to DuctTape for this bottle. I have a feeling that I let it sit around for too long though as I can see where this beer was trying to get but it didnt quite make it.
It poured a beautiful dark toasted malty black with a  disappointingly thin head. It was a lovely oily consistency with rich malty flavours. I look forward to trying a fresh bottle!

Pours black with a thin tan head.  Nice aroma of chocolate and some fruit.  Good complex flavor.  Nice bittersweet chocolate and a great creamy mouthfeel.  Has a little bit of alcohol kick at the end, hopefully it will get a little better with aging.

12 oz bottle from unclemike. Pours an opaque black color with a medium tan head that fades slowly. The aroma was rich with  chocolate, molasses, dark fruits and a hint of rubbing alcohol. The flavor is big and bold with burnt malts, biter dark chocolate, plums and biter walnuts. The mouthfeel is full, creamy and smooth. Absolutely perfect palate The finish was very long with dry dark biter chocolate. Overall: An outstanding  stout. I found the alcohol on the nose to be slightly distracting, otherwise a great concoction.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2009 Shared bottle at DLD 08. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is burnt malt, hops, coffee anbd a little chocolate. Flavor is really complex with sweet chocolate, brown suger and some vanilla. Perfectly balanced for this big of a beer. Great stuff.
Re-rate 1/23/08. Pours pitch black with thin dark tan head. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruits booze and caramel. Flavor is rich and creamy with roasted malt, rich chocolate, brown sugar, caramel, coffee and booze. Finishes smooth and boozy. Have been drinking a lot of RIS lately and this reminds me of what a good one is supposed to tast like. 4.4

12 ounce bottle picked up from Indiana by one of my buddies! Thanks! I have been saving this one for quite a while. Illini08 and nimrod were going to enjoy a tasty beer, so I decided there was no better time to open this baby! Poured a jet black color with a small brown head. The term "used motor oil" describes the look of this one perfectly. The aroma consisted of chocolate, vanilla, suggary malts. and dark fruit. The taste was a wonderful mix of chocolate with a surprising amount of vanilla. It left a taste in my mouth that made me wanting more! The mouthfeel was very heavy also. An excellent brew that I would definitely seek out again!

Dark-ruby with light brown head...a dark beer lovers delight. Taste is very complex, with a symphony of coffee, chocolate, red wine. Acidic and full-strength in character. The alcohol is obvious and provides some nice warmth. This one was aged after six months, and was better than the ones I drank last fall. Not for the light-hearted!

12 oz bottle. Pours a motor oil black with some, but not much head. Aroma is sweetness with chocolate. Starts of sweet but ends on a dry note. Not unlike drinking semi-sweet chocolate. Excellent stuff!

UPDATED: APR 27, 2008 12 oz. bottle.  Thanks drewbeerme!  Pours a very dark brown to black with little head.  Aroma is brown sugars with a touch of raisin and chocolate.  The flavor starts a malty sweet and finishes with a bitter coffee note.  Very good!

A- Pours a deep black with a small dark brown head which fades quickly.

S- Smell is sweet, notes of caramel, toffee and coffee.

T- Taste is deep coffee, lingering sweet caramel, dark fruits, very intense with some alcohol warming at the end. Doesnt sit well on my palate, just not the kind of RIS I enjoy.

M- Thick as motor oil with decent carbonation.

D- I choked this one down. I could see how other people would think this one is good because of its complexity but I just could not get myself to like it.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 Bottle, many thanks to Acknud.  This is an enormous beer on the nose and palate.  Dark dark brown, super dark brown head.  Thick and rich and delicious.  Sweet and powerful...truly a wonderful beer.  Flavor is full of chocolate, molasses, raisins, prunes, some light roast and is thick and rich!!

from a 12 oz bottle.  pours a dense black with a thick brown head.  aroma of dark malt, alcohol and malt blend perfectly.  flavor is a completely mouthfilling and complex experience.  I believe that other styles typically can bring more to the great beer table, but this one delivers like no other.  about as perfect an imperial stout as there is... anywhere

This is one of  the  better stouts that I have had in a while.   The beer is black with little foam.  The taste is smooth with a hint of sweetness to the palate.   I really like this beer!  perhaps the 10.5% alcohol content has something to do with that!!!

Rich, threatening Imperial aroma - alcohol, chocolate, patent malt, fruit.  Pours like 10W-30 thats been run too hot for too long.  Respectable tan head, boozy legs on the side of the glass, average clipart label.  An initial alcohol surge, like with a liqueur, fading off to a chickory nuttiness.  Coffee finish, medium heavy body.  Coffee/hop bitterness hangs around for a long time.  Very good, pretty distinctive.  Id have gone a slightly different direction, but on the whole very enjoyable.  Market Square Liquors.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Extremely dark and thick pour, syrupy appearance. Dark reddish brown head that lingers as a thin layer, with good lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, with molasses, some very Bells-like hoppiness, chocolate, some fruitiness/sourness, and a hint of alcohol. Very creamy, oily mouthfeel. Flavor starts sweet and malty, with chocolate and coffee. Lightly sour dried fruit as well. Ends with some crisp hoppy bitterness. Dry on the finish, with a slight taste of alcohol. Very full-bodied and complex, but well balanced. Excellent beer, good to savor while contemplating the world. Having tried this a second time, I’m bumping it up a bit - just a touch better to my taste than Speedway Stout.

Pours an extremely dark fudge chocolate brown with a small dark brown head. Amazing aroma of chocolate, very light roasted coffee, and some dark caramel fruits like plums or figs. Extremely creamy texture. Pure delicious malty sweetness right away, almost cherry chocolate like. Swallows like creamy molasses, and the finish hits with a strong vinous taste that I cant wait to experience mellowed with age. Leaves a lasting sweetness that is really amazing. Glad I have two more of these!!

Bottle. Thanks Dave! Pours a beautiful dark brown/black with a reddish dark brown head. Aroma is somewhat sweet with roasted barley, dark fruits, molasses, choolate. Warming. Sweet, hoppy and full bodied. This beer is very well balanced. No one flavor dominates, they all compliment each other. Definately the most balanced impy stout that I have had so far.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2012 Finally decided to give this one a try. The pour here is heavy and thick, pitch black color and topped with a thick tan head. The head does settle down to a thin layer. The aroma is chocolaty, with molasses, some coffee, roasted malt, and a faint alcoholic presence. The flavor starts creamy and smooth with chocolate, roasted malts and molasses. It finishes quite bitter and dry; that of fresh black coffee and hops. A light bitterness settles on the palate. The beer is solid, high in alcohol, but not incredibly hard to drink. Definitely a sipper thoughy and something that could be a terrific after dinner drink.

Sampled at Hellbillys gathering.  Thanks Sparky27!  I think I drank the bottle by myself!  Dark black pour with a creamy brown head that lasts forever.  Nice lacing.  Strong aromas of roasted malt and coffee, dark chocolate, some hops and alcohol.  Great flavors of coffee and chocolate, molasses and licorice.  Delicious brew!

Wow, a very dark beer, 10.5% nice nice. Kind of looked like pouring a bottle of syrup into a glass. aroma definitely good. Thick chocolate taste but smooth finish and good after taste. I plan on enjoying this tasty brew again.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2009 bottle with number 8311 on the label poured into a snifter has a heavy dark black color and a thick chewy brown head that subsided to a ring on the glass. aroma is so rich with lightly roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, alcohol, and some background hops. mouth feel is full with some thickening and just enough carbonation to get it all across. chewy rich chocolate and malts kick off the flavor party joined with light smoke, molasses, bitters, and hops. such an all out brew but the taste is fantastic. hits of vanilla and sweetness contrast the bitterness nicely.

A great beer and Im incredibly happy that my local beer store is now stocking it. Big brown head that lasts a long time and a complex aroma of roast, chocolate and malts. It starts off tasting like chocolate and ends like a good cup of coffee. Probably one of the best stouts I have ever tasted.

Bottle 33cl. [Courtesy of my brother, thanks buddy!] Huge dark brown creamy head that really lasted. Excellent display of lacework. Pitch black color with bubbles inside the glass. Lovely roasted malty, hint of wood / smoke, berries, chocolate, coffee and dried fruit. Over the palate came burned malt, bitter coffee and chocolate, mild liquorish, vinous port wine like, brown sugar and finally hint of hoppy notes as well. Full bodied with a soft carbonation and thick light dry alcoholic texture. Moderated to heavy bitter with good counter sweetness to balance this brew. Coffee  hoppy bitter liquorish lingering finish.

This is a potent, bruiser of a beer. I read a review somewhere that this beer was "elegant."  If its elegant, its elegant like Muhammad Ali.  Very complex flavors that do  not disappoint, you can taste the alcohol but its not too strong, just enough to know youre getting pounded. Intense flavors throughout, long lingering finish.
A wonderful example of an American Stout. truely enjoyed this one. rich roasty. sweet, great balances though .

Gigantic thanks to dchlema for this one!!!!!Pours almost black with a thick tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, roast, and caramel.  Extremely smooth but complex at the same time.  Initial taste of chocolate, caramel flows into a coffee bitterness with some warming alcohol at the finish.  Excellent beer.  I cant wait to taste it aged.

wow....was I ever surprised by this beer......thanks drewbeerme....

my new semi favorite IRS.....great complex malt flavor super smooth and complex.....I wish I had more so I can age some.....soooo goood

12oz bottle. Pours a thick looking black color with minimal tan head, touch of lace. Smells subdued, sweet roasty malts. Tastes of thick sweet dark malts and a bit of alcohol on the finish. Actually tastes a little oxidized to me as well. I had a better stout just last night in LAs Serpents Stout. Anyway, full bodied with nice carbonation.

A damn fine Imp. Stout.  As Ive stated before, you cant go wrong with Bells.  A thick full as you want it to be bodied Imperial Stout.  Malt flavors out the Wazoo and enough alcohol to knock you on it.  A must have for beer conisours.

[To celebrate my 1300th rating - thanks Brad] Pitch black with huge brown thick creamy lasting head. Sweet aroma with notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and liquerice. Sweet flavor with hard roasted malt, hops, liquerice, bitter dark  chocolate and coffee notes. Hints of overripe fruits and vanilla. Good complecity and it finishes bitter. Excellent!

Served draft at Bells Ecclectic Cafe in Kalamazoo, MI.  Coffee and dark chocolate nose.  Dark khaki head that leaves an attractive lacing.  Robust roasted flavor widens out to an almost white chocolate mocha.  Finishes with just a little hoppiness and more coffee.  What a tremendous beer.  There is so much going on in this glass I know I am not doing it justice.

Strong aroma of toasted malt and dark fruit, with a little blueberry and tar. Opaque black color with a tan ring. Full bodied with very little carbonation. Its treacly sweet with almost enough bitter (and its bitter) to offset the sugars. Finishes rather smooth burnt toast - with sugar on it. Its almost contradictory in flavors. Must be one of the best for the style.

Got this in a tarde with punkrkr27. Excellent. A superior stout. Pours out a DEEP brown with a thin brown head. Chocolate, coffee, sweet malts, light hops, sweet prunes, and alcohol flavors meld together to create a brewing masterpiece. The flavors linger on your palate and remind you of the experience. An excellent effort. I look forward to trying their other beers. My only complaint is that this brew could have been a little bit more complex, but its tastyness overwhelms all possible qualms. Bravo!

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 [Bottle] One of my favorite beers. Pours used motor oil black with a finger of tan head. Thick, coating mouthfeel with flavors of molasses, roasted barley, bakers chocolate, caramel, and a surprising amount of citric and noble hops. Semi-sweet finish to round out the moderate bitterness. Awesome brew.

33 cl bottle, Fargo. Ink-black colour, dark tan head. Earthy malt aroma with subdued hops in the background. Tastes....thick. Smooth going down, roasted malt and finishes with a sharp hop bite. Aftertaste lingers and some alcohol burn at the end. Still quite nice, if it indeed mellows with age this could be a great beer.

poured pitch black with a large creamy tan head. great lacing. aroma is chocolate, roast, pine hops that linger. powerful. flavor is full and complex. start was creamy rich dark chocolate fades to a mellow roast and finishes with powerful hops. the hops would be much tamer if aged a little. oily and thick body. alcohol is well hidden among the flavor. great beer.

Pours black with thick brown head.  Great looking beer in the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt.  Nice thick, creamy mouthfeel.  Taste of chocolate, smoke, molasses, and coffee.  Alcohol is evident with nice burn in the finish.

Thick and goey, super super heavy roasted flavor.  Hard to drink the whole thing, it took me a long time to get it down.  Bold and delicious, Im not sure it was quite possible for it to live up to my expectations.

Bottle at Oldsmar Tap House.  Finally, the chance to drink this legend of a beer.  It pours an oily, opaque black with a rich mocha head.  Pouring the yeast in the glass makes no differnece in appearance.  The aroma is heavy on roasted malts and alcohol.  The flavor is intense!  This is a huge beer, maybe the most assertive Ive ever had.  Rich bittersweet chocolate, roasted coffee and molasses repeatedly slap my palate around with every sip.  Carbonation is strong, and the alcohol is very evident.  It forces you to drink slow and take small sips.  Its rounded out with a good dose of hoppiness, but the malt complexity is the real showstopper.  Absolutely fantastic.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2008 Syrupy pour, black as night with thin brownish head. thin spotty lacing. Aroma is chocolatey syrup, earthy piny hops and notes of licorice. Sweet and spicy flavor that blends well with a chocolatey syrup flavor. A little swirl of the glass brings the head to life accentuating the spicy hops and creamy mouthfeel. Very oily and piney flavors begin to push the chocolate notes back. Alcohol aromas awaken as it warms, though it just adds another level of character to this drinkable beauty. I could use a bit more chocolate sweetness for balance, though it doesnt need it really. Residual bitterness leaves a pleasant taste on the tongue, but seems just a tad off to me. dont get me wrong, this beer is top notch just the way it is.

12 oz. bottle, unknown age.  Poured black with one finger brown head.  Moderate lacing.  Coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts in the nose.  Flavor dominated by roasty malts, toffee, and dark chocolate.  BIG, hoppy finish that mellowed as the beer warmed.  Evident warming alcohol throughout.  Medium mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 Acquired a 6-pack tonight at Champanes wine/liquor for $12.99 (good price!).  Poured black as night, with thick frothy brown head.  Head lasted a long time, and left lacing.  Aroma of roast coffee, chocolate, and hops.  First flavor that hits you, and stays with you, is the bitterness of the hops.  Very creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation.  10.5% alcohol sneaks up on you, doesnt taste really alcoholic, but you definitely feel it.  Overall, clearly a quality brew, but may be a bit strong and heavy for me.  Was tasting it for hours afterward.

Update: have  had a couple more of these, and its growing on me, great taste...
Hands down, the blackest beer Ive ever seen with equally dark, brown head.  Good carbonation.  Overdid the hops in my opinion so not as balanced as it could be.

Thanks toTy5592 for this one! Pours black with a little bit of ruby around the edges.  Thick tan head.  Aroma is a hoppy burst of coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is heavy chocolate,  piney hops,  caramel,  toffee,  smoke,  wood.  Nice!  The mouthfeel is very creamy,  not a bit of chalkiness,  great carbonation.  I think that is the best part of this beer,  and that is saying a lot.  This ranks up with the best of imperial stouts,  and its standing on here is well deserved.

Courtesy of BBB63. Thank you, sir.

Last beer of the night for me. 2002 vintage. Dark black pour with almost no head. Could have oxidized and flattened out a bit. Ive had new vintages of Expedition, but this one was different. There was a soy sauce/teriyaki thing going on, along with tons of chocolate, booze, coffee and dark fruits. Also get some nutty sweetness on the very back end of the aroma and into the flavor. Flavor is delicious, chocolate, coffee beans, soy, and dark roasted malts. Full bodied, low carbonation,, very substantial and filling. Super long finish, chocolate and coffee the stars. I dont know, if you would have told me before hand what this would taste and smell like, I probably would have been put off by it, but this is the best of the very few Expeditions I have had. The best Bells beer I have had yet, and thats saying something from possibly my favorite brewery.

Pitch black poor with a THICK brown frothy head.  Aromas of olives, roasted malts, bitter chocolate, chocolate pudding, very hoppy, alochol, hickory and toffee. Explosion on the palate... extreme mouthfeel, perfect bitterness... persistant and long lasting. Creamy, oily perfectly balanced.  Added flavors of burnt toast, caramelised malts... very complexe flavors and mouthfeel.  I have to say that this has to be one of the most complexe ive rated.  Definitely up there with the best.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2009 12 oz. bottle shared with Matt7215, RyanMac13. Thanks Matt!! Pours the epitomy of what an Imperial Stout should look like. Absolutely no light permeates this roasted beast. Perfect aromas of basically every single complex IS aroma there is. Flavour is the same, BOOM on the palate. Anise, plum, chocolate, coffee, etc. Nice. Other beers, you have to wait a second or two before the flavours hit, or even take a breathe. This guy here, starts coming at you the second it hits the tongue! Waves and waves of Imperial Stout goodness. Hops and bitterness are quite evident too, but take a supporting role to all the malts in there. Man, this is definitely the single most impressive beer Ive ever had the pleasure of consuming! I just wish I had more of it!

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2008 (USA) Nice pitch Black color with a Sm-Tan Head. There is a nice Roasted Aroima with a Coffee/Chocolate taste. Starts with a Smooth Mouthfeel and ends with a Slight Bitter finish. A well balanced Brew!!!!  (Happy B-Day to me)

Thanks to Jason! (JB175) A downright amazing stout brewed by Bells. Pours motor-oil black with little head (which can be expected). Smells very complex and deep. Deep fruits, cherries, coffee all pull through. Amazing on the palate, very thick and creamy. Nice hop tingle that offsets the malt perfectly. I can definitely see why this beer is so highly rated.
Motor Oil Appearance, Little or No Head, Chewy Palate, very Complex Malty and Strong Coffee Flavor, Huge Beer

Bottle that Miketd gave to me at Zythos 08, Many thanks Mike youre very generous, cheers!   Pours oily black, very dense with a nutty brown head, it looks superb. This has a huge infusion of coffee, bitter chocolate and general all round roastyness quite lovely. Despite the big bold full on nature of this beer it also has a softer and smoother edge to it albeit still quite bitter. I really liked this its full bodied and despite its strength is never too pushy in the alcohol stakes. Im not sure how old this beer was that Mike gave me was but I reckon that it would get smoother and improve even more with a year or two behind it.

fruity chocolate coffee aroma, pours black with small tan head. creamy smooth thick mouth feel. rich sweet malty flavor hits first then the hoppy bitterness climbs on top of the tongue. chocolate and a fruity flavor I cannot quite place. the sweetness and bitter hops linger. the first time I tried this beer I didnt like it. I am happy for second chances.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Black, almost too thick to allow a head to develop, with lasting brownish-tan ring that almost looks like pond phosphorus.  Mild aroma of espresso, earth, chocolate cookies, with slight alcohol.  Chocolate, coffee, chocolate truffle sweetness with very mild port wine fruitiness and woodsiness and medium bitter finish.  Very full body, maybe too full, low carbo.  An extreme stout without being ridiculous.  Sippable.  Very very rich.  Should probably be served with a defibrillator.
UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 This beer pours very dark with a thick foamy head.  The aroma is heavy chocolate with some caramel.  Very malty and rich.  Makes a great desert beer.

Bottle. Pours black with a think foamy head that leaves good lacing around the glass. Aroma includes malt, hops, hint of coffee, and a hint of caramel. The taste is tart, bitter, tangy, and filled with alcohol. Even though the initial taste is tough Expedition Stout does fall off into a nice aftertaste. Personally I like my stouts to be a little smoother, that tough alcohol taste I usually find more complementing to the taste of ales. Overall its not a bad beer, but still not one that Im going to be having on the regular.
Pours black with a thick dark brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate malt. The flavor is strong with chocolate, coffee, some bitterness... very rich.

12oz bottle thanks to stfun: pours pitch black with tandish red head, aroma strong with hops chocolate and roasted malt, flavor matches the aroma but with a little more roasted malt. well balanced but a little on the hoppy side fpr a stout. like this one a lot.

By far the best beer I think ive ever tried.  The first true stout Ive tried as there arent many available in my area.  Visiting a friend in Michigan and tried on his reccomendation.  Pours dark and almost thick with a definite coffeish flavor with a bit of chocolate flavor.  Tastes better (if thats possible) after a year of cellaring as the milder nut and fruit flavors become more defined and add to the flavor.

Poured jet black with quarter inch of dark brown head.  Nose is chocolate and roasted malt.  Taste is very bold, strong chocolate and expresso flavors.  Very potent beer, makes your taste buds dance in joy.  Fairly carbonated as well, has a wet finish going down.  Highly recommended

Acquired via trade from SQNfan...and a sincere thank you for this one!!!  A metric ton of chocolate, brown sugar, and toffee evident in the aroma.  This beers appearance was, perhaps, its most underwhelming characteristic.  Jet black body with 1/8 inch caramel head; no visible differentiation from most imperials.  Flavor is BEYOND bold.  Bitter chocolate and roasted coffee, but in amazing proportions.  No aftertaste.  Bells...consistently impresses!!!

I finally got to try this one!  Bottle at a local beer bar.  Poured nice with a smaller head than I expected.  The stout was dark and almost thick.  Flavors were everywhere with dark chocolate, coffee, toffee and roasty flavors.  I can see why this is such a high rated beer!

Bottle courtesy of cmr1517.  Pours an opaque black with a small tan head.  Nose is coffee and dark chocolate. Palate is just like it smells, black coffee at first with bitter sweet dark chocolate finish.  Nice creamy mouth feel.  The alcohol is pretty well hidden.  A terrific stout that deserves the hype.

On tap at Terminal.  Pours black with a chocolate head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee.  First sip was roasted malts, chocolate, and a good hop bite.  Wow is that good.  Heavy and smooth on the mouth.  Leaves a good lacing as you drink it.  Great chocolate hop aftertaste.  Excellent stout!
UPDATED: MAR 5, 2008 On tap at the Blind Tiger in NYC. Such a flavorful and rich stout. With all the amazing beers they had on draft, this was the one I had to have 2 of.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2010 this beer has truly made a hop-head a stout guy. pours jet black with a soft dark brown head, and great lacing. aroma was of roast coffee, cocoa powder, and a great hoppy presence with a touch of alcohol. flavor was just superb. intense coffee, fresh expresso, dark malts, dark chocolate, and a lovely hop bitterness. after the swallow a long lasting bittersweetness lingers on the toungue. 10.5%abv adds a touch of warmth adding balance to the beer. simply another great offering from bells.

Only had this one on tap a few times. Pitch black in the glass with a cocoa froth. Pungent smell of cocoa-coffee-hops. Its a full tilt stout that makes a mouthful out of a swig. By the time you find the bottom of the pint youll be appreciating the high ABV and the morphic character of the taste.
Bottle. Nice black pour with a pretty big head. Coffee and chocolate aroma. Very smooth and blaanced taste, covers the alcohol well. Very warming and good

bottle. pours a midnight black with a large silky chocolate-cherry head. the smells that emanate from the glass resemble the bastard love child of a chocolate-espresso-cordial cherry menage a trois. has a deep rich roasted bitterness that carries into the finish. alcohol makes its presence know around mid-glass, blending seamlessly into the bitter finish. warmth creeps down your throat and fills your core with happiness. leaves a lovely delicate sheet of lace all the way down to the bottom of the glass. this is one for any stout lover to try.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Imagine pulling the plug from the oil pan of your car,  thats how this stuff pours. Its opaque as could be and built an unexpected  deep brown head. Tastes like espresso, maybe has some slight hints of cherries?? Aftertaste is wonderful and almost non-existent. Im not a big fan of stouts but this one surprised me and had me coming back for more.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with Photekut.  Pours black with a luscious, moderate-large brown head that lasted until mid-glass and left lots of lacing.  Very strong aroma of chocolate liquer, roasted malt and to a lesser extent, coffee.  The flavor is more dominated by the roasted malt than the aroma, with lots of chocolate and again some light coffee.  Initially, there is also a strong tobacco flavor that emerges near the finish which I did not care for all that much.  As the beer warmed a bit and breathed, that aspect thankfully disappeared.  Some bitterness at the finish, but not overdone.  A great beer for a snowy and cold winters night to enjoy by the fire, which I did.

Pours dark, syrupy, motor oil. Half inch dark brown head with an aggressive pour. Full glass lacing.

Initial smell of sweet, chocolate followed by roasted coffee.

Sweet, syrupy, malty, very hot.. I can taste the alcohol here. As it warms, alcohol starts to disappear.. burnt coffee, chocolate, hop bite on the back end.
Bottle.  Nice roasty aroma.  Pours dark black with a dark brown almost black thin head that disappears quickly.  Tastes of coffee and dark chocolate, some sweetness but well balanced.

The first time I met this beer, I was utterly defeated. Now, I am the master. It goes into a tulip with an inch of coffee like foam. This quickly dissipates to a thin ring which stays around the edge of the beer. It appears to be black, but when held in the light at the proper angle, one can see that it is dark ruby in color. 

The nose is very complex. It is roasty and has a vinous quality. I detect just a slight licorice aroma. The nose is very well blended. The taste does not disappoint either. There is coffee, licorice, port wine, and others I am sure. Beneath all of this, I detect me some hops. There is absolutely no hint at the 11.5% ABV. The mouthfeel is great. It is thick and chewy, but is not syrupy. As I am writing this review, the quality of this beer is starting to sink in. The drinkability is high, especially with the way the alcohol is masked. I will consider myself lucky to have this beer available in IN.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-18-2005 08:36:40

12oz bottle. Poured an oily, molasses black with half inch creamy head. The top layer has a dark, warm reddish tint to it. Great malty, coffee, caramel, and nutty aroma. I was hit with chocolate, molasses, cream, and a blend of other nutty flavors. I was amazed by the blend between sweet, rich, and roasted palate of this beer.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Bells Expedition Stout is a fantastically complex beer. Sweet, chocolate, smoke and coffee are all combined to create a great imperial stout. Dark motor oil color with chocolatey head great sweet and bitter aroma.

Another big winner from Bells.  Incredible drinkablilty from such a big beer, and one heck of an aftertaste.  Very smooth, with all the buzzwords that typically describe a stout.  Bourban aged stouts may taste better for one glass, but you cant go all night with them - This is the best of all worlds.

What can I say that hasnt already been said?  Pours thick and slow, like molasses in January.  Black as black can get with a thick, whipped chocolate mousse head.  Aroma is typical for the style...roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, and espresso.  Flavor is the same.  Astoundingly smooth, and velvety.  This is some kind of liquid love...or Vahlrona chocolate, not sure which is closer.  The flavor palate, while simple, couldnt be done much better.  Dont like the price though.

Deep dark black with thick coffee colored head, mouthfeel is like velvet.  Aroma of bitter bakers chocolate and black coffee a trace of alcohol.  Flavor is very similar, sweet and dry, espresso and chocolate tones with some malty sweetness slight hop presence.  Finish is phenomenal with velveteen smoothness, a dry slight hop tang, and the warm presence of the 10 %.

12 oz. brown bottle. Batch 8145. Bottle conditioned.
Served in a brandy snifter. Pours an opaque black with a slight tan head. Roasted malt aroma with a slight whiff of alcohol. Very fully bodied. Rich mouthfeel. Lots of roasted barley flavor with a fair amount of hop bitterness. Super long dry finish with lots of coffee flavors.

A classic version of the style. This one was fresh, save some for the cellar.

If i had to describe this beer in one word, i would say thick. This beer was my first foray into into stouts other than Guniness, so i may just need some experiance. has a very malty taste with a speck of coffee. Aftertaste brims of chocolate. if it was only 6 ounces it would be awesome, but u still have to choke through the next 6 ounces.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 black as night pour with an espresso colored head with a slight reddish tint as well.  dark chocolate, roasted malts, sugar and all kinds of smells going on.   great thickness and a taste screaming of chocolate, wood, thick malts, dried fruits.  this is probably the most complex tasting beer ive ever had.

12 oz bottle from Tertons.  Pours thick as oil with a creamy tan head.  Flavor and aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts and a subtle sweetness.  Rich and complex, full of flavor.  The mouthfeel is unbelieveable, it is like pure velvet and the alcohol is undetecable.  I had forgotten what a true imperial stout should taste like.  I need to get a couple more for my cellar.
poured like oil. hints of chocolate,coffee,and maple syrup. coats your mouth like pepto, smooth finish. wonderful beer
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: A Godsend among beer. This is a truly rich deep dark beer, with dark chocolate flavors rich oily texture and espresso notes. pour this into your morning cup and you would never know the difference.

The aroma is like chocolate cream with coffee, nuts, molasses, and toasted malt. The appearance is dark brown with a brown head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is thick and smooth. Overall I like it.

Appearance: Pours a jet black body with a full, frothy tan-colored head.

Smell: Aroma of black malts, roasted coffee, dark chocolate syrup, scorched almonds, molasses, and herbal, piney hops.

Taste: Black roasted malts with flavors of coffee and exceedingly dark chocolate. Some burnt almonds and fire-blackened marshmallows. The hops are bold in their bitterness, but not overbearing, and provide a taste of dried herbs and pine. Finishes with a lingering bitterness and acidic char taste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Mild carbonation. Chewy mouthfeel. Warming from the first sip.

Drinkability: A very fine stout both fresh and cellared. To wit, I had an 02 this past weekend that had morphed into a slightly roasty chocolate liqueur.
Pours very dark, and leaves a yellow residue on the glass after drinking.  Smells very good and tastes better than any other stout.  Has full flavor and sweetness.

Its Bells Exp Stout, what more can you want from a stout. This is by far the most impressive full bodied and rich beer I have ever had. Extremely dark stout with a very thick pour. For the high alc percentage it has a very smooth and rich finish. IF YOU HAVE ACCESS TO THIS BEER, BUY IT!!

Bottle, poured black, no head. Reaked of hops. Super thick,  an awesome amount of hops in a stout. The malt lingers nicely in the background. This stout is quite smooth and I like the high percent of alcohol in it. You can skip dinner, for this is a nice meal all by itself. Over all, a great stout to get you hands on. I bet this beer gets much better with time... (SHOUT OUT TO STFUN FOR THIS ONE!!!)

A very very dark pour, with no light penetration going on at all. This is really not something that you can just dive into, it has to really be taken slowly to appreciate all that it has to offer.  It is very warming and very powerful.  Extremely full-bodied and in your face with a lot of flavors, most of which have already been described to much detail. This one just has a virtual smorgasbord of flavor, very bitter but sweet in the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 I really love this beer.  Everything about it.  It pours really beautifully--jet black and oily, and then a nice brown/orange 1-inch head makes its way to the top.  All the expected tastes in an imperial stout--coffee, chocolate, roasty malts--but a nice toasted marshmallow vibe sneaks in there, too.  The finish lasts forever... and ever... and ever... Im glad Bells isnt holding back production on these bad boys.  Yum.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2016 Awesome!  This is definitely the most impressive beer Ive ever had.  Black with tan/orange head.  Lots of chocolate and roasted coffee flavors.  Definitely potent too!  Cant wait to have another!!

12/2016. Aged a 10/2012 for over 4 years and had on Christmas Eve.  As good as it gets for a beer.  Remains the best beer Ive ever had

Thanks to MuenchenerKindl for this one too

Bottle poured into a sniffer produced fingers worth of coco colored head that turned quickly to a skin coat of lace .it sat on top of a jet black body 

Aromas of vinous fruit, fist time I really can say that but pretty mild aromas after that some toasted malts 

Flavors here roasted malts and chocolate some raisins with a heavy bitter finish 

Thick and creamy finishes with oily coating on the tongue 

I dont know I think I had this bottle to early will have to revisit this one was bottled Nov 07 Ive being drinking a lot of stouts lately and this is not one of the tops but not on the bottom either

Pours pitch black.  It has little head though, but what there is is a dark tan head that does leave lacing.  The aroma is loaded with roasted chocolates and coffee with a subtle presence of alcohol.  The flavor is unbelievably loaded and complex.  A bitter chocolate with plenty of hops and a hint of the alcohol.  Its really almost too much to drink at times.  The mouthfeel is thick and smooth like velvet with nice bubbly carbonation.  Amazing beer.
Wonderful. Black with a dark creamy head. Sweet aroma of fruit and malts Taste is very rich, sweet and malty with a dry hoppy finish. Nice warm burn on the throat.

Bottle. Looks like something youd put in your car. Little to no head. Not crazy about that but seems to be the norm for a strong RIS. Heavy chocolate and coffee aroma. Lots of malt and hops but finishes relatively smooth.  10.5...nice...
Black of color with a nice beige head. An aroma of liqurice, chocolate, hops and notes of alcohol. A nice oily flavor of chocolate, liqurice and hops.

Smells great,tastes great.  What more could a beer lover want?

It literally poured like moor oil, thick viscous black body.  Little, to no head.  Strong coffee flavor with pronounced notes of heavy roasting.  The alcohol content comes in at the end, not in an overpowering way, but definitely evident.  good, warming sensation follows.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2008 A little too sweet for me...  Appearance is great, jet black, nice rocky tan head...  Aroma is fruity to me, with a burnt coffee note.  I have some set back to cellar, this tastes a bit like some homebrew Ive made that I got out a little too early, with too many things going on at once, and nothing coming together.  In a year or so it might be better.  A little too sweet... had much more hopes for this one... of course, I think Im not as big a fan of imperials as I thought I was.


re-rate
gigantic boost for this one on the re-rate... kept some cellared back and boosted almost all of the areas of rating.  Huge roasted quality to this one, all of my initial comments stand except for the negatives.  Still a bit sweet, but as it mellowed even over 6 months it got considerably more balanced.  I will get more of this, Ill just note that when I get it in the summer, Im going to drink it in the winter...

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2008 Poures like oil. Smells kind of nutty with roasted notes. Tastes of cashews, roast, coffee, cocoa, and malts. The dark tan head never seemed to leave. Great lacing. I still dont think this beer stacks up to my favorite Imperial Stout Storm King by Victory.

This was a great disappointment for the price.  I heard great things about this brew, but when it came to my tasting I was shocked.  It had a great looking head, a wonderful smell, and price tag to match a GREAT beer, however, this is nowhere near the top of my list.  In fact it is close to the bottom and I love the dar stuff.  I would reccomend Old Rasputin for an Imperial Stout....its great.

Had on draft several times in the past month. Beautiful dark brown head. Served a bit too cold though. I had to let it sit for a while before I could get any of the bouquet. Big roasted mouthful, with a thick, heavy body. The taste stayed with me for a while afterwards. Nice bit of hop backbone for a RIS. Didnt even remember the 10.5 until I stood up!

Poured a deep black color with a thick creamy brown head. The aroma was of a double chocolate milkshake with hints of coffee. The initial taste was again like a creamy chocolate milkshake. There was a flavor of a rich coffee that followed with a nice mild bitterness that rolled on the tongue. The flavor lasted well for a nice flavorful finish. I was surprised that the 10.5% alcohol was hidden really well. There was also some nice lacing from the head

12oz. bottle, courtesy of VeloVampire - pours totally black. Big mocha head. Aroma is full of a lot of chocolate and a lot of nutty roasted malt. Hops and malts are in perfect unison here. Coffee and chocolate as well. The flavour is a huge attack, lots of chocolate off the top whereas the coffee hides out until the finish and aftertaste. Espresso. Very hoppy as well with the alcohol showing itself but its warming rather than offensive. Nutty flavours as well. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy. This is an awesome beer. The best imperial stout that Ive had. Wow.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2008 12 oz bottle.  Perfect looking pour.  Thick with a long lasting dark brown head.  Very intense aroma with raisins an chocolate, hops, milk, malt.  Complex flavor with just the right balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Perfect

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 I had to rerate this one, I was just done being sick after the first one and the second one I had seemed much better.

This beer poured a beautiful creamy black into a snifter with a generous brown head with a nice ruby tint. Smells of Coffee, Chocolate and Malt are apparent. The mouthfeel is quite nice and creamy. As for taste the coffee and chocolate are definiteley there, Theres a hint of bitter hoppiness is cutting through my Imperial stout making this brew much more complex. Wow, and yum..screw guinness this stuff is the real black magic.

An excellent Imperial stout, bravo bells

bottle - batch #8145.  Pours black as motor oil.  Brown head that starts small and then just grows.  Tremendous lacing.  Aroma of coffee.  Tastes of roasted malts, licorice, coffee, and maybe a little cough syrup.  Very complex and great for tasting, but maybe just a little too big to enjoy for mainstream drinking.  Its almost overdone.  Overall a great beer, but not one I want to drink just for fun.

Very good indeed, however not as good as some other Imperial Stouts such as Yeti by Great Divide or WWW by Dogfish Head. The alcohol almost overpowers the taste and palate (never thought Id say that). Not a 100 but definitely very good.

Ive been waiting for this beer to come around since Ive read about it. This beer did not live up to my expectations. I hate to go into one of my comparision tyrads again, but for roughly half the cost, Brooklyn Black Chocolate Stout is as good. Sure the beer is tasty - not for $15. Maybe it was my bottles? Who knows.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Got his beer at 3 Sons in Wexford PA.  Poured into one of my best Pilsner Glasses, Monheimer kruezen Pils.  The beer poured like ruby red oil, with shimmers of gold.  The head poured to a nice 3/4 inch and held well leave a tan lace.  The aroma was not remarkable,but certainly pleasant molasses.  The taste was marvelous.  Bursting across the [allete first with a little carbonic acid, oats, and deep caramels, but then the licorice builds strongly along with a sweetness.  There is just enough of an earthy done, and the taste lingers with pleasant bitterness for a long time.

12oz Bottle - Trade with bullet2urbrain 
Aroma  Dark malts with chocolate, coffee with a huge amount of hops
Appearance  Dark black, Thick and a very thin head. 
Flavor  Tons of hops, great dark malts. This was a great Impy stout.  
Palate  Nice Mouthfeel, thick with a great texture with a nice dry finish. 
Overall  One of the best Impy Stouts out there.  Had great flavor and was not over the top and killed you for other beers.

The poor on this beer is crazy.  Definitely the thickest I have seen so far.  Looks like melted chocolate going into the glass.  This stuff coats the palate long after a sip.  The alcohol smell was there, but surprisingly wasnt too apparent compared to other 10.5% beers.  This stuff is the real deal as far as thickness, but I wouldnt want to have two in a row.

Pours thick and looks like motor oil/ molasses. Color is almost totally black but you can see the reddish brown lacing. Head is a dark reddish brown, one of the most impressive heads I have ever seen. Smells of chocolate malt, roast, smoke, cocoa, and wood. Tastes of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, Mouthfeel is amazingly thick and the finish is lasting warming and chewy. A great beer but just a bit hard to drink. Did a mention there is quite a bit of hops in this beer too?

bottle.  for my 100th rating, i figured id go with one of my favorites over the years.  cheers!

pours a completely opaque black, with a medium light brown head that fades fairly quickly, but never completely.  huge nose of roasted malts, with brief hints of a cocoa, some sherry, oak, dark fruits, and even a bit of hops, if youre looking for it.  dark burnt toffee, wood, molasses, bitter chocolate, dark fruits, everything you could imagine from a stout as big and black as this.  additionally, you can notice a pretty insistent citrus floral hop taste.  big alcohol warming, and leaks into the taste sometimes, depending on the temperature and what ive had on my palate before.  big hop bitterness, balancing out the dark malty sweetness.  thick, chewy, coating, oily and silky mouthfeel, massive body, lots of tingly bubbles.  this is nearly the perfect imperial stout.  what flaws does it have?

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 re-Rate: Ok, this is flat out awesome. First time I tried this, I was a little let down because nothing stood out to me. However, on the second try, I was blown away. Nothing stands out because everything is balanced almost to perfection. 10.5%? Really? Wow, doesnt taste like it. Color is creamy and black. Taste is an explosion of malt, coffee, chocolate, and hops. Alcohol sneaks up on you, the way it should be. Beers warms as it goes down, but not in an overpowering way.  Beer is just thick and complex all the way through. Last time I worried about rating it too high, now Im worried that I didnt rate it high enough.  Delicious. I bought some for cellaring and cant wait to try it again next year.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 Bottle. No batch number. Pours deep, dark and thick. Like my man. Gooey paint-like tan head. Awesome. Aroma is a metaphorical punch to the face, in a metaphorical good way. Roasted coffee beans, coated with layers of soy sauce and sugar cane. Flavor is out-worldly. Dank, smoky tea rooms. Pretentious chocolate. Sweet floral hops. Nougat and caramel intertwined in a lovers embrace. Viscous, velvety, voluptuous.

Really black.  Dark brown head.  Aroma of coffee and sugar coated almonds.  The flavor is burnt toast covered in nutella.  Lots of chocolate at first.  As it warms Im getting tons of licorice and marshmallows.  This beer is soggy, sticky and sweet.  I love it.  Thanks Ty!

Aroma is strong with chocolate and coffee with a slight scent of alcohol as well.  Pours very dark and very thick with a short lasting deep tan head.  Flavor is strong with coffee and chocolate hops.  Goes down very smooth with a long lasting after taste.  This is one of the best I have had.  I would recommend it to any real beer drinker.

Pours pitch black into my snifter. Big mocha head leaves some scattered lacing and reduces to a thin cap.

Aroma is very strong, with boozy sweet chocolate and a hint of caramel. A fleeting note of red fruit as well.

Taste reminds me of Bourbon County Stout. Ludicrously rich chocolatiness with a coffee bean bitterness in the finish. A hint of estery alcohol is also present, but its fruity enough so as to not be unpleasant.

Carbonation is modest, body is really really thick. Pretty damn smooth for a beer over 10%.

Drinkability is hampered by the syrupiness and hefty alcohol level but its just so damn smooth and tasty! Great beer.

Beer poured really, really dark with smallish dark brown head and little lacing. The aroma on this was chocolate and molasses. This was probably the richest, sweetest beer Ive ever had. The flavor was really strong chocolate with alcohol sweetness and an infusion of coffee. A perfect amount of hop bitterness on the backend. Fantastic!  The beer is bordering on being just too sweet. If you let it warm too much, its is kinda too much.  This beer really is a standout.  One complaint...if a beer is going to be $15 for a 6-pack, have the decency to package it in 4-packs instead!

Bottle. Starts with a tiny tan head, but it grew beautifully into as good lookin a beer as you could ask for. The nose is surprisingly minimal...no alcohol, no burn, just a real thin layer of coffee and smoke. Delicious roasty flavor with some hints of coffee, brown sugar, almonds, and a nice warm finish. A little stickiness on the finish and the simple aroma are all that keep this from being the perfect beer. Still, its damn incredible.
This beer was heavy, syrupy and amazing.  There is a huge amount of dark barley and coffee coming through.  I would buy it over and over

I am kind of perplexed by the rating. Once again, I was spoiled with the other stouts I had before trying this one. Very dark, which is to be expected, but the linger is almost overwhelming. Maybe I need to read into this brand a bit more, but it didnt seem as high of a standard as is being rated on here.

This was back in color with a brown head of fine bubbles.  There were scents of molasses, chocolate, roasted coffee, dark fruit and a slight spicyness toward the end.  In the mouth this was concentrated with lots of midpalate power and shows off mainly coffe & chocolate flavors with a hint of the alcohol.  Very well balanced with the hops just poking out at the end.  I look forward to trying this repeatedly as it ages.
Had to get this one in Indiana because its not available in Illinois. defiantly worth the trip. This is a huge stout with a very complex taste

From a bottle.  Pours a dark with a small tan head.  Aromas of sweet and dark chocolate, coffee, caramel.  Flavor is very smooth and complex.  Notes of sweet chocolate and roasted coffee.  A bit of underlying bitterness balances out the sweet malts.  Very silky smooth mouthfeel.  Great imperial stout.

Definitely my go-to stout, but finally getting around to rating.  Rating is for a fresh bottle; Batch 8145.  Pours black...thin dark-tan head.  Aroma is roasted coffee, sweet malts, and some sweet chocolate.  Flavor is very nice, and has a mind of its own.  Theres the characteristic chocolate malts and roasted nuts/coffee, but theres also a smooth underlying alcohol...almost like a canadian whisky, that I cant help but notice.  Flavor evolves very nicely as it warms, and theres a strong bitterness long after the drink is over, but it is pleasant.  The balance between the sweetness and bitterness is what makes this a wonderful beer.  Palate is creamy, but not overly thick, with a nice level of carbonation.  Although the ABV isnt listed on the bottle, you know theres some alcohol content with a slight burn/warming after  swallowing.  Id be hard pressed to find a better beer for the price at about $2.50/bottle...this is a great drink!

Very full beer.  2007 not as great as 2005 & 6.  The flavor is greatly enhanced when it warms up to around 50+ degrees.  Much more coffee and chocolate comes through.  Try it, you wont be disappointed

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 Bottle. Pours black and thick with a very thin head. This beer is a shape-shifting monster, or at least one with multiple personalities.  Flavors and aftertaste seem to change with each mouthful. Hops go in and out of hiding while roasted coffee and chocolate battle for supremacy neither having the strength to stay in front of their fierce opponent for long. Even with all this going on, the beer is quite drinkable, and at its current price, you can afford to. Expedition stout is a great brewerys flagship beer and worthy of its current rank.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2008 (thx thebeercellar / batch 8145) Extemely intense hopoy aroma for a stout, also a slight sweet, smoked, coco smell. Super jet black, with a small brown head.  Rich, burnt malty, sweet start, roasted coffee bean/ chocolate  taste. Coco hoppy, sour/bitter finish. Another great Imp. Stout!

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2009 I dont even know where to begin with....this is one of the most complex beers I have had, also probably the best as well. The pour is very black...oily even, maybe like looking across the event horizon into a black hole. The only other beer that I have seen as thick is Founders KB. The nose is almost pure roasted malt...coffee and underlying tones of chocolate. A very subtle hint hops, although most of the hops are covered by the malt. The flavor is intense...undulating waves of roasted coffee and smooth, silky chocolate. A sweetness that is similar to dark sugar (Belgian maybe) or to dark fruits. The only bitterness might come at the end (I have found that sometimes its there, and other times its not..very mysterious). Overall this beer is amazing...so smooth and roasted....you sink into the intense maltiness with every sip of this masterpiece. RERATE: The wording stays the same, but the new rating is 5.0 to reflect the newest batch from Bells, which is quite possibly the best beer ever created. Simply put....the best beer I’ve ever had

It pours dark.  Very dark.  It looks almost like motor oil that should have been changed a long time ago.  The head is thick, frothy, and the color of milk chocolate.  The aroma is malty with hints of alcohol , coffee and chocolate.  The flavor is of sweet chocolate and coffee with a bit bitterness.  The most noticeable aspect of drinking this beer is how creamy it is in the mouth.  This beer has a lot of flavor and is very heavy.  A good winter beer no doubt.
UPDATED: JAN 30, 2008 Chocolate and coffee well hidden by hops. What a beer. Pitch black color with a chocolate head. Bitter hop finish.

Bottle marked 8145. Special thanks to ilovedarkbeer for this one. Aroma is very nice with pine hops, chocolate, and Raspberry. Pour yields a dark black body with a very dark creamy head. Good lacing. Sweet and bitter balanced flavor. The coffee and chocolate are hidden by hops. Creamy texture with nice lively carbonation.

Pours black with a very delightful chocolate head.  Aroma is strong with chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt.  Definately on the sweeter malt side with chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, coffee, and hops with a warm finish.

Pure black with brown head. Very well-balanced nose of sweet and bitter dark chocolate, coffee, dusty earthiness and faint earthy hops, roasted malt, etc.-- the list could go on and on. Flavor is again incredibly balanced, with notes of roasted malt and chocolate at the forefront. Bitter enough to counter the sweet flavors, full and very drawn-out mouthfeel, with a wonderful bitter chocolate aftertaste. Opens up beautifully as it warms, and the alcohol is completely masked. Cant say enough about this one, it was just perfect all around. Really impressed!

Motor oil pour, pitch black with a big brown head. Excellent lacing, smells of dark chocolate, light hops, coffee. Perfection as far as mouthfeel goes, leaves a distinct coating on the tongue well after the last sip. Alcohol is relatively well-hidden, but surely not one to chug down. This is $2.75 a bottle? Incredible value.

Batch #8145. Pours a deep dark brown, with a deep tan, big head.Nice lacing. Aromas of caramel, roasted malts, and chocolate. Flavors of sweet roasted  malts, light chocolate, and slight caramel sweetnes,with dark esters. Smooth, full body beer. Very easy drinking, nice with a light dessert.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: Pours an inky balck that that generated a small mocha head. Smells of roasted malts,Toast,Bittrsweet chocalate, and hops.Taste is damn near spot on perfect. Palate is chewy and lush. A great Impy!

Pours black and thick like chocolate milk. Best beer to date. I like this one because you cant taste the alcohol. Beats Stones Russian Imperial stout. On my second case from Shangys. Only 48 dollars a case.

I was lucky enough to have this on draft at Redlight Redlight. Huge thanks to Brent for putting this on tap. This poured a deep black color, almost opaque, with dark brown around the edges and a thin tan head. The aroma was very complex and very inviting, just outstanding. It smelled at first of dark chocolate and malts and a huge roasty smell with a touch of hops as well. As it warmed up I was able to get some vanilla, oak, and milk chocolate as well. It was to cold at first from the tap so the flavor was very roasty and bitter, but as it warmed up the true flavor came out. The chocolate came through first with a touch of coffee in there follwed by the vanilla and oak flavors that blended perfectly together. The hops and roasty tasty came through in the finish. This was definitely full bodied with a nice creamy mouthfeel. It is a big beer and one meant for sipping. It went down very smooth with the right amount of roastednes and bitterness in the background. Just a pleasure to have been able to try on tap. Bells never seems to disappoint.

draft. oily black  carmel thin head. nice roasted aroma and alcohol. roasted coffee and smooths out with some chocolate finishing with a nice hop punch. alcohol is warming and present yet still nicely hidden for such a high percentage.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2010 12 oz. bottle, batch # 6672. 
Wow... Opaque black with a brown head. A slightly oxidized smell is mildly sweet with chocolate and plums, prunes. Medium heavy body with a oily mouthfeel. Rich taste of dark chocolate truffles, expresso, and plums with a slight hint of alcohol. A cloying finish has that expresso taste to it. 
One of the best stouts brewed these days. Excellent  July 2005**********************************************  Batch eight thousand something.... still a great stout but not quite excellent
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: WOW!!!  this beer is a mind blower.  pours like coffee syrup with a full mid brown head that sticks around.  aroma is surprisingly hoppy, with hints of coffee and caramel.  smooth, alcoholy, slightly bitter finish.  again, wow, i see now why its 100%.

Bottle, Pours like engine oil and has an oddly sweet aroma which I wasnt expecting. Very thick mouthfeel, might as well be chewing on the malts. Very long finish with an upward bitterness. Awesome stuff
Pours black and thick, like syrup, head is brown.  Flavors are robust coffee, chocolate and hops.  A little alcoholic, but very good.
very smooth and dark... exactly what stout lovers are looking for. I have had this both on tap and bottled and, although the bottle is a wonderful brew, the tap is even better

Oh my.  Pours hedonistically dark with a lovely looking, dissipating, foamy cocoa head.   Nose is very chewy, like a chocolate malt shake, with toasty character and an intiai caramel sweetness, and a peaty alcohol  nose somewhat similar to a single-malt scotch.  Starting off very rich and creamy, progressing to a strong bitter menthol and licorice finish like the kalamazoo to the nth degree, this is about everything you could want in a stout.

Ive had it bottle and tap and both are amazing.  Tap was definitely preferred though.  Pours very thick and completely opaque.  Very chocolately and smokey in aroma.  It tastes extremely strong but in a very good way.  Try not to drink to many of these at once though.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a thick, viscous pitch black with a large, dark brown head.  Small bit of lacing around the snifter.  Aroma  of piney hops, dark chocolate, and smoke.  Flavor is mouthwatering delicious.  Roasted malty notes mesh unbelievable well with the hops.  Coffee notes and hints of soy sauce peek out from the bottom of the glass as the beer opens up.  Long, drawn out bitter finish.  Its no wonder why this one is near the top of the class!

Wow.. All the good qualities of the kalamazoo on steroids.  Appearance is darkest of dark with evident lacing resulting from the tan creamy head.  Aroma is strong and pleasant.  Taste is malt and hops on top of a full creamy body.  Finish is very long lasting.
I love this beer. Very smooth ,yet dark and hoppy and strong. Very well may be the best Stout!

Thick black in colour with lively toffee coloured head. Big alcohol aroma with hint of coffee. Burt coffee and hop flavours, that lingers on back palate for ages. If have a couple of these perpear for a big night in.
Thanks John.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 Wow!  Thanks to Adrian for a bottle of this.  Pours out black as crude oil with a light brown head.  Aroma of malt, yeast, alcohol, and a little citrus.  Nice, low key label.  Had this at room temperature, and what a strong, rich stout it turned out to be.  The flavors play around in the mouth, sometimes one dominates, sometimes another.  There is coffee, alcohol, yeast, hops, honey, tobacco, cocoa, and roasted grains.  The finish is not bitter and the aftertaste is nice.  Amazing - this is the kind of beer that could make its way into my dreams.  Unfortunately, I did take it down a couple of notches in 2009.  The flavor was smoother and not as rich as I remembered it.  But I upgraded it again in 2014 - my buddy Dave was very impressed!  A truly superior brew, and not impossible to find, since it does sometimes turn up in good bottle shops.
What a beautiful pour and an amazing sight to watch settle.  Chocolate and coffee taste are prevalent and this stout is as smooth as they come.  An unbelievable beer!
Nice roasted bittersweet chocolate aroma. The appearance is awesome, dark with a mocha colored foamy head. Tastes like chocolate leather/velvet/suede. Smooth and rich truly an amazing beer.

From bottle, thanks sercret santa : Pours black as night and thick.  Nice finger of brown expresso colored head, that dies down to a nice rim around the edge.  Very pleasent aroma of roasted chocolate with hints of coffee beans.  Taste is big and strong.  A fair amount of alcohol at the beginning, but mellows a small amount into some chocolate notes.  Finishs with some alcohol present again, but not really a bad alcohol taste.  Body is pretty thick, about average for a imp. stout, palate is kinda sticky then smooths toward the end.  Pretty nice.

Batch # 8183.   Poured a dark, dark brown with minimal tan head.  The aroma was of dark malt, along with some chocolate and dark fruit.    Alcohol was in the forefront, but the flavor was still good.   I consider this a good brew to share.
Pours like used engine oil.  Aroma of chocolate.  Taste of espresso mixed with a Hershey bar with a handful of hops thrown in for good measure.
Looks just like used Castrol when poured. Definite alcohol taste. Am drinking one as I rate right now. Very good but a little overpowering to drink quickly.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 Pours a thick engine oil black.  Aroma of strong hops and licorice.  Little to no head.  Very heavy body with an overwhelming blast of flavor.  Chocolate, strong coffee, licorice, and hops.  Very thick and shouldnt be rushed while drinking.  Id go out of my way to buy again.

I heard about this beer but wasnt prepared for the incredibleness that can only be Bells Expedition Stout.  Served at room temp, it was like my tastebuds were exploding with a thousand beautiful and delicious flavors.  The aftertaste about knocked me out of my chair, it was so sweet and long and heavenly.  I made my first youtube video to forever remember it by: http://youtube.com/watch?v=NzdeY51mVgM

If theres a better stout out there, Id like to know what it is.  This thing is incredible! 


Absolutely pitch black, black as night.  Not much in the way of a head, but still...damn, this thing is jet black. 

Smells just like a hersheys Dark Chocolate Bar.  Very smoky and dark with a bit of sweetness to it.  

I actually drank this at room temperature, about 65 or 70 degrees.  Grabbed it right off the shelf, paid for it, got home and popped the top on it.  Glad I did now.  You can really taste the complexities of this beer at this temperature.  

Sure, it kicks a little bit at around 10% but what else can you expect?  This is excellently crafted.  Excellently....  This is just amazing.

Oh boy, this is a serious beer.  One of the thickest pours Ive seen, almost no head.  Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, and cherries.  Flavor is enormous, just like the smell, dominated by roasted malt and very bitter.  Sticky mouthfeel.  Exceptional.

Bottle. Dark dark brown color, with a rich brown head. Amazing aroma of malt and chocolate-covered cherries and blueberries. Intense flavor of malt and dark chocolate, but not overly heavy. Incredibly tasty and very drinkable.

Pours an oil black color with a thin mocha head.  Aroma is slightly sweet and bitter, with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is rather sweet and bitter, little alcohol, and chocolate with the palate being coffee.  I would have preferred more chocolate complexity and less bitterness but not bad.  Still enjoy their Java Stout much more but this would probably improve with a lot of aging.

Pours a dark opaque black color with some brown highlights when held to a light. Chocolate milk head that sticks and laces. Smells sweet, roasted coffee beans, chocolate, cocoa. Taste has a lot of delicious layers with everything the smell offers and more. Alcohol warms but is not present in the taste. Drinks like a dessert. A wonderful stout that is a must try for all stout lovers and beyond.

waves, yes waves of lacing on the glass. Chocolate aroma, only a faint coffee smell and a little bit of alcohol in the nose; a little more coffee roasted flavor and this would have had a five. Chocolate starts you off, leading you into a bit of coffee flavor mixed with some hopiness, then chocolate and coffee paired together with an alcohol warmth at the finish. A complete joyride the taste is. Thick, full bodied, little carbonation and seems to be perfect. Each drink is great and an all out experience of the senses, just a little short of perfect.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2009 Pours very dark with a small tan head.  Nose is of coffee, fruit, and chocolate.  Taste is great.  Coffee, sweetness, and a good amount of hop bitterness make this stout stand out.  Mouthfeel is great as well.  Some light carbonation and very smooth. A great beer.

Appearance is very nice, the head is thick and doesnt dissapte very fast and has a good lacing that sticks. Black color is solid.

Smell has coffee, molasses, dark fruit tones and is full in body and flavor.

Taste has flavors of coffee, molasses, and slight flavors of dark fruit like prune.

Mouthfeel is very silky and smooth, very nice.

Drinkable for sure, I would buy this for sure.

What can I say, I really like this beer.  Nearly no carbonation, but very port like in flavor and quality.  Dark roasted grains dominate the flavor and mouthfeel.  Coffee and bittersweet chocolate notes are very strong.  Hop bitterness is noticable but balances the intense malt sweetness.  Plum and rasin notes are very strong as well. Lack of carbonation leaves a syrup quality to the beer but very nice.   The kind of beer to sit by the fireplace on a cold winter night read a good book and smoke a cigar.
12 oz. bottle. Pour like motor oil with a thin brown head. Aroma of bitter chocolate and coffee. Great mouthfeel, thick. Great stuff.
Great Stout!  This is the best imperial stout that Ive had.  I am going to judge all imp stouts against this beer.
