I was given this beer after it had been sitting in someones closet for a year.  It was incredibly fabulous.  Bought a fresh 6 pack - and it wasnt the same.  I would suggest letting it age.  If you think its good now . . .just wait!

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 vertical on 3/25/10.
batch #8145 very dark pour with a 1/4" tan head... a bit of dark brown on the tail end of the pour... roasted nose with some deep dark fruit notes and a slight touch of coffee.  medium to thick body with a nice sweetness throughout... dark fruits dominate (raisin, dates and red grapes).... some molasses... sweet malts... licorice... a faint red wine characteristic lingers... silky smooth body.... wonderful elegant finish with cream coated malts and a touch of roasted coffee.  I prefer my Expedition with a few years on it.

batch #9459 dark pour with a 1/4" tan head and a bit of see through brown on the tail end of the pour... deep plum aromas with a touch of roasted malts... medium to thick body with a general sweetness and licorice presence... big roasted malts... sweet finish with a burst of mint and licorice with a twist of alcohol and a solid bitterness... a bit too sticky on the finish.... the fresh bottle really lacks the depth of the aged bottle... these need to sit in the cellar.

rating on 12/21/07.  bottle.  what can i say about expedition stout.....?  Ive been looking forward to this beer for quite awhile, since they dont distribute in my home state of Georgia... but finally got my hands on some.... absolutely outstanding!  This imperial stout is probably the best Ive ever had - just absolutely delicious.  Pours a magnificant pitch black with a thick 1" + tan head.  Strong aromas of roasted malts, coffee, fruits, licorice and  chocolate.  Thick full body which rolls right over the tongue while unleashing its multiple qualities previously described in its aroma.  If you can get this beer - buy it today.  If not, trade for it, call someone who can get it, do whatever is necessary to get some, b/c it does not disappoint one bit.

At last we meet. My fears that you would be another imperial stout overly dominated by hops proved to be unfounded. Instead, you were a powerful and complex black brew with some real balance. Extreme, yes, but gorgeous and intelligent. Bottle pours thick and oily black, with an equally thick head thats nearly dark brown. Whoa. Aroma is roasty and bitter, with loads of espresso and dark chocolate. Flavor begins a touch sweet (like mocha) before folding into the bitterness. Its hoppy, but its malty enough that the espresso and dark chocolate supercede the old, dry greenery. I dont even know if that makes sense. I dont care. Thick, creamy and oily mouthfeel. Lightly sweet but mostly bitter, roasty finish and aftertaste. Challenging and delicious.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Bottle on 12/20/07 from Jan07. Appearance: Pretty damn black, dark brown head. Aroma: Licorice, dark fruits, faint pine hops, caramel & toffee mixed with a little bit of alcohol, sweet chocolate. Sweet milk chocolate comes out more as the beer approaches room temperature. Aroma: Taste:  Hits you right away with dark fruits & a little bit of alcohol. Then chocolate comes in, but soon relinquishes its spot back to the dark fruits & alcohol at the very beginning of the finish. But then it leaves an amazing chocolate/toffee/burnt malt taste on the front half of the tongue. Perfect smoothness, no stickiness. Yes, thick as motor oil. 9/5/9/4/17-4.4

07/08 bottle on 3/15/08. Very chocolaty and roasty. Not much dark fruit action in there. Alcohol was hidden well, despite being a fresh bottle. 8/5/10/5/16-4.6

Pours like thick, black ink. The head is one of the darkest Ive seen. The aroma is toffee, caramel, coffee and roasted malt. The first sip is a little bit rough, but after that its smooth sailing. The taste of alcohol lingers, but it only compliments the thick, creamy, chocolate/toffee flavor of the beer. Fantastic brew.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 1-6-08 bottle shared at tasting (2004 bottle) 
The rating above is from the 2004 cellared bottle.  So much bettter than the non-cellared versions.  This was fantastic!  Smell is ideal and alcohol has set in nicely - quite sweet.  Perfect creaminess and ideal smooth mouthfeel.  Taste is perfection - sweet caramel undertones and chocolate aftertaste.  Feels like melted chocolate on the palate.  Just great!  The hit of the night!


12-16-07 and again on 1-6-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to Gregis (2007 bottles) 
7  -  4  -  7  -  4  -  15
Thick black with creamy tan head and big lacing.  Roasted caramel and malt in the aroma.  Taste is high in alcohol but very nice and enjoyable.  Tastes like toffee candy with alcohol in it.

I drank this particular beer right alongside VMILaxer29, and couldnt agree more with his assessment.
We found this over an hours drive away and coordinated logistics support to have it transported here to our office for Gentlemans Hour. It all comes down to this... Pours dark like used motor oil after 5,000 miles. No head at all! Very deep beer, that punches you in the stomach like the bully in third grade on the playground. You dont get up for 10 minutes, and feign being more hurt than you really are just to keep him from hitting you again, but this beer isnt going to drink itself. You go in for more. It goes down smooth, washing away your pain and anguish of the day.

We found this over an hours drive away and coordinated logistics support to have it transported here to our office for Gentlemans Hour.  It all comes down to this... 
Pours dark like used motor oil after 5,000 miles.  No head at all!  Very deep beer, that punches you in the stomach like the bully in third grade on the playground.  You dont get up for 10 minutes, and feign being more hurt than you really are just to keep him from hitting you again, but this beer isnt going to drink itself.  You go in for more.  It goes down smooth, washing away your pain and anguish of the day.

Bottle. Pours an oily jet black with a small tan head that fades to a ring and leaves good lacing. Huge aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, caramel, and a hint of dark fruit. Full oily mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness considering the amount of roasted malt they put in this beer. The alcohol is barely detectable. Very well balanced and very good.

2004 bottle, consumed 12/17/07.  So dark brown its almost black.  No head on pour, but it spontaneously erupts a few seconds later, dying quickly.   Coats the sides of the glass when swirled.  Aroma is a little musty, salty.  Velvety smooth mouthfeel.  Red wine flavors, saltiness (like soy sauce) bitter finish.  No carbonation a major bummer; this bottle must have passed its prime.  Too bad, as its supposed to be so good.

Wow...this is a damn good Imperial Stout.  Great black viscoitty that pours and looks like motor oil. NIce and dark brew with lots of espresso and roasty flavors.  One of the best Imp Stouts Ive ever had, do not pass up on this if you have a chance.

Almost slid out of the bottle into my glass. Like pouring oil. Pours pitch black with a nice tan head that diminishes to a ring that that remained with sticky lacing covering the glass. Aroma is of cinnamon, sugar cookies, molasses, and alcohol. Very chewy oily body. Alcohol is present from start to finish. Flavor starts out slightly bitter like a dark roasted coffee, then molasses, and coffee lingers in the finish. A good beer, but I think I would enjoy this beer more after cellaring for a year or two.

Bottle.  Poured deep brown to black with a thick brown head.  Subtle aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Has a nice roasted coffee flavor with a hint of chalkiness.  You can taste the hops, too.  Wonderfully heavy mouthfeel.

Bottle massive thanks to secret santa. Aroma is very meaty and roasty, no hops or chocolate character, but as it warms the meatyness goes away and is just sweet roasty. Taste is balanced but one dimentioanl roasty, sweet an not really much else. Alcohol is really really well hidden leading to good drinkablity. A good imperial stout actually as it breathes in my glass gets better.

This is a phenomenal imperial stout.  It was very dark, with a nice thick brown head that lingered for a long time.  The aroma had quite a bit of burnt caramel and chocolate, and a little bit of citrus.  The flavor and palate were also spectacular with the same huge roasted chocolate and burnt caramel as the nose.  The flavor lingered on the palate for ever.  On Tap at Tria, Philadelphia

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2008 Bottle courtesy of Gregis Big oily black pour, big brown lasting head in a snifter.  Smell is figgy, banana notes, lots of dark roastiness and dry dry chocolate.  Taste is dry dark roasty malt on the bitter side with figgy character.  Some molassesy sweetness perhaps.  Some alcohol showing a bit too in the flavor.  Slightly sweet, but more rich, heavy chalky and slightly bitter malt.  Big heavy rich mouthfeel and light carbonation.  Nice, big, big stout.  Thanks Greg!

’04 Bottle still has lots of dark fruity flavors but shows no signs of alcohol and is still incredibly rich and has a decadent mouthfeel.  Very enjoyable.

Pours like oil and has a small milk chocolate colored head.  A lot of great dark malts and sweet alcohol in the nose.  Excellent toasted flavor with a sweetness of chocolate and molasses balanced with a nice bitter finish.  It has a great texture and drinks like butter.

This stout pours black with a nice tan head.  It smells like sweet coffee, almost like toffee, with notes of chocolate.  The flavor is loaded with bittersweet chocolate.  It is so rich and deep in flavor.  A nice creamy, velvet ending to top it all off.  Another excellent stout from Bells.

The pour is almost black with a nice copper head.  The nose it chocolate, roasted malt, and hints of toffee.  The flavor is extremely refined with much the same entities as the nose.  A great stout, and I would love to age foe a few years and try again.  Which is not to put down the immediate flavor, as the is a great stout.

Purchased at Hatboro Beverage, PA. Pour is like motor oil, with a few syrupy brown drops at the end. Aroma is like coffee. Mouthfeel is thick, wonderful. Alcohol is very well hidden. Tastes like chocolate, but not overwhelming. Gives you a very warm feel. Im a stout fan, and  you cant get much better than this. Thanks to Chip, Burt, and Matt (you know who you are).

12 oz bottle. Part of my Secret Santa package. Pours as black as midnight with a 1/2" brown head. Fair amount of lacing stays with me till the end. Nose is of heavy roasted malts and strong coffee. Mouthfeel is thick and heavy. Flavors of roasted malt and sorghum molasses assualt the taste buds. Alcohol is present, but not overwhelming. This stuff rocks!

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2008 The aroma was a nice malty, chocolaty one, but it was faint. Pours black out of the bottle with a small, dark head that faded away rather quickly. The 10.5% alcohol by volume was very evident. After sitting out a while, this became nicely thick and creamy. Overall, I didnt love this as much as everyone else seems to. Its good, but the great reviews just got my hopes up too much. As a result, I was disappointed. It was stupid of me to read others reviews first.

Pours syrupy black, forming a dark brown foamy head.  Aroma is of burnt coffee, malts, hops, cherry fruits.  Flavour is bold, full bodied, roasted malts, coffee, with a nice hop like character towards the end.  No sense or presence of alcohol, well balanced.  Huge character with a lovely complex, yet subtle taste.  Extremely well made and impressive beer.  Beer lovers rejoice!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
12oz Bottle
$15.00 6-Pack
Bells General Store

Packaged 10/25/07

This is a fresh bottle consumed on 11/23/07. Expedition Stout pours midnight black and actually swallows up the light present. A one finger faded brown head grew on the pour and fell rather quickly to a thin skim coat leaving somespotted lacing on its way down. An expected expierence with the high abv.

The aroma starts off with some deeply and freshly roasted barley. This roastiness is consistent throught the aroma and everything else is just a compliment. Deeply roasted coffee beans, a quick flash of dark fruit, quick lactic quality on the second half, and a flash of spicy alcohol and mild hops on the backend.

Flavor goes hand in hand with the aroma. Theres deep roasted qualities from both coffee and malts. Lactic, still green from the freshness, a touch of dak fruit, and a nice alcohol spiciness on the swallow. Its actually nice to get an alcohol kick from an RIS since most dont let the alcohol add the complexity needed.

Body is heavy but leaning more toward the medium side of the spectrum than the hugely creamy side. Alcohol fumes exhale through the nose. Spiciness warms my cheeks. Theres more of a hop presence than tasted or smelled and it leaves the tongue somewhat beat up.

This, especially in its raw young age, is a sipper without a doubt. I could easily drink a couple in a night but thats about all. 

Another great beer from Bells. Their stouts are above verage to outstanding. This is one that leans toward outstanding. I reviewed this one while it was very fresh. Up next will be an ged example and this beer ages with the best of them.

11/24/07

Bottle. Poured a brownish-black color with a medium brown head. Nice lacing. Aroma is a nice roasted malt with a pleasant chocolate hint to it. Mouthfeel is about perfect. Flavor is rich with a chocolate and roasted malt taste. Aftertaste has a hint of coffee to it. A very special brew.

Roasted malt aroma with notes of sweet, dark fruit.  Complex flavor of chocolate, coffee, ripe fruit, and alcohol.  Nice lasting finish of chocolate and caramel.  Very thick feel with just enought carbonation.  This is a great stout; definately one of the best.

Draft. Keg had just been tapped. The beer poured black with an incredibly creamy light brown head. The aroma had lots of burnt smells accompanied by a little bit of fruit sweetness. The flavor is full of chocolate, coffee with some alcohol. The body is very full and the aftertaste lingers with a pleasing bitterness.

12oz via trade with KingpinIPA. Pours yellowish orange with a 1 finger bright white head. Nose is very lagery and yeasty. Taste has a bit more cream in it, but has an unncessary bitter bite. Overall big ehh in my book.

This beer is packed with flavor! So much going on in the taste! Really an all around great beer. Its like a roller coaster for your palate! Sweet Chocolate, toffee, candy, licorice and dry bitter finish of a strong black espresso and hops. A little too thick though, like it should be changed every 3000 miles

120z bottle from G&G. Pours a pitch black with a mocha head. Aroma of malts, coffee, and chocolate. Great lacing. Im in heaven right now. Usualy im very let down buy the higher rated stouts but this one is amazing. Wish i had bought more.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 12oz bottle(courtesy of mreusch)-Pitch black body with a nice light brown head which has an aroma of dark roasted malt, coffee, and sweetness. A full bodied brew with a thick viscosity and a taste of coffee, maple syrup, chocolate syrup, slight alcohol and chocolate milk on the back end. This is one of the very best stouts I have had. Very well blanced and the alcohol hidden.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2010 On tap at Redlight, served in a wine glass by Teej. Pours inky black with a small tan head popping up out of the glass, that settled quickly. Aroma is chocolate, cognac, and cherry with a hint of a warming alcohol. Big thick and creamy in the mouth with lots and lots of hops cherry and fresh ground coffee. Nice carbonation for a stout, not flat, sparkles in the mouth. Finishes very clean for so thick a taste, then gets a little lingering hops and chocolate as it warms, but doesnt get cloying. I was only suppose to have one and head home, but had to have a second one. Simply beautiful. 

Rerate from bottle #7251, courtesy Durhambeer. Inky black pour little head. Oily dark tan film around glass. Huge roasted grain, soy sauce and hints of chocolate aroma. Big thick black body, roasted grain, chocolate malt and some hop bite in the taste. Has aged wonderfully.

Deep ass brown to black...thick  appearance with a dark brown sugar head....deep and pungent, just on the swirl....looks like glass blowing on the swish...when I inhale, Im nestled inside a coffee bean and wrapped up in sweet chocolate leaves...when i inhale again, I almost orgasm...ok well it defiantly takes me away, but not like calgon....silky and rich body...baking chocolate...carob...mocha and smokiness all blended to a supreme perfection...sweet on the buds, with a tight structure to hold it all together, its simply a perfect imperial stout...pure velvet in the glass, and a sticky loveliness on the lips...pure pleasure...I crave more...and all other imperial stouts must bow to this supreme creation

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2008 Admittedly, imperial stouts are not my favorite. Im very torn on this rating, because I think this is an excellent representative of what an imperial stout should be...  thick, rich exploding with flavor and black as coal. Unfortunately, it poured so thick that I was tempted to pour it on top of some vanilla ice cream rather than drink it... It was tough to finish. ll join the crowd and say that this is a great imperial stout, but not a beer that will join my list of favorites due to its viscosity.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2012 Bottle acquired via trade with Ty. I had this beer once before from Eric and I was unsure how to rate it. It is really a great beer. Pours a dark black with a awesome brown head. The flavor is really complex: a hoppy bite, alcohol, burnt malts, sweet and dark fruit, coffee, chocolate, industrial sludge and various mineral deposits. Warm and inviting. The body is great: thick and rich, but also smooth. A great balance overall. Awesome. 
Re-rate: bottle thanks to John. Batch 8145, brewed in September 2007, drank August 2009. Pours that amazing picture of a dark crude oil color with a thick and mouthwatering brown head. I love this beer! A full flavor of so many dark fruits, lots of coffee hides in the background. Vanilla and ripe citrus hops come to the fore as well. Amazing. Especially considering that I can trade for this beer easily. Just as good as anything else. Smooth and creamy. Re-rate: another bottle thanks to John. Batch 7740 bottled December 19, 2006 drank October 2009. Its amazing how the aroma wafts out of the bottle, it hits me with an intensity; I know this beer, and I love it. Rich and fruity, not much of a hop presence. Perfect. A perfect mouthfeel and appearance. What can I say? Please Bells, never stop making this, and never change it. Batch 7817, packaged February 1st 2007, drank December 2009. Just lovely as always. Massive oil can like deep dark flavors. This aroma is ingrained into my memory, when I breath in the Expedition goodness I feel great. Amazing beer every time you try it.  Re-rate: batch 9459 bottled Nov 19, 2009- drank 1/31/10- so very fresh. Sweeter, hops are present for sure. Juicier and slightly hot. Different than the older vintages Ive had, very good. So much dark fruit. Amazing. Batch 8729 Sept 2008 drank July 2010. Two years of age. What a wonderful colored head, so dark and unusual. Lovely. Thick oily dark fruits, no one does this except Bells. Hail! Batch 9971, just over two months old. This beer needs a bit more time to reach its full potential. Still, robust, fruity and lots of hops. Smoky almost, which isnt something I always notice. Brown sugar comes out too. Batch 10105: From Dec 2010, drank June 2011. Amazing, this is the best fresh batch Ive had, huge fruit, very rich. Cherries layered into a dark chocolate cake. Lovely. Batch 6811bottled on my birthday April 26 2005, seven years old. A more subdued nose with a smaller head. Light oxidation but overall very rich and robust, as good as always. Very mature and sherry like at times. Some warmth. Superb. Drank March 2012.

This beer pours jet black with a thick dark mocha colored head. It smells like dark malt, dark chocolate, alcohol, and has a general sweet aroma. The taste is very sweet and very malty and it is very obvious that this is a high alcohol beer. There is a bit of alcohol burn after each sip. Its a bit too sweet for my taste. The mouthfeel is good and full, just like it should be. Overall, its a bit too sweet for my taste, but this is a good beer.
Pours like oil and looks greasy as it curls through the glass.  It has a wonderfully intense flavor of toasted malt.  I need to buy some more and let it cellar to see how far it can go.  Great beer!

UPDATED: APR 16, 2008 In a 12 oz bottle, from papous wine shop, slyva, NC.  Solid black with dark head.  Awesome aroma, i could smell this beer all day.  Very toasty, makes you feel warm inside.  The alcohol is well hidden.  Well balanced beer.  Would buy this one again.  One of the best stouts I have ever had.Rerate 4-4.3
A delicious stout. Had it bottled then poured it in a mug. It poured a dark oil color black, and tasted very hearty. Great beer to sit out in the cold around a blazing hot camp fire!

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2011 Rich, dark chocolate, dark fruit and roast, big caramel malt body with just enough bitterness to cut through and alcohol to lift. This is my gold standard IS, and my most missed beer from the East (roughly) coast.

---initial rating: 12/2/2007---
on tap @ redlight, 12oz snifter. So, this was my first experience with this beer. It poured pitch black with a thick brown head. Could smelled the hops, chocolate, roasted malts. Taste was of chocolate, heavily hoppy but well balance with the roastyness and strong malts. Mouthfeel was amazing and though I could feel the warming effects of the alcohol, it wasnt apparent in the taste at all. Aftertaste was where the hops really stood out. Didnt quite realize the full effect of the hops until after the other flavors had faded and the hops were still there. Pretty great, looking forward to picking up some bottles and seeing how they taste after they have a little age on them.

Wow, a very dark pour.  Motor oil is a good descriptor.  A small tan layer of filmy head forms on top and then disappears shortly.  The aroma is a bit smoky but also has some sweetness of dried fruits and chocolate.  The flavor is rich.  Up front is a thick layer of malty sweetness that makes way for a bitter finish of hops and roasted malts.  It is thick and smooth all the way through with a well hidden alcohol character.
bottle.  wow. dark thick black pour.  warm bitter chocolate strong raisin bitter.

12oz. Bottle: Motor oil black, dark brown head. Looks evil, dark as night New Moon style. Sweet malty aroma, slight dark roasted coffee, smokey, a hint of alcohol. Full, smooth mouthfeel. Coffee, baking chocolate, a little bit of licorice. You know what...I will say no more. Buy it, drink it, love it...amazing. 12oz. isnt enough for the four of us :o)

12 oz. bottle.  Batch # 8183.  Pours black with thick, foamy, long lasting brown head.  Creamy.  Thick and viscous, oily.  Coffee and chocolate, carmel and licorice and dark fruits, plum and raisin.  Hints of alcohol.  Head laces very well.  Mouthfeel of chocolate milk.  Thick and viscous.  Sticky in the back of the throat.  Carmel and chocolate, touch of dried fruit.  Well hopped, bitter finish that lingers well into the after.  Lots of alcohol warmth, but it doesnt really take away from it.  This will be revisited in a year.  Wow.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2009 Sampled during Manhattan Blind IS Tasting: Not sure why I didnt put up my other rating for this but I am glad I didnt. I mean it definitley held up to what I had found previously. I love it. Nice, sweet, some nice hops, very good fresh, ages well too, less hops after a few years. Every time I have this I remember why I love it so much. It is amazing and complex.

Bottle. Beautiful pour. Maybe the best looking imperial stout Ive seen. Inky glossy black with creamy brown head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, fruits, hops, liquorice. Flavor is intense dark malts and chocolate. Hints of coffee especially in the aftertaste. Very complex, hop presence noticeable especially at the back of the throat. Mouthfeel is creamy and solid. A very filling beer. This one lives up to the hype imo, one of my favorites.

Not up to the level of a Founders ... but still wonderful.  On a cask pull this sucker held on to its medium brownish head to the bitter end.  The complex flavors were accented by the warming of the alcoholness.

Quite a nice imperial stout.  I remember having this perhaps 2 years ago, and being a bit turned off by it, but my how my tastes have changed.  This beer is not the biggest imperial stout Ive had, but still has plenty to offer.

It poured a bit viscous, and was the opaque black that characterizes the style.  A pretty thick cappuccino colored head topped it.  Aroma was of liquorice, chocolate and coffee.  Flavor was definitely more liquorice-y...gave a nice sweetness to the beer and accompanied the dark malt.  Mouthfeel was full but not syrupy and was quite nice.

I dont know why its taken me so long to return to this beer.  It is a winner!

Perfection!  Dark black pour with a coffee colored head.  Very full aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, caramel.  This beer is so smooth that it become dangerous at 10.5 abv.  The flavor is very complex with malty chocolate and coffee, dark berries, and many other things that are silly to even try to list.  Simply amazing!

Bottle:  Super thick pour with a heavy red/brown head.  Alcohol very present in aroma along with lots of roasted notes.  Slightly sweet flavor with lots of coffee and malt to it.  Bitterness makes for a nice crisp finish.

Ive been waiting a long tome to try this and i wasnt dissapointed.A thick glub glub pouring out with a dark beige head that was thin.The nose was boozy with fruits and coffee.Flavor was boozy but not overwhelming with coffee and malts with a small bite.Finish was strong and bitter.

Extremely solid looking dark liquid, the nose isnt really in your face but a good whiff indicates all sorts of condensed, aged and preserved aromas trying to de-compress and escape. nice palate though this bottle is less perfect than others Ive enjoyed over the years (nearly 20!), a small amount of papery oxidation mid palate marks it down a half a notch or so but the brilliance of this beer shines through, it deserves its reputation as a clssic.

Just a gorgeous milk chocolate colored head with an deep obsidian liquid center.  the taste had a prominent creamy texture with coffee notes. Big achol after tast this has to be my favorite stout to date.

I loved this beer...  absolutely loved it.  I was sad when I finished it.  When I first read the description of what a stout tastes like, this is what I thought it would taste like.  This was the first beer that met that image that I had in my head.

My jaw dropped when I poured this one - black color with a very deep brown-colored foamy head.  Its gorgeous.  The aroma is the aroma that I always expected in a stout.  Malty aroma balanced out with coffee notes and subtle chocolate notes.  Wow.  Flavor is a wonderful blend of the malty sweetness and slight coffee-like bitterness that lingers on the palate for the perfect length of time.

This beer is gorgeous.  Thank you Bells and keep up the great brewing.
Chocolately and rich with a ton of malt character. Surprised to hear they use 5 times the hops in this, as its tremendously malty. A very nice medium-bodied stout.

Bouteille de 12 oz obtenue via un échange avec Dmac621. Arôme: Odeur de mélasse et de chocolat avce une pointe de vanille. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col brun mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café, de chocolat et de petits fruits foncés. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #1349)

The aroma was roasty and fruity with strong presence of chocolate and sweet caramel. The aroma had an espresso acidity and dark fruits, raisins and prunes, coupled with a sweetness that was cakelike and bready. The chocolate was dark and luscious to the nose. The beer poured pitch black with a dark brown slow rising and falling head which laced the glass from top to bottom. The flavor was rich and luscious with malty chocolate and strong espresso roast. The flavor was smoky and deep with strong acidic bittering which kept the malt in check and eventually won the battle. Dark fruits of raisin and prune were present. The flavor also contained a nice grassy flavor and bittering. The finish was dry with lasting roast and hop bittering into the aftertaste. The body was full and viscous and the carbonation was low. The beer was nice and creamy on the palate. Alcohol warming was notable post consumption and was substantial. A truly excellent RIS. 12 ounce bottle, batch 8183, purchased at Sams.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 14, 2008 Wow. This beer is like chewing on candy. Its the thickest beer Ive ever had. So many flavors, so complex I wont even try to describe them. Simply the best stout Ive had.
Nice brown color. Great taste. Chocolate, malt, coffee flavour. A good stout
High alcohol up front taste.  Very nice toasty smell and taste.  Perfect balance of malt and hops.  Gets better as you drink it.  Smooth mouthfeel and good lacing.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 07 Bottle  
This bottle thanks to artusory (have another one aging thanks to miketd[).  Pours a thick black color with a moderate, dark tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, some dark fruit notes.  Rich chocolate and coffee flavor with hints of vinuous fruits and roasted malts.  Powerful beer, but not overpowering.  Nice, full mouthfeel and great lacing.  Awesome, awesome beer.  Thanks Ryan for sending me this. 
07 Rating 9-5-9-5-18=4.6

06 Bottle
Batch 7696, bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Pours the same inky black color with a thin, deep tan head that diminishes.  Deep roasty aroma with chocolate, coffee, and a hint of alcohol peaking through.  Smooth caramel chocolate entry transitions into a strong roasty middle, with a nice coffee flavor on the finish.  Smooth and silky as ever.   Still could probably hold longer, thank goodness Drew sent me a couple more, thanks a ton Drew.
06 Rating  8-4-9-5-18= 4.4

12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a small light-brown head that dissipated quickly.  Only a vestige of head remained on the rim, which did leave beautiful, intricate lacing.  Aroma is of chocolate, coffee, picked up some vinous hints and alcohol.  Mmmmm!  This is incredibly tasty!  Mouthfeel is medium to thick and creamy.  Some chocolate bitterness in the aftertaste.  This brew is one to sip slowly and appreciate the complex flavors.  Cherish every bit of it.  I did.  Look forward to getting more of this in the future and spreading the word about the best Impy stout Ive tasted.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 bottle 12 oz coded 8145. Ultra drk brown with large dark tan head. Aroma of rich dark roast malt, floral, sweet, spicy hops with some chocolate, coffee and a trace of alcohol. Flavor is very full bodied, rich, creamy dark rst malt, almost viscous with plenty of bitterness early on and through into the lingering finish. Alcohol is noticeable, perhaps an aged bottle should be sampled. Some sweetness but not overdone. Plenty of complexity and flavor in this well balanced Impy stout. Excellent! I cant stop sniffing the empty bottle.

Aroma of chocolate, malts, coffe, a creamy smooth buttery scent that is really pleasant to catch a whif of. Black as coal no light shines through. Small light brown head that reduces to a patchy sprinkling of foam. A really smooth dark flavor. Coffee grounds, dark chocolate, a really creamy flavor that sits in your mouth really pleasantly... Delicious, this is my first Bells Brewery beer. There will be more to come.

Courtesy of JB175. Pours a pitch black color with a tan head. Has an amazing taste of chocolate, coffee, maaaalts, and barley. Finishes creamy with a slight hop presence. This is a staple for imperial stouts.

Sampled some from bottle.  Overall this beer nearly met my expectations.  Dark pour, like dark as black as black can be oil.  Aroma is extremely malty with coffee grounds and bitter dark chocolates in there.  Flavor is very bitter and includes quite a strong bitter coffee taste.  Dry as Death Valley.  Alcohol presence was noted.  I think Im a bit more partial to Bells Kalamazoo Stout instead.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2008 HUGE thanks to BrinK for this one. I had been saving it, and I just picked up another from JCapriotti as a bonus, so I figured it was time to try one! Thanks to both you guys!
  Pours opaque midnight. No light can be seen through this gorgeous Impy! The aroma is rich and malty, with leather, bourbon (?), coffee and chocolate with a hint of alcohol. The head is full and lasting, foaming slowly down to nice lacing. The flavor is remarkable, with the aroma supported perfectly, but in addition there is an earthy character that compliments nicely. 
 RERATE- every time I have this beer it’s different. First time was awesome, every time since just good. Dropped .3 points for lack of consistency, and for shelling out for shipping and for trading to get a case that now is a very good beer, but not great like when I first had it.
Pours like thin tar. Very malty take the coffee and chocolate a bit to hit the taste buds.  Very taste but not to thick.

Thick dark beige lacing head.  Dark black in colour.  Malty and sweet scent with a hint of alcohol.  Could definitely use some cellaring (and have already put a couple more bottles in the cellar).  Very strong alcohol taste with a malty and sweet aftertaste followed by a bitter followup.  I can see the interest in this kind of beer, but its a little too strong tasting for me.

Only moderately strong bouquet of cashew, charred oak,  black cherry, and milk chocolate. Thick, viscous, black pour with a slow building medium sized, dark brown head. Ridiculous amount of glass coating. Ive had milk shakes that werent as thick. Powerfully strong taste is like getting sucker punched in the face. Very good balance of charred oak, thistle, bourbon, and cherry notes  Bitter ash and grapefruit peel finish. At first, I felt it came on too strong, but once I got over the shock I began to really enjoy it. Even so, it would be very hard to drink a lot of these in succession. Its better for special occasions and blowing your newbie friends minds. I let my teen son try a sip and his reaction said it all, "Woweeeee!"

Fourth beer, third round, in a 5 round, top-rated imperial stout blind tasting to be held over the next year. Four beers with similar characteristics will be sampled in each round. Beers in this round were cellared for about two years.  Round 3 - Full body.  12 oz bottle.  Dark brown, almost no head.  Mild nose of coffee, touch of grape and brown sugar.  Coffee, chocolate, cherries.  Taste is most complex of the four with some hops in the end.  Medium body, mild carb.  Never disappoints.

Pours jet black with a small head.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee, and a lot of roasted flavor.  It is sweet, dry, and has bitterness that lingers. The alcohol was masked very well, it took me a couple of minutes to realize how potent it was.  Definitely a great stout.

Poured into my Corsendonk Christmas Ale Chalice!
Black as night! with a very minimal head that dissipated rather quickly! lacing is virtually none! The mouthfeel is extremely thick and creamy with heavy notes of bitter chocolate, coffee, burnt caramel,and figs with a nice lasting bitter finish,one of the best Stouts i have had the pleasure of tasting!

Rating #1000. Batch 6672 November 2004. (I think... the brewerys website says 6672 is an amber ale). Pours jet black with a small dark-yellow foamy head. Smells of malts, bread and a hint of alcohol. Quite sweet with an underlying bitterness that especially shows towards the end. Lots of sweet caramel. Aromas of roasted AND burned malts. Also coffee, port, raisins and a hint of vanilla. Very full creamy mouthfeel. Long dry frinish with a warming alcohol sensation in the back of the throat In the very late finish ther is a tiny hint of fungi. Big thanks to MIBRomeo (Secret Santa in July 06) for this fantastic brew!!!

12oz pour.  Poured black with a pillowy dark orange head.  Mostly roasted malt in the nose, I was expecting a bit more aroma.  That said, the body took me to new places.  Loads of sweet roasted malt, coffee, raisin, and a dab of sour malt that makes this really interesting!  The finish lingers forever, and the mouthfeel is second to none.

This is a top shelf stout! From a 12 oz. bottle it pours out a lovely tar black color, leaving a very attractive deep tan head. The aroma is an incredible cornucopia of coffee, malt, butterscotch, vanilla and caramel, highly complex.  After a sniff of that I was ready for a let down as it could not possibly taste as good as it smelled. Wrong!  All the flavors I had smelled now danced on my tongue.   The intricate throng of well balanced flavors was near perfect.  It had a heavy syrup mouth feel with a smooth finish.  Nice lacing was left behind in this top notch Imperial Stout.

Bottle thanks to HogTownHarry. Very dark pour into a snifter. Dark head on this beer, with delicious aromas of dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. The mouthfeel is extremely creamy with heavy notes of bitter chocolate, coffee, caramel and butterscotch. Easily one of the best stouts I have ever tasted and probably ever will.

wow, theres a lot to say here. This beer is black as black as night with a dark brown head.  Very very thick and chewy.  Tastes of chocolate coffee and alcohol, Aroma the same.  So far my favorite stout and worthy of all its praise
In the nose: alcohol, plum, chocolate, medicine. Black as night and retains a small cocoa head with large bubbles. Lots of cocoa, port, chicory and hops. Bit of bacon in the aftertaste. Classic.

12oz bottle, Batch 8145. Pours black in color with brwon head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and coffee. Taste is black coffee, roasted malt and sweet chocolate with bitter and dry finsih. The alcohol is very will hinden for the high alcohol %.
12 oz bottle.  Such a powerful tasting beer.  Black with very little tan head.  The taste is very unique and complex.  Chocolate came to mind first, then cream, and coffee.

Bottle. Completely opaque black. Nearly no head. Nearly no aroma. Hoppiness, chocolate, toffee just barely there in the aroma. Definitely a very complex taste... coffee, cream, coffee, toffee, hops, and what else? This is fun. Part 2 (of 4) of tonights Bells stout tasting. Mmm.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 355 ml botlle from a trade with hogtownharry. ohmyfrieakingod. this beer is insane. it pours pitch black with almost no head. aromas are of chocolate, coffee, hops, but just layer after layer of aromas. deep dark bruising aromas that make you not even want to take a taste for fear of being let down. the flavours actually are actually deeper and more intense then the aromas. the complexity is awesome but this is a well crafted brew that doesnt overwhelm any one part of your palate but instead leads you down a long twisted path of imperial stout extacy. i cant believe harry ever gave one of these up to trade but im truely glad he did. the best ive ever had and my first 5.
12oz bottle Pours out a nice thick black topped with a nice tan head. A very nice and tast sweet roast. Nice dark chocolate all over this brew. Very good.

100th Rating.  Batch 7740 bottle.  Pitch black pour with tan foamy head.  Light does not penetrate the beer.  Sweet roast, chocolate, with some faintness of hops and alcohol in the aroma.  Lots of chocolate and coffee flavors on the initial taste.  Full mouthfell.  Bitterness is ever present from start to finish.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  Very, Very good.

Pours raven nevermore--black with barely 2 centimeters of tan head. Loose lacing. Nose is cloyingly thick with roasted cocoa beans and shaved rubber. Tastes are more robust with fired marshmallow, espresso bean, and dark fruits.Medium carbonation and full-bodied. Rich and robust flavors throughout. A fine beer.

Very sweet and full flavored. Chocolate and coffee flavors but something even sweeter lurking almost piercing. Excellent body and texture and very dark pour with a creamy head. Girls (ime) dont tend to like it, but more for me!

so here it is my one year rate beer anniversary beer, and it will only be my second perfectly rated beer. i am not a stout person as you can get from my rb name, but this was awesome! this will also be my 280th rating for the year! to the beer! 2007. pours pitch black with a very nice two finger dark brown head, probably one of the best i have seen on a stout. aroma is roasted chocolate malt with a touch of hops. has a very full body with huge clumpy lacing and just enough carbonation for a stout. flavor is the same as aroma, but much stronger huge chocolate and a bit of coffee at the end. and dont get me wrong the aroma is awesome but the flavor is even better. there is a bite in the aftertaste and a little coffee that sits on the tongue. very creamy on the palate just an awesome impy stout! the best i have had yet! i can see why this is in the top ten! as it warms the hops come out to play a bit more and there is also some pine. there is also a little more coffee flavor and aroma as well. to me, i like this beer a little cooler to keep the chocolate flavor, but thats just me. cheers all!!!
Bottle at Akkurat. Black - small brown head. Raisins, plums, licorice, high dried dark fruits, coffee, high sharp hoppy. Light Wineous. Very nice.
This is definitely one of my favorites that Bells makes.  The look, smell, and taste all come together to form a great stout.  The chocolate and coffee tastes really play off each other well.
Bottle:  Balck in colour.  Minimal head.  Aroma of dark chocolate and coffee.  Full body, stong bitter flavour.  Batch 7740.

Bottle shared with thewolf. Thanks a bunch for sharing this one René! Bottle. Pours a totally bitch black colour with a medium creamy brown head leaving a very good thick lacing. Lovely aroma of dark chocolate indeed with coffee, roasted malt and bitter hops. Great mouthfeel. The flavour has very good profund creamy chocolate, good roasty maltiness, dark fruits, bitter hops, nut and some alcohol. Very good long lasting finish with chocolate, roasted malt and some alcohol. A mother of a stout indeed!

Bottle. [shared with faroeviking @ Plan B. Thanks to drmatt for this wonderful brew!]
Pours "bitch"-black as Jacob and I agreed. A Medium creamy brown head on top. Extreme amount of lacing. Wonderful aroma, coffee, loads and loads of chocolate and a slight hoppyness at the back. Thick, sticky creamy mouthfeel. Complex flavour. Sweet, cream, roasted, lots of chocolate. A good dose of hops without ever going bitter. Some nuts as well. Power and stunning balance!

Thank you Irishboy, deep dark black, think deeper darker black again, Ginger-coffee-chocolate-nut aroma with a sticky-chewy-bitter "Respect me" flavour and a definite alcohol finish but not dislikeable

Poured into a snifter with an opaque black colour, some brown particulates, and large dark tan creamy head. Aroma of dark fruits and boozy make up the first layer of this beer. The aroma then continues to fade into a light roast and nut finish. Initial taste is very creamy and soft mouthfeel. Some dark fruits & mollasses make their presence, but then they get a splash of bitter hops that overlay it. The dark chocolate comes in the third tier it is also very smooth and calm leading you into a roasted coffee. The bitter hops seem to remain in the background until the end of the finish. Alcohol is masked quite well, there some apparency with the beggining dark fruits but overall very pleasing. Everything was perfectly balanced, nothing overwhelmed another leaving a complex flavor that was awesome. Palate duration is strong. Head retention is decent with some lacing of the glass.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2016 Bottle at Aukurat Stockholm  March 2007... Deep solid black ... light smoke deep fruit and roast coffee little spice nose ... Meaty heavy body ... some spirit evaporation ... lots of sweet roast malt ... quite syrupy ... bitter chocolate little tartness ... little spirit burn ... Nice but not worth the £16($32) i paid for it.3.7 

Bottle at home  Feb 2011 ... deep back ... thin tan head ... deep dark roast malts ... little meaty ... little tobacco ... nose ... deep dark roast ... dark chocolate ... rich sweet oily body ... little hop bitterness ... big big chocolate .... quite a light alcohol burn ... heavy ... light meatyness ... rich 4.1


Bottle at home March 2016.. Bottle 10/23/14.. Dark black... Thin tan lacing...  Dark chocolate roast malts nose.... Big sweet caramel.. Sweet caramel malts.. Rich chocolate.. Soft soy. 

Bottle at home March 2016 ... Bottle 9/19/14... Dark black... Thick tan head... Soft sweet toffee chocolate roast malts nose... Soft sweet chocolate roast.. Light meaty malts.. Dark chocolate.. Dark roast... Soft chocolate roast

Bottle. round and sweet, with a balanced chocolate malt
sweetness and a hint of coffee too not that much hops..Very nice.

Bottle. Thans to JohnC for this one!. Pours a black color with a tan head. Sweet roasted malty hoppy aroma with hints of chocolate, dark fruit and alcohol. Sweetish roasted malty hoppy flavor with hints of cocholate, coffee and dark fruits. Roasted malty hoppy finish with more of that chocolate and leaves you with a bitter aftertaste. Very lovely!.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2010 bottle batch 7740 courtesy of SamuraiArtist...thick viscous pour is nearly black with a fluffy rich tan head. aromas of everything...dark chocolate, fig, super roasted malts, charred wood and molasses. tastes like chocolate cake with dark chocolate butter cream icing. additional flavors of vanilla, dark dried fruits, a porter-like sourness and a bit of smoke.  light premium quality coffee after taste and slight bitterness. creamy smooth mouth feel with very light carbonation. very well balanced. so much going on but nothing really jumps out. i wish i could drink this everyday!!!
8/5/8/519/4.5

8245 ... hints of smoke in the aroma with cream and dark fruit. the flavor is full of ashy grain and astringency with a very dry finish and coffee-like nutty aftertaste. super soft rich mouth feel. astringency keeps it drinkable even though it is still quite sweet... needs to sit. 8/5/7/5/17/4.
9512 first batch in az!

really sweet but really hoppy, bitter and delicious!

tons of licorice, cocoa powder, coffee and green stanky hops. so much that the finish is tingly with them. ive never had one so fresh... it is much better and more complex with a bit of age but it is still really tasty. 8/5/7/4/18/4.2

It looks like molasses, tastes like molasses and even smells a little like molasses, but it is definitely not molasses.Theres also some licorice, roasts and chocolate in there too. A very hearty beer that will warm you up.

I hate molasses. 

Pours pitch black with a large dark tan head. Nose is dusty with strong molasses tones. Flavor is oh so smooth. Strong molasses flavors prevail, but stay perfectly balanced. Feel is thick in the liquid and thin on the carbonation. This is a beautiful stout that is a hard one to surpass. Amazingly crafted and worth seeking out...at all costs.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2008 Amazing.  This is the best stout ever!  Pours very dark.  Nose of chocolate and a little coffee.  Thick bodied.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Bottle, batch 7205 @ London Sumtin in honour of Hog Town Harry, provided by the man himself...Easily my best beer of the evening edging out Speedway Stout ftw. Impenetrable dark brown with a tan head, stunning. Oily pour. Nose of chocolate, cereal, coffee and a subtle alcohol note. Coffee, granola, oatmeal and mint choclate chip with a dusty cocoa finish. Belly warming as it goes down...Velvety decadent mouthfeel. Everythings in there but its so well balanced, I could nurse one of these all night long.
A great beer indeed, Henri, Ill gladly have your bit next time... Thank you Harry!

12oz bottle: Pours a midnight black with virtually no head. Surprisingly the head grew as it settled to a little less than a finger. The aroma is laced with dark chocolate, espresso, and charred firewood. The flavor  has chocolate, a hint of vanilla and lots of dark roasted characteristics. The mouth feel is basically perfect. An excellent overall beer even if Im drinking it a little cool.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 On tap at Eccentric.  Pours dark as hell, with a copper brown head.  Palate is thick and creamy.  Good dark coffee and chocolate.  Looked forward to this for a long time, glad I had it on tap first.


Re-rate for an older batch i revisited.
Even better, more sweetness and a lot less abrasive.  Excellent.  Bumped the rating.

2007 12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a moderate, oily dark brown head that recedes quickly.  Aroma is intense with mostly bitter chocolate and charred wood/smoke.  Flavor is intensely complex - starts with a super roasted malt explosion evolving into dark fruits, smoke, vanilla and bourbon notes.  Very bitter, but well-balanced.  Finishes long and dry.  Palate is giant, with moderate carbonation.  Alcohol is present as it damn well should be.  This is a monster; all platitudes apply.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2009 12 oz #7251.  Thanks to Dankman38!  As black as any beer I have ever seen- absolutely no light would pass even towards the end of the glass; Head was zero, zilch, nada, however there was some spotty lacing.  thick, slick, and chewy mouthfeel. A perfect blend of roasted malts with robust hop bitterness and flavor lead to a beer with unmatched complexity.

3rd LCRBM. Aroma is full of roast,  chocolate and dark fruits. Wonderfull! Slick, black coloured with a small brown head. Taste is sweet with dark fruits, rye, chocolate, roast, some vanilla and wood. Lots in there. Very smooth taste. It has great balance and complexness. Wonderfull brew. Im glad I took some more time tasting this one.

12 oz. Thanks Ohio Dad. #7205.  2006? Deep brown/black with small dense brown head. Nice lacing. Sharp Roast with some floral hop in the aroma. Dense thick creamy palate. Taste of Blackstrap molasses, oysters, dark fruits, figs with a coffee bitterness at the end . Side by side with Siberian night and Stone
3rd LCRBM. Licorice, apple and roast in the aroma. Sugary sweet roasted flavor with grapes. Licorice in the aftertaste. Good, but not a world classic.

Thank you Linus_stick/Alan, I have looked very much forward to this treat and had it on my birthday September 06. 2007!! It is completely pitch black and the head is brown, huge, creamy and nicee - yummi! It get notes of chocolates, berries, coffee and a hint of alcohol in the aroma. The mouthfeel is thick and oily. The flavour is complex, impressive and yummiiiii..... It has notes of bitter chocolate, berries, coffee, strong licorice. The finish is extremely long, and new notes turn up all the time, they are among others chocolate, bitterness, licorice and again some berries. Its like the flavour never ends, even so several minutes after each sip. This is truly an impressive Impy!!

Botte, yesterday @ ratebeer meeting, Kulminator
Black color, with beige-lightbrown head. Aroma roasted malt, chocloate. Medium to fuul body. Taste very strong, roasted malts, dry and sticky @ the end.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2007 Yum, this is what people should try if they want to taste a good stout.!  It pours darker than a winters night in the arctic, the nose was malty with a little hint of chocolate, the flavor consisted of a smorgasborg of sweet wholesome goodness (vanilla, malt, chocolate, oak, al the good stuff), it is a heavy beer that isnt too syrupy and finishes with just a hint of bitterness.  This is the best beer Ive had in a long time.

If you like imperial stouts you should definitely try this one. Massive malt flavor and abundant roasted malt more than compensate for alcohol content. It is very thick on the palate w/o being syrupy. Just about the perfect amount of hops, enough to mask the sweetness of all that malt.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2008 This fits the bill. Liquid darkness in an understated bottle, this patient, chocolate froth will leave no taste bud unsatisfied and no throat unmassaged.

Pours a deep and viscous mahogany, sits an absolutely opaque black in the glass.  Very little head, but it stayed put until the beer was gone.  Hop, malt, and chocolate on the nose.  Taste is dominated by roast malt and hops, which balance nicely.  Plenty of chocolate and smokiness in there as well, plus some tangy fruitiness.  Great stuff.
Bottle: Very creamy and dark appearance.  Nice head with a slight aroma of malt and chocolate.  Full palate and body with a lasting flavor.  Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007 Bottle #7817.  Purchased at Discount Liquor, Milwaukee.  Ive had this many times, and it has been a favorite for a long time, but I have never rated it.  One of the best bottles Ive had was a 2003 that they found under the counter at Clark St. Ale House in Chicago a couple years ago; wish I would have rated that one.  Dark all the way through, from the inky black syrup pour to the dark tan foam of head (which is pretty small and fizzy, and dissipates quickly).  Pungent aroma full of aparent alcohol; smells like it was bourbon aged.  Leaves no lacing, but an oily layer of liquid clings to the side like Karo syrup; very viscous.  First impressions: Luxurious feel.  Finish is very hoppy, somewhat dry, but not that bitter (overwhelmed by the texture and the latent sugars).  Woosdy sweetness lingers on the top of the tongue as butterscotch starts on the sides, and gives way to alcohol burn only on the sides of the tongue.The hops in the finish are somewhat tangy, and the feel of the beer lingers forever.  Deeper:  Initially like melted dark chocolate.  The chocolate stays but is much less sweet in the finish, blending with the hops to add to the bitterness.  The head comes back in a thick layer of foam when twirled; it looks contiguous, with no bubbles comprising it.  I feel like I could light this on fire in the winter if I ran out of wood for the fireplace.  Maybe Ill try putting it in the car if gas gets too expensive.  Either way, its uncanily tasty for fuel.  Gets silkier when it ages, and I hope to save some of my bottles for later; maybe a little overrated for a young bottle, but at its best, its dope.

Multiple batches.  #7251bottled 25 Feb 2006.  Inky black pour.  Pitch in the glass.  Slight ring of ta head.  Sweet sugary plummy raisin aroma.  Cocoa toffee and spices.  Cookies.  Full bodied and big.  Wonderful play over the tongue.  Inital mild coffee flavor.  then the toffee sweetness.  Caraeml and raisins.  Then the citrus astringent alcohol ka-blam that sticks with you the rest of the swig.  Good but thick big burn!  Sticky sweet with bitter coffee acidity.  Evolving into the port/sherry vinuous notes.  Dreid dark fruits and woody smokey character.  Wow!  This is fantastic!  Rich creamy bitter stout.  Hop finish is mingled in with the coffee malts.  Tingling, whether from the alcohol or the hops.  Lingering piney resinous malt goo.  Stellar achievement!  Next up...Batch #7696 bottle 23 OCT 2006.  Same pitch hue.  Much more, Im talkin a fine layer here, tan head.  Larger bubbles.  Milder nose, more cocoa less fruit and burn.  Sugar cookie aromas.  Just as big and bad as the previous.  Softer somehow.  Smoother malts and less big bourbon burn.  More burnt toast and coffee notes.  Roughly 8 months fresher.  Makes a difference.  Malts are fresher yet still melded perfectly.  Stickier brew.  Coats the tongue.  Or it could just be an amalgamation of the nights libations.  Syrupy.  Burnt sugar and bitter coffee.  Still young as the noticeable residual sugars have not yet evolved into the apparent alcohol burn so prevalent in the previous.  Now, which do I prefer?  Itll take more than two batches to determine this!

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2009 Batch #8245 (Dec. 2007).  Aged only 3 months, this is the freshest Expedition Ive had to date.  It seems that the malt components are even richer when yound, taking on a fudgy, deep chocolate, desert-like profile.  Anise and raisons also show pretty strong, with less vanilla and oak coming through.  It seems that theres a real trend developing here, with some of the chocolaty malts mellowing over time, givng way to smoothing, oaky vanilla.  This is fantastic when fresh, but I think Id give the slight nod to the 2006 vintage that Ive sampled.  Seems like 1.5 years is the perfect age for this, my favorite brew.Below examples are courtesy boboski.  Two vintages, both rated 8/11/07.2006 vintage.  What an absolutely fantastic beer!  Black body with dark mahogany edges when held to the light.  Beautiful, complex aroma of sweet chocolate roasted malts, anise, vanilla, oak, and raisons.  I could inhale this intoxicating smell all day long.  Layer after layer of decadent flavor fills the mouth with each and every sip.  Sweet, desert like chocolate maltiness is balanced well by just the right touch of hops and coffee bitterness.  Vanilla, oak, and anise provide perfect complementary flavors.  The palate is on the heavy side of medium bodied.  A bit syrupy, but not in a bad way.  Think Kalamazoo Stout to the Nth degree.  Thank goodness Bells is finally available in Florida.  Heaven in a bottle!2003 vintage. Very similar to the 2006, though it did show just a bit of oxidation.  Probably a year long in the tooth, but still fantastic.  I noticed a higher concentration of vanilla, and perhaps even a bit of hazelnut that I didnt pick up in the younger version.  Even at 4 years old, this beats 95% of the stouts I have tried.  Awesome!

Nice aroma of chocolate malt and coffee. Color is almost black with a nice amber brown head. A flavor explosion of sweet malt, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, coffee, balanced nicely with a good deal of  bitterness. Heavy mouthfeel and strong although the alcohol is masked well.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 A Mes rate: 
***RE-RATE*** A Mes rate: 
Batch 7205 bottle at Chris_Os HogTownHarry minifest. Big thanks to Harry. Not sure what was wrong with the bottle I had at Chriss Shindig but the 3 times I have had this since have convinced me this needs a re-rate. Brown but almost black with a slight rim of tan. Lovely chocolate malt aroma with really nice hops. Excelent roasty flavour with a long long bitter finish. Actually the bitterness throughout is utterly fantastic. Thick and luxurious palate. An awesome impy stout. ***ORIGINAL NOTES*** (Score: 7, 4, 7, 4, 15 = 3.7) Bottle at Chris Os shindig. Black with a good tan head. Big fat and way overweight. Roasty, malty, coffee chocolate and huge huge alcohol. Coffee finish that has an odd acidic almost sour note to it. Good but rather over rated in my opinion.

This stuff looked thick coming out of the bottle.  Pours black, with a thick head, aroma is sweet and a bit bitter, notes of coffee, caramel and chocolate, hides the alcohol really well.  WOW.  This is an amazing beer that any imperial stout fan should try.  Even if you dont like imperial stouts you should try this.  Excellent stuff.

Many ratings below say there isnt much head, but I got a very nice head (poured in tulip).  Pours an inky black with creamy tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit (plums and a bit of raisin), bittersweet chocolate, coffee, molasses, and caramel.  Nice flavors of sweet malt, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, coffee, finishes with roast, bitterness and just a hint of alcohol.  Damn good, well balanced.  Oh almost forgot, I got this bottle thanks to footbalm.

Pours black w/ a mediUm sized, creamy froth. Head retention is good resulting in a full canopy and a fluffy ring. Aroma is very potent w/ sweet malts and chocolate cake. Full nectar w/ full, creamy effers that expand on the palate. A fat marbled, malty backbone is quickly slapped down by an army of Robo Hops. As the fight for dominance ensues a few nuances are thrown in the mix. Flavors of  cakebread, roasted coffee bean, vanilla, coconut, and molases are thrown about like rag dolls as the mighty competitors call a truce. This war could go on forever. The balance is set and my palate is very well satisfied. The finish is long w/ a citrus rind bittering lingering. Highly recommended.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2016 Black with a lasting light brown head. Intense aroma, caramel, chocolate, dried fruit and roast malts. In the mouth there is a flavour explosion of caramel, burned and roast flavours. It?s on the sweet side, and almost too much, but not quite.

This I like. 
Soft, appealling notes, rather than the smack your head heavy ness of the standard US impy stout. 
Pleased to have sampled this excellent brew,

Thanks to Solan and Mgumby.  Pours thick black, like oil, no head, no sign of carbonation.  Thick feeling, oily, strong and deep roasty flavors, spicy hops, rich burnt coffee with chocolate, with a vanilla finish.  Very smooth for the intesnse flavors in the beer.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2007 This is one of my favorite Imperial Stouts.  There is very little head, and an inky black color.  What little head there is reduces to a nice lace.  Strong flavor, with an almost bourbon-y alcohol finish.

Drank in a bottle.

poured into tulip.  pours a thick black with full fizzy caramel head that stays.  sweet mocha, slight coffee aroma.  smooth creamy palate with alchohol finish.  coffee on front, sweet mocha comes thru middle to finish.  coffee presents itself more the more your drink and more it warms, strong alchohol finish kind of taints the experience, overal a great Impy stout, good stuff..

(bottle) Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma varies with some piney hops, roasted malt, coffee, raisin, alcohol, and gets sweeter as the beer warms.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, raisin with a long pine hop finish.  A very good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2013 [Bottle] Pours dark brown with a dark tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla  and a little bit of alcohol.  Taste is roasted malt, piney hops, a little coffee and some hints of chocolate.  Nice thick mouthfeel. Long finish.  The first time I had this beer I was not overly impressed with it, but Im definitely glad I tried it again because now I can see that this is a very solid beer.Yeah, this beer is awesome. Everytime I have it, I am impressed. Im bumping the score 0.1.Consistently one of the best imperial stouts I have ever had, and still for a relatively reasonable price at many places. Bumping another 0.1.Same sentiment as before. Im pushing this into a tie for my #1 beer of all time.

Pours a pitch black with a thick, lovely dark brown head that disappears after the very first sip, leaving small patches of foam and nice lace. Aroma is pungent and heavenly - strong notes of alcohol & chocolate liquor, molasses and sweet dark malt too. Taste = LOVE. Strong roasted barley and great hops to balance still dont cover the strong alcoholic taste. Wonderful creamy body is perfectly blended from start to finish - at no point do I feel it change texture in my mouth, its perfectly silky smooth. Fine carbonation. I am wracking my brain to think of something to complain about, some reason not to give this a perfect 5, but I really, really cant. This beer is love.

Bells Expedition Stout
12 oz bottle
Moderate pour in a snifter
Batch 7251, packaged 02/06, ventured into 07/07

Poured black with a medium mostly  lasting brown head with fair lacing.

Smelt of strong dark chocolate and mocha without even putting my nose up to it.  Upon closer inspection,strong dark chocolate, dried plums, mocha, burnt grain, sherry.

Taste was upfront rich sweet dark chocolate, strong bitter burnt grain, moderate sherry and vinous bitterness, moderate fruity esters, like dried plums or figs, followed by a harsh bitter burnt grain and yeast, and sherry with moderate chocolate sweetness on a long lingering bitter burnt finish.

Palate was full bodied, creamy, silky and viscous, softly but slightly stinging  carbonation, strongly astringent and moderately alcoholic.

Overall, a good strong Imperial stout.  Not my favorite, but I will see how aging affects it.  Lots of alcohol warmth and strong bitter flavors.  Hell of a punch on the palate.  Very good over all, although a bit over the top, still after one year.

Holy crap do I have to thank Theisti for this one! WOW! Dark as night with a dark tan head. Roasted coffee with a thick mouth feel. Raisins, figs and dark fruits. Creamy mouth feel with mocha on the finish. MMMMmmmmmm....

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2008 Pours incredibly dark and oily.  Very thick and viscous.  Alcohol and roasty chocolate on the nose.  This beer is simply incredible.  It starts out with this amazingly creamy mouthfeel, and wave of velvety-chocolate flavor.  A fairly substantial sweetness that reminds me of dark fruits like plums or figs.  Finish is long and roasty.  Only complaint is that is  the roastyness is a little bitter in the finish, but this is a very small complaint.  Overall, this beer is so smooth, rich and velvety that I was blown away by every sip.  The price is reasonable too (I paid $3 for a bottle), especially when compared to other stouts or high abv beers.  Simply the best beer Ive ever had.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 Pour was super dark with a nice brown head.  Spotty lacing.  The aroma was roasted malt, chocolate, smoke, and some cherry and raisin.  Its a nice aroma that is somewhat subdued initially but really opens up as the beer progresses.  The flavor was chocolate, smoke, candied fruits, coffee and brown sugar.  The mouthfeel on this beer was ridiculous.  No alcohol heat, in fact I dont think I noticed it at all.  Creamy palate, just enough carbonation, nice finish.

Bottle. [ Courtesy of drewbeerme ] Black color with a small, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, dark chocolate, mocca / cacao. Flavor is wow .... moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. So good balance ... very very nice. Body is full, texture is creamy / syrupy, carbonation is flat. This is very nice wow .. ;o))

[bottle, from darkmagus] Strong roasted malt aroma, with some dark fruit and alcohol. Very dark appearance, opaque, with some nice dark brown lacing. Flavors are massive-- roasted barley, black patent malts, some plum, coffee and chocolate along with some strong bitterness round things out. Warming finish. Very creamy, dense mouthfeel.  Really outstanding complexity, overall.

Bottle. Pours an opaque brownish-black  (cant even see through it when held directly up to the light!) with tiny brown head and a sheen like an oil spill. Aroma of fine dark chocolate, rich wine scents and vanilla beans. Really enticing. Flavor is mellow viniousness, roasted coffee beans, bitterness pricking the cheeks, toffee, figs, plums and smokiness. Smokiness, alcohol sting and good resiny bitterness in the finish. Palate is thick, slightly oily and unbelievably chewy. A big beer. Delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2010 Re-rate 9/26/10: Bottle shared by reakt at t Arendsnest in Amsterdam. Thanks reakt! Black-colored with a big brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, wood and a bit of chocolate. Sweet flavor with some dark chocolate, coffee notes, roasted malt and a drier finish. Thick full body. Awesome stuff. 8/4/8/5/16=4.1

Re-rate 2/16/10: Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks archmik for this bottle! Batch #8728. Black-colored with a  brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, some smoky burnt malt and alcohol. Sweet chocolatey flavor with coffee, caramel hints, roasted malt and a bitter burnt finish with some hops. Full silky body. This was my first Imperial Stout almost 3 years ago - it doesnt amaze me as the first time I tried it, but it is still a great IS. 8/4/8/5/16=4.1

Bottle. Batch #7817. Opaque black color with a small dark brown head. Powerful aroma with roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, plums, raisins and alcohol. Amazing sweet flavor of firm roasty, burnt, maltiness and lots of chocolate and coffee. Ends with a bitter and slightly alcoholic finish. Very thick and full-bodied. Wow! This is wonderful. Too bad I dont have another bottle to cellar for a few years. 9/5/9/5/19=4.7

Shared a 12-oz bottle with joebrew at Cellars Wine & Spirits. Pours an opaque, motor-oil, nearly black color brew with a thick, creamy tan head that has good retention at near room temperature. Aroma of rich dark molasses, dark roasted coffee, some bittersweet chocolate and rich Californian figs. Taste is smooth, creamy with very little carbonation. Flavors picked up were dark molasses, toasted dark malt and some milk chocolate. Finish is bittersweet, smooth with a burnt oak aftertaste. Sampled with three other Imperial Stouts. Bells Expedition Stout is in a class of its own. Awesome!

UPDATED: APR 26, 2009 [18Jul07] Bottle, batch 7740.  Pours pitch black with a deep brown head.  Aroma consists mainly of chocolate and coffee malts.  Full, heavy, malty body with great complexity.  Espresso and dark chocolate flavors dominate with a little smokiness/burnt malt; smooth, somewhat creamy mouthfeel.  Slightly alcoholic finish. {8/5/9/4/18}

[26Apr09] Bottle, batch 8729.  Pours an opaque black body with creamy brown head.  Aroma of sweet and roasted dark malts, brown sugar, cocoa, and a hint of black licorice.  Flavor of chocolate, coffee, and dark malts with a slight tar taste near the finish.  Full, heavy body with a smooth mouthfeel. {8/5/9/5/18}
Bottle.  Black beer with chocolate head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is a little smoked and sweet.  Very thick and strong.  Smoked, coffee and chocolate flavor.  Very malty.

Poured this into a brandy snifter.

A- pours a deep, dark black. Head is tan of about 1/4" that sticks to the side of the glass. Two color head of tan and creme. Reminds me of creme resting at the top of a coffee.

S- Strong malt, and roasted coffee

T- Huge taste. Strong alcohol flavor that is complimented by coffee, and espresso flavors, dark chocolate.

M- I am in awe, smooth sipping beer. I slowly enjoyed this huge drink.

D- I am going to age the other 4 and see what happens. If this is like a fine wine or a woman, I dont see how this can get better with age, but we will see.

pours black/brown with a lumpy dark brown head... head lasted longer than expected with a good amount of lacing...smells of warm alcohol...bitter black coffee ans alcohol taste.. good mouth feel with a pleasant finish...this confirms my suspicition that I am a closet Imperial Stout lover

I was blown away by this rich and creamy dark stout. It has a rich walnut color and many of the aged characteristics of brandy. The first flavor that hits you is a roasted hopness combined with a sweet liquorise after bite. very smooth and not to overpowering. by far the best Ive had in quite some time

Bottled on 12-19-06, notes from a 2-1-07 rating.  Pours very thick and black, small rocky and fizzy head that disapears very quickly.  Huge malt bill.  Strong coffee, molasses and caramel.  Along with some roasted and burnt malt and flavors as well.  This is quite bitter, the taste of grapefruit, orange, lemon and pine hops.  There is also a very distinct earthy yeasty notes.  Very complex.  At first it is quite sweet, but then the bitterness shines through.  In the end there is a slight alcohol burn.

Bottle from 1/06 courtesy of csbosox. Pours black with virtually no head. Just a thin ring clinging to the sides of the snifter. The aroma is chocolate, dark fruits, faint licorice. Malty, warm and inviting, the mouthfeel is quite full and creamy. Chocolate, plums and roasted malts dominate with other subtle flavors coming and going with each sip: some coffee, some berries... I think Im going to have to snag a case of this come October, as this is the best beer that Ive had, to date, from a bottle. This is the kind of beer that you want to share with everyone in your life that you care about (and hide from those that you dont). Thanks again, Chris, for your generosity.
Pours jet black into a snifter.  Espresso and dark chocolate aromas.  Dark chocolate upfront with an espresso and twangy hop finish.  Lasting alcohol burn.
Near black with tan head.  Lots of chocolate, but a bit too much coffee for my taste

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 On tap at HDG. Part 2 of an indeterminite length ratings miniseries entitled "Getting back beastiefan2ks buddyship."  Oh baby...utter blackness with plenty of that tan head I enjoy so much.  Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, and piney hops.  Based on my previous experiences with hoppy stouts...well just the one, Im not sure if I enjoy them much.  Well, this makes it 1 for 2.  Totally decadent.  When it first hits your tongue, you can sense youre in for good ride.  Creamy chocolate and slight pine hops hit you first, along with the 2nd most luscious mouthfeel Ive ever experienced (1st is Raspberry Eisbock).  So beautifully thick, yet not to the point of sticky syrupiness.  After that first wave of great taste, comes the roasty portion of this huge beer.  It stays with me to the end, giving me a coffee aftertaste for quite some time.  What else can I say, this beer is truly awesome.  Glad Ive got a bottle of 7740 in the fridge.  I think Ill sit on it for a while.

Draught at HDG.  Poured straight black with a rich brown creamy head leaving broad sheets of lacing.  Aroma of rich dark chocolate, dark coffee along with a vinous and/or Godiva liqueur note.  This one is truly exceptional.  Rich, dark, molten chocolate malts infused with underlying notes of ultra-dark roast espresso coffee.  Wonderful roasty bittersweet flavors of the malts complimented by a precise addtion of hops. Full velvety body thats in no way syrupy.  This one is clearly a top Impy.  I just wish it was cold and snowy out when I tried it--then it would have been an etheral experience.

draft- pitch black, with a nice tan head, and good carbonation for the style. Bittering from the hops does well against some burnt coffee undertones. chocalte is predominate here. velvety smooth mouthfeel. great.

Hoppier than I like in a stout but not  so hoppy that it was distracting like with the Yeti. This one had such a great malt flavor and smell. It is not up there with AleSmith but it was an outstanding stout.

RBSG07. From bottle. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is hoppy and and sweet raisin. Flavour is soft malty, chocolate, raisin sweet. Finish is slight bitter on top of the coffee note. Very nice indeed.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 Tap at Hop Devil: Pours an opaque black, thick with an extremely deep brown, thick consistent head. Enormous aroma. Thick malts, chocolate, almost brownie-like, roasted barley, licorice and wood notes. Has an amazingly full body without being syrupy or cloying, just velvety and perfect. Thick dark chocolate flavors everywhere. Has some light licorice/anisette suggestions with a roasty espresso character, making it almost like an Irish coffee. Theres an extreme hop dryness to balance the ridiculous body. The finish is long, roasty, mocha-like/hoppy and dry.

Wow, as good as it gets! Definately a top 5 beer in my book but thats not saying much! 12oz bottle courtesy of Drewbeerme. Thanks Andrew! Love this beer, a nice thick pour with barely a head on it. Strong notes of coffee and fairly smokey. Drinking this with a bar of dark chocolate is one helluva desert!

12oz bottle; batch 7817. Poured pitch black, with a one finger creamy brown head that lasts forever. Complex aroma; coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, plum, and hops. Big malt flavor, complimented with coffee, smoke, hops, and some dried fruit. Full bodied. The beer is excellent, but I recall finding previous batches more flavorful and more enjoyable.

What can be said? This beer is larger than life; The 10.5% ABV is considerable, but this beer is so powerful that youd think its somewhere up around 17 or 18. Magnificent taste, complex flavors of licorice and coffee, chocolate, and some nice grains. Amazing.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2007 10/05/2007:  2 1/2 yr bottle from Styles.  Thanks!  Batch 6811, 4/26/07.    No carbonation on pour, but a small ring of brown bubbles forms on the edge.  Slightly oxidized aroma.  Thick malty syrupy taste.  Alcohol is present, but blends well with rich fig flavors.  Slight stinging bitterness on the edge of my tongue. I dont think its peaked yet.  It reminds me of an unrefined 7000.  9,4,7,4,17:4.0.

6/19/2007:  12 oz bottle tried in Japan with my wifes Japanese parents.  Lets start by saying they hated it.  They described it as a mixture of wine and beer and watered down.  A drain pour.  Hmmmm?
  Now for my review:  Direct pour into middle of glass, but still only small head, half way between creamy and not.  Still, I love this light carbonation level.  Dark rich syrupy color and thickness.  Slight roasted grain flavor, with hints of malt and coffee, lots of coffee.  Taste is thick, sweet, and a hint too much roasty flavor.  I think some aging will perfect the beer.
  Nice creamy texture and a some alchohol nose in the finish. 8,4,7,5,18:4.2

first rating! much love to darkmagus for the beer and encouragement....a creamy boot leather, a romantic lick of carpet, an honor to have an imperial stout that others strive to be, huffing a nutty coffee filter with orange peel.

12 oz. bottle, batch #7696. Im drinking some of my best stuff in preparation for the RateBeer Summer Gathering, where I know that Im going to experience some intense tastes. Aroma of chocolate, raisins, coffee, the usual for the style. Also ginger, cinnamon, vanilla, and cookie scents. Very nice and complex aroma but not as strong as I expected. Improves upon multiple sniffs. Pours a very dark, nearly black, mahogony with a moderate amount of dark tan head. Produces a moderate amount of lacing. Pronounced sugar-sweet start balanced by a roasted coffee bitter finish and aftertaste. These tastes are overly extreme: Its too sugary and too coffeeish for my ideal. Alcohol evident. A touch of hops-derived pine taste is present. Complex flavors include vanilla, carmel, black cherry, peach, lemon, milk chocolate, and whipped cream. Sweetness and coffee flavors are not my favorite tastes in beer. If those two elements had been toned down, I could easily have given this a 9 instead of a 7 for flavor. The long, bitter aftertaste is as complex an aftertaste as I have ever experienced. Medium to full in body. Rich, smooth, oily, and somewhat lively in the palate. Not hard to drink, unlike many examples of the imperial stout style. Bells Expedition Stout is quite good, but I have to say that Im a bit disappointed, because it is not world-class good, as the ratings on this site would suggest. It is unmistakably a Bells product, and it certainly is reminiscent of the even better Bells Batch 7000 that I have tried previously. Note that I also was not a huge fan of Bells Kalamazoo Stout, which, like Expedition Stout, gets great reviews here.
